eng: "You've arranged it delightfully," he rejoined, alive to the flatness of the words, but imprisoned in the conventional by his consuming desire to be simple and striking.
fr: -- Vous l'avez arrange avec un gout exquis, repondit Archer, rougissant de la banalite du propos. ~~~ Il se sentait comme emprisonne dans le convenu par son desir meme de dire quelque chose de frappant.

eng: "Oh, it's a poor little place. My relations despise it. But at any rate it's less gloomy than the van der Luydens'."
fr: -- C'est bien insignifiant ! Ma famille meprise mon petit coin. En tout cas, c'est moins triste que chez les van der Luyden.

eng: Those privileged to enter it shivered there, and spoke of it as "handsome."
fr: Les privilegies qui y penetraient, avec un leger frisson, etaient d'accord pour louer l'elegance des salons.

eng: But suddenly he was glad that she had given voice to the general shiver.
fr: Archer etait ravi que la comtesse Olenska eut traduit l'impression generale.

eng: Parting the curtains he looked out into the early dusk. A street-lamp faced him, and in its light he saw Julius Beaufort's compact English brougham, drawn by a big roan, and the banker descending from it, and helping out Madame Olenska.
fr: En ecartant les rideaux, il vit, a la lueur du reverbere, Julius Beaufort qui aidait Mme Olenska a descendre de son petit coupe anglais.

eng: The words gave him an electric shock, for few were the rebellious spirits who would have dared to call the stately home of the van der Luydens gloomy.
fr: Archer fut ebloui de tant d'audace : on aurait trouve peu d'esprits assez subversifs pour traiter de triste l'imposante demeure des van der Luyden.

eng: His position was becoming rather foolish.
fr: Sa position devenait assez ridicule.

eng: "It's delicious--what you've done here," he repeated.
fr: -- Ce que vous avez fait ici est delicieux, repeta-t-il.

eng: and signed to him to return to his armchair, adding: "I see you've already chosen your corner."
fr: -- Puis, faisant signe a Archer de reprendre sa place : Je vois que vous avez deja choisi votre coin.

eng: Leaning back, she folded her arms behind her head, and looked at the fire under drooping lids.
fr: Renversee dans un fauteuil, elle croisa ses bras derriere sa tete, et regarda le feu, les yeux mi-clos.

eng: She sat down near the fire, said: "Nastasia will bring the tea presently,"
fr: -- Elle s'assit pres du feu et ajouta : Nastasia nous apportera le the.

eng: "Yes; as long as my friends keep me from feeling lonely."
fr: -- Oui, puisque mes amis m'empechent de sentir ma solitude...

eng: "You like so much to be alone?"
fr: -- Vous aimez tant que ca etre seule ?

eng: She spoke so low that he hardly heard the last phrase;
fr: Elle parlait si bas qu'il entendit a peine la fin de la phrase.

eng: "I like the little house," she admitted; "but I suppose what I like is the blessedness of its being here, in my own country and my own town; and then, of being alone in it."
fr: '-- Je l'avoue, j'aime cette petite maison ; mais c'est surtout, je crois, parce qu'elle est dans mon pays, a New-York, et... et que j'y suis seule.'

eng: but in his awkwardness he took it up.
fr: Embarrasse, il repondit :

eng: "This is the hour I like best--don't you?"
fr: -- C'est l'heure que je prefere, dit-elle ; et vous ?

eng: "I've never been in a city where there seems to be such a feeling against living in des quartiers excentriques. What does it matter where one lives? I'm told this street is respectable."
fr: -- Je n'ai jamais vu une ville ou l'on ait plus de repugnance a habiter les quartiers excentriques. Quelle importance cela a-t-il ? On m'a dit que cette rue est tres convenablement habitee.

eng: She appeared to dismiss both Beaufort and himself from her mind, and went on:
fr: Elle avait l'air de se desinteresser et de Beaufort et de son visiteur, et continua :

eng: "Why--have you waited long? Mr. Beaufort took me to see a number of houses--since it seems I'm not to be allowed to stay in this one."
fr: -- Que voulez-vous dire ? Avez-vous attendu longtemps ? Mr Beaufort m'a menee voir un tas de maisons, puisqu'on a decide que je ne devais pas rester dans celle-ci.

eng: She looked amused.
fr: Elle prit un air amuse.

eng: A proper sense of his dignity caused him to answer: "I was afraid you'd forgotten the hour. Beaufort must have been very engrossing."
fr: Archer crut devoir au sentiment de sa dignite de demander : -- Je craignais que vous n'eussiez oublie l'heure. Beaufort vous a sans doute retardee.

eng: "It's not fashionable."
fr: -- Elle n'est pas a la mode.

eng: "But I suppose I've lived too independently; at any rate, I want to do what you all do--I want to feel cared for and safe."
fr: 'Peut-etre ai-je toujours vecu avec trop d'independance. En tout cas, je veux faire ce que vous faites tous : je veux sentir de l'affection et de la securite autour de moi.'

eng: "New York's an awfully safe place,"
fr: 'Il n'y a rien a craindre a New-York, ajouta-t-il avec une pointe de sarcasme.'

eng: "He was touched, as he had been the evening before when she spoke of her need of guidance."
fr: 'Il fut emu, comme la veille quand elle lui avait parle de son desir d'etre guidee.'

eng: "Fashionable! Do you all think so much of that?"
fr: '-- A la mode ? Attachez-vous tant d'importance a la mode ?'

eng: "Yes, isn't it?"
fr: '-- Oui, n'est-ce pas ?'

eng: "Why not make one's own fashions?"
fr: 'Pourquoi ne pas se faire sa mode a soi ?'

eng: "That's what your friends want you to feel."
fr: '-- Voila justement ce que souhaitent vos amis.'

eng: One feels that," she cried, missing the mockery.
fr: On en a l'impression, s'ecria-t-elle, sans saisir l'ironie.

eng: "Being here is like--like--being taken on a holiday when one has been a good little girl and done all one's lessons."
fr: 'C'est comme d'entrer en vacances, quand on a ete une bonne petite fille qui a bien fait tous ses devoirs.'

eng: The analogy was well meant, but did not altogether please him.
fr: La comparaison ne plut pas a Newland.

eng: He did not mind being flippant about New York, but disliked to hear any one else take the same tone.
fr: Il voulait bien parler de New-York sur un ton cavalier, mais il n'aimait pas que d'autres prissent la meme liberte.

eng: He wondered if she did not begin to see what a powerful engine it was, and how nearly it had crushed her.
fr: Il se demandait si Ellen ne commencait pas a comprendre que la societe de New-York etait une redoutable machine qui avait ete bien pres de la broyer.

eng: The Lovell Mingotts' dinner, patched up in extremis out of all sorts of social odds and ends, ought to have taught her the narrowness of her escape; but either she had been all along unaware of having skirted disaster, or else she had lost sight of it in the triumph of the van der Luyden evening.
fr: Le diner des Lovell Mingott, retape in extremis, fait de pieces et morceaux pris a differents milieux sociaux, aurait du lui apprendre le peril auquel elle avait echappe. ~~~ Elle n'avait jamais compris le danger, ou elle l'avait perdu de vue dans le triomphe de la soiree des van der Luyden.

eng: Archer inclined to the former theory; he fancied that her New York was still completely undifferentiated, and the conjecture nettled him.
fr: Archer inclinait a la premiere supposition, et l'idee que, pour la jeune femme, les distinctions sociales de New-York n'existaient pas encore, l'agacait vaguement.

eng: "Last night," he said, "New York laid itself out for you.
fr: -- Hier soir, dit-il, tout New-York se pressait pour vous faire honneur.

eng: "No: how kind they are! It was such a nice party. Every one seems to have such an esteem for them."
fr: "Les aimables gens ! Leur reunion etait si charmante ! Tout le monde parait avoir pour eux tant d'estime !"

eng: "The van der Luydens do nothing by halves."
fr: "Les van der Luyden ne font pas les choses a moitie."

eng: The terms were hardly adequate; she might have spoken in that way of a tea-party at the dear old Miss Lannings'.
fr: Les termes semblaient peu appropries : les memes eussent convenu pour un gouter chez la chere vieille miss Lanning.

eng: "The van der Luydens," said Archer, feeling himself pompous as he spoke, "are the most powerful influence in New York society.
fr: -- Les van der Luyden, dit pompeusement Archer, disposent d'une grande influence sur la societe de New-York.

eng: Unfortunately--owing to her health--they receive very seldom."
fr: Malheureusement, a cause de la sante de Mrs van der Luyden, ils recoivent tres rarement.

eng: She unclasped her hands from behind her head, and looked at him meditatively.
fr: Elle degagea ses mains de dessus sa tete et attacha sur Archer des yeux pensifs.

eng: "Isn't that perhaps the reason?"
fr: -- N'est-ce pas la, la raison ?...

eng: "The reason--?"
fr: -- La raison ?...

eng: "For their great influence; that they make themselves so rare."
fr: -- De leur grande influence... qu'ils se fassent si rares !

eng: He coloured a little, stared at her--and suddenly felt the penetration of the remark.
fr: Il rougit un peu, la regarda fixement, puis soudain il comprit la portee de cette remarque.

eng: At a stroke she had pricked the van der Luydens and they collapsed.
fr: D'un seul coup elle avait frappe les van der Luyden, et ils s'ecroulaient !

eng: He laughed, and sacrificed them.
fr: Il rit et les sacrifia.

eng: "But you'll explain these things to me--you'll tell me all I ought to know," Madame Olenska continued, leaning forward to hand him his cup.
fr: -- Vous m'expliquerez tout : vous me direz tout ce que je dois savoir, continua-t-elle, en s'approchant pour lui offrir une tasse de the.

eng: "It's you who are telling me; opening my eyes to things I'd looked at so long that I'd ceased to see them."
fr: -- C'est vous qui m'expliquez, vous qui ouvrez mes yeux a des choses que je regarde depuis si longtemps que je finis par ne plus les voir !

eng: Nastasia brought the tea, with handleless Japanese cups and little covered dishes, placing the tray on a low table.
fr: Nastasia apporta le the avec des tasses japonaises sans anses, et des assiettes couvertes. Elle placa le plateau sur une table basse aupres de la comtesse Olenska.

eng: "Ah, then we can both help each other. But I want help so much more. You must tell me just what to do."
fr: -- Alors, nous pouvons nous aider mutuellement. Mais c'est surtout moi qui ai besoin de secours. Dites-moi exactement ce que je dois faire.

eng: but he was being too deeply drawn into the atmosphere of the room, which was her atmosphere, and to give advice of that sort would have been like telling some one who was bargaining for attar-of-roses in Samarkande that one should always be provided with arctics for a New York winter.
fr: mais il etait trop penetre par l'atmosphere de la chambre, qui etait son atmosphere a elle, pour risquer cet avis. ~~~ C'eut ete comme de dire a quelqu'un, au moment ou il achete des parfums a Samarkande, qu'il est necessaire de s'approvisionner de vetements chauds pour passer l'hiver a New-York.

eng: She detached a small gold cigarette-case from one of her bracelets, held it out to him, and took a cigarette herself.
fr: Elle detacha de son bracelet un petit porte-cigarettes en or, le lui tendit, et prit elle-meme une cigarette.

eng: It was on the tip of his tongue to reply: "Don't be seen driving about the streets with Beaufort--"
fr: Il fut sur le point de lui dire : << Ne vous montrez pas en voiture avec Beaufort ; >>

eng: On the chimney were long spills for lighting them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: New York seemed much farther off than Samarkand, and if they were indeed to help each other she was rendering what might prove the first of their mutual services by making him look at his native city objectively.
fr: New-York semblait beaucoup plus loin que Samarkande, et si vraiment ils devaient s'entraider, elle lui rendait le premier de leurs services mutuels en lui faisant voir sa ville natale objectivement.

eng: Viewed thus, as through the wrong end of a telescope, it looked disconcertingly small and distant; but then from Samarkand it would.
fr: Vu ainsi, comme par le gros bout d'un telescope, New-York semblait singulierement petit et distant : c'est ainsi qu'on l'aurait vu de Samarkande.

eng: A flame darted from the logs and she bent over the fire, stretching her thin hands so close to it that a faint halo shone about the oval nails.
fr: Une flamme jaillit des buches, et la comtesse Olenska, se penchant en avant, tendit ses mains fines si pres du feu qu'une fine aureole entoura l'ovale de ses ongles.

eng: "There are plenty of people to tell you what to do," Archer rejoined, obscurely envious of them.
fr: Il y a assez de monde pour vous dire ce que vous devez faire, reprit Archer avec une secrete envie.

eng: The light touched to russet the rings of dark hair escaping from her braids, and made her pale face paler.
fr: La lumiere soudaine fit rougir les boucles echappees des nattes sombres de la jeune femme et rendit plus pale encore la paleur de son visage.

eng: "Oh--all my aunts? And my dear old Granny?"
fr: Mes tantes ? Et ma chere vieille grand'mere ?...

eng: He was impressed by this light way of speaking of the formidable Catherine, and moved by the thought of what must have given Madame Olenska this thirst for even the loneliest kind of freedom.
fr: Archer fut abasourdi par cette facon legere de s'exprimer sur la formidable Catherine, et emu a la pensee de ce qui avait pu donner a Mme Olenska cette soif d'une liberte qui comportait tant de solitude.

eng: She considered the idea impartially. "They're all a little vexed with me for setting up for myself--poor Granny especially. She wanted to keep me with her; but I had to be free--"
fr: Elles m'en veulent un peu de m'etre emancipee, ma pauvre grand'mere surtout. Elle aurait voulu me garder avec elle ; mais j'avais besoin d'etre libre.

eng: But the idea of Beaufort gnawed him.
fr: Mais l'image de Beaufort l'irritait.

eng: "I think I understand how you feel," he said.
fr: -- Je crois comprendre ce que vous eprouvez, dit-il.

eng: "Still, your family can advise you; explain differences; show you the way."
fr: Votre famille vous conseillera, vous expliquera les differences, vous montrera la voie.

eng: She lifted her thin black eyebrows.
fr: Elle releva ses fins sourcils.

eng: "Is New York such a labyrinth?
fr: -- New-York est-il un tel labyrinthe ?

eng: I thought it so straight up and down--like Fifth Avenue. ~~~ And with all the cross streets numbered!"
fr: Je le croyais tout droit d'un bout a l'autre, comme la Cinquieme avenue, et avec toutes ses rues numerotees.

eng: So close to the powers of evil she must have lived that she still breathed more freely in their air.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He saw his chance.
fr: Il saisit la balle au bond.

eng: But just at first don't let go of your old friends' hands: I mean the older women, your Granny Mingott, Mrs. Welland, Mrs. van der Luyden. They like and admire you--they want to help you."
fr: '-- mais tout d'abord, gardez l'appui de vos vieux amis, des femmes comme votre grand'mere Mingott, Mrs Welland, Mrs van der Luyden. Elles vous aiment, vous admirent, desirent vous aider.'

eng: He answered gently: "I understand.
fr: Il repondit doucement : -- Je comprends :

eng: But since she felt that he understood her also, his business would be to make her see Beaufort as he really was, with all he represented--and abhor it.
fr: Mais il songea a l'atmosphere malsaine ou Ellen avait vecu ; il pensa qu'il devait profiter de la confiance qu'elle lui temoignait pour lui montrer Beaufort et tout ce qu'il representait sous son jour veritable, et lui en inspirer le degout.

eng: Archer winced at the joining of the names, and then, with a quick readjustment, understood, sympathised and pitied.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She seemed to guess his faint disapproval of this, and added, with the rare smile that enchanted her whole face: "If you knew how I like it for just THAT--the straight-up-and-downness, and the big honest labels on everything!"
fr: '-- Elle sembla deviner, chez le jeune homme, une legere desapprobation, et ajouta, avec ce sourire qui illuminait tout son visage : -- Si vous saviez comme je l'aime, precisement a cause de cela : toutes ces lignes droites, dans tous les sens, avec toutes ces grandes etiquettes honnetes sur chaque chose !'

eng: She turned from the fire to look at him.
fr: '-- Elle se tourna vers lui.'

eng: "Perhaps. I may simplify too much--but you'll warn me if I do."
fr: '-- Peut-etre. Sans doute je simplifie trop : mais vous m'avertirez quand je me tromperai.'

eng: "Everything may be labelled--but everybody is not."
fr: '-- On peut mettre des etiquettes sur les choses, pas sur les personnes.'

eng: "There are only two people here who make me feel as if they understood what I mean and could explain things to me: you and Mr. ~~~ Beaufort."
fr: '-- Il n'y a que deux personnes ici qui puissent me renseigner : vous et Mr Beaufort.'

eng: She shook her head and sighed.
fr: Elle hocha la tete et soupira : -- Oh !

eng: "Oh, I know--I know!"
fr: 'je sais, je sais.'

eng: "Aunt Welland put it in those very words when I tried...."
fr: 'Ma tante Welland me l'a dit en propres termes.'

eng: "Does no one want to know the truth here, Mr. Archer?"
fr: 'On ne desire donc pas savoir la verite ici ?'

eng: "The real loneliness is living among all these kind people who only ask one to pretend!"
fr: 'La solitude, c'est de vivre parmi tous ces gens aimables qui ne vous demandent que de dissimuler vos pensees.'

eng: "She lifted her hands to her face, and he saw her thin shoulders shaken by a sob."
fr: 'Elle cacha sa figure dans ses mains et Archer vit ses minces epaules secouees par un sanglot.'

eng: ""Madame Olenska!--Oh, don't, Ellen," he cried, starting up and bending over her."
fr: '-- Madame Olenska ! ~~~ Je vous en prie... Ellen, supplia-t-il, en se levant et se penchant sur elle.'

eng: "He drew down one of her hands, clasping and chafing it like a child's while he murmured reassuring words; but in a moment she freed herself, and looked up at him with wet lashes."
fr: 'Il prit une de ses mains, la serra, la caressa comme celle d'un enfant, pendant qu'il murmurait des mots de reconfort. Mais elle se libera, et leva sur lui des yeux encore pleins de larmes.'

eng: ""Does no one cry here, either? I suppose there's no need to, in heaven," she said, straightening her loosened braids with a laugh, and bending over the tea-kettle.'
fr: '-- Ici, on ne pleure pas ; au Paradis, il n'y a pas de raison de pleurer, dit-elle, en rajustant ses tresses, et se penchant, deja souriante, au dessus de la bouilloire.'

eng: "But on condition that they don't hear anything unpleasant."
fr: 'Elles veulent m'aider, mais a la condition de ne rien entendre qui leur deplaise.'

eng: It was burnt into his consciousness that he had called her "Ellen"--called her so twice; and that she had not noticed it.
fr: Archer se disait en tremblant que deux fois il l'avait appelee << Ellen >> et qu'elle ne l'avait pas remarque.

eng: Far down the inverted telescope he saw the faint white figure of May Welland--in New York.
fr: Bien loin, comme par le petit bout de la lorgnette, il apercut la blanche image, estompee, de May Welland, a New-York.

eng: Madame Olenska, again with a hand at her hair, uttered an exclamation of assent--a flashing "Gia--gia"--and the Duke of St. Austrey entered, piloting a tremendous blackwigged and red-plumed lady in overflowing furs.
fr: Mme Olenska, la main encore dans ses cheveux, poussa une exclamation, un vif << gia ! ~~~ gia ! ~~~ >> et le duc de St-Austrey entra, pilotant une grosse dame, coiffee d'une perruque noire surmontee de plumes rouges : d'abondantes fourrures l'emmitouflaient.

eng: Suddenly Nastasia put her head in to say something in her rich Italian.
fr: Tout a coup, Nastasia passa la tete, dit quelques mots a voix basse.

eng: "My dear Countess, I've brought an old friend of mine to see you--Mrs. Struthers.
fr: -- Ma chere comtesse, je vous ai amene une de mes vieilles amies, Mrs Struthers.

eng: She wasn't asked to the party last night, and she wants to know you."
fr: On ne l'avait pas invitee a la soiree d'hier, et elle desire vous connaitre.

eng: The Duke beamed on the group, and Madame Olenska advanced with a murmur of welcome toward the queer couple.
fr: Mme Olenska s'avanca, avec des paroles de bienvenue, vers le singulier couple.

eng: She seemed to have no idea how oddly matched they were, nor what a liberty the Duke had taken in bringing his companion--and to do him justice, as Archer perceived, the Duke seemed as unaware of it himself.
fr: Elle ne sembla pas trouver insolite la liberte que prenait le duc en lui amenant ainsi une etrangere. ~~~ Le duc lui-meme semblait trouver cela parfaitement naturel. ~~~ -- J'ai tant desire faire votre connaissance, ma chere !

eng: "Of course I want to know you, my dear," cried Mrs. Struthers in a round rolling voice that matched her bold feathers and her brazen wig.
fr: s'ecria Mrs Struthers, d'une voix sonore qui s'accordait avec ses plumes eclatantes et avec sa perruque aux reflets metalliques.

eng: "I want to know everybody who's young and interesting and charming.
fr: Je veux connaitre tous ceux qui sont jeunes, interessants et charmants.

eng: And the Duke tells me you like music--didn't you, Duke?
fr: Le duc me dit que vous aimez la musique. ~~~ N'est-ce pas, mon cher duc ?

eng: You know I've something going on every Sunday evening--it's the day when New York doesn't know what to do with itself, and so I say to it: 'Come and be amused.'
fr: Je recois tous les dimanches. ~~~ C'est le jour ou New-York ne sait que faire ; alors je lui dis : << Venez, amusez-vous ! >>

eng: You're a pianist yourself, I believe?
fr: Vous etes pianiste, vous-meme, je crois.

eng: You'll find a number of your friends.
fr: Vous retrouverez beaucoup d'amis.

eng: And the Duke thought you'd be tempted by Sarasate.
fr: Le duc a pense que vous seriez attiree par Joachim.

eng: Well, do you want to hear Sarasate play tomorrow evening at my house?
fr: Alors voulez-vous venir demain entendre Joachim ?

eng: Madame Olenska's face grew brilliant with pleasure.
fr: Le visage de Mme Olenska s'illumina de plaisir.

eng: "I can't put a name to you--but I'm sure I've met you--I've met everybody, here, or in Paris or London. Aren't you in diplomacy? All the diplomatists come to me."
fr: '-- Excusez-moi, je ne peux pas retrouver votre nom ; mais je suis sure de vous avoir deja rencontre. J'ai rencontre tout le monde, ici, a Paris, ou a Londres. Etes-vous dans la diplomatie ? Tous les diplomates viennent chez moi.'

eng: Mrs. Struthers extended a hail-fellow hand to Archer.
fr: 'Mrs Struthers tendit a Archer une main cordiale.'

eng: "That's all right, my dear. And bring your young gentleman with you."
fr: '-- Voila qui est convenu, ma chere ; et amenez ce jeune homme avec vous.'

eng: She pushed a chair up to the tea-table and Mrs. Struthers sank into it delectably.
fr: 'Elle avanca un fauteuil pres de la table a the et Mrs Struthers s'y installa beatement.'

eng: "Of course I shall be too happy to come."
fr: 'Je serai trop heureuse de venir.'

eng: "How kind! How good of the Duke to think of me!"
fr: '-- Comme c'est aimable ! Comme le duc est bon d'avoir pense a moi !'

eng: You like music too?
fr: Vous aussi, vous aimez la musique ?

eng: The Duke said "Rather" from the depths of his beard, and Archer withdrew with a stiffly circular bow that made him feel as full of spine as a self-conscious school-boy among careless and unnoticing elders.
fr: Archer remercia et prit conge ; il se sentait gene comme un ecolier.

eng: He had never seen any as sun-golden before, and his first impulse was to send them to May instead of the lilies.
fr: Il n'en avait jamais vues d'un jaune aussi dore, aussi lumineux. Son premier mouvement fut de les envoyer a May au lieu des muguets.

eng: The next day he persuaded May to escape for a walk in the Park after luncheon.
fr: Le lendemain, apres le dejeuner, Archer put obtenir de May qu'elle vint avec lui faire une promenade au Central Park.

eng: "They'll go at once?" ~~~ he enquired, pointing to the roses. The florist assured him that they would.
fr: -- Portez-les tout de suite, fit-il, en designant les roses. X

eng: then, just as he was turning away, he drew the card out again, and left the empty envelope on the box.
fr: Puis, au moment de s'en aller, il retira la carte, laissa l'enveloppe vide sur la boite.

eng: In a sudden revulsion of mood, and almost without knowing what he did, he signed to the florist to lay the roses in another long box, and slipped his card into a second envelope, on which he wrote the name of the Countess Olenska;
fr: Presque sans savoir ce qu'il faisait, dans une brusque saute d'humeur, Newland fit signe a la fleuriste de mettre les roses dans un long carton, et glissa une carte dans une seconde enveloppe, sur laquelle il inscrivit le nom de la comtesse Olenska.

eng: But they did not look like her--there was something too rich, too strong, in their fiery beauty.
fr: Mais ces fleurs ne seyaient pas a la jeune fille : elles avaient quelque chose de trop riche, de trop fort, dans leur chaud eclat.

eng: As he wrote a word on his card and waited for an envelope he glanced about the embowered shop, and his eye lit on a cluster of yellow roses.
fr: Apres avoir ecrit un mot sur une carte, comme il attendait une enveloppe, il parcourut des yeux la boutique fleurie, et son regard fut attire par un bouquet de roses jaunes.

eng: He turned into his florist's to send her the daily box of lilies-of-the-valley which, to his confusion, he found he had forgotten that morning.
fr: Il se dirigea vers sa fleuriste habituelle, pour envoyer a la jeune fille la corbeille de muguets qu'a sa grande confusion il avait oublie de commander le matin.

eng: As he went out into the wintry night, New York again became vast and imminent, and May Welland the loveliest woman in it.
fr: Dehors, il se rappela qu'il etait a New-York et il eut l'impression que May Welland se rapprochait de lui.

eng: He was not sorry for the denouement of his visit: he only wished it had come sooner, and spared him a certain waste of emotion.
fr: Au surplus, il ne regrettait pas que sa visite eut ete interrompue par cette entree inopinee : si seulement elle s'etait produite un peu plus tot, elle lui aurait epargne une depense d'emotion bien inutile.

eng: "Duke, you must be sure to bring him."
fr: 'Mon cher duc, ne manquez pas de l'amener.'

eng: As was the custom in old-fashioned Episcopalian New York, she usually accompanied her parents to church on Sunday afternoons; but Mrs. Welland condoned her truancy, having that very morning won her over to the necessity of a long engagement, with time to prepare a hand-embroidered trousseau containing the proper number of dozens.
fr: C'etait un dimanche et, selon la vieille coutume de New-York, elle devait accompagner ses parents a l'eglise matin et apres-midi ; mais Mrs Welland ferma les yeux sur cette infraction aux usages, car, le matin meme, elle avait obtenu de sa fille de se plier aux longues fiancailles qui permettraient de constituer un trousseau brode a la main, et comptant le nombre de douzaines necessaires.

eng: The day was delectable.
fr: Le temps etait exquis.

eng: The bare vaulting of trees along the Mall was ceiled with lapis lazuli, and arched above snow that shone like splintered crystals.
fr: Le long du Mail, la voute des branches depouillees se dessinait sur un fond de lapis, au-dessus d'une couche de neige etincelante.

eng: "Ah--they would!"
fr: Ainsi avait fait Lawrence Lefferts, lorsqu'il s'est fiance avec la pauvre Gertrude. (No direct equivalent in text, but this sentence sets up the following English sentence)

eng: laughed Archer, amused at her keenness.
fr: -- Ca leur ressemble, dit Archer, enchante de cette fine remarque.

eng: "Yesterday they came late. I hadn't time in the morning--"
fr: -- Pardonnez-moi, si, hier, votre bouquet est arrive en retard ; je n'avais pas eu le temps de passer chez la fleuriste le matin, repondit-il.

eng: Archer was proud of the glances turned on her, and the simple joy of possessorship cleared away his underlying perplexities.
fr: Archer, fier des regards qu'elle attirait, oubliait ses perplexites secretes dans la joie de la regarder.

eng: He looked sideways at her fruit-like cheek and felt rich and secure enough to add: "When I sent your lilies yesterday afternoon I saw some rather gorgeous yellow roses and packed them off to Madame Olenska. Was that right?"
fr: Et il se sentit assez sur de lui-meme pour ajouter : -- Quand je vous ai envoye des muguets hier, j'ai vu quelques belles roses jaunes, et je les ai fait porter a la comtesse Olenska. Ai-je bien fait ?

eng: It was the weather to call out May's radiance, and she burned like a young maple in the frost.
fr: Les couleurs de May s'avivaient dans le froid, comme celles d'un jeune erable a la premiere gelee.

eng: "But your remembering each day to send them makes me love them so much more than if you'd given a standing order, and they came every morning on the minute, like one's music-teacher--as I know Gertrude Lefferts's did, for instance, when she and Lawrence were engaged."
fr: -- C'est la preuve que vous les choisissez vous-meme chaque jour. Pour rien au monde je ne voudrais que votre bouquet arrivat toujours a la meme heure, comme un professeur de piano, car je saurais alors que vous l'avez commande d'avance une fois pour toutes.

eng: "It's so delicious--waking every morning to smell lilies-of-the-valley in one's room!" she said.
fr: -- C'est une sensation delicieuse de s'eveiller le matin en respirant l'odeur des muguets ! dit-elle en souriant.

eng: "How dear of you!
fr: -- Comme c'est gentil !

eng: Anything of that kind delights her.
fr: Cela lui fait tant de plaisir quand on pense a elle !

eng: It's odd she didn't mention it: she lunched with us today, and spoke of Mr. Beaufort's having sent her wonderful orchids, and cousin Henry van der Luyden a whole hamper of carnations from Skuytercliff.
fr: Ce qui m'etonne, c'est qu'elle n'ait pas parle de vos roses. Elle a dejeune avec nous ce matin, et nous a dit que Mr Beaufort lui avait envoye de magnifiques orchidees et que Mr van der Luyden avait fait venir pour elle de Skuytercliff toute une corbeille d'oeillets.

eng: She seems so surprised to receive flowers.
fr: Il semble que ce soit nouveau pour elle de recevoir des fleurs.

eng: Don't people send them in Europe?
fr: N'en envoie-t-on pas en Europe ?

eng: She thinks it such a pretty custom."
fr: Elle trouve que c'est une coutume charmante.

eng: "Oh, well, no wonder mine were overshadowed by Beaufort's," said Archer irritably.
fr: -- Mes fleurs auront ete eclipsees par celles de Beaufort ! ~~~ songea Archer, legerement pique.

eng: He was out of spirits and slightly out of temper, and a haunting horror of doing the same thing every day at the same hour besieged his brain.
fr: ~~~ << Monotonie !... ~~~ monotonie !... ~~~ >> soupira-t-il. Ce mot l'obsedait.

eng: He had failed to stop at his club on the way up from the office where he exercised the profession of the law in the leisurely manner common to well-to-do New Yorkers of his class.
fr: Archer, comme presque tous les jeunes gens de son monde, avait fait son droit, et avait maintenant un emploi dans l'etude d'un avocat distingue[1]. Il etait revenu de l'etude ce jour-la d'assez mauvaise humeur, vaguement deprime, et obsede par l'idee que jusqu'a la fin de sa vie il ferait vraisemblablement toujours la meme chose a la meme heure, et dans le meme cadre.

eng: The next afternoon, as Archer, before dinner, sat smoking sullenly in his study, Janey wandered in on him.
fr: Le jour suivant, pendant qu'Archer, avant le diner, fumait un cigare dans la bibliotheque, Janey vint le trouver.

eng: "Oh, did I tell you that I showed Ellen my ring? She thinks it the most beautiful setting she ever saw. There's nothing like it in the rue de la Paix, she said. I do love you, Newland, for being so artistic!"
fr: Elle reprit, rassuree : -- Vous ai-je dit que j'avais montre ma bague a Ellen ? Elle assure qu'elle n'a jamais vu une aussi jolie monture. Il n'y a rien de pareil rue de la Paix. Vous etes tellement artiste, Newland !...

eng: He stood silent, beating his stick nervously against his boot-top; and feeling that she had indeed found the right way of closing the discussion, she went on light-heartedly:
fr: Il restait silencieux, frappant nerveusement le bout de sa bottine avec sa canne. Il sentait qu'apres tout elle avait trouve le vrai moyen de clore l'incident.

eng: "Of course I should hate it--so would you," she rejoined, a trifle irritably.
fr: -- Avez-vous si peur de paraitre << mauvais genre ? >> -- Mais oui, j'en serais fachee. Et vous aussi, ajouta-t-elle, legerement piquee.

eng: But how many generations of the women who had gone to her making had descended bandaged to the family vault?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Sameness--sameness!" he muttered, the word running through his head like a persecuting tune as he saw the familiar tall-hatted figures lounging behind the plate-glass; and because he usually dropped in at the club at that hour he had gone home instead.
fr: En rentrant, ce soir-la, il ne s'etait pas arrete au cercle comme d'habitude. ~~~ A la vue des grandes fenetres derriere lesquelles les memes figures connues, coiffees des memes chapeaux haut-de-forme, se montraient toujours a la meme heure, le courage lui avait manque.

eng: "Are you so much afraid, then, of being vulgar?"
fr: >> suggera-t-elle doucement.

eng: "I'm not clever enough to argue with you. But that kind of thing is rather--vulgar, isn't it?" she suggested, relieved to have hit on a word that would assuredly extinguish the whole subject.
fr: -- Je ne suis pas assez forte pour discuter avec vous ; mais ne serait-ce pas -- comment dire ? -- << mauvais genre ?

eng: She looked a little bored by his insistence. She knew very well that they couldn't, but it was troublesome to have to produce a reason.
fr: Elle parut un peu contrariee de son insistance. Elle sentait tres bien que ce qu'il voulait etait impossible, mais visiblement elle ne trouvait pas de raison a lui opposer.

eng: "Why not--why not--why not?"
fr: Pourquoi pas ?

eng: She was evidently staggered by this.
fr: Elle avait conscience d'avoir enonce l'argument sans replique.

eng: He knew not only what they were likely to be talking about, but the part each one would take in the discussion.
fr: Il devinait non seulement ce dont on parlait, mais comment chacun en parlait.

eng: "What if it had happened to Mrs. van der Luyden?" people asked each other with a shudder.
fr: Dire que cela aurait aussi bien pu arriver a Mrs van der Luyden ! se disaient les douairieres en frissonnant d'horreur.

eng: Such "women" (as they were called) were few in New York, those driving their own carriages still fewer, and the appearance of Miss Fanny Ring in Fifth Avenue at the fashionable hour had profoundly agitated society.
fr: En effet, << ces personnes, >> comme on les appelait dans le milieu de Mrs Archer, etaient rares a New-York, et aucune d'elles, jusqu'a present, n'avait ose se montrer dans sa propre voiture.

eng: Only the day before, her carriage had passed Mrs. Lovell Mingott's, and the latter had instantly rung the little bell at her elbow and ordered the coachman to drive her home.
fr: Aussi, la veille, le coupe jaune ayant croise l'attelage de Mrs Lovell Mingott, celle-ci avait a l'instant meme donne l'ordre a son cocher de rentrer.

eng: "We can't behave like people in novels, though, can we?"
fr: -- Pourquoi pas ?

eng: Archer could hear Lawrence Lefferts, at that very hour, holding forth on the disintegration of society.
fr: Archer croyait entendre Lawrence Lefferts prophetisant la debacle de la societe...

eng: He raised his head irritably when his sister Janey entered, and then quickly bent over his book (Swinburne's "Chastelard"--just out) as if he had not seen her.
fr: Il leva brusquement la tete a l'entree de sa soeur, puis, sans faire attention a elle, se replongea dans sa lecture. C'etait le Chastelard de Swinburne, qu'on venait de lui envoyer de Londres.

eng: She glanced at the writing-table heaped with books, opened a volume of the "Contes Drolatiques," made a wry face over the archaic French, and sighed: "What learned things you read!"
fr: Janey s'approcha du bureau charge de livres, ouvrit un volume des Contes Drolatiques, fit la moue sur le vieux francais et soupira : -- Quelles choses serieuses tu lis !

eng: "Well--?" he asked, as she hovered Cassandra-like before him.
fr: Elle continuait a roder autour de lui avec une mine mysterieuse ; enerve par son mutisme, il finit par lui demander : -- Tu as quelque chose a me dire ?

eng: "Mother's very angry."
fr: -- Oui. Maman est tres fachee.

eng: "Angry? With whom? About what?"
fr: -- Fachee ? Contre qui ? A propos de quoi ?

eng: "Miss Sophy Jackson has just been here. She brought word that her brother would come in after dinner: she couldn't say very much, because he forbade her to: he wishes to give all the details himself. He's with cousin Louisa van der Luyden now."
fr: -- Miss Sophie Jackson sort d'ici. Elle a dit que son frere viendrait apres le diner. ~~~ Elle n'a pas voulu raconter grand'chose, son frere le lui a defendu ; il veut nous donner tous les details lui-meme. Il est maintenant chez notre cousine van der Luyden.

eng: "For heaven's sake, my dear girl, try a fresh start. It would take an omniscient Deity to know what you're talking about."
fr: -- Pour l'amour du ciel, ma chere, de quoi s'agit-il ? Il faudrait etre le bon Dieu pour comprendre tes enigmes.

eng: "It's not a time to be profane, Newland.... Mother feels badly enough about your not going to church ..."
fr: -- Allons, Newland, ne plaisante pas ; maman a deja assez de chagrin que tu n'ailles pas a l'eglise.

eng: The Duke of course would be their principal theme; though the appearance in Fifth Avenue of a golden-haired lady in a small canary-coloured brougham with a pair of black cobs (for which Beaufort was generally thought responsible) would also doubtless be thoroughly gone into.
fr: Le duc de Saint-Austrey etait naturellement le theme principal des conversations ; et sans doute on ne manquerait pas d'epiloguer sur l'apparition, dans la Cinquieme avenue, d'une demoiselle aux cheveux teints, dans un petit coupe jaune canari attele de deux cobs noirs -- et Beaufort en porterait la responsabilite.

eng: "But then--why not be happier?"
fr: Nous ne pouvons pourtant pas agir comme des amoureux de roman, dit-elle en riant.

eng: He had stopped and faced her in the excitement of their discussion, and her eyes rested on him with a bright unclouded admiration.
fr: Ils s'etaient arretes l'un en face de l'autre, excites par la discussion. May le regardait, les yeux brillant d'admiration.

eng: "If you would--"
fr: -- Je ne demande pas mieux !

eng: Then he remembered that he had not put a card with the roses, and was vexed at having spoken of them.
fr: Puis il se souvint qu'il n'avait pas joint sa carte a l'envoi des roses, et regretta d'en avoir parle.

eng: He wanted to say: "I called on your cousin yesterday," but hesitated.
fr: Il etait sur le point de dire : << J'ai ete voir votre cousine hier, >> mais il hesita.

eng: If Madame Olenska had not spoken of his visit it might seem awkward that he should.
fr: Si Mme Olenska avait passe sa visite sous silence, mieux valait faire comme elle.

eng: Yet not to do so gave the affair an air of mystery that he disliked.
fr: Tout cela prenait un air de mystere qu'Archer n'aimait qu'a moitie.

eng: To shake off the question he began to talk of their own plans, their future, and Mrs. Welland's insistence on a long engagement.
fr: Pour changer de sujet, il se mit a parler de leur mariage, de leur avenir, et de l'obstination de Mrs Welland a prolonger le temps des fiancailles.

eng: "If you call it long! Isabel Chivers and Reggie were engaged for two years: Grace and Thorley for nearly a year and a half. Why aren't we very well off as we are?"
fr: -- Rappelez-vous qu'Isabelle et Reggie Chivers ont ete fiances deux ans, Grace et Thorley pres d'un an et demi ! Et puis, est-ce que nous ne sommes pas tres bien comme nous sommes ?

eng: It was the traditional maidenly interrogation, and he felt ashamed of himself for finding it singularly childish.
fr: C'etait la reponse classique de toute jeune fiancee. Archer s'en voulait de la trouver un peu puerile dans la bouche de May, qui avait pres de vingt-deux ans.

eng: No doubt she simply echoed what was said for her; but she was nearing her twenty-second birthday, and he wondered at what age "nice" women began to speak for themselves.
fr: Et il se demandait a quel age les femmes << bien elevees >> commencaient a penser par elles-memes.

eng: "Never, if we won't let them, I suppose," he mused, and recalled his mad outburst to Mr. Sillerton Jackson: "Women ought to be as free as we are--"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You DO love me, Newland! I'm so happy."
fr: -- Comme vous m'aimez, Newland ! Je suis si heureuse !

eng: He shivered a little, remembering some of the new ideas in his scientific books, and the much-cited instance of the Kentucky cave-fish, which had ceased to develop eyes because they had no use for them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It would presently be his task to take the bandage from this young woman's eyes, and bid her look forth on the world.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "We might be much better off. We might be altogether together--we might travel."
fr: Nous pourrions faire beaucoup mieux que d'attendre : etre ensemble tout a fait, voyager.

eng: Her face lit up.
fr: La figure de la jeune fille s'illumina :

eng: "That would be lovely," she owned: she would love to travel.
fr: elle avoua qu'elle adorait les voyages.

eng: But her mother would not understand their wanting to do things so differently.
fr: Mais sa mere ne comprendrait pas qu'on put desirer ne pas faire comme tout le monde.

eng: "As if the mere 'differently' didn't account for it!" the wooer insisted.
fr: Mais ne pas faire comme tout le monde, c'est justement ce que je veux !

eng: "Newland! You're so original!" she exulted.
fr: Vous etes si original !

eng: His heart sank, for he saw that he was saying all the things that young men in the same situation were expected to say, and that she was making the answers that instinct and tradition taught her to make--even to the point of calling him original.
fr: Une sorte de decouragement s'empara du jeune homme. Il sentait qu'il prononcait exactement toutes les paroles que l'on attend d'un fiance, et qu'elle faisait toutes les reponses qu'une sorte d'instinct traditionnel lui dictait, -- jusqu'a lui dire qu'il etait original.

eng: "Original! We're all as like each other as those dolls cut out of the same folded paper. We're like patterns stencilled on a wall. Can't you and I strike out for ourselves, May?"
fr: Original ? Nous sommes tous aussi pareils les uns aux autres que ces poupees decoupees dans une feuille de papier plie. Ne pourrions-nous pas etre un peu nous-memes, May ?

eng: With a groan he plunged back into his book.
fr: Avec un geste agace il se replongea dans son livre.

eng: "Mercy--shall we elope?" she laughed.
fr: -- Mon Dieu ! Vous voulez donc m'enlever ?

eng: What if, when he had bidden May Welland to open hers, they could only look out blankly at blankness?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "NEWLAND!
fr: -- Newland !

eng: Do listen.
fr: Ecoute donc.

eng: Your friend Madame Olenska was at Mrs. Lemuel Struthers's party last night: she went there with the Duke and Mr. ~~~ Beaufort."
fr: Ton amie Mme Olenska etait a la soiree de Mrs Lemuel Struthers hier soir ; elle y est allee avec le duc et Mr Beaufort.

eng: To smother it he laughed.
fr: Il affecta de rire :

eng: At the last clause of this announcement a senseless anger swelled the young man's breast.
fr: A ce nom, une colere irraisonnee s'empara du jeune homme.

eng: "Well, what of it? I knew she meant to."
fr: -- Et bien ? Apres ? Je savais qu'elle comptait y aller.

eng: "Oh, family--family!" he jeered.
fr: -- Oh ! la famille ! la famille ! railla-t-il.

eng: Janey paled and her eyes began to project.
fr: Les yeux de Janey sortaient de leurs orbites.

eng: He laughed again.
fr: -- Il rit de nouveau.

eng: "I'm not engaged to be married to the Countess Olenska!"
fr: -- Et de quel droit ? Ce n'est pas avec la comtesse Olenska que je suis fiance !

eng: The words had a fantastic sound in his own ears.
fr: Ces paroles lui sonnerent etrangement aux oreilles.

eng: "You're marrying into her family."
fr: -- Tu te maries dans sa famille.

eng: "Newland--don't you care about Family?"
fr: -- Newland ! Est-ce que tu ne te soucies pas de la famille ?

eng: "You knew she meant to--and you didn't try to stop her? To warn her?"
fr: -- Comment ? Tu le savais, et tu n'as pas essaye de l'empecher, de l'avertir ?

eng: "Stop her? Warn her?"
fr: -- L'empecher ? L'avertir ?

eng: "Not a brass farthing."
fr: -- Pas pour un liard !

eng: "Nor about what cousin Louisa van der Luyden will think?"
fr: -- Ni de ce que pensera notre cousine van der Luyden ?

eng: But he saw her long gentle face puckering into tears, and felt ashamed of the useless pain he was inflicting.
fr: Mais il vit le long et doux visage de Janey s'assombrir et il regretta la peine inutile qu'il venait de lui infliger.

eng: He felt like shouting back: "Yes, she is, and so are the van der Luydens, and so we all are, when it comes to being so much as brushed by the wing-tip of Reality."
fr: Il aurait voulu crier : << Si ! ~~~ elle en a, et aussi les van der Luyden, et nous tous, des que la realite nous effleure. >>

eng: "No; but you DID ask the Wellands to announce your engagement sooner so that we might all back her up; and if it hadn't been for that cousin Louisa would never have invited her to the dinner for the Duke."
fr: -- Non ; mais tu as demande aux Welland d'avancer l'annonce de tes fiancailles, afin que nous puissions la soutenir, et c'est seulement pour faire plaisir a maman que la cousine Louisa l'a invitee a diner.

eng: "Not the half of one--if she thinks such old maid's rubbish."
fr: '-- Pas pour un centime... si elle a des idees saugrenues de vieille fille.'

eng: "Well--what harm was there in inviting her?"
fr: -- Eh bien ! ~~~ Quel mal y avait-il a l'inviter ?

eng: "Hang Countess Olenska! Don't be a goose, Janey--I'm not her keeper."
fr: -- Tant pis pour la comtesse Olenska ! Ne fais pas la sotte, ma petite Janey ! Je ne suis pas le tuteur de la belle Ellen !

eng: "Mother is not an old maid," said his virgin sister with pinched lips.
fr: '-- Mais, maman n'a pas des idees de vieille fille, dit sa soeur d'un air pince.'

eng: She was the best-looking woman in the room; she made the dinner a little less funereal than the usual van der Luyden banquet."
fr: C'etait la plus jolie femme du salon ; grace a elle, le diner a ete un peu moins morne que ne le sont en general les banquets van der Luyden.

eng: "You know cousin Henry asked her to please you: he persuaded cousin Louisa. ~~~ And now they're so upset that they're going back to Skuytercliff tomorrow.
fr: -- Tu sais que cousin Henry l'a invitee pour te faire plaisir, que c'est lui qui a obtenu de notre cousine de la recevoir ; et maintenant les voila si bouleverses en apprenant qu'elle est allee chez Mrs Struthers, qu'ils retournent a Skuytercliff des demain.

eng: I think, Newland, you'd better come down.
fr: Je crois, Newland, que tu feras bien de descendre au salon.

eng: "She raised a troubled brow from her needlework to ask: 'Has Janey told you?'"
fr: 'Elle leva sur lui un regard trouble, et demanda : -- Janey t'a dit ?'

eng: "You don't seem to understand how mother feels."
fr: 'Tu sembles ne pas comprendre ce que maman eprouve.'

eng: "In the drawing-room Newland found his mother."
fr: 'Newland trouva sa mere dans le salon, penchee sur son metier.'

eng: "'The fact that they can be offended by such a trifle as Countess Olenska's going to the house of a woman they consider common.'"
fr: '-- Le fait qu'ils puissent se sentir froisses parce que la comtesse Olenska a ete chez une femme qu'ils trouvent commune !'

eng: "He tried to keep his tone as measured as her own. 'But I can't take it very seriously.'"
fr: '-- Il sourit. -- Mais je ne trouve pas que ce soit tres serieux.'

eng: "'Not the fact of having offended cousin Louisa and cousin Henry?'"
fr: '-- Le fait d'avoir froisse nos cousins ?'

eng: "'I don't suppose, dear, you're really defending the French Sunday?'"
fr: '-- Je ne suppose pas, mon enfant, que tu defendes serieusement la maniere francaise de passer le dimanche ?'

eng: "'Well--that kind of thing happens in other places, and the world still goes on.'"
fr: '-- Eh bien, apres ? ~~~ Tout cela est arrive, et le monde continue a tourner.'

eng: "'Good music? All I know is, there was a woman who got up on a table and sang the things they sing at the places you go to in Paris. There was smoking and champagne.'"
fr: '-- De la bonne musique ? Tout ce que je sais, c'est qu'il y avait chez elle, dimanche dernier, une creature qui est montee sur la table, et qui a chante des choses comme celles qu'on chante dans les endroits ou tu vas a Paris. On a fume, et bu du champagne.'

eng: "'Well, who is; but who has good music, and amuses people on Sunday evenings, when the whole of New York is dying of inanition.'"
fr: '-- Ils ne sont pas seuls de cet avis. -- Eh bien ! oui, d'accord, elle est commune ; mais on fait chez elle de la bonne musique, et ses receptions du dimanche apportent une distraction a des gens qui meurent d'ennui.'

eng: "'Consider--!'"
"I've heard you often enough, mother, grumble at the English Sunday when we've been in London."
fr: -- Je vous ai souvent entendu, maman, vous plaindre de la tristesse maussade des dimanches a Londres, quand nous y etions !

eng: her son groaned.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh, no, it's not!"
fr: "-- Ah, fichtre non !"

eng: "New York is neither Paris nor London."
fr: "-- New-York n'est ni Paris, ni Londres."

eng: "You mean, I suppose, that society here is not as brilliant?"
fr: "-- Tu veux dire sans doute que notre societe est moins amusante que celle des villes d'Europe ?"

eng: "You're right, I daresay; but we belong here, and people should respect our ways when they come among us."
fr: "Peut-etre as-tu raison ; mais nous sommes d'ici, et, quand on vient parmi nous, on doit respecter nos habitudes."

eng: Ellen Olenska especially: she came back to get away from the kind of life people lead in brilliant societies."
fr: Ellen Olenska surtout, puisqu'elle est revenue dans son pays pour echapper a la vie dissipee des societes plus brillantes.

eng: Newland made no answer, and after a moment his mother ventured: "I was going to put on my bonnet and ask you to take me to see cousin Louisa for a moment before dinner."
fr: Newland ne repondant pas, sa mere s'aventura a dire, apres un moment de silence : -- Je vais mettre mon chapeau, et te demanderai de m'accompagner chez Louisa.

eng: He frowned, and she continued: "I thought you might explain to her what you've just said: that society abroad is different ... that people are not as particular, and that Madame Olenska may not have realised how we feel about such things.
fr: Je veux la voir un instant avant le diner. ~~~ Archer fronca le sourcil, mais elle insista, conciliante : -- J'ai pense que tu pourrais lui expliquer ce que tu viens de me dire : que la societe a l'etranger est differente, qu'on y est moins collet-monte, que la comtesse Olenska n'a peut-etre pas cru froisser mes sentiments.

eng: It would be, you know, dear," she added with an innocent adroitness, "in Madame Olenska's interest if you did."
fr: Ce serait, tu sais, mon cheri, ajouta-t-elle avec une inconsciente habilete, dans l'interet meme de Mme Olenska.

eng: "Dearest mother, I really don't see how we're concerned in the matter. The Duke took Madame Olenska to Mrs. Struthers's--in fact he brought Mrs. Struthers to call on her. I was there when they came. If the van der Luydens want to quarrel with anybody, the real culprit is under their own roof."
fr: '-- Chere maman, je ne vois vraiment pas en quoi cette affaire nous regarde. Le duc a mene Mme Olenska chez Mrs Struthers ? ~~~ Le fait est qu'il etait venu voir Mme Olenska avec Mrs Struthers. J'etais la. Si les van der Luyden veulent se disputer avec quelqu'un, le veritable coupable est sous leur toit.'

eng: "Quarrel? Newland, did you ever know of cousin Henry's quarrelling? Besides, the Duke's his guest; and a stranger too. Strangers don't discriminate: how should they? Countess Olenska is a New Yorker, and should have respected the feelings of New York."
fr: '-- Se disputer ?... Newland ! Quelle expression ! ~~~ Notre cousin, se disputer ? Et puis, le duc est un etranger, et leur hote. Les etrangers ne connaissent pas nos habitudes. Comment les connaitraient-ils ? Tandis que la comtesse Olenska est une New-Yorkaise, et devrait avoir egard aux sentiments de New-York.'

eng: "Well, then, if they must have a victim, you have my leave to throw Madame Olenska to them," cried her son, exasperated.
fr: '-- Eh bien, puisqu'il leur faut une victime, je vous permets de leur livrer la comtesse Olenska, s'ecria Archer.'

eng: "Ah--a charming woman. I have just been to see her," said Mr. van der Luyden, complacency restored to his brow. He sank into the chair, laid his hat and gloves on the floor beside him in the old-fashioned way, and went on: "She has a real gift for arranging flowers. I had sent her a few carnations from Skuytercliff, and I was astonished. Instead of massing them in big bunches as our head-gardener does, she had scattered them about loosely, here and there ... ~~~ I can't say how. The Duke had told me: he said: 'Go and see how cleverly she's arranged her drawing-room.' And she has. I should really like to take Louisa to see her, if the neighbourhood were not so--unpleasant."
fr: '-- Une femme charmante ! Je sors de chez elle, dit Mr van der Luyden, rasserene. Il s'assit, deposa ses gants et son chapeau a cote de son fauteuil, selon le vieil usage, et continua : -- Elle a un veritable don pour arranger les fleurs. Je lui avais envoye quelques oeillets de Skuytercliff, et j'ai ete emerveille de la facon dont elle les a groupes. Au lieu de les masser en gros bouquets comme notre jardinier-chef, elle les avait disperses, je ne saurais pas dire comment. Le duc m'avait prevenu ; il m'avait dit : << Allez voir avec quel gout elle a meuble son salon ! >> Et c'est vrai. J'aurais bien voulu lui mener Louisa, si le quartier n'etait pas si boheme.'

eng: "I don't see myself--or you either--offering ourselves up to expiate her crimes."
fr: 'Je ne me soucie pas du tout de m'offrir en holocauste pour expier les crimes de Mme Olenska.'

eng: "Oh, of course you see only the Mingott side," his mother answered, in the sensitive tone that was her nearest approach to anger.
fr: '-- Naturellement tu es tout entier du cote Mingott, repondit la mere d'un ton qui trahissait son irritation interieure.'

eng: Mrs. Archer dropped her needle and pushed her chair back with an agitated hand.
fr: 'Mrs Archer piqua son aiguille et repoussa sa chaise d'un geste nerveux.'

eng: "Another lamp," she cried to the retreating servant, while Janey bent over to straighten her mother's cap.
fr: '-- Une autre lampe, ordonna-t-elle au domestique, pendant que Janey se penchait sur sa mere pour lui rajuster son bonnet de dentelle.'

eng: Mr. van der Luyden's figure loomed on the threshold, and Newland Archer went forward to greet his cousin.
fr: 'Mr van der Luyden apparut sur le pas de la porte, et Newland Archer s'avanca pour le recevoir.'

eng: "We were just talking about you, sir," he said.
fr: '-- Nous parlions justement de vous, mon cousin, dit-il.'

eng: Mr. van der Luyden seemed overwhelmed by the announcement. He drew off his glove to shake hands with the ladies, and smoothed his tall hat shyly, while Janey pushed an arm-chair forward, and Archer continued: "And the Countess Olenska."
fr: 'Mr van der Luyden sembla deconcerte par ces paroles. Il retira son gant pour serrer la main des dames, et lissa son haut-de-forme avec un peu d'embarras, pendant que Janey avancait un fauteuil. Archer continua en souriant : -- Et de la comtesse Olenska...'

eng: Mrs. Archer paled.
fr: 'Mrs Archer palit.'

eng: A dead silence greeted this unusual flow of words from Mr. van der Luyden. Mrs. Archer drew her embroidery out of the basket into which she had nervously tumbled it, and Newland, leaning against the chimney-place and twisting a humming-bird-feather screen in his hand, saw Janey's gaping countenance lit up by the coming of the second lamp.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The sad butler drew back the drawing-room portieres and announced: "Mr. Henry van der Luyden."
fr: 'Le maitre d'hotel ouvrit les portieres du salon et annonca : << Monsieur Henry van der Luyden. >>'

eng: Mrs. Archer produced an indulgent smile.
fr: 'Mrs Archer prit un air naif :'

eng: "Has the Duke been carrying her off to parties?"
fr: '-- Le duc l'a-t-il menee dans le monde ?'

eng: "You know what these English grandees are. ~~~ They're all alike.'
fr: '-- Eh, oui ! ~~~ Vous savez ce que sont ces grands seigneurs anglais ; tous les memes.'

eng: "The fact is," Mr. van der Luyden continued, stroking his long grey leg with a bloodless hand weighed down by the Patroon's great signet-ring, "the fact is, I dropped in to thank her for the very pretty note she wrote me about my flowers; and also--but this is between ourselves, of course--to give her a friendly warning about allowing the Duke to carry her off to parties with him. I don't know if you've heard--"
fr: 'A vrai dire, poursuivit Mr van der Luyden, appuyant sur son pantalon gris sa main decoloree, alourdie par la grande bague du Patroon, a vrai dire, j'etais alle la remercier du mot charmant qu'elle m'avait ecrit a propos de mes fleurs, et aussi, -- mais ceci entre nous, -- pour lui donner un avertissement amical sur l'inconvenient de se faire mener dans le monde par le duc. Je ne sais pas si vous en avez entendu parler.'

eng: Louisa and I are very fond of our cousin--but it's hopeless to expect people who are accustomed to the European courts to trouble themselves about our little republican distinctions.
fr: Louisa et moi aimons beaucoup notre cousin, mais on ne peut s'attendre a ce que des gens habitues a la vie des cours tiennent compte de nos petites distinctions republicaines.

eng: The Duke goes where he's amused."
fr: Le duc va ou il s'amuse.

eng: Mr. van der Luyden paused, but no one spoke.
fr: Mr van der Luyden fit une pause, mais personne ne prit la parole.

eng: "Yes--it seems he took her with him last night to Mrs. Lemuel Struthers's.
fr: -- Il l'a menee, parait-il, hier soir chez Mrs Lemuel Struthers.

eng: We are dining early, to take the Duke to the Opera."
fr: Nous dinons de bonne heure pour mener le duc a l'Opera.

eng: With a glance at the clock he rose and added: "But Louisa will be waiting.
fr: Puis, ayant jete un coup d'oeil a la pendule, il se leva et ajouta : -- Mais Louisa m'attend.

eng: "I never ask to my house, my dear Newland," he said, "any one whom I do not like.
fr: -- Je n'invite jamais chez moi, mon cher Newland, les gens qui ne me plaisent pas.

eng: Mr. van der Luyden looked at him with extreme gentleness.
fr: Mr van der Luyden le regarda avec une extreme affabilite.

eng: And so I have just told Sillerton Jackson."
fr: Je viens de le dire a Sillerton Jackson.

eng: Newland will particularly appreciate what you have done because of dear May and his new relations."
fr: Newland sera particulierement touche de ce que vous avez fait la pour lui et la chere May.

eng: Sillerton Jackson has just been to us with the foolish story, and Louisa was rather troubled.
fr: Sillerton Jackson est venu tout a l'heure nous raconter cette sotte histoire, et Louisa en a ete un peu troublee.

eng: ~~~ But I was sure you'd like Madame Olenska."
fr: -- Je vous suis tres reconnaissant, mon cousin ; mais j'etais sur que Mme Olenska vous plairait.

eng: So I thought the shortest way was to go straight to Countess Olenska and explain--by the merest hint, you know--how we feel in New York about certain things.
fr: J'ai pense que le plus court serait d'aller tout droit chez Mme Olenska et de lui expliquer, tres amicalement, ce que nous pensons a New-York.

eng: I felt I might, without indelicacy, because the evening she dined with us she rather suggested ... rather let me see that she would be grateful for guidance.
fr: Il m'a semble que je le pouvais sans indiscretion, car le soir ou elle a dine chez nous, elle m'avait laisse entendre qu'elle accepterait mes conseils avec quelque gratitude.

eng: She shot an admonitory glance at her son, who said: "Immensely, sir.
fr: Elle jeta un regard a son fils, qui dit aussitot :

eng: Mr. van der Luyden looked about the room with what would have been self-satisfaction on features less purged of the vulgar passions.
fr: Mr van der Luyden regarda autour de lui.

eng: On his face it became a mild benevolence which Mrs. Archer's countenance dutifully reflected.
fr: A defaut d'un air de satisfaction que ne pouvait revetir un visage aussi distingue, il eut un sourire de sereine bienveillance, que le visage de Mrs Archer se fit un devoir de refleter.

eng: "How kind you both are, dear Henry--always!
fr: -- Comme vous etes bons tous les deux, mon cher Henry !

eng: And she WAS.
fr: Et c'est ce qu'elle a fait.

eng: After the portieres had solemnly closed behind their visitor a silence fell upon the Archer family.
fr: Quand les portieres se furent refermees sur leur cousin, le silence tomba sur la famille Archer. ~~~ -- Bonte du ciel !

eng: "Gracious--how romantic!"
fr: Que tout cela est romanesque !

eng: at last broke explosively from Janey.
fr: finit par s'ecrier Janey.

eng: No one knew exactly what inspired her elliptic comments, and her relations had long since given up trying to interpret them.
fr: Personne n'avait jamais su ce que voulaient dire ses brusques sorties, et sa famille avait depuis longtemps renonce a y rien comprendre.

eng: Mrs. Archer shook her head with a sigh.
fr: Mrs Archer secoua la tete en soupirant.

eng: "Provided it all turns out for the best," she said, in the tone of one who knows how surely it will not.
fr: -- Esperons que tout tournera pour le mieux, dit-elle, d'un ton qui signifiait visiblement le contraire.

eng: "Newland, you must stay and see Sillerton Jackson when he comes this evening: I really shan't know what to say to him."
fr: -- Newland, il faut que tu restes a la maison pour voir Sillerton Jackson quand il viendra ce soir. ~~~ Je ne saurais vraiment que lui dire.

eng: '"Poor mother! But he won't come--" her son laughed, stooping to kiss away her frown.
fr: '-- Ma pauvre maman ! Mais il ne viendra pas, dit son fils en riant, et en se penchant pour poser un baiser sur le front inquiet de sa mere.

eng: XI. Some two weeks later, Newland Archer, sitting in abstracted idleness in his private compartment of the office of Letterblair, Lamson and Low, attorneys at law, was summoned by the head of the firm.
fr: XI Environ quinze jours plus tard, Archer, assis, inoccupe et distrait, devant son bureau du cabinet << Letterblair, Lamson et Low, >> avocats a la cour, fut demande par Mr Letterblair.

eng: Old Mr. Letterblair, the accredited legal adviser of three generations of New York gentility, throned behind his mahogany desk in evident perplexity.
fr: Le vieux Mr Letterblair, le conseil accredite de la haute societe de New-York depuis trois generations, tronait derriere son bureau d'acajou en proie a une evidente perplexite.

eng: As he stroked his closeclipped white whiskers and ran his hand through the rumpled grey locks above his jutting brows, his disrespectful junior partner thought how much he looked like the Family Physician annoyed with a patient whose symptoms refuse to be classified.
fr: Le voyant caresser ses favoris blancs, passer ses doigts dans ses cheveux en broussaille au-dessus de ses gros sourcils fronces, son jeune associe le comparait, peu respectueusement, au medecin de famille aupres d'un malade dont les symptomes se refusent a tout diagnostic.

eng: "My dear sir--"
fr: '-- Cher monsieur, --

eng: --"he always addressed Archer as "sir"--"I have sent for you to go into a little matter; a matter which, for the moment, I prefer not to mention either to Mr. Skipworth or Mr. ~~~ Redwood."
fr: -- Mr Letterblair, tres ceremonieux, disait toujours << monsieur >> a son jeune associe, -- je vous ai fait demander a propos d'une petite affaire, une affaire dont, pour le moment, je prefere ne pas parler a Mr Lamson ni a Mr Low.

eng: The gentlemen he spoke of were the other senior partners of the firm; for, as was always the case with legal associations of old standing in New York, all the partners named on the office letter-head were long since dead; and Mr. Letterblair, for example, was, professionally speaking, his own grandson.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He leaned back in his chair with a furrowed brow.
fr: Il se renversa sur sa chaise, le front ride.

eng: "For family reasons--" he continued.
fr: -- Pour des raisons de famille, continua-t-il.

eng: Archer looked up.
fr: Archer leva la tete.

eng: "The Mingott family," said Mr. Letterblair with an explanatory smile and bow.
fr: -- La famille Mingott, dit Mr Letterblair, avec un sourire significatif et en s'inclinant.

eng: "Mrs. Manson Mingott sent for me yesterday.
fr: Mrs Manson Mingott m'a fait demander hier.

eng: Her grand-daughter the Countess Olenska wishes to sue her husband for divorce.
fr: Sa petite-fille, la comtesse Olenska, desire plaider en divorce contre son mari.

eng: Certain papers have been placed in my hands."
fr: Certains documents m'ont ete remis.

eng: He paused and drummed on his desk.
fr: -- Il s'arreta et tapota sur son bureau.

eng: "In view of your prospective alliance with the family I should like to consult you--to consider the case with you--before taking any farther steps."
fr: -- En raison de vos projets d'alliance avec la famille, je voudrais vous consulter, etudier le cas avec vous, avant d'aller plus loin.

eng: Archer felt the blood in his temples.
fr: Archer sentit le sang lui monter au visage.

eng: He had seen the Countess Olenska only once since his visit to her, and then at the Opera, in the Mingott box.
fr: Depuis sa visite a la comtesse Olenska, il ne l'avait vue qu'une fois, a l'Opera, dans la loge des Mingott.

eng: During this interval she had become a less vivid and importunate image, receding from his foreground as May Welland resumed her rightful place in it.
fr: Et, dans cet intervalle, l'image de la jeune femme s'etait attenuee dans son esprit, tandis que May Welland y reprenait legitimement le premier plan.

eng: He had not heard her divorce spoken of since Janey's first random allusion to it, and had dismissed the tale as unfounded gossip.
fr: Il n'avait pas entendu parler du divorce de Mme Olenska depuis l'allusion faite en passant par Janey, et dont il n'avait tenu aucun compte.

eng: Theoretically, the idea of divorce was almost as distasteful to him as to his mother; and he was annoyed that Mr. Letterblair (no doubt prompted by old Catherine Mingott) should be so evidently planning to draw him into the affair.
fr: Theoriquement, il etait presque aussi hostile que sa mere a l'idee du divorce et il en voulait a Mr Letterblair (sans doute pousse par la vieille Catherine Mingott) de se montrer ainsi dispose a le meler a l'affaire.

eng: After all, there were plenty of Mingott men for such jobs, and as yet he was not even a Mingott by marriage.
fr: Les hommes de la famille etaient assez nombreux, et lui-meme n'etait pas encore un Mingott.

eng: He waited for the senior partner to continue.
fr: Il attendit que son chef continuat.

eng: Mr. Letterblair unlocked a drawer and drew out a packet.
fr: Mr Letterblair ouvrit un tiroir et en tira une liasse de papiers.

eng: "If you will run your eye over these papers--"
fr: '-- Si vous voulez parcourir ces documents ?...'

eng: Archer frowned.
fr: Archer s'en defendit :

eng: He bowed.
fr: Il s'inclina.

eng: It was unusual for a junior to reject such an opening.
fr: Generalement un jeune associe ne rejetait par de telles ouvertures.

eng: Mr. Letterblair looked surprised and slightly offended.
fr: Mr Letterblair parut surpris et legerement froisse.

eng: "I beg your pardon, sir; but just because of the prospective relationship, I should prefer your consulting Mr. Skipworth or Mr. ~~~ Redwood."
fr: '-- Excusez-moi, monsieur, mais precisement a cause de mes projets d'alliance, je prefere que vous consultiez Mr Low ou Mr Lamson.'

eng: "I respect your scruple, sir; but in this case I believe true delicacy requires you to do as I ask.
fr: -- Je respecte votre scrupule, monsieur ; mais, dans le cas present, je crois que la vraie delicatesse vous oblige a faire ce que je vous demande.

eng: Indeed, the suggestion is not mine but Mrs. Manson Mingott's and her son's.
fr: La proposition, du reste, ne vient pas de moi, mais de Mrs Manson Mingott et de son fils.

eng: I have seen Lovell Mingott; and also Mr. Welland. ~~~ They all named you."
fr: J'ai vu Lovell Mingott, et aussi Mr Welland ; ils vous ont tous designe.

eng: Archer felt his temper rising.
fr: Archer eut un mouvement d'irritation.

eng: He had been somewhat languidly drifting with events for the last fortnight, and letting May's fair looks and radiant nature obliterate the rather importunate pressure of the Mingott claims.
fr: Depuis quinze jours il s'etait laisse porter par les evenements. ~~~ La beaute, le charme de May lui avaient fait oublier la pression des chaines Mingott.

eng: "Will you oblige me, Mr. Archer, by first looking through these papers? Afterward, when we have talked the case over, I will give you my opinion."
fr: Vous m'obligerez, Mr Archer, en parcourant d'abord ces papiers. Ensuite, quand nous aurons examine la question ensemble, je vous dirai mon opinion.

eng: "I believe it is suggested; but she denies it."
fr: On le suppose ; mais elle le nie.

eng: "Does she want to marry again?"
fr: Est-ce qu'elle veut se remarier ?

eng: The young man was silent: he had not opened the packet in his hand.
fr: Le jeune homme gardait le silence. Il n'avait pas ouvert le paquet qu'il tenait toujours a la main.

eng: "They have. The matter has been gone into by the family. They are opposed to the Countess's idea; but she is firm, and insists on a legal opinion."
fr: Ses oncles s'en sont occupes : la question a ete examinee par la famille. Tous sont opposes au desir de la comtesse, mais elle tient ferme, et insiste pour avoir un avis juridique.

eng: "Her uncles ought to deal with this," he said.
fr: C'est l'affaire de ses oncles.

eng: But this behest of old Mrs. Mingott's roused him to a sense of what the clan thought they had the right to exact from a prospective son-in-law; and he chafed at the role.
fr: Le commandement de la vieille Mrs Mingott lui rappela tout ce que le clan se croyait en droit d'exiger d'un futur gendre : il se rebiffa.

eng: "Then--"
fr: Alors ?

eng: Archer withdrew reluctantly with the unwelcome documents.
fr: Archer sortit, emportant a contre-coeur les documents.

eng: Since their last meeting he had half-unconsciously collaborated with events in ridding himself of the burden of Madame Olenska.
fr: Depuis leur derniere rencontre, les circonstances l'avaient aide a se liberer de la pensee de Mme Olenska.

eng: His hour alone with her by the firelight had drawn them into a momentary intimacy on which the Duke of St. Austrey's intrusion with Mrs. Lemuel Struthers, and the Countess's joyous greeting of them, had rather providentially broken.
fr: Les instants passes au coin de la cheminee les avaient amenes a une intimite momentanee, que l'arrivee du duc de Saint-Austrey, pilotant Mrs Lemuel Struthers, et si bien accueilli par la comtesse, avait interrompue assez a propos.

eng: Two days later Archer had assisted at the comedy of her reinstatement in the van der Luydens' favour, and had said to himself, with a touch of tartness, that a lady who knew how to thank all-powerful elderly gentlemen to such good purpose for a bunch of flowers did not need either the private consolations or the public championship of a young man of his small compass.
fr: Deux jours plus tard, Archer avait assiste a la comedie de la rentree en grace de la jeune femme aupres des van der Luyden. ~~~ Il s'etait dit, avec une pointe d'aigreur, qu'une femme, qui, par ses remerciements a propos d'un bouquet de fleurs, avait su toucher le vieux et important personnage qu'etait Mr van der Luyden, n'avait nul besoin, ni des consolations, ni de l'appui moral d'un jeune homme d'aussi petite envergure que lui, Newland Archer.

eng: That was the old New York note; that was the kind of answer he would like always to be sure of his wife's making.
fr: C'etait la note du vieux New-York : c'etait celle qu'il aimerait toujours a retrouver chez sa femme.

eng: They consisted mainly of an exchange of letters between Count Olenski's solicitors and a French legal firm to whom the Countess had applied for the settlement of her financial situation.
fr: C'etait un echange de lettres entre l'avocat du comte Olenski et l'etude parisienne a laquelle la comtesse avait confie la defense de ses interets financiers.

eng: but they plunged him into an atmosphere in which he choked and spluttered.
fr: mais le plongerent dans un courant d'idees penibles.

eng: "You know, when it comes to the point, your parents have always let you have your way ever since you were a little girl," he argued;
fr: "<< Vous savez que vos parents vous ont toujours cede depuis votre enfance, >> avait-il dit.

eng: He had even yielded to her wish for a long engagement, since she had found the one disarming answer to his plea for haste.
fr: Il s'etait meme resigne aux longues fiancailles, depuis qu'elle avait trouve a lui opposer un argument qui l'avait desarme.

eng: and she had never seemed to him finer or fairer than in the week that followed.
fr: Jamais elle ne lui sembla plus fine et plus charmante que dans la semaine qui suivit.

eng: and she had answered, with her clearest look: "Yes; and that's what makes it so hard to refuse the very last thing they'll ever ask of me as a little girl."
fr: Elle, avec son clair regard, lui avait repondu : << C'est bien pour cela qu'il me serait dur de leur refuser la derniere chose qu'ils aient a me demander, avant que je ne les quitte. >>

eng: To look at the matter in this light simplified his own case and surprisingly furbished up all the dim domestic virtues.
fr: Ces considerations ironiques rendaient quelque lustre aux ternes vertus domestiques.

eng: The papers he had retired to read did not tell him much in fact;
fr: Les documents dont il prit connaissance ne lui apprirent pas grand'chose,

eng: If one had habitually breathed the New York air there were times when anything less crystalline seemed stifling.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He could not picture May Welland, in whatever conceivable emergency, hawking about her private difficulties and lavishing her confidences on strange men;
fr: Impossible d'imaginer May Welland etalant ses affaires privees et repandant ses confidences parmi des etrangers !

eng: There was also a short letter from the Count to his wife: after reading it, Newland Archer rose, jammed the papers back into their envelope, and reentered Mr. Letterblair's office.
fr: Il y avait aussi une courte lettre du comte a sa femme. ~~~ Apres l'avoir lue, Archer se leva, serra les papiers dans leur enveloppe et rentra dans le bureau de Mr Letterblair.

eng: "Here are the letters, sir. If you wish, I'll see Madame Olenska," he said in a constrained voice.
fr: '-- Voici les lettres, monsieur. C'est entendu, je verrai la comtesse Olenska, dit-il, d'une voix nerveuse.'

eng: "Thank you--thank you, Mr. Archer. Come and dine with me tonight if you're free, and we'll go into the matter afterward: in case you wish to call on our client tomorrow."
fr: '-- Je vous remercie, Mr Archer. Etes-vous libre ce soir ? Venez diner ; nous causerons ensuite, pour le cas ou vous voudriez voir notre cliente des demain.'

eng: Newland Archer walked straight home again that afternoon.
fr: Newland Archer rentra directement chez lui.

eng: It was a winter evening of transparent clearness, with an innocent young moon above the house-tops; and he wanted to fill his soul's lungs with the pure radiance, and not exchange a word with any one till he and Mr. Letterblair were closeted together after dinner.
fr: C'etait une soiree d'une lumineuse transparence : une lune jeune et candide montait au-dessus des toits. ~~~ Archer voulait impregner son ame de cette pure splendeur, et ne parler a personne jusqu'au moment de son rendez-vous avec Mr Letterblair.

eng: It was impossible to decide otherwise than he had done: he must see Madame Olenska himself rather than let her secrets be bared to other eyes.
fr: Depuis la lecture des lettres, il avait compris qu'il fallait qu'il vit lui-meme Mme Olenska, afin d'eviter que les secrets de la jeune femme ne fussent exposes devant d'autres.

eng: A great wave of compassion had swept away his indifference and impatience: she stood before him as an exposed and pitiful figure, to be saved at all costs from farther wounding herself in her mad plunges against fate.
fr: Une grande vague de compassion avait eu raison de son indifference. ~~~ Ellen Olenska se presentait a lui comme une creature malheureuse et sans defense, qu'il fallait, a tout prix, empecher d'entreprendre une lutte dont elle ne sortirait que plus meurtrie.

eng: "Are we only Pharisees after all?" he wondered, puzzled by the effort to reconcile his instinctive disgust at human vileness with his equally instinctive pity for human frailty.
fr: L'innocence de New-York n'etait-elle donc qu'une simple attitude ? Sommes-nous des pharisiens ? se demanda Archer.

eng: He remembered what she had told him of Mrs. Welland's request to be spared whatever was "unpleasant" in her history, and winced at the thought that it was perhaps this attitude of mind which kept the New York air so pure.
fr: Elle avait dit que Mrs Welland desirait qu'elle passat sous silence tout ce qu'il pouvait y avoir de << penible >> dans son passe.

eng: For the first time he perceived how elementary his own principles had always been.
fr: Pour la premiere fois, il fut amene a reflechir sur les principes qui l'avaient jusque-la dirige.

eng: But Mrs. Rushworth was "that kind of woman"; foolish, vain, clandestine by nature, and far more attracted by the secrecy and peril of the affair than by such charms and qualities as he possessed.
fr: Mais Mrs Rushworth etait de la categorie des femmes un peu sottes, frivoles, eprises de mystere : le secret et le danger d'une intrigue l'avaient plus interessee que les merites de celui qui avait ete son amant.

eng: He passed for a young man who had not been afraid of risks, and he knew that his secret love-affair with poor silly Mrs. Thorley Rushworth had not been too secret to invest him with a becoming air of adventure.
