fr: Il passait pour un jeune homme qui ne craignait pas de se compromettre : son flirt avec cette pauvre petite Mrs Thorley Rushworth lui avait donne quelque prestige romanesque.

eng: When the fact dawned on him it nearly broke his heart, but now it seemed the redeeming feature of the case.
fr: Newland avait beaucoup souffert de cette constatation : il y trouvait, maintenant, presque un soulagement.

eng: The affair, in short, had been of the kind that most of the young men of his age had been through, and emerged from with calm consciences and an undisturbed belief in the abysmal distinction between the women one loved and respected and those one enjoyed--and pitied.
fr: L'aventure, en somme, ressemblait a celles que les jeunes gens de son age avaient tous traversees, et dont ils etaient sortis la conscience calme, convaincus qu'il y a un abime entre les femmes qu'on aime d'un amour respectueux et les autres.

eng: In the complicated old European communities, Archer began to guess, love-problems might be less simple and less easily classified.
fr: Archer commenca a soupconner que, dans la vie compliquee des vieilles societes europeennes, riches, oisives, faciles, les problemes d'amour etaient moins simples, moins nettement catalogues.

eng: The only thing to do was to persuade him, as early as possible, to marry a nice girl, and then trust to her to look after him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: On reaching home he wrote a line to the Countess Olenska, asking at what hour of the next day she could receive him, and despatched it by a messenger-boy, who returned presently with a word to the effect that she was going to Skuytercliff the next morning to stay over Sunday with the van der Luydens, but that he would find her alone that evening after dinner.
fr: Arrive chez lui, il ecrivit un mot a la comtesse Olenska pour lui demander a quelle heure elle pourrait le recevoir le lendemain. Elle repondit que, partant le lendemain matin pour Skuytercliff, jusqu'au dimanche soir, elle ne pourrait l'attendre que le jour meme ; il la trouverait seule apres-diner.

eng: All the elderly ladies whom Archer knew regarded any woman who loved imprudently as necessarily unscrupulous and designing, and mere simple-minded man as powerless in her clutches.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The note was written on a rather untidy half-sheet, without date or address, but her hand was firm and free.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was amused at the idea of her week-ending in the stately solitude of Skuytercliff, but immediately afterward felt that there, of all places, she would most feel the chill of minds rigorously averted from the "unpleasant."
fr: Archer sourit en pensant qu'elle finirait la semaine dans la majestueuse solitude de Skuytercliff, mais aussitot apres, il se dit que, la plus qu'ailleurs, elle souffrirait de se trouver parmi des gens resolument fermes a tout ce qui est << penible. >>

eng: He had formed his own opinion from the papers entrusted to him, and did not especially want to go into the matter with his senior partner.
fr: Il s'etait fait une opinion personnelle d'apres les documents qui lui avaient ete confies, et il ne tenait pas specialement a la communiquer a son chef.

eng: On the sideboard, between fluted Sheraton knife-cases, stood a decanter of Haut Brion, and another of the old Lanning port (the gift of a client), which the wastrel Tom Lanning had sold off a year or two before his mysterious and discreditable death in San Francisco--an incident less publicly humiliating to the family than the sale of the cellar.
fr: Sur le buffet, entre de beaux coffrets canneles du XVIIIe siecle, se trouvait une carafe de Haut-Brion et une autre du vieux porto des Lanning (don d'un client). Le prodigue Tom Lanning avait deconsidere sa famille en vendant sa cave un an ou deux avant sa mort mysterieuse et suspecte a San Francisco. Ce dernier incident avait ete moins humiliant pour les siens que la vente de sa cave.

eng: After a velvety oyster soup came shad and cucumbers, then a young broiled turkey with corn fritters, followed by a canvas-back with currant jelly and a celery mayonnaise.
fr: Apres un potage veloute aux huitres, on servit une alose aux concombres, suivie d'un dindonneau entoure de beignets de mais, auquel succeda un canard sauvage avec une mayonnaise de celeris et de la gelee de groseille.

eng: Mr. Letterblair, who lunched on a sandwich and tea, dined deliberately and deeply, and insisted on his guest's doing the same.
fr: Mr Letterblair, qui dejeunait de the et d'une sandwich, dinait copieusement et sans hate ; il insista pour que son hote fit de meme.

eng: Finally, when the closing rites had been accomplished, the cloth was removed, cigars were lit, and Mr. Letterblair, leaning back in his chair and pushing the port westward, said, spreading his back agreeably to the coal fire behind him: "The whole family are against a divorce. ~~~ And I think rightly."
fr: La nappe enlevee, les cigares s'allumerent, et Mr Letterblair, se renversant sur sa chaise, poussa le porto vers Archer. Chauffant son dos au feu, il dit : -- Toute la famille est contre le divorce, et je crois qu'elle a raison.

eng: Rich and idle and ornamental societies must produce many more such situations; and there might even be one in which a woman naturally sensitive and aloof would yet, from the force of circumstances, from sheer defencelessness and loneliness, be drawn into a tie inexcusable by conventional standards.
fr: Il n'etait sans doute pas impossible d'imaginer, dans ces milieux indulgents, des cas ou une femme, sensible et delaissee se laisserait entrainer par la force des circonstances a nouer un de ces liens que la morale reprouve.

eng: He was at Mr. Letterblair's punctually at seven, glad of the pretext for excusing himself soon after dinner.
fr: Il arriva a sept heures chez Mr Letterblair, heureux d'avoir un pretexte pour se rendre libre aussitot apres le diner.

eng: Mr. Letterblair was a widower, and they dined alone, copiously and slowly, in a dark shabby room hung with yellowing prints of "The Death of Chatham" and "The Coronation of Napoleon."
fr: Mr Letterblair etait veuf : ils dinerent seuls dans une piece sombre, sur les murs de laquelle on voyait des gravures jaunies representant << La mort de Chatham >> et << Le Couronnement de Napoleon. >>

eng: In this view they were sedulously abetted by their mothers, aunts and other elderly female relatives, who all shared Mrs. Archer's belief that when "such things happened" it was undoubtedly foolish of the man, but somehow always criminal of the woman.
fr: Ils etaient encourages dans cette maniere de voir par leurs meres, leurs tantes et autres parentes : toutes pensaient comme Mrs Archer que, dans ces affaires-la, les hommes apportent sans doute de la legerete, mais qu'en somme la vraie faute vient toujours de la femme.

eng: Archer instantly felt himself on the other side of the argument.
fr: Archer se sentit immediatement d'un avis oppose.

eng: "But why, sir? ~~~ If there ever was a case--" "Well--what's the use?
fr: -- Pourtant, si jamais un cas s'est presente... -- Qu'y gagnerait-elle ?...

eng: The young man knew this and was silent.
fr: Le jeune homme le savait : il resta silencieux.

eng: Therefore, as the family say, why not let well enough alone?"
fr: alors, comme le dit la famille, pourquoi ne pas laisser les choses comme elles sont ?

eng: Archer had gone to the house an hour earlier in full agreement with Mr. Letterblair's view;
fr: Quand Archer etait arrive chez Mr Letterblair il etait en parfait accord de vues avec lui ;

eng: but put into words by this selfish, well-fed and supremely indifferent old man it suddenly became the Pharisaic voice of a society wholly absorbed in barricading itself against the unpleasant.
fr: mais, dans la maniere dont ce vieillard egoiste, bien nourri, supremement indifferent, exposait la question, il croyait entendre la voix pharisaique de la societe, ne songeant qu'a se barricader contre tout ce qui pouvait etre << penible. >>

eng: "I think that's for her to decide."
fr: Il me semble que c'est a la comtesse Olenska de decider, dit-il sechement.

eng: "H'm--have you considered the consequences if she decides for divorce?"
fr: -- Hum !... Avez-vous pense aux consequences, si elle se decidait pour le divorce ?

eng: "You mean the threat in her husband's letter? What weight would that carry? It's no more than the vague charge of an angry blackguard."
fr: -- Vous voulez dire la menace de son mari ?... De quel poids peut-elle etre ?... Simple vengeance d'un mauvais drole.

eng: As things go over there, Olenski's acted generously: he might have turned her out without a penny.
fr: A tout prendre, Olenski a agi genereusement. Il pouvait la renvoyer sans un sou.

eng: She'll never get back a dollar more of her money than what he's voluntarily returned to her: their damned heathen marriage settlements take precious good care of that.
fr: Elle ne retrouvera pas un dollar de plus que ce qu'il lui a rendu volontairement. Les clauses de cet abominable contrat francais y ont mis bon ordre.

eng: SHE'S here--he's there; the Atlantic's between them.
fr: Elle est ici, il est la ; l'Atlantique est entre eux.

eng: "I understand, though," Mr. Letterblair continued, "that she attaches no importance to the money.
fr: -- Il parait, cependant, continua Mr Letterblair qu'elle n'attache pas d'importance a l'argent ;

eng: "Yes; but it might make some unpleasant talk if he really defends the suit."
fr: -- S'il se defendait serieusement, il pourrait sortir des choses penibles.

eng: '"Unpleasant--!" said Archer explosively.
fr: '-- Penibles ! ... dit Archer avec ironie.'

eng: Mr. Letterblair looked at him from under enquiring eyebrows, and the young man, aware of the uselessness of trying to explain what was in his mind, bowed acquiescently
fr: Mr Letterblair le regarda d'un air etonne et le jeune homme, renoncant a faire comprendre sa pensee, acquiesca par un signe de tete,

eng: while his senior continued: "Divorce is always unpleasant."
fr: -- Un divorce est toujours une chose penible.

eng: "You agree with me?" Mr. Letterblair resumed, after a waiting silence.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Naturally," said Archer.
fr: -- En effet... dit Archer.'

eng: "Well, then, I may count on you; the Mingotts may count on you; to use your influence against the idea?"
fr: -- Alors, je compte sur vous, les Mingott comptent sur vous, pour user de votre influence sur Mme Olenska et la detourner de ce projet.

eng: Archer hesitated.
fr: Archer hesita.

eng: "I can't pledge myself till I've seen the Countess Olenska," he said at length.
fr: -- Je ne puis m'engager avant d'avoir vu la comtesse Olenska.

eng: Now that the job had been thrust on him he did not propose to relinquish it; and, to guard against the possibility, he saw that he must reassure the unimaginative old man who was the legal conscience of the Mingotts.
fr: Mais maintenant que la cause lui avait ete confiee, il pretendait la garder ; et il s'appliqua a rassurer le methodique vieillard qui representait la conscience legale des Mingott.'

eng: "Mr. Archer, I don't understand you. Do you want to marry into a family with a scandalous divorce-suit hanging over it?"
fr: '-- Mr Archer, je ne vous comprends pas. Voulez-vous vous marier dans une famille qui est sous le coup d'un scandale ?'

eng: "I don't think that has anything to do with the case."
fr: '-- Je ne vois pas que mon mariage ait rien a faire la-dedans.'

eng: Mr. Letterblair put down his glass of port and fixed on his young partner a cautious and apprehensive gaze.
fr: Mr Letterblair deposa son verre de porto et regarda son jeune associe d'un air inquiet.

eng: Archer understood that he ran the risk of having his mandate withdrawn, and for some obscure reason he disliked the prospect.
fr: Archer comprit que Mr Letterblair allait peut-etre lui retirer l'affaire.

eng: "You may be sure, sir, that I shan't commit myself till I've reported to you; what I meant was that I'd rather not give an opinion till I've heard what Madame Olenska has to say."
fr: -- Vous pouvez etre sur, monsieur, que je ne m'avancerai pas avant de vous en avoir refere. ~~~ Je voulais seulement dire que je prefererais reserver mon jugement jusqu'a ce que j'aie entendue Mme Olenska.

eng: Mr. Letterblair nodded approvingly at an excess of caution worthy of the best New York tradition, and the young man, glancing at his watch, pleaded an engagement and took leave.
fr: Mr Letterblair approuva de la tete une discretion digne de la meilleure tradition de New-York, et le jeune homme, pretextant un engagement, prit conge. ~~~ | Aux Etats-Unis, les avocats s'associent, et cumulent les roles d'avocats et d'avoues.

eng: It was not an Opera night, and no one was giving a party, so that Beaufort's outing was undoubtedly of a clandestine nature.
fr: Ce n'etait pas un soir d'Opera, personne ne recevait : donc la sortie de Beaufort devait etre clandestine.

eng: A little farther up Fifth Avenue, Beaufort appeared on his doorstep, darkly projected against a blaze of light, descended to his private brougham, and rolled away to a mysterious and probably unmentionable destination.
fr: Un peu plus loin, dans la Cinquieme Avenue, Beaufort se montra sur le pas de sa porte, vivement silhouette par la lumiere de l'antichambre. Il monta dans son coupe et partit dans une direction mysterieuse.

eng: Thus, as Archer crossed Washington Square, he remarked that old Mr. du Lac was calling on his cousins the Dagonets, and turning down the corner of West Tenth Street he saw Mr. Skipworth, of his own firm, obviously bound on a visit to the Miss Lannings.
fr: Ensuite il apercut, au tournant de la Dixieme Rue, Mr Samson, de son etude, qui allait rendre visite aux vieilles Misses Lanning.

eng: As the young man strolled up Fifth Avenue from Waverley Place, the long thoroughfare was deserted but for a group of carriages standing before the Reggie Chiverses' (where there was a dinner for the Duke), and the occasional figure of an elderly gentleman in heavy overcoat and muffler ascending a brownstone doorstep and disappearing into a gas-lit hall.
fr: Comme il descendait lentement la Cinquieme Avenue, Archer remarqua, dans la grande voie deserte, une file de voitures qui stationnaient devant la maison des Reggie Chivers ; il se souvint qu'ils donnaient ce soir-la un diner en l'honneur du Duc. Traversant Washington Square il vit un monsieur age, en pardessus et cache-nez, monter un perron et disparaitre dans un vestibule eclaire : c'etait le vieux Mr du Lac qui allait voir ses cousins Dagonet.

eng: XII. Old-fashioned New York dined at seven, and the habit of after-dinner calls, though derided in Archer's set, still generally prevailed.
fr: XII La coutume de faire des visites le soir, apres le diner, prevalait encore a New-York, malgre la jeune coterie de gens chic qui la trouvait ridicule.

eng: Archer connected it in his mind with a little house beyond Lexington Avenue in which beribboned window curtains and flower-boxes had recently appeared, and before whose newly painted door the canary-coloured brougham of Miss Fanny Ring was frequently seen to wait.
fr: Archer evoqua aussitot une petite maison situee au dela de Lexington Avenue, qui s'etait recemment ornee de rideaux enrubannes et de caisses fleuries. ~~~ Devant la porte nouvellement repeinte, on voyait souvent stationner le coupe jaune serin de Miss Fanny Ring.

eng: Beyond the small and slippery pyramid which composed Mrs. Archer's world lay the almost unmapped quarter inhabited by artists, musicians and "people who wrote."
fr: Au dela de la glissante pyramide qui composait le monde de Mrs Archer s'etendait la region heteroclite ou vivaient des artistes, des musiciens et des << gens qui ecrivent.

eng: These scattered fragments of humanity had never shown any desire to be amalgamated with the social structure.
fr: >> -- Ces echantillons epars de l'humanite n'avaient jamais essaye de s'amalgamer avec la societe.

eng: In spite of odd ways they were said to be, for the most part, quite respectable; but they preferred to keep to themselves.
fr: En depit de leurs originalites on les disait pour la plupart dignes d'estime ; mais ils preferaient rester entre eux.

eng: Medora Manson, in her prosperous days, had inaugurated a "literary salon"; but it had soon died out owing to the reluctance of the literary to frequent it.
fr: Medora Manson, dans ses jours de prosperite, avait fonde un << salon litteraire ; >> mais il s'etait eteint de lui-meme, faute de gens de lettres pour le frequenter.

eng: Others had made the same attempt, and there was a household of Blenkers--an intense and voluble mother, and three blowsy daughters who imitated her--where one met Edwin Booth and Patti and William Winter, and the new Shakespearian actor George Rignold, and some of the magazine editors and musical and literary critics.
fr: D'autres avaient fait la meme tentative. ~~~ Chez Mrs Blenker, femme bouillonnante et bavarde, et mere de trois filles a sa ressemblance, on rencontrait le grand acteur tragique Edwin Booth, Adelina Patti, William Winter le critique dramatique, l'acteur anglais George Rignold, des editeurs, des critiques litteraires et musicaux.

eng: Mrs. Archer and her group felt a certain timidity concerning these persons.
fr: Mrs Archer et son groupe eprouvaient une certaine timidite vis a vis de ces personnes.

eng: They were odd, they were uncertain, they had things one didn't know about in the background of their lives and minds.
fr: Elles etaient d'espece particuliere, difficiles a classer ; on ne connaissait pas l'arriere-plan de leurs vies et de leurs esprits.

eng: Literature and art were deeply respected in the Archer set, and Mrs. Archer was always at pains to tell her children how much more agreeable and cultivated society had been when it included such figures as Washington Irving, Fitz-Greene Halleck and the poet of "The Culprit Fay."
fr: La litterature et les arts etaient hautement apprecies dans l'entourage des Archer ; et Mrs Archer s'evertuait toujours a expliquer a ses enfants combien la societe etait plus agreable a l'epoque ou elle comprenait des gens de lettres comme Washington Irving, Fitz Greene Halleck et l'auteur de The Culprit Fay.

eng: Only old Catherine Mingott, with her absence of moral prejudices and almost parvenu indifference to the subtler distinctions, might have bridged the abyss; but she had never opened a book or looked at a picture, and cared for music only because it reminded her of gala nights at the Italiens, in the days of her triumph at the Tuileries.
fr: Peu embarrassee de prejuges, indifferente aux fines distinctions sociales, la vieille Mrs Mingott aurait pu relier les deux milieux ; mais elle n'ouvrait jamais un livre, ne regardait jamais un tableau ; et la musique lui rappelait seulement les soirees de gala aux Italiens, a l'epoque de ses triomphes aux Tuileries.

eng: "When I was a girl," Mrs. Archer used to say, "we knew everybody between the Battery and Canal Street; and only the people one knew had carriages. It was perfectly easy to place any one then; now one can't tell, and I prefer not to try."
fr: -- Quand j'etais jeune fille, disait Mrs Archer, nous connaissions tous les gens qui habitaient entre la Batterie et Canal Street. Les gens qu'on connaissait etaient seuls a avoir leur voiture : rien n'etait plus facile que de situer quelqu'un. Maintenant, on ne sait plus, -- et on aime autant ne pas savoir.

eng: The most celebrated authors of that generation had been "gentlemen"; perhaps the unknown persons who succeeded them had gentlemanly sentiments, but their origin, their appearance, their hair, their intimacy with the stage and the Opera, made any old New York criterion inapplicable to them.
fr: 'Les plus celebres auteurs de cette generation avaient ete des << gentlemen. >> Peut-etre les inconnus qui leur avaient succede etaient-ils d'aussi honnetes gens ; mais leur origine, leur tenue, leurs tignasses incultes, leurs relations avec les acteurs et les chanteurs, empechaient de les classifier d'apres le criterium du vieux New-York.

eng: Possibly Beaufort, who was her match in daring, would have succeeded in bringing about a fusion; but his grand house and silk-stockinged footmen were an obstacle to informal sociability.
fr: Beaufort aussi, qui la valait en audace, aurait pu essayer de combler le fosse ; mais ses salons somptueux, ses laquais en culottes, intimidaient la race artistique.

eng: Moreover, he was as illiterate as old Mrs. Mingott, and considered "fellows who wrote" as the mere paid purveyors of rich men's pleasures; and no one rich enough to influence his opinion had ever questioned it.
fr: De plus, aussi peu cultive que Mrs Mingott, il considerait les ecrivains comme des pourvoyeurs salaries, preposes au plaisir des riches, et son opinion n'avait jamais ete mise en question par quelqu'un d'assez riche pour l'influencer.

eng: He enjoyed them there, and was bored with them at the Blenkers', where they were mingled with fervid and dowdy women who passed them about like captured curiosities;
fr: S'il les voyait avec plaisir dans ces milieux-la, il n'en etait pas de meme chez les Blenker, ou ils se trouvaient meles a des femmes du monde aussi ferventes que mal fagotees, qui les exhibaient comme des curiosites.

eng: Archer knew most of the "fellows who wrote," the musicians and the painters: he met them at the Century, or at the little musical and theatrical clubs that were beginning to come into existence.
fr: Archer connaissait personnellement la plupart des ecrivains, musiciens et peintres de sa ville natale. Il les rencontrait au Century Club, ou dans les petits cercles litteraires et musicaux qui commencaient a naitre.

eng: But such things were inconceivable in New York, and unsettling to think of.
fr: Mais, a New-York, quel reve irrealisable !

eng: he had often pictured to himself what it would have been to live in the intimacy of drawing-rooms dominated by the talk of Merimee (whose "Lettres a une Inconnue" was one of his inseparables), of Thackeray, Browning or William Morris.
fr: Il aimait a se figurer quel avait du etre le plaisir de vivre dans des salons ou l'on s'entretenait avec ses auteurs favoris : Thackeray, Browning, William Morris, Merimee (dont les Lettres a une Inconnue etaient un de ses livres preferes).

eng: He knew that there were societies where painters and poets and novelists and men of science, and even great actors, were as sought after as Dukes;
fr: Il savait qu'il y avait, dans la vieille societe europeenne, des milieux ou les peintres, les poetes, les romanciers, les hommes de science, et meme les grands acteurs, etaient aussi recherches que des princes.

eng: Newland Archer had been aware of these things ever since he could remember, and had accepted them as part of the structure of his universe.
fr: Newland Archer avait toujours accepte cet etat de choses comme faisant partie de la structure de son univers.

eng: and even after his most exciting talks with Ned Winsett he always came away with the feeling that if his world was small, so was theirs, and that the only way to enlarge either was to reach a stage of manners where they would naturally merge.
fr: Meme apres ses conversations les plus interessantes avec Ned Winsett, Archer gardait l'impression que, si son monde a lui etait bien restreint, le leur l'etait encore davantage, et que le seul moyen de les elargir l'un et l'autre serait d'arriver a les fondre.

eng: He was reminded of this by trying to picture the society in which the Countess Olenska had lived and suffered, and also--perhaps--tasted mysterious joys.
fr: Tout en reflechissant ainsi, il essayait de se figurer le milieu ou la comtesse Olenska avait vecu, avait souffert, avait aussi, peut-etre, goute de mysterieuses joies.

eng: It was not the peril but the poverty that her family disliked; but that shade escaped her, and she supposed they considered literature compromising.
fr: En realite, ce que sa famille desapprouvait, c'etait l'originalite d'aller habiter un quartier si peu elegant ; mais cette nuance lui echappait, et elle pensait que la litterature etait consideree comme compromettante.

eng: She herself had no fears of it, and the books scattered about her drawing-room (a part of the house in which books were usually supposed to be "out of place"), though chiefly works of fiction, had whetted Archer's interest with such new names as those of Paul Bourget, Huysmans, and the Goncourt brothers.
fr: Elle, au contraire, n'en avait pas peur, a en juger par les livres qu'on voyait epars dans son salon (a New-York, on ne laissait pas trainer de livres dans un salon). La plupart de ces livres etaient des romans, mais qui avaient cependant eveille l'attention d'Archer par des noms nouveaux : Paul Bourget, Huysmans, les freres de Goncourt.

eng: He remembered with what amusement she had told him that her grandmother Mingott and the Wellands objected to her living in a "Bohemian" quarter given over to "people who wrote."
fr: Comme elle avait ri en lui racontant que sa grand'mere Mingott et les Welland s'opposaient a son installation dans un quartier boheme abandonne aux << gens qui ecrivent ! >>

eng: Ruminating on these things as he approached her door, he was once more conscious of the curious way in which she reversed his values, and of the need of thinking himself into conditions incredibly different from any that he knew if he were to be of use in her present difficulty.
fr: Il pensait a tout cela en approchant de la porte de Mme Olenska. ~~~ Il sentait qu'elle etait femme a changer en lui toute l'echelle des valeurs, et comprit qu'il serait force de se mettre a des points de vue incroyablement nouveaux s'il voulait lui etre utile dans ses difficultes presentes.

eng: He had thrust his chest out, supporting his shoulders against the mantel and resting his weight on one large patent-leather foot.
fr: Beaufort plastronnait, les epaules effacees, le poids du corps portant sur un de ses grands pieds,

eng: Archer remembered, on his last visit to Paris, seeing a portrait by the new painter, Carolus Duran, whose pictures were the sensation of the Salon, in which the lady wore one of these bold sheath-like robes with her chin nestling in fur.
fr: Archer se rappela avoir vu, lors de son dernier sejour a Paris, un portrait du nouveau peintre Carolus Duran (dont les tableaux faisaient sensation au Salon), qui representait une dame audacieusement habillee d'une robe fourreau, le cou niche dans la fourrure.

eng: But Madame Olenska, heedless of tradition, was attired in a long robe of red velvet bordered about the chin and down the front with glossy black fur.
fr: Mais Mme Olenska, insoucieuse de la tradition, etait vetue d'un long fourreau de velours rouge, borde autour du cou d'une haute fourrure noire.

eng: It was usual for ladies who received in the evenings to wear what were called "simple dinner dresses": a close-fitting armour of whale-boned silk, slightly open in the neck, with lace ruffles filling in the crack, and tight sleeves with a flounce uncovering just enough wrist to show an Etruscan gold bracelet or a velvet band.
fr: L'usage voulait que les dames qui recevaient le soir portassent de << simples robes de diner, >> c'est-a-dire une armure de soie baleinee, legerement decolletee, avec des ruches de dentelles remplissant l'echancrure du corsage et des manches etroites decouvrant tout juste assez de poignet pour laisser voir un bracelet en or etrusque ou un lien de velours noir.

eng: A table banked with flowers formed a screen behind it, and against the orchids and azaleas which the young man recognised as tributes from the Beaufort hot-houses, Madame Olenska sat half-reclined, her head propped on a hand and her wide sleeve leaving the arm bare to the elbow.
fr: Une table couverte de fleurs formait paravent derriere le canape ; et sur le fond d'orchidees et d'azalees, que Newland reconnut pour venir des serres de Beaufort, Mme Olenska se tenait a demi etendue, la tete appuyee sur sa main, laissant voir, par une large manche ouverte, un bras nu jusqu'au coude.

eng: As Archer entered he was smiling and looking down on his hostess, who sat on a sofa placed at right angles to the chimney.
fr: et regardait, en souriant, leur hotesse assise sur un canape pres de la cheminee.

eng: The banker stood leaning against the mantelshelf, which was draped with an old embroidery held in place by brass candelabra containing church candles of yellowish wax.
fr: Le banquier se tenait debout devant le feu. Derriere lui, deux candelabres de cuivre, garnis de cierges en cire jaunatre, retenaient la broderie ancienne dont s'ornait la cheminee.

eng: He had therefore no one but himself to blame if she had opened her doors to other visitors; and he entered the drawing-room with the dogged determination to make Beaufort feel himself in the way, and to outstay him.
fr: Il ne devait donc s'en prendre qu'a lui si elle avait du monde. Il entra dans le salon, resolu a faire sentir a Julius Beaufort que sa presence etait inopportune, et a rester le dernier.

eng: Archer was angry: so angry that he came near scribbling a word on his card and going away; then he remembered that in writing to Madame Olenska he had been kept by excess of discretion from saying that he wished to see her privately.
fr: Archer etait furieux, si furieux qu'il fut sur le point de griffonner un mot sur sa carte et de s'en aller ; mais il se rappela qu'en ecrivant a Mme Olenska il avait, par exces de discretion, omis de lui dire qu'il desirait la voir seule.

eng: On the bench in the hall lay a sable-lined overcoat, a folded opera hat of dull silk with a gold J. B. on the lining, and a white silk muffler: there was no mistaking the fact that these costly articles were the property of Julius Beaufort.
fr: Sur le banc de l'antichambre etaient poses une pelisse de zibeline, un claque marque aux initiales << J. B. >> et un foulard de soie blanche.

eng: Nastasia opened the door, smiling mysteriously.
fr: Nastasia ouvrit la porte en souriant d'un air mysterieux.

eng: There was something perverse and provocative in the notion of fur worn in the evening in a heated drawing-room, and in the combination of a muffled throat and bare arms; but the effect was undeniably pleasing.
fr: Il y avait quelque chose de pervers et de provocant dans l'idee de porter des fourrures en plein salon surchauffe, et dans la combinaison d'un cou emmitoufle avec des bras nus ; mais, sans conteste, l'effet etait agreable.

eng: "Lord love us--three whole days at Skuytercliff!"
fr: -- Seigneur !... ~~~ Trois jours entiers a Skuytercliff !...

eng: Beaufort was saying in his loud sneering voice as Archer entered.
fr: disait Beaufort de sa forte voix sarcastique, comme Archer entrait.

eng: "Granny would, of course.
fr: 'Grand'mere le dit, c'est tout naturel.'

eng: "Why? Is the house so cold?"
fr: 'Comment ! la maison est si froide ?... demanda-t-elle, tendant sa main gauche a Archer, qui eut l'impression qu'elle s'attendait a ce qu'il la baisat.'

eng: she asked, holding out her left hand to Archer in a way mysteriously suggesting that she expected him to kiss it.
fr: 'Comment ! la maison est si froide ?... demanda-t-elle, tendant sa main gauche a Archer, qui eut l'impression qu'elle s'attendait a ce qu'il la baisat.'

eng: "No; but the missus is,"
fr: 'Non, mais la bonne dame l'est !'

eng: said Beaufort, nodding carelessly to the young man.
fr: 'dit Beaufort en saluant negligemment le jeune homme par un signe de tete.'

eng: "But I thought her so kind.
fr: 'Moi, je la trouve si aimable !'

eng: She came herself to invite me.
fr: 'Elle est venue m'inviter elle-meme.'

eng: Granny says I must certainly go."
fr: 'Grand'mere dit que je ne dois pas manquer d'y aller.'

eng: And I say it's a shame you're going to miss the little oyster supper I'd planned for you at Delmonico's next Sunday, with Campanini and Scalchi and a lot of jolly people."
fr: 'Mais moi je dis que c'est une honte que vous manquiez le petit souper que j'ai arrange pour vous chez Delmonico, dimanche prochain, avec Campanini, Scalchi, et un tas de gens amusants.'

eng: "Ah--that does tempt me!"
fr: 'Ah !... Je suis bien tentee !...'

eng: "You'd better take all your furs, and a hot-water-bottle."
fr: 'Vous ferez bien d'emporter vos fourrures, et votre boule d'eau chaude aussi.'

eng: Except the other evening at Mrs. Struthers's I've not met a single artist since I've been here."
fr: A part la derniere soiree de Mrs Struthers, je n'ai pas rencontre un seul artiste depuis que je suis ici.

eng: "What kind of artists?
fr: -- Quel genre d'artistes voulez-vous dire ?...

eng: I know one or two painters, very good fellows, that I could bring to see you if you'd allow me," said Archer boldly.
fr: Je connais un ou deux peintres, de charmants garcons que je peux vous amener si vous le permettez, dit vivement Archer.

eng: "Painters?
fr: -- Des peintres ?...

eng: She said the words "my husband" as if no sinister associations were connected with them, and in a tone that seemed almost to sigh over the lost delights of her married life.
fr: Elle prononca les mots << mon mari >> comme s'ils ne rappelaient aucun souvenir douloureux, et d'une voix qui paraissait presque soupirer sur les delices perdues de sa vie conjugale.

eng: My husband's house was always full of them."
fr: La maison de mon mari en etait toujours pleine.

eng: "Are there painters in New York?" asked Beaufort, in a tone implying that there could be none since he did not buy their pictures;
fr: 'Y a-t-il des peintres a New-York ?... demanda Beaufort, d'un ton qui impliquait que, puisqu'il n'achetait pas leurs peintures, les peintres n'existaient pas.

eng: and Madame Olenska said to Archer, with her grave smile: "That would be charming.
fr: Mme Olenska repondit a Archer avec son sourire grave : -- Ce serait charmant ;

eng: But I was really thinking of dramatic artists, singers, actors, musicians.
fr: mais je pensais a des artistes dramatiques, a des chanteurs, des acteurs, des musiciens.

eng: Archer looked at her perplexedly, wondering if it were lightness or dissimulation that enabled her to touch so easily on the past at the very moment when she was risking her reputation in order to break with it.
fr: Archer se demandait si c'etait la legerete ou la dissimulation qui lui permettait de faire si aisement allusion a un passe dont elle cherchait, au moment meme, a s'emanciper au risque de perdre sa reputation.

eng: "I do think," she went on, addressing both men, "that the imprevu adds to one's enjoyment.
fr: -- Je trouve, continua-t-elle, que l'imprevu ajoute au plaisir.

eng: It's perhaps a mistake to see the same people every day."
fr: C'est peut-etre une erreur que de voir les memes personnes tous les jours.

eng: "It's confoundedly dull, anyhow; New York is dying of dullness," Beaufort grumbled.
fr: -- C'est bien ennuyeux en tout cas !... ~~~ New-York meurt d'ennui ! ~~~ bougonna Beaufort.

eng: "and I've a private room, and a Steinway, and they'll sing all night for me."
fr: 'J'ai un salon particulier, et un piano Steinway, et ils feront de la musique toute la nuit.'

eng: "And when I try to liven it up for you, you go back on me."
fr: 'Et quand j'essaie de l'animer pour vous, vous me lachez !... '

eng: "Come--think better of it! Sunday is your last chance, for Campanini leaves next week for Baltimore and Philadelphia;"
fr: 'Ecoutez ! ~~~ Pensez-y !... Nous ne pouvons rien arranger apres dimanche, car Campanini part la semaine prochaine pour chanter a Baltimore et Philadelphie. ~~~'

eng: "How delicious!
fr: -- Comme ce serait delicieux !...

eng: May I think it over, and write to you tomorrow morning?"
fr: Puis-je reflechir, et vous ecrire demain ?

eng: She spoke amiably, yet with the least hint of dismissal in her voice.
fr: Elle parlait en souriant, mais il y avait dans le ton de ses paroles une imperceptible invite a prendre conge.

eng: Beaufort evidently felt it, and being unused to dismissals, stood staring at her with an obstinate line between his eyes.
fr: Beaufort s'en rendit compte ; mais, n'etant pas habitue a etre econduit, il resta devant elle, un pli obstine entre les yeux.

eng: She returned his glance coolly.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ah," Beaufort snapped.
fr: "-- Ah ! dit Beaufort d'un ton cassant."

eng: "Yes; because I have still to talk business with Mr. Archer for a little while."
fr: "-- Oui, parce que j'ai encore a parler affaires avec Mr Archer."

eng: "Do you call it late?"
fr: "-- Vous trouvez qu'il est tard ?"

eng: "Why not now?"
fr: "-- Pourquoi pas maintenant ?"

eng: "It's too serious a question to decide at this late hour."
fr: "-- C'est trop grave pour se decider comme cela, a cette heure tardive."

eng: There was no appeal from her tone, and with a slight shrug he recovered his composure, took her hand, which he kissed with a practised air, and calling out from the threshold: "I say, Newland, if you can persuade the Countess to stop in town of course you're included in the supper," left the room with his heavy important step.
fr: Il eut un leger mouvement d'epaules, prit la main de la jeune femme, qu'il baisa avec aisance, et, s'adressant a Archer du pas de la porte : -- Newland, si vous pouvez persuader a la comtesse de rester en ville, vous etes du souper, c'est entendu. ~~~ Puis il partit de son pas lourd et arrogant.

eng: but the irrelevance of her next remark made him change his mind.
fr: la premiere question que lui adressa la jeune femme le detrompa :

eng: "Oh, not exactly. I don't know that the arts have a milieu here, any of them; they're more like a very thinly settled outskirt."
fr: -- Pas precisement. Les arts ici ne sont pas un milieu. On les tient plutot en marge.

eng: "You know painters, then? You live in their milieu?" she asked, her eyes full of interest.
fr: -- Vous connaissez des peintres, alors ?... Vous vivez dans leur milieu ?

eng: For a moment Archer fancied that Mr. Letterblair must have told her of his coming;
fr: Archer se figura que Mr Letterblair avait prevenu Mme Olenska de sa visite ;

eng: "But you care for such things?"
fr: -- Vous aimez beaucoup les arts ?

eng: "Immensely."
fr: -- Beaucoup...

eng: When I'm in Paris or London I never miss an exhibition.
fr: Quand je vais a Paris ou a Londres, je ne manque pas une exposition...

eng: I try to keep up."
fr: J'essaie de me tenir au courant.

eng: "That's the reason I've come. He asked me to--you see I'm in the firm."
fr: C'est pour cela que je suis venu...

eng: She struck Archer, of a sudden, as a pathetic and even pitiful figure.
fr: Archer fut touche de son expression pathetique, d'autant plus touchante que la jeune femme avait completement perdu son air d'aisance et de domination.

eng: She sat silent, her head still propped by the arm that rested on the back of the sofa. Her face looked pale and extinguished, as if dimmed by the rich red of her dress.
fr: La comtesse Olenska restait silencieuse, la tete appuyee sur un bras, le visage pale, comme eteint par le rouge eclatant de sa robe.

eng: "I am here to talk about it," he repeated.
fr: Je suis venu pour que nous en parlions, reprit-il.

eng: He perceived that she had spoken of business to Beaufort simply to get rid of him; and to have routed Beaufort was something of a triumph.
fr: Il comprit qu'elle n'avait pretexte une conversation d'affaires que pour congedier Beaufort, et d'avoir fait congedier Beaufort etait pour lui presqu'un triomphe.

eng: She looked down at the tip of the little satin boot that peeped from her long draperies.
fr: Elle regarda le bout de la petite bottine de satin qui sortait de ses longues draperies.

eng: "I used to care immensely too: my life was full of such things. But now I want to try not to."
fr: Je les aimais beaucoup aussi... Ils remplissaient ma vie... Mais je veux essayer de ne plus y penser...

eng: "You want to try not to?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Yes: I want to cast off all my old life, to become just like everybody else here."
fr: Je veux rompre tout a fait avec ma vie passee ; devenir comme tout le monde ici.

eng: Archer reddened.
fr: Archer rougit.

eng: "You'll never be like everybody else," he said.
fr: Vous ne serez jamais comme tout le monde.

eng: Her tone touched him, and his confidence grew with his self-satisfaction.
fr: L'intonation de la jeune femme le toucha et il prit confiance.

eng: "Ah, don't say that. If you knew how I hate to be different!"
fr: Ne dites pas cela !... Si vous saviez combien j'ai horreur d'etre differente !

eng: Her face had grown as sombre as a tragic mask. She leaned forward, clasping her knee in her thin hands, and looking away from him into remote dark distances.
fr: Penchee en avant, le masque tragique, elle sembla perdue dans quelque reverie lointaine.

eng: "I want to get away from it all," she insisted.
fr: Je veux tout oublier, repeta-t-elle.

eng: He waited a moment and cleared his throat.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I know. Mr. Letterblair has told me."
fr: Je sais ; Mr Low me l'a dit.

eng: "Ah?"
fr: Ah ?

eng: "You mean you can manage it for me? I can talk to you instead of Mr. Letterblair? Oh, that will be so much easier!"
fr: Ainsi, je puis vous parler de mon affaire, au lieu d'en parler a Mr Low ?... Ce sera tellement plus facile !

eng: She raised her straight eyebrows a little.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She looked slightly surprised, and then her eyes brightened.
fr: Elle parut un peu surprise, mais sa figure s'eclaira :

eng: "Now we're coming to hard facts," he thought, conscious in himself of the same instinctive recoil that he had so often criticised in his mother and her contemporaries.
fr: << Maintenant, nous arrivons aux dures realites, >> pensa-t-il, eprouvant le meme recul instinctif qu'il avait si souvent critique chez sa mere et chez ses contemporaines.

eng: How little practice he had had in dealing with unusual situations!
fr: Qu'il avait peu l'experience de ces situations anormales !

eng: Their very vocabulary was unfamiliar to him, and seemed to belong to fiction and the stage.
fr: Leur vocabulaire meme etait inusite pour lui et semblait n'appartenir qu'au roman ou au theatre.

eng: "I understand that."
fr: Je comprends votre desir.

eng: Her face warmed.
fr: Le visage de la jeune femme s'anima :

eng: "Then you'll help me?"
fr: -- Alors vous m'aiderez ?

eng: After a pause Madame Olenska broke out with unexpected vehemence: "I want to be free; I want to wipe out all the past."
fr: Apres un silence Mme Olenska s'ecria brusquement : -- Je veux etre libre !... Je veux que tout le passe soit efface !

eng: In face of what was coming he felt as awkward and embarrassed as a boy.
fr: Devant ce qui se preparait, il se sentait aussi gauche et embarrasse qu'un petit garcon.

eng: "First--" he hesitated--"perhaps I ought to know a little more."
fr: -- D'abord, hesita-t-il... peut-etre aurais-je besoin d'en savoir un peu plus.

eng: She seemed surprised.
fr: Elle sembla surprise.

eng: "You know about my husband--my life with him?"
fr: -- Vous savez ce qu'etait mon mari... ce qu'etait ma vie avec lui ?

eng: He made a sign of assent.
fr: Il fit un signe d'assentiment.

eng: "Well--then--what more is there?
fr: -- Eh bien, alors... que faut-il de plus ?...

eng: The letter filled only half a page,
fr: Cette lettre n'avait qu'une demi-page,

eng: "Certainly not."
fr: -- Non, certainement.

eng: I'm a Protestant--our church does not forbid divorce in such cases.
fr: Je suis protestante ; notre eglise ne defend pas le divorce dans un cas comme le mien...

eng: In this country are such things tolerated?
fr: De telles choses sont-elles tolerees ici ?

eng: and was just what he had described it to be in speaking of it to Mr. Letterblair: the vague charge of an angry blackguard.
fr: et n'etait, comme Archer l'avait dit a Mr Low, qu'une vague accusation de coquin exaspere.

eng: and Archer felt the spectre of Count Olenski's letter grimacing hideously between them.
fr: La lettre du comte Olenski etait entre eux comme un spectre.

eng: They were both silent again,
fr: Tous deux retomberent dans le silence.

eng: But how much truth was behind it?
fr: Mais quelle part de verite enfermait-elle ?

eng: Only Count Olenski's wife could tell.
fr: Seule la femme du comte Olenski aurait pu le lui dire.

eng: "I've looked through the papers you gave to Mr. Letterblair," he said at length.
fr: -- J'ai parcouru les documents que vous avez remis a Mr Letterblair, dit-il enfin.

eng: "Well--can there be anything more abominable?"
fr: '-- Eh bien... peut-on rien voir de plus abominable ?'

eng: "No."
fr: '-- Non, certes.'

eng: "She changed her position slightly, screening her eyes with her lifted hand."
fr: 'Elle changea legerement de position, abritant ses yeux avec sa main.'

eng: "Of course you know," Archer continued, "that if your husband chooses to fight the case--as he threatens to--" "Yes--?"
fr: -- Vous savez sans doute, continua Archer, que si votre mari veut se defendre comme il vous en menace... -- Eh bien ?...

eng: "He can say things--things that might be unpl--might be disagreeable to you: say them publicly, so that they would get about, and harm you even if--" "If--?"
fr: -- Il peut dire des choses -- des choses qui pourraient etre desagreables pour vous, les dire publiquement. ~~~ Elles risqueraient de courir le monde, de vous blesser, si... -- Si ? ~~~ dit-elle dans un souffle.

eng: It was on his lips to exclaim: "My poor child--far more harm than anywhere else!"
fr: Il fut pres de s'ecrier : << Ma pauvre enfant ! ~~~ plus de mal ici qu'ailleurs ! >>

eng: She said nothing, and he continued: "Our ideas about marriage and divorce are particularly old-fashioned. ~~~ Our legislation favours divorce--our social customs don't."
fr: Nos idees sur le mariage et le divorce tout particulierement... Notre legislation favorise le divorce... nos habitudes sociales ne l'admettent pas.

eng: Instead, he answered, in a voice that sounded in his ears like Mr. Letterblair's: "New York society is a very small world compared with the one you've lived in. And it's ruled, in spite of appearances, by a few people with--well, rather old-fashioned ideas."
fr: Mais il repondit, d'un ton qui resonna a ses oreilles comme la voix de Mr Letterblair : -- La societe de New-York est un monde bien petit aupres de celui ou vous avez vecu... et il est mene, ce petit monde, par quelques personnes qui ont... des idees un peu arrierees...

eng: "What harm could such accusations, even if he made them publicly, do me here?"
fr: -- Mais ses accusations, meme publiques, quel mal pourraient-elles me faire ici ?

eng: She paused for a long interval; so long that, not wishing to keep his eyes on her shaded face, he had time to imprint on his mind the exact shape of her other hand, the one on her knee, and every detail of the three rings on her fourth and fifth fingers; among which, he noticed, a wedding ring did not appear.
fr: Elle garda longtemps le silence, si longtemps que ne voulant pas fixer les yeux sur son visage, qu'elle abritait toujours, Archer eut le temps d'imprimer dans son esprit la forme exacte de son autre main, celle qui reposait sur son genou, et tous les details des trois bagues qu'elle portait. Parmi ces bagues, il remarqua qu'il n'y avait pas d'alliance.

eng: "I mean: no matter how unfounded they were."
fr: '-- Je veux dire : si peu fondees qu'elles soient.'

eng: "Never?"
fr: -- En aucun cas ?

eng: None came.
fr: Rien ne vint.

eng: A little travelling clock ticked purringly at her elbow, and a log broke in two and sent up a shower of sparks.
fr: Une petite pendule de voyage ronronnait ; une buche se brisa, faisant jaillir une gerbe d'etincelles ;

eng: The whole hushed and brooding room seemed to be waiting silently with Archer.
fr: toute la chambre, calme et immobile, semblait attendre en silence avec Archer.'

eng: '"Well--not if the woman, however injured, however irreproachable, has appearances in the least degree against her, has exposed herself by any unconventional action to--to offensive insinuations--"
fr: '-- Elles ne l'admettent pas, si une femme, meme calomniee, meme irreprochable, a la moindre apparence contre elle, si elle s'est exposee a la critique en prenant une attitude qui ne rentre pas dans les conventions habituelles, si sa conduite prete a des insinuations...'

eng: She drooped her head a little lower, and he waited again, intensely hoping for a flash of indignation, or at least a brief cry of denial.
fr: La comtesse Olenska baissait la tete : Archer attendit, esperant un eclair d'indignation, tout au moins une breve parole de denegation...

eng: "Yes," she murmured at length, "that's what my family tell me."
fr: -- Oui, murmura-t-elle enfin, c'est ce que ma famille me dit.

eng: He winced a little.
fr: -- Il tressaillit legerement.

eng: "It's not unnatural--" "OUR family," she corrected herself; and Archer coloured.
fr: -- << Notre >> famille, corrigea-t-elle, et Archer rougit.

eng: "For you'll be my cousin soon," she continued gently.
fr: -- Car vous serez bientot mon cousin.

eng: "I hope so."
fr: -- Je l'espere.

eng: "And you take their view?"
fr: -- Et vous partagez leur point de vue ?

eng: "But aren't you as free as air as it is?" he returned. "Who can touch you?"
fr: -- N'etes-vous pas libre ?... Que peut-on contre vous ?

eng: He stood up at this, wandered across the room, stared with void eyes at one of the pictures against the old red damask, and came back irresolutely to her side.
fr: Archer se leva, marcha dans la chambre, fixa un regard vague sur les tableaux accroches sur le vieux damas rouge, et revint pres d'elle d'un pas indecis.

eng: How could he say: "Yes, if what your husband hints is true, or if you've no way of disproving it?"
fr: Comment pouvait-il dire : << Oui... Si ce que votre mari avance est vrai ou si vous n'avez pas un moyen de le refuter. >>

eng: "Sincerely--" she interjected, as he was about to speak.
fr: -- Vous le partagez ? insista-t-elle, comme il hesitait encore.

eng: He looked down into the fire.
fr: Il regarda le feu :

eng: "Sincerely, then--what should you gain that would compensate for the possibility--the certainty--of a lot of beastly talk?"
fr: -- Franchement, que gagneriez-vous qui put compenser la possibilite, la certitude d'etre mal vue de tout le monde ?

eng: "But my freedom--is that nothing?"
fr: -- Mais... ma liberte : n'est-ce rien ?

eng: It flashed across him at that instant that the charge in the letter was true, and that she hoped to marry the partner of her guilt.
fr: Au meme instant, une pensee traversa l'esprit d'Archer comme un jet de lumiere. L'accusation de la lettre etait-elle fondee, Ellen esperait-elle epouser le complice de sa faute ?

eng: How was he to tell her that, if she really cherished such a plan, the laws of the State were inexorably opposed to it?
fr: Comment lui dire, si elle caressait ce projet, que les lois de l'Etat s'y opposaient formellement ?

eng: The mere suspicion that the thought was in her mind made him feel harshly and impatiently toward her.
fr: Le simple soupcon qu'elle put avoir cette pensee lui durcissait le coeur.

eng: Mr. Letterblair tells me the financial question has been settled--" "Oh, yes," she said indifferently.
fr: Mr Letterblair m'a dit que la question financiere etait reglee. ~~~ -- Oui, dit-elle avec indifference.

eng: "Well, then: is it worth while to risk what may be infinitely disagreeable and painful?
fr: -- Alors, est-ce que cela vaut la peine de risquer des choses infiniment desagreables et douloureuses ?...

eng: Think of the newspapers--their vileness!
fr: Pensez aux journaux, a leurs vilenies...

eng: It's all stupid and narrow and unjust--but one can't make over society."
fr: C'est stupide, c'est injuste ; mais comment changer la societe ?

eng: "No," she acquiesced; and her tone was so faint and desolate that he felt a sudden remorse for his own hard thoughts.
fr: -- En effet, acquiesca-t-elle, mais d'une voix si faible et si desolee qu'il sentit soudain le remords de ses mauvaises pensees.

eng: "The individual, in such cases, is nearly always sacrificed to what is supposed to be the collective interest: people cling to any convention that keeps the family together--protects the children, if there are any," he rambled on, pouring out all the stock phrases that rose to his lips in his intense desire to cover over the ugly reality which her silence seemed to have laid bare.
fr: -- L'individu, dans ces cas-la, est presque toujours sacrifie a l'interet collectif ; on s'accroche a toute convention qui maintient l'integrite de la famille, protege les enfants, s'il y en a, divaguait-il, deversant le stock de phrases qui lui venait aux levres dans son intense desir de couvrir l'affreuse realite que le silence de la jeune femme semblait avoir mise a nu.

eng: Since she would not or could not say the one word that would have cleared the air, his wish was not to let her feel that he was trying to probe into her secret.
fr: Puisqu'elle ne voulait pas, ou ne pouvait pas, dire le seul mot qui aurait eclairci l'horizon, le desir d'Archer etait de ne pas lui laisser deviner qu'il avait penetre son secret.

eng: Better keep on the surface, in the prudent old New York way, than risk uncovering a wound he could not heal.
fr: Mieux valait se tenir a la surface, a la maniere prudente du vieux New-York, que de risquer de decouvrir une blessure qu'il ne pouvait guerir.

eng: "It's my business, you know," he went on, "to help you to see these things as the people who are fondest of you see them.
fr: -- C'est mon devoir, continua-t-il, de vous aider a voir la situation comme les personnes qui vous aiment le plus : les Mingott, les Welland, les van der Luyden, tous vos amis et vos parents...

eng: The Mingotts, the Wellands, the van der Luydens, all your friends and relations: if I didn't show you honestly how they judge such questions, it wouldn't be fair of me, would it?"
fr: Si je ne vous disais pas comment ils la jugent, ce ne serait pas loyal de ma part.

eng: He spoke insistently, almost pleading with her in his eagerness to cover up that yawning silence.
fr: -- Il parlait avec insistance, dans son ardeur a remplir ce silence beant.

eng: 'The fire had crumbled down to greyness, and one of the lamps made a gurgling appeal for attention.'
fr: 'Le feu s'etait reduit en cendres, et une des lampes se mit a baisser.'

eng: 'She said slowly: "No; it wouldn't be fair."'
fr: 'Elle repondit lentement : -- Non, ce ne serait pas loyal.'

eng: 'Madame Olenska rose, wound it up and returned to the fire, but without resuming her seat.'
fr: 'Mme Olenska se leva, la remonta, et revint pres de la cheminee, mais sans se rasseoir.'

eng: Her remaining on her feet seemed to signify that there was nothing more for either of them to say, and Archer stood up also.
fr: En restant debout, elle semblait signifier qu'ils n'avaient plus rien a se dire ; Archer se leva aussi.

eng: "Very well; I will do what you wish," she said abruptly.
fr: -- Je ferai ce que vous desirez, dit-elle brusquement.

eng: The blood rushed to his forehead; and, taken aback by the suddenness of her surrender, he caught her two hands awkwardly in his.
fr: Le sang monta au front d'Archer. ~~~ Deconcerte par la soudainete de son triomphe, il s'empara maladroitement des deux mains de la jeune femme : -- Je...

eng: He bent and laid his lips on her hands, which were cold and lifeless.
fr: Il posa ses levres sur les mains glacees de la jeune femme.

eng: She drew them away,
fr: Mais elle les retira.

eng: and he turned to the door, found his coat and hat under the faint gas-light of the hall, and plunged out into the winter night bursting with the belated eloquence of the inarticulate.
fr: Archer endossa son pardessus et se plongea dans la nuit d'hiver, la tete bouillonnante de toute l'eloquence qu'il n'avait pas depensee.

eng: XIII.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You do help me.
fr: Mais c'est bien ce que vous faites...

eng: Good night, my cousin."
fr: Bonsoir, mon cousin.

eng: "I--I do want to help you," he said.
fr: Je voudrais tant vous aider !...

eng: It was a crowded night at Wallack's theatre.
fr: XIII La salle etait bondee au theatre Wallack.

eng: The play was "The Shaughraun," with Dion Boucicault in the title role and Harry Montague and Ada Dyas as the lovers.
fr: On jouait The Shaughraun, avec Dion Boucicault dans le premier role, Harry Montague et Ada Dyas dans les roles des amoureux.

eng: The popularity of the admirable English company was at its height, and the Shaughraun always packed the house.
fr: La reputation de l'admirable troupe anglaise etait a son apogee, et The Shaughraun faisait toujours salle comble.

eng: There was one episode, in particular, that held the house from floor to ceiling.
fr: Un episode, surtout, ravissait la salle :

eng: It was that in which Harry Montague, after a sad, almost monosyllabic scene of parting with Miss Dyas, bade her good-bye, and turned to go.
fr: c'etait celui ou Harry Montague, apres une scene douloureuse et presque muette, disait adieu a Ada Dyas.

eng: In the galleries the enthusiasm was unreserved; in the stalls and boxes, people smiled a little at the hackneyed sentiments and clap-trap situations, and enjoyed the play as much as the galleries did.
fr: Au paradis, l'enthousiasme etait sans borne ; dans les fauteuils et dans les loges, on souriait un peu des sentiments rebattus et des situations sensationnelles, mais on ne s'en amusait pas moins.

eng: The actress, who was standing near the mantelpiece and looking down into the fire, wore a gray cashmere dress without fashionable loopings or trimmings, moulded to her tall figure and flowing in long lines about her feet.
fr: L'actrice se tenait pres de la cheminee, regardant le feu. ~~~ Elle etait vetue d'une robe de cachemire gris, qui moulait sa taille et tombait en longs plis jusqu'a ses pieds.

eng: Around her neck was a narrow black velvet ribbon with the ends falling down her back.
fr: Autour du cou, elle portait un ruban de velours noir, dont les bouts pendaient en arriere.

eng: When her wooer turned from her she rested her arms against the mantel-shelf and bowed her face in her hands.
fr: Lorsque le jeune homme la quittait, elle restait, les bras appuyes sur la cheminee, la tete dans les mains.

eng: On the threshold he paused to look at her; then he stole back, lifted one of the ends of velvet ribbon, kissed it, and left the room without her hearing him or changing her attitude.
fr: Arrive sur le pas de la porte, Harry Montague s'arretait pour la regarder encore ; puis il revenait, prenait un des bouts du ruban de velours, le portait a ses levres et quittait la piece sans que la jeune femme eut fait un mouvement.

eng: And on this silent parting the curtain fell.
fr: Le rideau tombait sur cet adieu muet.

eng: It was always for the sake of that particular scene that Newland Archer went to see "The Shaughraun."
fr: C'etait pour cette scene que Newland Archer aimait revoir The Shaughraun.

eng: He thought the adieux of Montague and Ada Dyas as fine as anything he had ever seen Croisette and Bressant do in Paris, or Madge Robertson and Kendal in London; in its reticence, its dumb sorrow, it moved him more than the most famous histrionic outpourings.
fr: Il trouvait admirables les adieux de Montague et d'Ada Dyas ; cela lui rappelait ses meilleurs souvenirs de Bressant et de Croisette a Paris, ou de Madge Robertson et Kendall a Londres. ~~~ Dans leur douleur inexprimee, ces adieux le remuaient autrement que les accents les plus pathetiques des comediens en renom.

eng: On the evening in question the little scene acquired an added poignancy by reminding him--he could not have said why--of his leave-taking from Madame Olenska after their confidential talk a week or ten days earlier.
fr: Ce soir-la, cette petite scene lui parut specialement poignante ; elle evoquait le conge qu'il avait pris de Mme Olenska apres leur entretien confidentiel, quelque dix jours auparavant.

eng: It would have been as difficult to discover any resemblance between the two situations as between the appearance of the persons concerned.
fr: Et pourtant, il y avait aussi peu de ressemblance entre les situations qu'entre les personnes.

eng: Newland Archer could not pretend to anything approaching the young English actor's romantic good looks, and Miss Dyas was a tall red-haired woman of monumental build whose pale and pleasantly ugly face was utterly unlike Ellen Olenska's vivid countenance.
fr: Newland ne pretendait guere a la beaute romantique du jeune acteur anglais, et Miss Dyas etait une grande femme aux cheveux roux, dont la haute stature et la figure plutot laide ne rappelaient en rien la grace plaintive d'Ellen Olenska.

eng: Nor were Archer and Madame Olenska two lovers parting in heart-broken silence; they were client and lawyer separating after a talk which had given the lawyer the worst possible impression of the client's case.
fr: Archer et Mme Olenska n'etaient pas davantage deux amoureux desoles qui se separent en silence, mais un avocat et sa cliente se disant au revoir apres une conversation d'ou celui-ci remportait sur le cas de celle-la l'impression la plus douteuse.

eng: The pity was that her gratitude put her, in the law's eyes and the world's, on a par with her abominable husband.
fr: Avait-elle ete reconnaissante a son sauveur ? Cette gratitude la mettait, aux yeux de la loi et du monde, de pair avec son abominable mari.

eng: It seemed to be in Madame Olenska's mysterious faculty of suggesting tragic and moving possibilities outside the daily run of experience.
fr: Etait-il au pouvoir de Mme Olenska de suggerer des possibilites tragiques et troublantes ?

eng: The conditions from which she had fled were intolerable, past speaking of, past believing: she was young, she was frightened, she was desperate--what more natural than that she should be grateful to her rescuer?
fr: La vie a laquelle elle avait voulu echapper etait intolerable. Elle etait jeune, elle avait peur, elle etait desesperee.

eng: The mysterious person who figured in his wife's past as "the secretary" had probably not been unrewarded for his share in her escape.
fr: Le personnage mysterieux qui figurait dans le passe de Mme Olenska, le << secretaire du comte >> disait le document, avait sans doute recu sa recompense apres l'avoir aidee dans sa fuite.

eng: Archer had left her with the conviction that Count Olenski's accusation was not unfounded.
fr: Archer l'avait quittee avec la conviction que l'accusation du comte Olenski n'etait pas sans fondement.

eng: She had hardly ever said a word to him to produce this impression, but it was a part of her, either a projection of her mysterious and outlandish background or of something inherently dramatic, passionate and unusual in herself.
fr: La jeune femme, avec son passe mysterieux et exotique, semblait nee pour le drame et la passion.

eng: It was precisely the odd absence of surprise in her that gave him the sense of her having been plucked out of a very maelstrom: the things she took for granted gave the measure of those she had rebelled against.
fr: Les choses qu'elle acceptait comme naturelles donnaient la mesure de celles contre lesquelles elle se revoltait.

eng: The exciting fact was her having lived in an atmosphere so thick with drama that her own tendency to provoke it had apparently passed unperceived.
fr: C'etait precisement son calme resigne qui permettait de deviner l'orage devant lequel elle avait fui.

eng: The quiet, almost passive young woman struck him as exactly the kind of person to whom things were bound to happen, no matter how much she shrank from them and went out of her way to avoid them.
fr: La tranquille, presque passive jeune femme, etait comme vouee a une vie hasardeuse, quelque peine qu'elle prit pour l'eviter ou s'en eloigner.

eng: This tendency he had felt from the first in Madame Olenska.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer had always been inclined to think that chance and circumstance played a small part in shaping people's lots compared with their innate tendency to have things happen to them.
fr: Archer avait toujours pense que le hasard et les circonstances ne jouent qu'une faible part dans la destinee de chacun de nous ; les etres sont menes par leur nature : chez Mme Olenska la nature allait au dramatique, Archer le sentait.

eng: Wherein, then, lay the resemblance that made the young man's heart beat with a kind of retrospective excitement?
fr: Ou donc etait l'analogie qui faisait battre le coeur du jeune homme ?

eng: Archer had made her understand this, as he was bound to do; he had also made her understand that simplehearted kindly New York, on whose larger charity she had apparently counted, was precisely the place where she could least hope for indulgence.
fr: Archer le lui avait explique, comme son devoir le voulait, ajoutant qu'a New-York, si les coeurs etaient simples et bons, elle ne devait cependant pas sur ce chapitre escompter leur indulgence.

eng: To have to make this fact plain to her--and to witness her resigned acceptance of it--had been intolerably painful to him.
fr: Il avait trouve infiniment penible de constater la facilite avec laquelle elle avait accepte sa decision.

eng: He felt himself drawn to her by obscure feelings of jealousy and pity, as if her dumbly-confessed error had put her at his mercy, humbling yet endearing her.
fr: La faiblesse qu'elle avait tacitement avouee la mettait a la merci de Newland ; il se sentait attire vers elle par d'obscurs sentiments de jalousie et de pitie.

eng: He was glad it was to him she had revealed her secret, rather than to the cold scrutiny of Mr. Letterblair, or the embarrassed gaze of her family.
fr: Il etait heureux que ce fut a lui qu'elle eut revele son secret, plutot que de le confier a la froide enquete de Mr Letterblair, ou a la curiosite embarrassee des siens.

eng: He immediately took it upon himself to assure them both that she had given up her idea of seeking a divorce, basing her decision on the fact that she had understood the uselessness of the proceeding; and with infinite relief they had all turned their eyes from the "unpleasantness" she had spared them.
fr: Il se chargea du soin de faire savoir a la famille, qu'ayant reconnu l'inutilite de ses demarches, elle avait renonce au divorce ; et tous s'empresserent de ne plus penser aux choses << penibles >> dont ils avaient ete menaces.

eng: "I was sure Newland would manage it," Mrs. Welland had said proudly of her future son-in-law; and old Mrs. Mingott, who had summoned him for a confidential interview, had congratulated him on his cleverness, and added impatiently: "Silly goose!
fr: -- J'etais sure que Newland arrangerait cela, disait Mrs Welland en parlant de son futur gendre : et la vieille Mrs Mingott, qui avait convoque Archer pour un entretien confidentiel, lui avait fait ses compliments, en ajoutant : -- La petite sotte !

eng: I told her myself what nonsense it was. ~~~ Wanting to pass herself off as Ellen Mingott and an old maid, when she has the luck to be a married woman and a Countess!"
fr: Je lui avais bien dit que c'etait une betise : vouloir se faire passer pour Ellen Mingott, devenir une sorte de vieille fille, quand elle a la chance d'etre mariee et comtesse !

eng: These incidents had made the memory of his last talk with Madame Olenska so vivid to the young man that as the curtain fell on the parting of the two actors his eyes filled with tears, and he stood up to leave the theatre.
fr: La scene d'amour entre les acteurs avait rappele, avec une telle acuite, au jeune homme, sa derniere conversation avec Mme Olenska que, lorsque le rideau tomba sur la separation des deux amants, il sentit les larmes lui monter a la gorge et il se leva pour quitter le theatre.

eng: He had not spoken with her alone since their evening together, and had tried to avoid being with her in company; but now their eyes met, and as Mrs. Beaufort recognised him at the same time, and made her languid little gesture of invitation, it was impossible not to go into the box.
fr: Depuis leur derniere entrevue, il avait evite de la rencontrer ; mais comme Mrs Beaufort, le reconnaissant, lui faisait un petit signe d'invitation, il fut oblige de se rendre dans la loge.

eng: In doing so, he turned to the side of the house behind him, and saw the lady of whom he was thinking seated in a box with the Beauforts, Lawrence Lefferts and one or two other men.
fr: En se retournant, il apercut la jeune femme dont il avait l'esprit rempli, assise dans une loge avec les Beaufort et d'autres invites.

eng: Beaufort and Lefferts made way for him, and after a few words with Mrs. Beaufort, who always preferred to look beautiful and not have to talk, Archer seated himself behind Madame Olenska.
fr: Les hommes lui firent place, et apres quelques mots echanges avec Mrs Beaufort, qui tenait a montrer sa beaute, mais non a causer, Archer alla s'asseoir derriere Mme Olenska.

eng: Mr. Welland was a mild and silent man, with no opinions but with many habits.
fr: Mr Welland etait convaincu qu'il avait les bronches delicates. C'etait un homme de nature douce et silencieuse : il n'avait pas d'opinions personnelles, mais, en revanche, il avait des habitudes.

eng: Now her sudden recognition of the gift, and her associating it with the tender leave-taking on the stage, filled him with an agitated pleasure.
fr: Maintenant, non seulement elle y faisait une allusion, mais elle l'associait a la tendre separation des amants de la scene : Newland en fut emu et trouble.

eng: Under cover of this circumstantial narrative, to which Mrs. Beaufort listened with her perfect smile, and her head at just the right angle to be seen in profile from the stalls, Madame Olenska turned and spoke in a low voice.
fr: Mrs Beaufort ecoutait ce minutieux recit avec son impeccable sourire, la tete tournee de facon a etre vue de profil par les fauteuils d'orchestre.

eng: He had called only twice on Madame Olenska, and each time he had sent her a box of yellow roses, and each time without a card.
fr: Il n'etait alle que deux fois chez Mme Olenska et chaque fois il lui avait envoye un bouquet de roses jaunes, mais sans y joindre de carte.

eng: She had never before made any allusion to the flowers, and he supposed she had never thought of him as the sender.
fr: Elle n'avait jusqu'alors fait aucune allusion aux fleurs, et ne semblait pas soupconner leur provenance.

eng: There was no one else in the box but Mr. Sillerton Jackson, who was telling Mrs. Beaufort in a confidential undertone about Mrs. Lemuel Struthers's last Sunday reception (where some people reported that there had been dancing).
fr: Mr Jackson, installe pres de Mrs Beaufort, lui faisait, a demi-voix, le recit de la soiree du dimanche precedent chez Mrs Lemuel Struthers (quelques personnes disaient qu'on y avait danse).

eng: "I was thinking of that too--I was going to leave the theatre in order to take the picture away with me," he said.
fr: -- Je m'en allais pour emporter le souvenir de cette scene, dit-il.

eng: To his surprise her colour rose, reluctantly and duskily.
fr: A sa grande surprise, il vit palir la jeune femme.

eng: She looked down at the mother-of-pearl opera-glass in her smoothly gloved hands, and said, after a pause: "What do you do while May is away?"
fr: Elle porta les yeux sur la jumelle de nacre que tenaient ses mains finement gantees, et dit apres un silence : -- Que faites-vous pendant l'absence de May ?

eng: "I stick to my work," he answered, faintly annoyed by the question.
fr: -- Je m'absorbe dans mon travail, repondit-il, un peu froisse de la question.

eng: In obedience to a long-established habit, the Wellands had left the previous week for St. Augustine, where, out of regard for the supposed susceptibility of Mr. Welland's bronchial tubes, they always spent the latter part of the winter.
fr: Selon une habitude prise depuis longtemps, les Welland etaient partis la semaine precedente pour Saint-Augustin, dans la Floride, ou ils passaient la fin d'hiver.

eng: With these habits none might interfere; and one of them demanded that his wife and daughter should always go with him on his annual journey to the south.
fr: Nul ne devait y contrevenir : sa femme et sa fille etaient donc obligees de l'accompagner dans le midi.

eng: To preserve an unbroken domesticity was essential to his peace of mind; he would not have known where his hair-brushes were, or how to provide stamps for his letters, if Mrs. Welland had not been there to tell him.
fr: Il fallait que partout ou il allait, il retrouvat son milieu habituel : sans Mrs Welland, il n'aurait su ni trouver ses brosses ni se procurer des timbres.

eng: All the members of this family adored one another.
fr: Tous les membres de cette famille s'adoraient entre eux.

eng: Archer reddened, and his heart gave a leap of surprise.
fr: Archer rougit et son coeur battit violemment.

eng: "Do you think," she asked, glancing toward the stage, "he will send her a bunch of yellow roses tomorrow morning?"
fr: Mme Olenska se retourna vers Archer et lui dit a voix basse : -- Croyez-vous qu'il lui enverra un bouquet de roses jaunes demain matin ?

eng: As all the members of the family adored each other, and as Mr. Welland was the central object of their idolatry, it never occurred to his wife and May to let him go to St. Augustine alone; and his sons, who were both in the law, and could not leave New York during the winter, always joined him for Easter and travelled back with him.
fr: Jamais Mrs Welland ni sa fille n'auraient admis l'idee que Mr Welland put aller seul a Saint-Augustin, et les fils, ne pouvant a cause de leurs occupations s'absenter pendant l'hiver, allaient le rejoindre a Paques pour revenir avec lui.

eng: It was impossible for Archer to discuss the necessity of May's accompanying her father.
fr: Archer ne pouvait discuter la necessite ou May se trouvait d'accompagner son pere.

eng: The reputation of the Mingotts' family physician was largely based on the attack of pneumonia which Mr. Welland had never had; and his insistence on St. Augustine was therefore inflexible.
fr: Le medecin de famille des Mingott avait attache sa reputation a une pneumonie que Mr Welland n'avait jamais eue, et il exigeait le sejour a Saint-Augustin.

eng: Originally, it had been intended that May's engagement should not be announced till her return from Florida, and the fact that it had been made known sooner could not be expected to alter Mr. Welland's plans.
fr: Les fiancailles de May n'avaient du etre annoncees qu'apres le retour de la Floride et le fait qu'on avait ete amene a les annoncer plus tot ne changeait en rien les plans de Mr Welland.

eng: Archer would have liked to join the travellers and have a few weeks of sunshine and boating with his betrothed; but he too was bound by custom and conventions.
fr: Archer aurait aime se joindre aux voyageurs, vivre pour quelques semaines au soleil, canoter et se promener avec sa fiancee ; mais lui aussi etait tenu par les usages et les conventions.

eng: Little arduous as his professional duties were, he would have been convicted of frivolity by the whole Mingott clan if he had suggested asking for a holiday in mid-winter; and he accepted May's departure with the resignation which he perceived would have to be one of the principal constituents of married life.
fr: Ses devoirs professionnels n'etaient guere accablants, mais tout le clan Mingott se fut etonne, s'il avait demande un conge au milieu de l'hiver ; et il avait accepte le depart de May avec la resignation qui allait certainement devenir un des principaux elements de sa vie d'homme marie.

eng: He was conscious that Madame Olenska was looking at him under lowered lids.
fr: Il sentait que, sous ses paupieres baissees, Mme Olenska le regardait.

eng: "I have done what you wished--what you advised," she said abruptly.
fr: -- J'ai fait ce que vous desirez, -- ce que vous m'avez conseille, dit-elle sans preambule. ~~~ -- Ah !...

eng: "Ah--I'm glad," he returned, embarrassed by her broaching the subject at such a moment.
fr: J'en suis heureux, repondit-il, embarrasse qu'elle abordat ce sujet a un pareil moment.

eng: "I understand--that you were right," she went on a little breathlessly; "but sometimes life is difficult ... perplexing..." "I know."
fr: -- Je me suis rendu compte que vous aviez raison, continua-t-elle, un peu haletante. ~~~ Mais la vie est parfois difficile... troublante... -- Je sais !

eng: as the door of the box opened and Beaufort's resonant voice broke in on them.
fr: ~~~ La porte de la loge s'ouvrit et laissa passer les eclats de voix de Beaufort.

eng: "And I wanted to tell you that I DO feel you were right; and that I'm grateful to you," she ended, lifting her opera-glass quickly to her eyes.
fr: '-- Je voulais vous dire que j'ai reconnu que vous aviez raison, et que je vous en ai de la gratitude, acheva-t-elle, en portant vivement sa lorgnette a ses yeux.

eng: Archer stood up, and left the box and the theatre.
fr: Archer se leva, et sortit du theatre.

eng: Only the day before he had received a letter from May Welland in which, with characteristic candour, she had asked him to "be kind to Ellen" in their absence.
fr: La veille, il avait recu une lettre de May Welland dans laquelle, avec une candeur caracteristique, elle lui demandait d'etre << bon pour Ellen >> en son absence...

eng: "She likes you and admires you so much--and you know, though she doesn't show it, she's still very lonely and unhappy.
fr: << Elle vous aime et vous admire beaucoup. Elle dissimule sa tristesse, mais elle est isolee et malheureuse.

eng: I don't think Granny understands her, or uncle Lovell Mingott either; they really think she's much worldlier and fonder of society than she is.
fr: Je ne crois pas que grand'mere la comprenne, ni mon oncle Lovell Mingott. ~~~ Ils la croient beaucoup plus mondaine qu'elle ne l'est reellement.'

eng: And I can quite see that New York must seem dull to her, though the family won't admit it.
fr: Je comprends bien, quoi qu'en dise la famille, que New-York doit lui sembler triste.

eng: I think she's been used to lots of things we haven't got; wonderful music, and picture shows, and celebrities--artists and authors and all the clever people you admire.
fr: Je crois qu'elle est habituee a beaucoup de plaisirs que nous n'avons pas : a entendre de belle musique, a voir des expositions, a rencontrer les celebrites, les artistes et les auteurs, tous les gens intelligents que vous admirez.

eng: Granny can't understand her wanting anything but lots of dinners and clothes--but I can see that you're almost the only person in New York who can talk to her about what she really cares for."
fr: Grand'mere ne peut pas se mettre dans la tete qu'elle a besoin d'autre chose que de diner en ville et d'etre bien habillee. ~~~ Pour moi, je ne vois a New-York que vous qui puissiez l'entretenir des choses qui l'interessent vraiment.

eng: His wise May--how he had loved her for that letter!
fr: >> Sa May si sage ! ~~~ Comme il l'aimait pour cette lettre !

eng: She had Beaufort at her feet, Mr. van der Luyden hovering above her like a protecting deity, and any number of candidates (Lawrence Lefferts among them) waiting their opportunity in the middle distance.
