fr: Elle avait Beaufort a ses pieds, Mr van der Luyden planait au-dessus d'elle comme une divinite protectrice, et de nombreux candidats attendaient leur tour de se declarer ses defenseurs.

eng: He had an idea that she knew how to take care of herself a good deal better than the ingenuous May imagined.
fr: Elle savait se garder toute seule beaucoup mieux que ne le croyait la candide May.

eng: But he had not meant to act on it; he was too busy, to begin with, and he did not care, as an engaged man, to play too conspicuously the part of Madame Olenska's champion.
fr: Mais il n'avait pas eu l'intention de suivre ses avis. D'abord il etait trop occupe, ensuite il ne tenait pas a jouer trop ostensiblement le role de champion de Mme Olenska.

eng: Yet he never saw her, or exchanged a word with her, without feeling that, after all, May's ingenuousness almost amounted to a gift of divination. ~~~ Ellen Olenska was lonely and she was unhappy. ~~~ XIV.
fr: Neanmoins, il ne voyait jamais la jeune femme, n'echangeait jamais un mot avec elle, sans se rendre compte que, dans sa naivete, May avait devine bien des choses : Ellen Olenska sentait sa solitude, elle souffrait.

eng: As he came out into the lobby Archer ran across his friend Ned Winsett, the only one among what Janey called his "clever people" with whom he cared to probe into things a little deeper than the average level of club and chop-house banter.
fr: XIV Dans le vestibule du theatre, Archer tomba sur son ami, Ned Winsett ; le seul, parmi ceux que Janey appelait ses << amis intellectuels, >> avec lequel il aimat, parfois, vraiment s'entretenir.

eng: He had caught sight, across the house, of Winsett's shabby round-shouldered back, and had once noticed his eyes turned toward the Beaufort box.
fr: Il avait apercu dans la salle le dos voute et rape de l'ecrivain, et avait surpris un moment son regard plongeant dans la loge des Beaufort.

eng: The two men shook hands, and Winsett proposed a bock at a little German restaurant around the corner.
fr: Les deux hommes echangerent une poignee de main, et Winsett proposa d'aller prendre un bock dans une petite brasserie allemande au coin de la rue.

eng: Archer, who was not in the mood for the kind of talk they were likely to get there, declined on the plea that he had work to do at home; and Winsett said: "Oh, well so have I for that matter, and I'll be the Industrious Apprentice too."
fr: Archer, qui n'etait pas en veine d'epanchement, declina l'invitation : il avait a travailler. ~~~ -- Vous avez raison, dit Winsett, allons travailler.

eng: They strolled along together,
fr: Ils deambulerent ensemble.

eng: and presently Winsett said: "Look here, what I'm really after is the name of the dark lady in that swell box of yours--with the Beauforts, wasn't she? The one your friend Lefferts seems so smitten by."
fr: En realite, reprit Winsett, ce que je voulais savoir c'est le nom de cette dame brune dans votre loge. Elle etait avec les Beaufort, n'est-ce pas ?

eng: Archer, he could not have said why, was slightly annoyed.
fr: Archer eut un mouvement d'inquietude.

eng: What the devil did Ned Winsett want with Ellen Olenska's name?
fr: Pourquoi diable Ned Winsett voulait-il savoir le nom d'Ellen Olenska ?

eng: And above all, why did he couple it with Lefferts's?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was unlike Winsett to manifest such curiosity;
fr: Cela ne lui ressemblait pas de faire ainsi le curieux ;

eng: but after all, Archer remembered, he was a journalist.
fr: mais Archer se souvint que Winsett etait journaliste.

eng: "It's not for an interview, I hope?"
fr: -- Vous n'allez pas l'interviewer, j'espere ?

eng: he laughed.
fr: dit-il en riant.

eng: "Well--not for the press; just for myself," Winsett rejoined.
fr: -- Pas pour mon journal, mais peut-etre pour moi-meme.

eng: "The fact is she's a neighbour of mine--queer quarter for such a beauty to settle in--and she's been awfully kind to my little boy, who fell down her area chasing his kitten, and gave himself a nasty cut."
fr: 'Figurez-vous qu'elle est ma voisine : drole de quartier pour une femme elegante ! ~~~ Et elle a ete si bonne pour mon petit garcon ! L'enfant avait degringole du perron dans la cour, et s'etait fait une mauvaise ecorchure.'

eng: "She rushed in bareheaded, carrying him in her arms, with his knee all beautifully bandaged, and was so sympathetic and beautiful that my wife was too dazzled to ask her name."
fr: 'Elle s'est precipitee pour le relever, et, tete nue, elle nous l'a rapporte dans ses bras apres lui avoir fait un beau pansement. Elle etait si belle et si touchante que ma femme en a oublie de lui demander son nom.'

eng: "A pleasant glow dilated Archer's heart."
fr: 'Le coeur d'Archer s'emut.'

eng: "There was nothing extraordinary in the tale: any woman would have done as much for a neighbour's child."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "But it was just like Ellen, he felt, to have rushed in bareheaded, carrying the boy in her arms, and to have dazzled poor Mrs. Winsett into forgetting to ask who she was."
fr: 'C'etait bien d'Ellen de s'etre ainsi precipitee, tete nue, portant l'enfant dans ses bras.'

eng: ""That is the Countess Olenska--a granddaughter of old Mrs. Mingott's.""
fr: '-- Votre voisine s'appelle la comtesse Olenska : c'est une petite-fille de la vieille Mrs Mingott.'

eng: ""Whew--a Countess!" whistled Ned Winsett."
fr: '-- Fichtre ! Une comtesse ! fit Winsett.'

eng: ""Well, I didn't know Countesses were so neighbourly. Mingotts ain't."
fr: 'Je ne les aurais pas crues aussi aimables. Les Mingott ne le sont pas.'

eng: "They would be, if you'd let them."
fr: -- Ils le seraient, si vous les y encouragiez.

eng: "Because she doesn't care a hang about where she lives--or about any of our little social sign-posts," said Archer, with a secret pride in his own picture of her.
fr: Parce qu'elle se moque bien du quartier : elle passe devant nos petites categories sociales sans meme s'en apercevoir.

eng: "Ah, well--" It was their old interminable argument as to the obstinate unwillingness of the "clever people" to frequent the fashionable, and both men knew that there was no use in prolonging it.
fr: Allons ! C'etait la leur vieille controverse : la mauvaise volonte obstinee des << intellectuels >> a frequenter le monde elegant. Archer renonca a poursuivre cette eternelle discussion.

eng: "I wonder," Winsett broke off, "how a Countess happens to live in our slum?"
fr: Je me demande, dit Winsett, comment une comtesse a pu s'installer dans notre affreux quartier.

eng: "H'm--been in bigger places, I suppose," the other commented. "Well, here's my corner." He slouched off across Broadway, and Archer stood looking after him and musing on his last words.
fr: -- Hum !... Elle a sans doute frequente une societe moins fermee, commenta Winsett... Je vous quitte... A bientot. Archer le suivit des yeux, ruminant ses dernieres paroles,

eng: Ned Winsett had those flashes of penetration; they were the most interesting thing about him, and always made Archer wonder why they had allowed him to accept failure so stolidly at an age when most men are still struggling.
fr: Ce Winsett, il avait ainsi ses eclairs... il voyait... il etait interessant. Archer se demandait comment, a un age qui pour la plupart des hommes est celui de la lutte, il se resignait a une vie si mediocre.

eng: Archer, who dressed in the evening because he thought it cleaner and more comfortable to do so, and who had never stopped to consider that cleanliness and comfort are two of the costliest items in a modest budget, regarded Winsett's attitude as part of the boring "Bohemian" pose that always made fashionable people, who changed their clothes without talking about it, and were not forever harping on the number of servants one kept, seem so much simpler and less self-conscious than the others.
fr: Archer, qui trouvait plus propre et plus confortable de se mettre en habit tous les soirs, ne s'etait jamais rendu compte que la proprete et le confortable sont les deux choses les plus couteuses d'un mediocre budget. L'attitude de Winsett lui semblait faire partie de l'insupportable pose des << bohemes. >>

eng: The two men always met at the Century, or at some haunt of journalists and theatrical people, such as the restaurant where Winsett had proposed to go for a bock.
fr: Les deux hommes se rencontraient, soit au << Century Club, >> soit au restaurant avec d'autres journalistes ou a la brasserie allemande.

eng: He had given Archer to understand that his wife was an invalid; which might be true of the poor lady, or might merely mean that she was lacking in social gifts or in evening clothes, or in both.
fr: Il avait laisse entendre a Archer que sa femme etait confinee a la maison : cela pouvait aussi bien vouloir dire qu'elle etait souffrante, ou qu'elle n'avait pas l'habitude du monde, ou, peut-etre, qu'elle n'avait pas de robe pour y aller.

eng: Winsett himself had a savage abhorrence of social observances:
fr: Winsett lui-meme temoignait d'une horreur farouche pour les usages << du monde. >>

eng: Nevertheless, he was always stimulated by Winsett, and whenever he caught sight of the journalist's lean bearded face and melancholy eyes he would rout him out of his corner and carry him off for a long talk.
fr: Mais Winsett lui offrait un stimulant intellectuel, et, des qu'il apercevait sa figure maigre et barbue, aux yeux melancoliques, il engageait avec lui la conversation.

eng: Winsett was not a journalist by choice. He was a pure man of letters, untimely born in a world that had no need of letters; but after publishing one volume of brief and exquisite literary appreciations, of which one hundred and twenty copies were sold, thirty given away, and the balance eventually destroyed by the publishers (as per contract) to make room for more marketable material, he had abandoned his real calling, and taken a sub-editorial job on a women's weekly, where fashion-plates and paper patterns alternated with New England love-stories and advertisements of temperance drinks.
fr: Ce n'etait pas par gout que Winsett etait journaliste : ne malencontreusement dans un monde ferme aux lettres, il avait une vraie vocation d'ecrivain. Apres avoir publie un petit livre exquis de critique litteraire, dont cent vingt exemplaires seulement avaient ete vendus et trente donnes, il avait abandonne sa veritable voie et pris une situation de petit redacteur dans un magazine feminin ou les reclames se melaient aux patrons de robes, aux romans d'amour et aux affiches de boissons antialcooliques.

eng: On the subject of "Hearth-fires" (as the paper was called) he was inexhaustibly entertaining; but beneath his fun lurked the sterile bitterness of the still young man who has tried and given up.
fr: Sur le sujet des << Hearth-Fires >> (c'etait le titre du magazine) l'ironie de Winsett etait inepuisable ; mais derriere cette gaite se cachait l'amertume d'un homme, jeune encore, qui avait lutte et se declarait vaincu.

eng: His conversation always made Archer take the measure of his own life, and feel how little it contained; but Winsett's, after all, contained still less, and though their common fund of intellectual interests and curiosities made their talks exhilarating, their exchange of views usually remained within the limits of a pensive dilettantism. "The fact is, life isn't much a fit for either of us," Winsett had once said.
fr: En causant avec Winsett, Archer constatait le vide, l'inutilite de sa propre vie ; mais celle de Winsett etait plus vide et plus inutile encore.

eng: "I'm down and out; nothing to be done about it."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer had known that Winsett had a wife and child, but he had never seen them.
fr: Winsett avait une femme et un enfant, mais Archer ne les connaissait pas.

eng: I've got only one ware to produce, and there's no market for it here, and won't be in my time.
fr: Je suis fini, c'est entendu, avait dit un jour Winsett, je ne tiens qu'un article, et il n'a pas cours ici...

eng: 'Archer threw his head back and laughed.'
fr: 'Archer se mit a rire.'

eng: 'There's only one way to do it: to go into politics.'
fr: 'Il n'y a qu'un avenir : la politique !'

eng: 'But you're free and you're well-off.'
fr: 'Mais vous, vous etes libre, vous etes riche.'

eng: 'Why don't you get into touch?'
fr: 'Pourquoi renoncer ?'

eng: There one saw at a flash the unbridgeable difference between men like Winsett and the others--Archer's kind.
fr: Cette parole lui avait permis de mesurer encore une fois la distance qui separait sa classe a lui de celle de Winsett.

eng: It was useless to prolong the discussion: everybody knew the melancholy fate of the few gentlemen who had risked their clean linen in municipal or state politics in New York.
fr: Inutile de prolonger la discussion ! On ne connaissait que trop la triste fin des rares gentlemen qui avaient sali leurs manchettes dans les affaires municipales ou dans la politique d'Etat.

eng: The day was past when that sort of thing was possible: the country was in possession of the bosses and the emigrant, and decent people had to fall back on sport or culture.
fr: Ce n'etait plus possible. Le pays appartenait aux nouveaux riches et aux emigrants : les gens comme il faut devaient s'en tenir aux sports ou a la culture intellectuelle.

eng: "Culture! Yes--if we had it!"
fr: -- La culture ?... Oui... Si nous en avions une !

eng: Archer's laugh lingered on his lips in a slightly condescending smile.
fr: Archer eut un sourire de condescendance.

eng: Every one in polite circles knew that, in America, "a gentleman couldn't go into politics."
fr: En Amerique, un << gentleman >> n'entre pas dans la politique.

eng: But, since he could hardly put it in that way to Winsett, he answered evasively: "Look at the career of the honest man in American politics! They don't want us."
fr: Ne pouvant expliquer cela a Winsett, Archer repondit evasivement : -- Est-ce que vous voyez un homme propre dans la politique ? Ils n'ont pas besoin de nous.

eng: "Who's 'they'? Why don't you all get together and be 'they' yourselves?"
fr: -- Qui cela, ils ? Pourquoi n'etes-vous pas, vous, les gentlemen, tous ensemble a leur place ?

eng: But there are just a few little local patches, dying out here and there for lack of--well, hoeing and cross-fertilising: the last remnants of the old European tradition that your forebears brought with them.
fr: Mais la vie intellectuelle ici meurt d'inanition. ~~~ Elle ne se nourrit que des restes de la tradition europeenne qu'ont apportee vos arriere-grands'peres.

eng: Archer mentally shrugged his shoulders and turned the conversation back to books, where Winsett, if uncertain, was always interesting.
fr: Archer n'insista pas et ramena la conversation sur les livres : la, Winsett, eclectique, etait toujours interessant.

eng: No one was deceived by his pretense of professional activity.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It made Archer shiver to think that it might be spreading over him too.
fr: Archer frissonnait a la pensee que lui-meme pourrait en etre la.

eng: But none of these young men had much hope of really advancing in his profession, or any earnest desire to do so; and over many of them the green mould of the perfunctory was already perceptibly spreading.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Though it was supposed to be proper for them to have an occupation, the crude fact of money-making was still regarded as derogatory, and the law, being a profession, was accounted a more gentlemanly pursuit than business.
fr: Ainsi pour le monde, pour leur famille, ils etaient << occupes. >> Aucun de ces jeunes gens n'avait la pretention de gagner de l'argent, ni meme le desir d'avancer dans sa profession, et il leur suffisait de savoir que dans les nobles travaux du droit ils ne derogeaient pas.

eng: In old-fashioned legal firms like that of which Mr. Letterblair was the head, and which were mainly engaged in the management of large estates and "conservative" investments, there were always two or three young men, fairly well-off, and without professional ambition, who, for a certain number of hours of each day, sat at their desks accomplishing trivial tasks, or simply reading the newspapers.
fr: Dans les vieilles etudes, comme celle qui avait a sa tete Mr Letterblair, il y avait toujours deux ou trois jeunes gens riches, sans ambition professionnelle, qui s'asseyaient quelques heures chaque jour devant un bureau.

eng: Why should he not be, at that moment, on the sands of St. Augustine with May Welland?
fr: Pourquoi n'etait-il pas en ce moment sur les sables de Saint-Augustin avec May Welland ?

eng: In consequence of this search he arrived late at the office, perceived that his doing so made no difference whatever to any one, and was filled with sudden exasperation at the elaborate futility of his life.
fr: Il se rendit compte que son absence avait passe inapercue. ~~~ Quel inutile assujettissement !

eng: The next morning Archer scoured the town in vain for more yellow roses.
fr: Le lendemain matin, Archer parcourut en vain la ville a la recherche de roses jaunes, et arriva en retard a son etude.

eng: But you couldn't make a man like Winsett see that; and that was why the New York of literary clubs and exotic restaurants, though a first shake made it seem more of a kaleidoscope, turned out, in the end, to be a smaller box, with a more monotonous pattern, than the assembled atoms of Fifth Avenue.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A gentleman simply stayed at home and abstained.
fr: Un << gentleman >> restait chez lui tout simplement et s'abstenait.

eng: One could no more do that than one could roll up one's sleeves and go down into the muck.
fr: C'etait aussi impossible que de se meler a la politique.

eng: Emigrate! As if a gentleman could abandon his own country!
fr: Emigrer ! Comme si un << gentleman >> pouvait abandonner son pays !

eng: You'll never amount to anything, any of you, till you roll up your sleeves and get right down into the muck.
fr: Vous n'aboutirez jamais a rien, tant que vous ne vous mettrez pas en bras de chemise et que vous ne descendrez pas dans la rue.

eng: You're like the pictures on the walls of a deserted house: 'The Portrait of a Gentleman.'
fr: Vous etes comme, dans une maison abandonnee, un portrait reste accroche au mur.

eng: But you're in a pitiful little minority: you've got no centre, no competition, no audience.
fr: Vous n'etes qu'une pauvre petite minorite ; vous n'avez pas de centre, pas de concurrence, pas de clientele.

eng: That, or emigrate ... God! If I could emigrate ...
fr: Ca ou emigrer. ~~~ Ah Dieu ! Si je pouvais emigrer !

eng: He had, to be sure, other tastes and interests; he spent his vacations in European travel, cultivated the "clever people" May spoke of, and generally tried to "keep up," as he had somewhat wistfully put it to Madame Olenska.
fr: Il resistait a la stagnation, il passait ses vacances a voyager, il cultivait les << intellectuels, >> il essayait de se << tenir au courant, >> comme il l'avait dit un jour a Mme Olenska.

eng: But once he was married, what would become of this narrow margin of life in which his real experiences were lived?
fr: Mais une fois marie, que deviendrait cette etroite marge que se reservait sa personnalite ?

eng: "I ran away," the writer began abruptly (without the usual preliminaries), "the day after I saw you at the play, and these kind friends have taken me in.
fr: << Je me suis evadee, ecrivait-elle brusquement et sans preambule, le lendemain du jour ou je vous ai rencontre au theatre.

eng: To his surprise it was dated from Skuytercliff, whither the van der Luydens had promptly retreated after putting the Duke on board his steamer.
fr: A son grand etonnement, elles etaient datees de Skuytercliff, ou les van der Luyden s'etaient retires aussitot apres avoir embarque le Duc.

eng: It was only on the third morning that he received a line by post from the Countess Olenska.
fr: Le troisieme jour enfin, il recut par la poste quelques lignes de Mme Olenska.

eng: and though the next morning he saw a glorious cluster of yellow roses behind a florist's window-pane, he left it there.
fr: le lendemain matin, il vit un superbe bouquet de roses jaunes a la devanture d'un fleuriste, mais s'abstint de l'envoyer.

eng: This unexpected silence mortified him beyond reason,
fr: Ce silence l'humilia :

eng: but at the club he found nothing, nor did he receive any letter the following day.
fr: Au cercle, il ne trouva pas de reponse, et n'en recut pas le jour suivant.

eng: From the office he sent a note by messenger to Madame Olenska, asking if he might call that afternoon, and begging her to let him find a reply at his club;
fr: Du cabinet de Mr Letterblair, il envoya un mot a Mme Olenska, lui demandant si elle pouvait le recevoir dans l'apres-midi.

eng: He had seen enough of other young men who had dreamed his dream, though perhaps less ardently, and who had gradually sunk into the placid and luxurious routine of their elders.
fr: Combien d'autres avant lui avaient reve son reve, qui graduellement s'etaient enfonces dans les eaux dormantes de la vie fortunee !

eng: I wish that you were with us."
fr: Je voudrais que vous y fussiez avec nous.

eng: You were right in telling me how kind they were; I feel myself so safe here.
fr: Vous aviez raison de me dire toute la bonte de mes hotes. Je me sens en securite ici.

eng: She ended with a conventional "Yours sincerely," and without any allusion to the date of her return.
fr: Elle terminait par une formule banale, sans allusion a la date de son retour.

eng: I wanted to be quiet, and think things over.
fr: Je voulais etre tranquille, reflechir.

eng: The tone of the note surprised the young man.
fr: Le ton de la lettre surprit le jeune homme.

eng: What was Madame Olenska running away from, and why did she feel the need to be safe?
fr: De quoi Mme Olenska s'evadait-elle, et pourquoi avait-elle besoin de se sentir en securite ?

eng: His first thought was of some dark menace from abroad;
fr: Il pensa d'abord que quelque nouveau danger venu d'Europe pouvait planer sur elle ;

eng: It amused him to think of the van der Luydens' having carried her off to Skuytercliff on a second visit, and this time for an indefinite period.
fr: Il souriait a la pensee des van der Luyden l'amenant une seconde fois a Skuytercliff, et cette fois pour un temps indefini.

eng: The doors of Skuytercliff were rarely and grudgingly opened to visitors, and a chilly week-end was the most ever offered to the few thus privileged.
fr: Les portes de Skuytercliff s'ouvraient rarement, et un ceremonieux week-end etait tout ce que pouvaient esperer les privilegies.

eng: He felt a distinct disappointment on learning that she was away; and almost immediately remembered that, only the day before, he had refused an invitation to spend the following Sunday with the Reggie Chiverses at their house on the Hudson, a few miles below Skuytercliff.
fr: Archer, en apprenant le depart de la jeune femme, se rappela aussitot qu'il venait de refuser une invitation a aller passer le dimanche chez les Reggie Chivers dans leur propriete a quelques kilometres de Skuytercliff.

eng: The van der Luydens had rescued Madame Olenska from a doom almost as icy; and though there were many other reasons for being attracted to her, Archer knew that beneath them all lay the gentle and obstinate determination to go on rescuing her.
fr: Les van der Luyden avaient retire Mme Olenska de la crevasse ou la societe de New-York avait failli la precipiter, et outre la sympathie qu'elle leur inspirait, ils sentaient couver en eux le desir d'assurer son sauvetage.

eng: But Archer had seen, on his last visit to Paris, the delicious play of Labiche, "Le Voyage de M. Perrichon," and he remembered M. Perrichon's dogged and undiscouraged attachment to the young man whom he had pulled out of the glacier.
fr: Mais Archer avait vu a Paris la delicieuse piece du Labiche : le Voyage de M. Perrichon, et se rappelait l'attachement tenace et profond de M. Perrichon pour le jeune homme qu'il avait retire du glacier.

eng: Women always exaggerated; and moreover she was not wholly at her ease in English, which she often spoke as if she were translating from the French. "Je me suis evadee--" put in that way, the opening sentence immediately suggested that she might merely have wanted to escape from a boring round of engagements; which was very likely true, for he judged her to be capricious, and easily wearied of the pleasure of the moment.
fr: Du reste, elle devait etre capricieuse et se fatiguer facilement de ce qui la divertissait un moment.

eng: then he reflected that he did not know her epistolary style, and that it might run to picturesque exaggeration.
fr: puis il reflechit qu'elle avait peut-etre dans sa maniere d'ecrire quelque exageration pittoresque.

eng: He had had his fill long ago of the noisy friendly parties at Highbank, with coasting, ice-boating, sleighing, long tramps in the snow, and a general flavour of mild flirting and milder practical jokes.
fr: Il en avait assez, depuis longtemps, des parties bruyantes de Highbank, des courses de luge, des promenades en traineau, des longues marches dans la neige, des flirts innocents et des plaisanteries aussi innocentes, mais plus insipides encore.

eng: He had just received a box of new books from his London book-seller, and had preferred the prospect of a quiet Sunday at home with his spoils.
fr: Il venait de recevoir une caisse de livres nouveaux de son libraire a Londres, et aurait une tranquille journee chez lui avec ses auteurs preferes.

eng: But on Sunday after luncheon he borrowed a cutter, and drove over to Skuytercliff.
fr: Mais le dimanche, il emprunta un traineau pour aller a Skuytercliff.

eng: People had always been told that the house at Skuytercliff was an Italian villa.
fr: La maison de Skuytercliff avait la pretention d'etre une villa italienne.

eng: and finally, about midnight, he assisted in putting a gold-fish in one visitor's bed, dressed up a burglar in the bath-room of a nervous aunt, and saw in the small hours by joining in a pillow-fight that ranged from the nurseries to the basement.
fr: Vers minuit, il aida a mettre des poissons rouges dans le lit d'un des invites et a fabriquer un cambrioleur-mannequin dans le cabinet de toilette d'une tante timide. ~~~ Enfin, il participa a la bataille d'oreillers qui, jusqu'apres minuit, bouleversa la maison depuis les chambres d'enfants jusqu'a la cave.

eng: Those who had never been to Italy believed it; so did some who had.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The house had been built by Mr. van der Luyden in his youth, on his return from the "grand tour," and in anticipation of his approaching marriage with Miss Louisa Dagonet.
fr: Construite par Mr van der Luyden en vue de son prochain mariage avec Miss Louisa Dagonet,

eng: It was a large square wooden structure, with tongued and grooved walls painted pale green and white, a Corinthian portico, and fluted pilasters between the windows.
fr: c'etait une grande batisse carree, peinte en blanc et vert pale, avec un portique corinthien et d'etroits pilastres entre les fenetres.

eng: From the high ground on which it stood a series of terraces bordered by balustrades and urns descended in the steel-engraving style to a small irregular lake with an asphalt edge overhung by rare weeping conifers.
fr: De la hauteur ou elle etait placee, une serie de terrasses, que bordaient des balustrades surmontees d'urnes, descendait jusqu'a un petit lac a bord d'asphalte, ombrage de coniferes pleureurs.

eng: To the right and left, the famous weedless lawns studded with "specimen" trees (each of a different variety) rolled away to long ranges of grass crested with elaborate cast-iron ornaments;
fr: A droite et a gauche des terrasses, s'etendaient les fameuses pelouses, parsemees d'arbres de choix, chacun d'une variete differente, et au dela, de longues rangees de serres.

eng: and below, in a hollow, lay the four-roomed stone house which the first Patroon had built on the land granted him in 1612.
fr: Plus bas, dans un vallonnement, se voyait la petite maison en pierres que le premier << Patroon >> avait fait construire sur le terrain qui lui avait ete concede en 1605.

eng: Against the uniform sheet of snow and the greyish winter sky the Italian villa loomed up rather grimly;
fr: Contre la blanche etendue de neige et le ciel gris d'hiver, la villa italienne avait un aspect assez lugubre.

eng: even in summer it kept its distance, and the boldest coleus bed had never ventured nearer than thirty feet from its awful front.
fr: Meme en ete, elle gardait sa dignite et les plus temeraires corbeilles de cannas ne s'aventuraient jamais a moins de trente pieds de sa facade.

eng: Now, as Archer rang the bell, the long tinkle seemed to echo through a mausoleum;
fr: Quand Archer sonna, le long tintement sembla se prolonger comme dans un mausolee,

eng: and the surprise of the butler who at length responded to the call was as great as though he had been summoned from his final sleep.
fr: et lorsqu'enfin le maitre d'hotel se presenta, il parut aussi etonne que s'il eut ete reveille de son dernier sommeil.

eng: Happily Archer was of the family, and therefore, irregular though his arrival was, entitled to be informed that the Countess Olenska was out, having driven to afternoon service with Mrs. van der Luyden exactly three quarters of an hour earlier.
fr: Mais Archer etait de la famille : le maitre d'hotel crut pouvoir lui dire que la comtesse Olenska etait sortie pour se rendre, avec Mrs van der Luyden, aux offices du soir.

eng: "Mr. van der Luyden," the butler continued, "is in, sir; but my impression is that he is either finishing his nap or else reading yesterday's Evening Post.
fr: -- Mr van der Luyden, continua le maitre d'hotel, est a la maison ; mais je crois qu'il finit sa sieste ou qu'il lit l'Evening Post d'hier.

eng: after tea he talked in a corner of the firelit hall with a young lady who had professed herself broken-hearted when his engagement was announced, but was now eager to tell him of her own matrimonial hopes;
fr: Apres le the, il causa dans un coin avec une jeune fille avec laquelle il avait flirte autrefois et qui venait de se fiancer.

eng: in the afternoon he "went over the farm" with Reggie, and listened, in the elaborately appointed stables, to long and impressive disquisitions on the horse;
fr: Dans la journee, il fit le tour du proprietaire.

eng: XV.
fr: XV

eng: Newland Archer arrived at the Chiverses' on Friday evening, and on Saturday went conscientiously through all the rites appertaining to a week-end at Highbank.
fr: Newland Archer arriva chez les Chivers le vendredi soir et executa, consciencieusement, le lendemain, tous les rites d'un week-end a Highbank.

eng: He knew that Mrs. Reggie didn't object to her visitors' suddenly changing their minds, and that there was always a room to spare in her elastic house.
fr: Il savait que Mrs Reggie avait toujours de la place pour un invite de la derniere heure, et qu'il pouvait compter sur son accueil.

eng: But he now went into the club writing-room, wrote a hurried telegram, and told the servant to send it immediately.
fr: Pourtant, tout en froissant entre ses doigts la lettre de Mme Olenska, il alla dans le salon de lecture du cercle, redigea un telegramme et le fit partir immediatement.

eng: In the morning he had a spin in the ice-boat with his hostess and a few of the hardier guests;
fr: Le matin, il fit du toboggan avec la maitresse de la maison et les plus allants des invites.

eng: I heard him say, sir, on his return from church this morning, that he intended to look through the Evening Post after luncheon; if you like, sir, I might go to the library door and listen--" But Archer, thanking him, said that he would go and meet the ladies; and the butler, obviously relieved, closed the door on him majestically.
fr: Je l'ai entendu dire ce matin, a son retour de l'eglise, qu'il lirait l'Evening Post apres le dejeuner. ~~~ Si vous le desirez, monsieur, je puis aller voir... Archer repondit qu'il irait au-devant des dames, et le maitre d'hotel, visiblement soulage, referma majestueusement la porte.

eng: Presently, however, coming down a foot-path that crossed the highway, he caught sight of a slight figure in a red cloak, with a big dog running ahead.
fr: Un instant apres, venant d'un sentier qui traversait la route, il apercut un grand chien devancant une mince silhouette en manteau rouge.

eng: The village of Skuytercliff was only a mile and a half away, but he knew that Mrs. van der Luyden never walked, and that he must keep to the road to meet the carriage.
fr: Le village de Skuytercliff n'etait distant que d'un kilometre, mais il savait que Mrs van der Luyden ne marchait jamais, et qu'il rencontrerait la voiture en chemin.

eng: A groom took the cutter to the stables, and Archer struck through the park to the high-road.
fr: Un groom mena le traineau aux ecuries et Archer traversa le parc pour gagner la grande route.

eng: He hurried forward, and Madame Olenska stopped short with a smile of welcome.
fr: Il pressa le pas et Mme Olenska s'arreta court, avec un sourire de bienvenue.

eng: "Ah, you've come!" she said, and drew her hand from her muff.
fr: '-- Ah ! ~~~ vous voila !'

eng: The red cloak made her look gay and vivid, like the Ellen Mingott of old days;
fr: Le manteau rouge lui rendait l'eclat de l'Ellen Mingott d'autrefois.

eng: and he laughed as he took her hand, and answered: "I came to see what you were running away from."
fr: Il rit, lui prenant la main, et repondit : -- Je suis venu pour savoir ce que vous avez voulu fuir...'

eng: Her face clouded over, but she answered: "Ah, well--you will see, presently."
fr: La figure de la jeune femme s'assombrit : -- Vous le comprendrez tout a l'heure...

eng: She looked up at him and smiled.
fr: Elle fixa sur lui son regard :

eng: The blood rose to his temples and he caught a fold of her cloak.
fr: Le sang monta aux tempes du jeune homme ; il saisit un des plis du manteau rouge.

eng: She shrugged her shoulders, with a little movement like Nastasia's, and rejoined in a lighter tone: "Shall we walk on? I'm so cold after the sermon. And what does it matter, now you're here to protect me?"
fr: D'un petit mouvement qui rappelait celui de Nastasia, Ellen haussa les epaules et dit d'un ton plus leger : -- Marchons ! Le sermon m'a glacee. Et puis, maintenant vous etes la, je n'ai plus peur.

eng: "Why--do you mean that you've been overtaken?"
fr: -- Qu'avez-vous donc ? Que se passe-t-il ?

eng: The answer puzzled him.
fr: La reponse intrigua Archer :

eng: "I knew you'd come!"
fr: -- Je savais que vous viendriez !

eng: "That shows you wanted me to," he returned, with a disproportionate joy in their nonsense.
fr: -- Cela prouve que vous le desiriez, repondit-il avec une joie secrete.

eng: The white glitter of the trees filled the air with its own mysterious brightness, and as they walked on over the snow the ground seemed to sing under their feet.
fr: Le scintillement des arbres givres remplissait l'air d'une lumiere mysterieuse et, comme ils marchaient, la neige durcie semblait chanter sous leurs pas.

eng: For a moment Archer stood watching, his gaze delighted by the flash of the red meteor against the snow; then he started after her, and they met, panting and laughing, at a wicket that led into the park.
fr: Archer s'arreta un moment, ravi de ce bondissement rouge sur la neige ; puis il s'elanca a la poursuite de la jeune femme. ~~~ Ils se rejoignirent, riant et hors d'haleine, devant le portillon qui ouvrait sur le parc.

eng: "Oh, presently--let's run a race first: my feet are freezing to the ground," she cried; and gathering up the cloak she fled away across the snow, the dog leaping about her with challenging barks.
fr: -- Tout a l'heure. Courons d'abord ; j'ai les pieds geles, cria-t-elle ; et, ramassant son manteau, elle s'elanca sur la neige, suivie du chien qui gambadait autour d'elle.

eng: "Ellen--what is it? You must tell me."
fr: -- Ellen ! Qu'y a-t-il ? Dites-le moi !

eng: "Where did you come from?"
fr: -- D'ou venez-vous ?

eng: He lowered his voice to ask: "What sort of a need?"
fr: Il baissa la voix : -- Quelle sorte de secours ?

eng: She stood still.
fr: Elle s'arreta :

eng: "Why--the house is open!" he said.
fr: -- Tiens ! la maison est ouverte ? dit-il.

eng: The shutters stood wide, and through one of the newly-washed windows Archer caught the light of a fire.
fr: Les volets etaient ouverts, et, a travers les vitres, Archer apercut la lueur d'un feu.

eng: They were walking past the house of the old Patroon, with its squat walls and small square windows compactly grouped about a central chimney.
fr: Ils passaient devant la maison du vieux << Patroon. ~~~ >> Sa facade basse, percee de petites fenetres, etait dominee, a la mode hollandaise, par une seule cheminee centrale.

eng: "Ah, you don't like us!" Archer exclaimed.
fr: -- Ah ! vous ne nous aimez pas ! s'ecria Archer.

eng: Finally she said: "I will tell you--but where, where, where? One can't be alone for a minute in that great seminary of a house, with all the doors wide open, and always a servant bringing tea, or a log for the fire, or the newspaper! Is there nowhere in an American house where one may be by one's self? You're so shy, and yet you're so public. I always feel as if I were in the convent again--or on the stage, before a dreadfully polite audience that never applauds."
fr: Enfin elle dit : -- Je vous l'expliquerai, mais ou ? On ne peut pas etre seul une minute dans cette maison aux portes toujours ouvertes, ou toujours quelque domestique vous apporte le the, une buche ou un journal ! Ne peut-on jamais, dans une maison americaine, etre un peu seule ? Vous qui etes si reserves, si discrets, comment se fait-il que vous ayez si peu le sens de l'intimite ?

eng: He was silent, and they walked on a few yards without exchanging a word.
fr: Ils marcherent quelques instants en silence.

eng: She shrugged again. "Does anything ever happen in heaven?"
fr: Elle haussa de nouveau les epaules : -- Que peut-il arriver dans le paradis ?

eng: She laid her hand lightly on his arm, and he pleaded earnestly: "Ellen--why won't you tell me what's happened?"
fr: Elle posa legerement sa main sur le bras du jeune homme. Il la pressa. ~~~ -- Ellen ! Pourquoi ne pas me dire ce qui est arrive ?...

eng: "Oh, my friend--!"
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ mon ami !

eng: "What did I come for, if I don't speak yours?"
fr: -- Pourquoi suis-je venu, si vous ne parlez pas ma langue ?

eng: The answer smote him like a blow, and he stood still in the path, looking down at her.
fr: La reponse le blessa ; il s'arreta dans le sentier.

eng: "Ah, don't ask me! I don't speak your language," she retorted petulantly.
fr: -- Ne me le demandez pas. Je ne parle pas votre langue, repliqua-t-elle avec vivacite.

eng: She ran up the steps and tried the door. "It's still unlocked--what luck!'
fr: Elle monta les marches en courant et tourna la poignee de la porte. -- Elle est encore ouverte. ~~~ Quelle chance !

eng: "You mean--I'm so evidently helpless and defenceless? What a poor thing you must all think me! But women here seem not--seem never to feel the need: any more than the blessed in heaven."
fr: -- Vous me trouvez donc bien visiblement sans defense ! Quelle pauvre creature vous me croyez tous ! Mais les femmes d'ici n'ont donc jamais besoin de secours, pas plus que les bienheureux dans le ciel ?

eng: "I didn't need any asking."
fr: -- Je n'avais pas besoin qu'on me le demandat...

eng: After a pause she said, with a just perceptible chill in her voice: "May asked you to take care of me."
fr: Apres un silence, elle dit, avec un imperceptible tremblement dans la voix : -- May vous a demande de vous occuper de moi ?

eng: He told her, and added: "It was because I got your note."
fr: Il le lui expliqua et ajouta : -- J'ai demande aux Chivers de me recevoir lorsque j'ai recu votre lettre.

eng: Madame Olenska asked.
fr: demanda Mme Olenska.

eng: "No; only for today, at least. I wanted to see it, and Mr. van der Luyden had the fire lit and the windows opened, so that we might stop there on the way back from church this morning."
fr: -- Pour aujourd'hui, tout au moins. Je desirais la visiter, et Mr van der Luyden a fait allumer du feu, afin que nous puissions y passer en revenant de l'eglise, ce matin.

eng: Come in and we can have a quiet talk.
fr: Entrez et nous pourrons causer tranquillement.

eng: Mrs. van der Luyden has driven over to see her old aunts at Rhinebeck and we shan't be missed at the house for another hour."
fr: Mrs van der Luyden est allee jusqu'a Rhinebeck voir les vieilles tantes, et on ne s'apercevra pas de notre absence.

eng: He followed her into the narrow passage.
fr: Il la suivit dans l'etroit couloir.

eng: His spirits, which had dropped at her last words, rose with an irrational leap.
fr: La depression que lui avaient causee les dernieres paroles de la comtesse Olenska fit place a un mouvement de joie.

eng: The homely little house stood there, its panels and brasses shining in the firelight, as if magically created to receive them.
fr: La petite maison intime, avec ses boiseries peintes, ses cuivres ou se refletait le feu, s'ouvrait la pour eux comme par enchantement.

eng: A big bed of embers still gleamed in the kitchen chimney, under an iron pot hung from an ancient crane.
fr: Un grand lit de braises luisait encore dans la cheminee de la cuisine, sous un chaudron suspendu a une vieille cremaillere.

eng: Rush-bottomed arm-chairs faced each other across the tiled hearth, and rows of Delft plates stood on shelves against the walls.
fr: Des chaises cannees se faisaient face des deux cotes du foyer revetu de vieilles faiences bleues, et des rangees d'assiettes de Delft ornaient les murs.

eng: Madame Olenska, dropping her cloak, sat down in one of the chairs.
fr: Mme Olenska, otant son manteau, prit une des chaises,

eng: Archer stooped over and threw a log upon the embers.
fr: Archer jeta un fagot dans la cheminee.

eng: Archer leaned against the chimney and looked at her.
fr: et Archer, appuye a la cheminee, l'interrogea du regard.

eng: "You're laughing now; but when you wrote me you were unhappy," he said.
fr: -- Vous riez maintenant ; mais quand vous m'avez ecrit, vous etiez malheureuse, dit-il.

eng: "Yes."
fr: -- Oui.

eng: "But I can't feel unhappy when you're here."
fr: 'Elle ajouta : -- Je ne peux pas me sentir malheureuse quand vous etes la...'

eng: "I sha'n't be here long," he rejoined, his lips stiffening with the effort to say just so much and no more.
fr: '-- Je ne serai pas ici longtemps, observa-t-il sechement.'

eng: "No; I know. But I'm improvident: I live in the moment when I'm happy."
fr: '-- Sans doute. Mais je ne sais pas prevoir ! ~~~ Je vis dans le moment ou je suis heureuse.'

eng: She paused.
The words stole through him like a temptation, and to close his senses to it he moved away from the hearth and stood gazing out at the black tree-boles against the snow.
fr: 'Ces mots glisserent en lui comme une tentation ; pour s'y derober, il s'eloigna de la cheminee et se mit a regarder les troncs noirs des arbres qui se detachaient sur la neige.'

eng: But it was as if she too had shifted her place, and he still saw her, between himself and the trees, drooping over the fire with her indolent smile.
fr: 'Mais il voyait encore, entre lui et les arbres, la jeune femme penchee sur le feu, avec son sourire indolent.'

eng: What if it were from him that she had been running away, and if she had waited to tell him so till they were here alone together in this secret room?
fr: 'Etait-ce lui qu'elle avait fui ? ~~~ Avait-elle attendu pour le lui dire qu'ils fussent ensemble seuls dans cette chambre ?'

eng: "Ellen, if I'm really a help to you--if you really wanted me to come--tell me what's wrong, tell me what it is you're running away from," he insisted.
fr: '-- Ellen, si vraiment je puis vous aider, si reellement vous desiriez ma venue ici, dites-moi ce qu'il y a, dites-moi a qui vous voulez echapper !'

eng: Archer's heart was beating insubordinately.
fr: 'Le coeur d'Archer battait en desordre.'

eng: He spoke without shifting his position, without even turning to look at her: if the thing was to happen, it was to happen in this way, with the whole width of the room between them, and his eyes still fixed on the outer snow.
fr: Il parlait sans changer de position, sans se retourner pour la regarder. ~~~ Si le destin devait parler, ce serait ainsi, avec toute l'etendue de cette chambre entre eux, tandis qu'il continuait, par la fenetre, a regarder la neige.

eng: For a long moment she was silent; and in that moment Archer imagined her, almost heard her, stealing up behind him to throw her light arms about his neck.
fr: Longtemps elle resta silencieuse. ~~~ Un moment, Archer s'imagina presque entendre qu'elle s'approchait de lui, prete a lui jeter ses bras legers autour du cou.

eng: While he waited, soul and body throbbing with the miracle to come, his eyes mechanically received the image of a heavily-coated man with his fur collar turned up who was advancing along the path to the house.
fr: Tout son etre palpitait dans l'attente...
-- Ah !

eng: The man was Julius Beaufort.
fr: Archer reconnut Julius Beaufort.

eng: Archer cried, bursting into a laugh.
fr: cria-t-il, eclatant d'un rire sonore.

eng: Madame Olenska had sprung up and moved to his side, slipping her hand into his; but after a glance through the window her face paled and she shrank back.
fr: Mme Olenska s'etait elancee de sa chaise et etait venue pres de lui, glissant sa main dans la sienne ; mais, apres avoir jete un coup d'oeil par la fenetre, elle palit et recula.

eng: "So that was it?"
fr: -- Enfin, je comprends !...

eng: Archer said derisively.
fr: dit Archer avec une ironie amere.

eng: "I didn't know he was here," Madame Olenska murmured.
fr: -- Je ne savais pas qu'il fut ici, murmura-t-elle.

eng: Her hand still clung to Archer's; but he drew away from her, and walking out into the passage threw open the door of the house.
fr: Sa main serrait encore celle d'Archer ; mais il s'eloigna d'elle brusquement, et, traversant le vestibule, il ouvrit la porte de la maison.

eng: "Hallo, Beaufort--this way!
fr: -- Bonjour, Beaufort ! ~~~ Par ici !

eng: Mrs. van der Luyden had not yet returned; and Archer took his leave and walked off to fetch the cutter, while Beaufort followed the Countess Olenska indoors.
fr: Mrs van der Luyden n'etant pas encore revenue, Archer prit conge et remonta dans son traineau, pendant que Beaufort entrait dans la maison avec Mme Olenska.

eng: Archer, as the three strolled back through the park, was aware of this odd sense of disembodiment; and humbling as it was to his vanity it gave him the ghostly advantage of observing unobserved.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: During his journey back to New York the next morning, Archer relived with a fatiguing vividness his last moments at Skuytercliff.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was undeniably in pursuit of the Countess Olenska; and Beaufort had only one object in view in his pursuit of pretty women.
fr: Il etait clair qu'il poursuivait Mme Olenska, et quand il poursuivait une jolie femme, Beaufort n'avait qu'un but.

eng: Beaufort knew all this, and must have foreseen it; and his taking the long journey for so small a reward gave the measure of his impatience.
fr: Beaufort le savait et ne devait pas s'en etonner, mais qu'il eut entrepris le long trajet pour une si petite recompense, voila qui pouvait donner la mesure de son zele.

eng: It was probable that, little as the van der Luydens encouraged unannounced visits, he could count on being asked to dine, and sent back to the station to catch the nine o'clock train; but more than that he would certainly not get, for it would be inconceivable to his hosts that a gentleman travelling without luggage should wish to spend the night, and distasteful to them to propose it to a person with whom they were on terms of such limited cordiality as Beaufort.
fr: Malgre l'habitude des van der Luyden de ne pas encourager les visites imprevues, il pouvait esperer etre retenu a diner, et reconduit a la gare pour le train de neuf heures. ~~~ Mais c'etait tout. ~~~ Jamais ses hotes n'auraient pense a demander a un visiteur venu sans bagages de passer la nuit chez eux ; dans les termes assez froids ou ils se trouvaient avec Beaufort, la question ne se posait meme pas.

eng: This struck from all three allusions to Edgar Poe and Jules Verne, and such platitudes as naturally rise to the lips of the most intelligent when they are talking against time, and dealing with a new invention in which it would seem ingenuous to believe too soon; and the question of the telephone carried them safely back to the big house.
fr: Ceci amena des souvenirs d'Edgar Poe et de Jules Verne ; et la question du telephone les conduisit sans encombre jusqu'a la grande maison.

eng: Beaufort had entered the little house with his usual easy assurance; but he could not smile away the vertical line between his eyes.
fr: Mais, malgre son air d'assurance habituelle, il ne pouvait effacer le pli qui s'etait creuse entre ses yeux.

eng: The ostensible reason of his appearance was the discovery, the very night before, of a "perfect little house," not in the market, which was really just the thing for her, but would be snapped up instantly if she didn't take it; and he was loud in mock-reproaches for the dance she had led him in running away just as he had found it.
fr: La raison qu'il donna de son arrivee fut qu'il avait decouvert, la veille au soir, une petite maison delicieuse, qui faisait absolument l'affaire de la jeune femme, mais qui pouvait lui etre soufflee d'un moment a l'autre. Il se repandit en reproches agreables : quelle peine elle lui avait donnee en s'enfuyant juste au moment ou il avait fait cette trouvaille !

eng: It was fairly clear that Madame Olenska had not known that he was coming, though her words to Archer had hinted at the possibility; at any rate, she had evidently not told him where she was going when she left New York, and her unexplained departure had exasperated him.
fr: Il semblait bien que Mme Olenska ignorat qu'il dut venir, et pourtant elle avait paru indiquer que cela etait possible.

eng: at any rate, she had evidently not told him where she was going when she left New York, and her unexplained departure had exasperated him.
fr: (Partially covered by existing alignments, but not a direct, single sentence equivalent)

eng: Beaufort, though clearly annoyed at finding him with Madame Olenska, had, as usual, carried off the situation high-handedly.
fr: Beaufort, visiblement contrarie de le trouver avec Mme Olenska, gardait quand meme tout son aplomb.

eng: "Madame Olenska was expecting you," he said.
fr: 'Mme Olenska vous attendait, dit-il.'

eng: "If only this new dodge for talking along a wire had been a little bit nearer perfection I might have told you all this from town, and been toasting my toes before the club fire at this minute, instead of tramping after you through the snow," he grumbled, disguising a real irritation under the pretence of it; and at this opening Madame Olenska twisted the talk away to the fantastic possibility that they might one day actually converse with each other from street to street, or even--incredible dream!--from one town to another.
fr: -- Si seulement cette nouveaute du telephone etait un peu plus perfectionnee, j'aurais pu vous avertir de loin, et je serais en train de me chauffer les pieds au feu du cercle, au lieu de courir apres vous dans la neige, bougonna-t-il, deguisant sous une irritation feinte son reel deplaisir. ~~~ Mme Olenska detourna vivement la conversation sur le miracle de pouvoir un jour converser d'une rue a l'autre, ou meme, -- reve insense ! -- d'une ville a l'autre.

eng: His way of ignoring people whose presence inconvenienced him actually gave them, if they were sensitive to it, a feeling of invisibility, of nonexistence.
fr: Il savait donner aux gens qui le genaient l'impression qu'ils ne comptaient pas, qu'ils existaient a peine.

eng: His dull and childless home had long since palled on him; and in addition to more permanent consolations he was always in quest of amorous adventures in his own set.
fr: Son interieur morose l'excedait depuis longtemps : et les consolations permanentes qu'il s'etait octroyees ne l'empechaient pas de se mettre en quete d'aventures amoureuses dans son monde.

eng: Little as he had actually seen of Madame Olenska, he was beginning to think that he could read her face, and if not her face, her voice; and both had betrayed annoyance, and even dismay, at Beaufort's sudden appearance.
fr: Si peu qu'il eut vu Mme Olenska, il croyait commencer a lire sur son visage, et il avait ete temoin de son desarroi a l'apparition soudaine de Beaufort.

eng: This was the man from whom Madame Olenska was avowedly flying: the question was whether she had fled because his importunities displeased her, or because she did not wholly trust herself to resist them; unless, indeed, all her talk of flight had been a blind, and her departure no more than a manoeuvre.
fr: Tel etait l'homme que Mme Olenska avait fui. Etait-elle obsedee par ses importunites ? Doutait-elle d'elle-meme, ou encore cette fuite n'etait-elle qu'une feinte et son depart de New-York une simple manoeuvre ?

eng: But, after all, if this were the case, was it not worse than if she had left New York for the express purpose of meeting him?
fr: Mais qu'elle eut fui Beaufort, n'etait-ce pas la le danger pour Archer ?

eng: If she had done that, she ceased to be an object of interest, she threw in her lot with the vulgarest of dissemblers: a woman engaged in a love affair with Beaufort "classed" herself irretrievably.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer did not really believe this.
fr: Archer ne le pensait pas.

eng: Beaufort was vulgar, he was uneducated, he was purse-proud; but the circumstances of his life, and a certain native shrewdness, made him better worth talking to than many men, morally and socially his betters, whose horizon was bounded by the Battery and the Central Park.
fr: Beaufort etait un parvenu sans education, mais les circonstances de sa vie et une certaine vivacite d'esprit naturelle, rendaient sa conversation plus interessante que celle d'hommes plus distingues, mais dont l'horizon n'avait jamais deborde New-York.

eng: No, it was worse a thousand times if, judging Beaufort, and probably despising him, she was yet drawn to him by all that gave him an advantage over the other men about her: his habit of two continents and two societies, his familiar association with artists and actors and people generally in the world's eye, and his careless contempt for local prejudices.
fr: Jugeant Beaufort, et sans doute le meprisant, il etait possible neanmoins qu'elle fut attiree vers lui, par tout ce qui composait son prestige : ses relations a New-York et a Londres, son commerce familier avec des artistes et des acteurs, son dedain des prejuges locaux.

eng: The box was full of things he had been waiting for impatiently; a new volume of Herbert Spencer, another collection of the prolific Alphonse Daudet's brilliant tales, and a novel called "Middlemarch," as to which there had lately been interesting things said in the reviews.
fr: L'envoi contenait de nombreux ouvrages qu'il attendait impatiemment : un nouveau volume d'Herbert Spencer, le dernier livre d'Edmond de Goncourt, un roman intitule Middlemarch, dont parlaient les revues.

eng: That evening he unpacked his books from London.
fr: En arrivant chez lui, Archer deballa les livres qui etaient arrives de Londres.

eng: A longing to enlighten her was strong in him; and there were moments when he imagined that all she asked was to be enlightened.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Thus, with a painful impartiality, did the young man make out the case for Beaufort, and for Beaufort's victim.
fr: C'est ainsi que le jeune homme s'efforcait d'analyser, avec une triste impartialite, la situation de Beaufort et de sa victime.

eng: He had declined three dinner invitations in favour of this feast; but though he turned the pages with the sensuous joy of the book-lover, he did not know what he was reading, and one book after another dropped from his hand.
fr: Le jeune homme avait refuse trois invitations a diner pour jouir de ce regal ; mais tout en tournant les pages, il ne savait pas ce qu'il lisait, et les livres, l'un apres l'autre, lui tomberent des mains.

eng: This might seem to be to his disadvantage with Count Olenski's wife; but Archer was too intelligent to think that a young woman like Ellen Olenska would necessarily recoil from everything that reminded her of her past.
fr: Cela aurait pu etre un desavantage pour lui ; mais Archer ne croyait pas qu'Ellen Olenska dut se derober necessairement a tout ce qui lui rappellerait le passe.

eng: But Beaufort understood every turn of her dialect, and spoke it fluently: his view of life, his tone, his attitude, were merely a coarser reflection of those revealed in Count Olenski's letter.
fr: Mais cette langue d'Ellen Olenska, Beaufort en connaissait toutes les nuances ; il pouvait lui donner la replique. Il y avait dans toute sa mentalite une certaine ressemblance avec ce que laissait entrevoir la courte lettre du comte Olenski.

eng: Madame Olenska, in a burst of irritation, had said to Archer that he and she did not talk the same language; and the young man knew that in some respects this was true.
fr: Mme Olenska avait dit a Archer qu'elle et lui ne parlaient pas la meme langue, et il sentait que jusqu'a un certain point c'etait vrai.

eng: How should any one coming from a wider world not feel the difference and be attracted by it?
fr: Comment une jeune femme revenue d'un monde plus vaste ne serait-elle pas sensible a ce contraste ?

eng: She might believe herself wholly in revolt against it; but what had charmed her in it would still charm her, even though it were against her will.
fr: Elle pouvait, tout en se croyant revoltee contre ce passe, en subir encore le charme.

eng: Suddenly, among them, he lit on a small volume of verse which he had ordered because the name had attracted him: "The House of Life."
fr: Tout a coup, parmi eux, il avisa un petit volume de vers qu'il avait demande sur la foi du titre : The House of Life.

eng: He took it up, and found himself plunged in an atmosphere unlike any he had ever breathed in books; so warm, so rich, and yet so ineffably tender, that it gave a new and haunting beauty to the most elementary of human passions.
fr: Il l'ouvrit et se trouva plonge dans une atmosphere qu'il n'avait jamais connue dans ses lectures, atmosphere chaude, voluptueuse et, cependant, d'une si ineffable tendresse qu'elle donnait a la passion une nouvelle beaute pathetique et obsedante.

eng: All through the night he pursued through those enchanted pages the vision of a woman who had the face of Ellen Olenska;
fr: Toute la nuit, il poursuivit a travers ces pages enchantees la vision d'une femme qui avait le visage de Mme Olenska ;

eng: but when he woke the next morning, and looked out at the brownstone houses across the street, and thought of his desk in Mr. Letterblair's office, and the family pew in Grace Church, his hour in the park of Skuytercliff became as far outside the pale of probability as the visions of the night.
fr: mais, quand il s'eveilla le lendemain et qu'il vit les maisons en face de ses fenetres et pensa au cabinet de Mr Letterblair, au banc de famille dans Grace Church, l'heure passee dans le parc de Skuytercliff devint aussi irreelle que ses reves de la nuit...

eng: "Mercy, how pale you look, Newland!" Janey commented over the coffee-cups at breakfast;
fr: -- Mon Dieu, que tu es pale, Newland ! observa Janey, en le devisageant lorsqu'il descendit pour le petit dejeuner ;

eng: and his mother added: "Newland, dear, I've noticed lately that you've been coughing; I do hope you're not letting yourself be overworked?"
fr: et sa mere ajouta : -- Newland, mon cheri, j'ai remarque que tu toussais ces jours-ci. J'espere que tu ne te laisses pas surmener.

eng: For it was the conviction of both ladies that, under the iron despotism of his senior partners, the young man's life was spent in the most exhausting professional labours--and he had never thought it necessary to undeceive them.
fr: Les deux femmes etaient convaincues que, sous le despotisme de Mr Leterblair, le jeune homme s'epuisait au travail, et Archer n'avait jamais cru necessaire de les detromper.

eng: The next two or three days dragged by heavily.
fr: Les jours suivants se trainerent peniblement.

eng: The taste of the usual was like cinders in his mouth, and there were moments when he felt as if he were being buried alive under his future.
fr: La monotonie de sa vie lui mettait dans la bouche comme un gout de cendres ; par moment, il avait le sentiment d'etre enterre vivant.

eng: He heard nothing of the Countess Olenska, or of the perfect little house, and though he met Beaufort at the club they merely nodded at each other across the whist-tables.
fr: Il ne savait plus rien de Mme Olenska ni de la petite maison. ~~~ Quand il rencontrait Beaufort au cercle, ils echangeaient un signe de tete silencieux a travers les tables de whist.

eng: (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: La verite, la realite, la vraie vie se trouvaient la !

eng: After dinner he went to a play; and it was not until his return home, after midnight, that he drew Madame Olenska's missive out again and re-read it slowly a number of times.
fr: Apres le diner, il se rendit au theatre, et ce ne fut qu'apres minuit, de retour chez lui, qu'il relut lentement cette missive.

eng: That on which, when morning came, he finally decided was to pitch some clothes into a portmanteau and jump on board a boat that was leaving that very afternoon for St. Augustine.
fr: Celle qu'il choisit fut de faire rapidement sa valise, et de sauter dans le bateau qui partait le lendemain pour Saint-Augustin.

eng: It was not till the fourth evening that he found a note awaiting him on his return home.
fr: Le quatrieme jour, il trouva, en rentrant chez lui, un billet ainsi concu : << Venez tard demain, il faut que je vous explique. Ellen. >>

eng: XVI. When Archer walked down the sandy main street of St. Augustine to the house which had been pointed out to him as Mr. Welland's, and saw May Welland standing under a magnolia with the sun in her hair, he wondered why he had waited so long to come.
fr: XVI Quand Archer descendit la grande rue sablonneuse de Saint-Augustin, se dirigeant vers la maison qui lui avait ete indiquee comme la demeure de Mr Welland, il apercut May debout sous un magnolia. Les rayons du soleil doraient ses cheveux, et le jeune homme se demanda pourquoi il avait tant tarde a venir.

eng: The young man, who was dining out, thrust the note into his pocket, smiling a little at the Frenchness of the "to you."
fr: Le jeune homme, qui dinait en ville, mit le petit mot dans sa poche.

eng: There were several ways of answering it, and he gave considerable thought to each one during the watches of an agitated night.
fr: Il y avait plusieurs manieres d'y repondre. ~~~ Il les etudia toutes, en un examen approfondi, au cours d'une nuit sans sommeil.

eng: "Come late tomorrow: I must explain to you. Ellen." These were the only words it contained.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Here was the truth, here was reality, here was the life that belonged to him; and he, who fancied himself so scornful of arbitrary restraints, had been afraid to break away from his desk because of what people might think of his stealing a holiday!
fr: Comment, lui, l'independant Archer, s'etait-il cru oblige de rester cloue a son bureau par crainte des critiques ?

eng: her happy blushes took the chill from her surprise, and he saw how easily he would be forgiven, and how soon even Mr. Letterblair's mild disapproval would be smiled away by a tolerant family.
fr: elle rougit delicieusement, et cette rougeur effaca la legere deception du jeune homme.

eng: But when he answered: "Yes--I found I had to see you,"
fr: Mais lorsqu'il repondit : << J'ai voulu vous revoir, >>

eng: and it occurred to him that it would have been more "feminine" if she had instantly read in his eyes why he had come.
fr: Ainsi elle ne devinait pas, elle ne lisait pas dans ses yeux la raison de sa venue !

eng: "Her first exclamation was: "Newland--has anything happened?"
fr: '-- Newland, est-il arrive quelque chose ? ~~~ s'ecria la jeune fille.'

eng: Early as it was, the main street was no place for any but formal greetings, and Archer longed to be alone with May, and to pour out all his tenderness and his impatience.
fr: Malgre l'heure matinale, la grand'rue se pretait mal a un entretien intime, et Archer souhaitait vivement de se trouver seul avec May.

eng: It still lacked an hour to the late Welland breakfast-time, and instead of asking him to come in she proposed that they should walk out to an old orange-garden beyond the town.
fr: Les Welland dejeunaient tard : la jeune fille lui proposa une promenade jusqu'au bois d'orangers au dela de la ville.

eng: She had just been for a row on the river, and the sun that netted the little waves with gold seemed to have caught her in its meshes.
fr: Elle venait de ramer sur la riviere et le soleil semblait l'avoir prise dans le filet d'or qu'il jetait sur les petites vagues.

eng: Across the warm brown of her cheek her blown hair glittered like silver wire; and her eyes too looked lighter, almost pale in their youthful limpidity.
fr: Sur le brun chaud de sa joue, ses cheveux fous brillaient comme des fils de metal ; ses yeux semblaient plus clairs, presque pales dans leur transparence.

eng: As she walked beside Archer with her long swinging gait her face wore the vacant serenity of a young marble athlete.
fr: Elle marchait a cote d'Archer de son long pas rythme, et son visage etait empreint de la serenite vide de pensees que l'on voit aux jeunes athletes des frises grecques.

eng: It was like drinking at a cold spring with the sun on it;
fr: C'etait boire a une source fraiche sous le soleil.

eng: They sat down on a bench under the orange-trees and he put his arm about her and kissed her.
fr: Ils s'assirent sous les orangers. Il mit son bras autour d'elle et l'embrassa.

eng: To Archer's strained nerves the vision was as soothing as the sight of the blue sky and the lazy river.
fr: Pour les nerfs tendus d'Archer, cette vision etait aussi apaisante que le ciel bleu et la riviere paresseuse.

eng: but his pressure may have been more vehement than he had intended, for the blood rose to her face and she drew back as if he had startled her.
fr: Mais la pression de ses levres avait peut-etre ete plus vive qu'il ne l'avait voulu, car le sang monta a la figure de la jeune fille, et elle recula.

eng: "What is it?"
fr: -- Qu'y a-t-il ?

eng: 'It was the only time that he had kissed her on the lips except for their fugitive embrace in the Beaufort conservatory,'
fr: 'Newland ne l'avait pas embrassee sur les levres depuis leur fugitif baiser dans le jardin d'hiver des Beaufort,'

eng: 'A slight embarrassment fell on them, and her hand slipped out of his.'
fr: 'Un leger embarras pesa sur eux ; leurs mains se separerent.'

eng: 'and he saw that she was disturbed, and shaken out of her cool boyish composure.'
fr: 'et il vit qu'elle etait troublee dans son calme d'enfant.'

eng: 'and she looked at him with surprise,'
fr: 'Elle le regarda surprise.'

eng: 'he asked, smiling;'
fr: 'demanda Newland en souriant.'

eng: 'and answered: "Nothing."'
fr: '-- Rien, repondit-elle.'

eng: "Tell me what you do all day," he said, crossing his arms under his tilted-back head, and pushing his hat forward to screen the sun-dazzle.
fr: -- Racontez-moi ce que vous faites toute la journee, demanda-t-il, croisant ses bras derriere sa tete et rabattant son chapeau sur ses yeux pour les garantir du soleil.

eng: To let her talk about familiar and simple things was the easiest way of carrying on his own independent train of thought; and he sat listening to her simple chronicle of swimming, sailing and riding, varied by an occasional dance at the primitive inn when a man-of-war came in.
fr: En la faisant parler des choses simples et familieres, il allait pouvoir suivre ses propres pensees. Il ecouta la simple chronique : baignades, promenades a voile, courses a cheval, reunions dansantes organisees au petit hotel en l'honneur d'un bateau de guerre.

eng: They were planning to lay out a lawn tennis court on the sands; but no one but Kate and May had racquets, and most of the people had not even heard of the game.
fr: On voulait faire un tennis sur le sable ; mais Kate et May seules avaient des raquettes, et presque personne ne savait le jeu.

eng: All this kept her very busy, and she had not had time to do more than look at the little vellum book that Archer had sent her the week before (the "Sonnets from the Portuguese"); but she was learning by heart "How they brought the Good News from Ghent to Aix," because it was one of the first things he had ever read to her;
fr: Tres occupee, May avait a peine eu le temps d'ouvrir un petit livre que Newland lui avait envoye la semaine precedente : Sonnets from the Portuguese ; mais elle apprenait par coeur le Last Ride de Browning, parce que c'etait une des premieres poesies que son fiance lui avait lues.

eng: and it amused her to be able to tell him that Kate Merry had never even heard of a poet called Robert Browning.
fr: Elle lui dit en souriant que Kate Merry n'avait jamais entendu parler de Browning.

eng: Presently she started up, exclaiming that they would be late for breakfast; and they hurried back to the tumble-down house with its pointless porch and unpruned hedge of plumbago and pink geraniums where the Wellands were installed for the winter.
fr: Tout a coup elle se leva : -- On va nous attendre pour le dejeuner ! Ils se haterent de rentrer. Les Welland campaient, pour l'hiver, dans une petite maison delabree. Une haie de geraniums et de plumbagos entourait la propriete.

eng: A few pleasant people from Philadelphia and Baltimore were picknicking at the inn, and the Selfridge Merrys had come down for three weeks because Kate Merry had had bronchitis.
fr: Il y avait quelques personnes agreables de Philadelphie et de Baltimore de passage a l'hotel et aussi les Selfridge Merry, venus a cause de la bronchite de Kate Merry.

eng: Mr. Welland's sensitive domesticity shrank from the discomforts of the slovenly southern hotel, and at immense expense, and in face of almost insuperable difficulties, Mrs. Welland was obliged, year after year, to improvise an establishment partly made up of discontented New York servants and partly drawn from the local African supply.
fr: Mr Welland s'effarait du manque de confort a l'hotel, et, a prix d'or, Mrs Welland se voyait obligee, d'annee en annee, d'improviser une installation, amenant de New-York des domestiques recalcitrants qu'aidaient les negres de la localite.

eng: but it had occurred to him to explain that he had felt himself on the verge of a nasty cold,
fr: mais celui-ci eut la bonne inspiration de parler d'un mauvais rhume,

eng: and Mr. Welland, beaming across a breakfast table miraculously supplied with the most varied delicacies, was presently saying to Archer: "You see, my dear fellow, we camp--we literally camp.
fr: Mr Welland, en toute serenite, devant sa table chargee des friandises les plus variees, disait a Archer : -- Vous voyez, mon cher ami, nous campons... nous campons !

eng: "The doctors want my husband to feel that he is in his own home; otherwise he would be so wretched that the climate would not do him any good," she explained, winter after winter, to the sympathising Philadelphians and Baltimoreans;
fr: '-- Les medecins exigent que mon mari soit absolument chez lui, autrement il serait si malheureux que le climat ne lui ferait aucun bien, expliquait-elle chaque hiver.

eng: Mr. and Mrs. Welland had been as much surprised as their daughter by the young man's sudden arrival;
fr: Mr et Mrs Welland avaient ete surpris de l'arrivee de leur futur gendre ;

eng: and this seemed to Mr. Welland an all-sufficient reason for abandoning any duty.'
fr: ce qui sembla a Mr Welland une raison plus que suffisante pour abandonner tout travail.'

eng: I tell my wife and May that I want to teach them how to rough it."
fr: Je dis a ma femme et a May qu'il faut s'accommoder de tout...

eng: "You can't be too careful, especially toward spring," he said, heaping his plate with straw-coloured griddle-cakes and drowning them in golden syrup.
fr: -- Vous ne serez jamais assez prudent, surtout aux approches du printemps, dit-il en versant du sirop d'erable sur son assiettee de crepes.

eng: Mrs. Welland smiled compassionately. "That is just like the extraordinary things that foreigners invent about us. They think we dine at two o'clock and countenance divorce! That is why it seems to me so foolish to entertain them when they come to New York.'
fr: Mrs Welland prit un air irrite : -- Encore un exemple des usages extraordinaires que nous attribuent les etrangers... Ils pensent que nous dinons a deux heures, et que nous favorisons le divorce... C'est pourquoi je trouve ridicule de les recevoir quand ils viennent a New-York...'

eng: "But European society is not given to divorce: Countess Olenska thought she would be conforming to American ideas in asking for her freedom."
fr: -- Mais le divorce n'est pas admis en Europe... La comtesse Olenska a cru se conformer aux usages americains en demandant sa liberte.

eng: "I'm afraid Ellen's ideas are not at all like ours. She was barely eighteen when Medora Manson took her back to Europe--you remember the excitement when she appeared in black at her coming-out ball? Another of Medora's fads--really this time it was almost prophetic! That must have been at least twelve years ago; and since then Ellen has never been to America. No wonder she is completely Europeanised."
fr: ~~~ -- Je crains que les idees d'Ellen ne soient pas du tout les notres ; elle avait a peine dix-huit ans quand Medora Manson l'a emmenee en Europe. Vous vous rappelez qu'elle est apparue en noir le jour de son entree dans le monde ? Encore une des excentricites de Medora, mais cette fois presque prophetique ! Il y a douze ans de cela, et, depuis, Ellen n'etait jamais revenue en Amerique. Rien d'etonnant a ce qu'elle soit si completement europeanisee.

eng: Mr. Letterblair had let Mrs. Welland know that Mr. Archer had "rendered an invaluable service" to the whole family, and that old Mrs. Manson Mingott had been particularly pleased; and one day when May had gone for a drive with her father in the only vehicle the place produced Mrs. Welland took occasion to touch on a topic which she always avoided in her daughter's presence.
fr: Mr Letterblair avait fait connaitre a Mrs Welland le service rendu par Mr Archer a toute la famille, service dont la vieille Mrs Manson Mingott s'etait declaree particulierement satisfaite. Et un jour que May etait allee faire une promenade avec son pere dans l'unique voiture de la localite, Mrs Welland saisit l'occasion pour aborder un sujet qu'elle evitait toujours en presence de sa fille.

eng: It was the first time that the young man had pronounced her name since he had left Skuytercliff, and he felt the colour rise to his cheek.
fr: C'etait la premiere fois que le jeune homme prononcait le nom de Mme Olenska depuis son retour de Skuytercliff : il se sentit rougir.

eng: "Newland must stay till he has quite thrown off his cold," said Mrs. Welland indulgently; and the young man laughed, and said he supposed there was such a thing as one's profession.
fr: -- Newland doit soigner son rhume avant tout, observa Mrs Welland avec indulgence ; sur quoi le jeune homme se mit a rire, en disant qu'en effet les devoirs professionnels n'avaient aucune importance.

eng: "Oh, but I love it here, Papa; you know I do. If only Newland could stay I should like it a thousand times better than New York."
fr: -- Mais j'adore etre ici, papa. Si Newland pouvait rester, j'aimerais mille fois mieux etre ici qu'a New-York...

eng: "If I'd only been as prudent at your age May would have been dancing at the Assemblies now, instead of spending her winters in a wilderness with an old invalid."
fr: 'Si j'avais ete aussi prudent a votre age, May danserait a New-York maintenant, au lieu de passer ses hivers dans un desert avec un malade.

eng: He managed, however, after an exchange of telegrams with the firm, to make his cold last a week; and it shed an ironic light on the situation to know that Mr. Letterblair's indulgence was partly due to the satisfactory way in which his brilliant young junior partner had settled the troublesome matter of the Olenski divorce.
fr: Archer arriva neanmoins, apres un echange de telegrammes avec Mr Letterblair, a faire durer son rhume pendant une semaine. L'indulgence de Mr Letterblair etait due en partie a la solution satisfaisante que son jeune associe avait obtenue dans l'affaire du divorce Olenski.

eng: They accept our hospitality, and then they go home and repeat the same stupid stories."
fr: Ils acceptent notre hospitalite, retournent chez eux et racontent toujours sur nous les memes sottes histoires.

eng: Archer made no comment on this, and Mrs. Welland continued: "But we do most thoroughly appreciate your persuading Ellen to give up the idea.
fr: Archer ne repondit pas, et Mrs Welland continua : -- Nous vous sommes tres reconnaissants d'avoir obtenu d'Ellen qu'elle renonce a son projet... Sa grand'mere et son oncle n'avaient pu l'en faire demordre.

eng: Her grandmother and her uncle Lovell could do nothing with her; both of them have written that her changing her mind was entirely due to your influence--in fact she said so to her grandmother.
fr: Tous deux ont ecrit que son revirement n'est du qu'a votre influence...

eng: She has an unbounded admiration for you.
fr: Elle a pour vous une admiration sans bornes...

eng: Poor Ellen--she was always a wayward child.
fr: Pauvre Ellen !...

eng: "I wonder what her fate will be?"
fr: 'Je me demande quel sort l'attend.'

eng: "If you'd all of you rather she should be Beaufort's mistress than some decent fellow's wife you've certainly gone the right way about it."
fr: 'Si vous preferez qu'elle soit la maitresse de Beaufort plutot que la femme d'un honnete homme..., vous faites tout ce qu'il faut pour cela.'

eng: "What we've all contrived to make it," he felt like answering.
fr: 'Celui que nous aurons tous travaille a lui faire, eut-il envie de repondre.'

eng: He wondered what Mrs. Welland would have said if he had uttered the words instead of merely thinking them.
fr: Il songea a ce que Mrs Welland aurait dit, s'il avait tenu ce propos.

eng: He could picture the sudden decomposure of her firm placid features, to which a lifelong mastery over trifles had given an air of factitious authority.
fr: Il imaginait la soudaine alteration de ce visage placide et ferme, qu'une longue maitrise des details de la vie materielle avait marque d'une apparence d'autorite.

eng: Traces still lingered on them of a fresh beauty like her daughter's; and he asked himself if May's face was doomed to thicken into the same middle-aged image of invincible innocence.
