fr: Elle gardait une certaine beaute saine qui rappelait celle de May ; et Archer se demandait si sa fiancee n'etait pas destinee a cette maturite a la fois lourde et innocente.

eng: Ah, no, he did not want May to have that kind of innocence, the innocence that seals the mind against imagination and the heart against experience!
fr: Oh non ! ~~~ il ne voulait pas que May eut l'innocence qui se refuse a la fois a l'experience et a l'imagination.

eng: But Mr. Welland was terribly upset; he had a slight temperature every morning while we were waiting to hear what had been decided.
fr: Mais mon mari a ete bouleverse : il a fait un peu de fievre tous les matins, tant que la decision est restee en suspens...

eng: Having an invalid to care for, I have to keep my mind bright and happy.
fr: Ayant un malade a soigner, je dois garder mon entrain et ma gaite...

eng: I don't know any of the details; I only ask not to, as I told poor Ellen when she tried to talk to me about it.
fr: Je ne sais pas les details... je n'ai pas voulu les connaitre... J'ai refuse a la pauvre Ellen de l'ecouter sur ce chapitre...

eng: "I verily believe," Mrs. Welland continued, "that if the horrible business had come out in the newspapers it would have been my husband's death-blow.
fr: '-- Je crois vraiment, continua Mrs Welland, que si on avait parle de cette triste histoire dans les journaux, c'eut ete le coup de grace pour mon mari...

eng: It was the horror of his girl's learning that such things were possible--but of course, dear Newland, you felt that too.
fr: C'etait sa terreur que sa fille ne vint a apprendre l'existence de choses pareilles... Vous avez eu naturellement la meme preoccupation que nous, cher Newland...

eng: But he could think of no arguments that would move her, and with a sense of relief he saw Mr. Welland and May driving up to the door.
fr: mais ne trouvant pas d'arguments capables de la convaincre, il fut soulage de voir rentrer May et son pere.

eng: We all knew that you were thinking of May."
fr: nous savions tous que vous pensiez a May !

eng: His only hope was to plead again with May, and on the day before his departure he walked with her to the ruinous garden of the Spanish Mission.
fr: Son seul espoir etait d'user de son influence sur sa fiancee, et, la veille de son depart, il alla visiter le jardin delabre de la vieille mission espagnole.

eng: The background lent itself to allusions to European scenes; and May, who was looking her loveliest under a wide-brimmed hat that cast a shadow of mystery over her too-clear eyes, kindled into eagerness as he spoke of Granada and the Alhambra.
fr: L'endroit rappelait des sites europeens, et May, jolie a ravir sous un chapeau dont les larges bords ombrageaient ses yeux trop pales, souriait aux descriptions que faisait Newland de Grenade et de l'Alhambra.

eng: "We might be seeing it all this spring--even the Easter ceremonies at Seville," he urged, exaggerating his demands in the hope of a larger concession.
fr: -- Nous pourrions voir tout cela au printemps et meme passer les fetes de Paques a Seville, proposa-t-il, exagerant sa demande pour obtenir une plus large concession.

eng: "Easter in Seville? And it will be Lent next week!" she laughed.
fr: -- Les fetes de Paques a Seville ! Mais le careme commence dans un mois !

eng: "Why shouldn't we be married in Lent?" he rejoined; but she looked so shocked that he saw his mistake.
fr: -- Enfin, bientot apres Paques, afin que nous puissions nous embarquer a la fin d'avril... (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Of course I didn't mean that, dearest; but soon after Easter--so that we could sail at the end of April. I know I could arrange it at the office."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She smiled dreamily upon the possibility; but he perceived that to dream of it sufficed her.
fr: Elle sourit a ce reve, l'assimilant aux aventures merveilleuses decrites dans les poemes que son fiance lui lisait a haute voix.

eng: It was like hearing him read aloud out of his poetry books the beautiful things that could not possibly happen in real life.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh, do go on, Newland; I do love your descriptions."
fr: -- Continuez Newland, j'adore vos descriptions !

eng: "But why should they be only descriptions? Why shouldn't we make them real?"
fr: -- Mais pourquoi vous contenter de mes descriptions ?... Pourquoi ne pas voir les lieux memes ?

eng: "We shall, dearest, of course; next year." Her voice lingered over it.
fr: -- Nous irons, surement, l'annee prochaine.

eng: He had meant to seize the opportunity of his private talk with Mrs. Welland to urge her to advance the date of his marriage.
fr: Il aurait voulu profiter de son entretien avec Mrs Welland pour la presser d'avancer la date du mariage,

eng: "Don't you want them to be real sooner? Can't I persuade you to break away now?"
fr: -- Pourquoi pas plus tot ?... insista-t-il.

eng: "Why should we dream away another year? Look at me, dear! Don't you understand how I want you for my wife?"
fr: -- Pourquoi rever encore un an ?... Regardez-moi, cherie... Comprenez-vous que je veux que vous soyez ma femme ?

eng: For a moment she remained motionless; then she raised on him eyes of such despairing dearness that he half-released her waist from his hold.
fr: Elle leva sur lui des yeux d'une franchise si limpide qu'il laissa tomber le bras dont il lui enserrait la taille.

eng: But suddenly her look changed and deepened inscrutably.
fr: Mais soudain le regard de May changea, devint profond et indechiffrable...

eng: "I'm always thinking of May," the young man rejoined, rising to cut short the conversation.
fr: -- Je pense toujours a May, dit le jeune homme, en se levant pour couper court a la conversation.

eng: Archer sprang up from his seat. "My God--perhaps--I don't know," he broke out angrily.
fr: Archer se leva brusquement : -- Mon Dieu ! peut-etre... je ne sais pas, repondit-il avec colere.

eng: May Welland rose also; as they faced each other she seemed to grow in womanly stature and dignity.
fr: May se leva aussi et ils se trouverent face a face. ~~~ Elle semblait grandie, plus femme par la stature et la dignite.

eng: Both were silent for a moment, as if dismayed by the unforeseen trend of their words: then she said in a low voice: "If that is it--is there some one else?"
fr: Tous deux se turent comme troubles par le cours imprevu que prenaient leurs paroles. ~~~ Enfin elle dit a voix basse : -- Y a-t-il quelqu'un entre vous et moi ?

eng: "Some one else--between you and me?" He echoed her words slowly, as though they were only half-intelligible and he wanted time to repeat the question to himself.
fr: -- Quelqu'un entre vous et moi ? -- Il redisait les mots lentement, comme s'ils n'etaient qu'a moitie intelligibles, et qu'il eut besoin, pour les comprendre, de les repeter.

eng: She seemed to catch the uncertainty of his voice, for she went on in a deepening tone: "Let us talk frankly, Newland. Sometimes I've felt a difference in you; especially since our engagement has been announced."
fr: May parut frappee par cette hesitation, car elle ajouta, d'une voix plus grave : -- Parlons franchement, Newland... J'ai eu le sentiment quelquefois que vous aviez change envers moi, particulierement depuis que nos fiancailles sont officielles.

eng: "Dear--what madness!" he recovered himself to exclaim.
fr: -- Ma cherie ! Quelle folie ! s'ecria-t-il, en se ressaisissant.

eng: She met his protest with a faint smile. "If it is, it won't hurt us to talk about it."'
fr: -- Si c'est une folie, cela ne nous fera aucun mal d'en parler.'

eng: She bowed her head, vanishing from him under her conniving hat-brim.
fr: Elle baissa la tete, se derobant au regard de son fiance.

eng: "I'm not sure if I DO understand," she said. "Is it--is it because you're not certain of continuing to care for me?"
fr: -- Je ne sais pas si je vous comprends, dit-elle. Pourquoi etes-vous si presse ? Est-ce parce que vous n'etes pas sur de continuer a m'aimer ?

eng: She paused, and added, lifting her head with one of her noble movements: "Or even if it's true: why shouldn't we speak of it?
fr: -- Elle s'arreta, puis ajouta, en relevant la tete avec un de ces gestes empreints de noblesse qui la caracterisaient : -- Et meme si c'etait vrai, pourquoi n'en parlerions-nous pas ?...

eng: "You might so easily have made a mistake."
fr: 'Vous pouvez si bien vous etre trompe !'

eng: "Her quiet lucidity startled him, but did not mislead him into thinking her insensible."
fr: 'Sa calme lucidite etonna Archer ; mais sous les grands bords du chapeau, il vit la paleur du visage, et remarqua un leger fremissement des narines au-dessus des levres immobiles et resolues.'

eng: "She looked downward too, disturbing the pattern with the point of her sunshade while she struggled for expression."
fr: 'Elle abaissa son regard, suivant du bout de son ombrelle le dessin des feuilles sur le chemin, et cherchant visiblement ses paroles.'

eng: "Yes," she said at length. "You might want--once for all--to settle the question: it's one way."
fr: '-- Vous pourriez desirer, une fois pour toutes, trancher la situation... C'est un moyen.'

eng: "Well--?" he questioned, sitting down on the bench, and looking up at her with a frown that he tried to make playful.
fr: '-- Expliquons-nous, ma cherie, dit-il, se rasseyant.'

eng: "She dropped back into her seat and went on:"
fr: 'Elle s\'assit a cote de lui et continua :'

eng: "You mustn't think that a girl knows as little as her parents imagine."
fr: 'Ne croyez pas que les jeunes filles soient aussi ignorantes que l'imaginent leurs parents...'

eng: "One hears and one notices--one has one's feelings and ideas."
fr: 'On ecoute, on observe ; on a ses sentiments et ses idees...'

eng: "He lowered his head, staring at the black leaf-pattern on the sunny path at their feet."
fr: 'Il baissa la tete, regardant l'ombre des feuilles sur le chemin ensoleille :'

eng: "And once I saw you sitting together on the verandah at a dance--and when she came back into the house her face was sad, and I felt sorry for her;"
fr: 'Je vous ai vus une fois ensemble sous la veranda, vous et elle, a un bal... Quand elle est rentree au salon, elle etait triste et m'a fait de la peine...'

eng: "And of course, long before you told me that you cared for me, I'd known that there was some one else you were interested in; every one was talking about it two years ago at Newport."
fr: 'Longtemps avant que vous vous soyez declare, j'ai su que vous etiez occupe de quelqu'un... Tout le monde en parlait a Newport il y a deux ans...'

eng: "I remembered it afterward, when we were engaged."
fr: '~~~ Je m\'en suis souvenue apres, quand nous avons ete fiances.'

eng: "Mistakes are always easy to make; but if I had made one of the kind you suggest, is it likely that I should be imploring you to hasten our marriage?"
fr: '-- Si je m'etais trompe, pourquoi vous supplierais-je de hater notre mariage ?'

eng: Her voice had sunk almost to a whisper, and she sat clasping and unclasping her hands about the handle of her sunshade.
fr: Sa voix s'eteignait dans un murmure, elle serrait et desserrait ses mains sur le manche de son ombrelle.

eng: What sort of a life could we build on such foundations?"
fr: Comment pourrions-nous commencer la vie ainsi ?'

eng: And I want to believe that it would be the same with you.
fr: et je veux croire que vous partagez mon sentiment...

eng: I couldn't have my happiness made out of a wrong--an unfairness--to somebody else.
fr: Je ne voudrais pas devoir mon bonheur a un tort, a une deloyaute envers une autre,

eng: "But that's what I want to know, Newland--what I ought to know.
fr: "Mais c'est ce que je veux savoir, Newland, ce que j'ai le droit de savoir...

eng: "I meant, the truth about the old story you speak of."
fr: "La verite, veux-je dire, a propos de cette vieille histoire dont vous parlez."

eng: She raised her head quickly.
fr: Elle releva vivement la tete :

eng: He kept his hand over hers.
fr: Il continuait a tenir ses mains.

eng: The young man laid his upon them with a gentle pressure; his heart dilated with an inexpressible relief.
fr: Le jeune homme les prit, les pressant legerement ; son coeur se dilatait dans un soulagement ineffable.

eng: "Then there is a truth I don't know?"
fr: "Il y a donc, a propos de vous, une verite que j'ignore ? je ne sais pas ?"

eng: "My dear child--was THAT it? If you only knew the truth!"
fr: "Chere enfant ! Est-ce la ce qui vous troublait ! Si seulement vous saviez la verite !"

eng: Her face had taken on a look of such tragic courage that he felt like bowing himself down at her feet.
fr: Le visage de la jeune fille avait revetu un air de si tragique resolution qu'il se sentit pres de se prosterner a ses pieds.

eng: "I've wanted to say this for a long time," she went on.
fr: -- Je voulais vous le dire depuis longtemps, continua-t-elle.

eng: "I've wanted to tell you that, when two people really love each other, I understand that there may be situations which make it right that they should--should go against public opinion. ~~~ And if you feel yourself in any way pledged ... pledged to the person we've spoken of ... and if there is any way ... any way in which you can fulfill your pledge ... even by her getting a divorce ... Newland, don't give her up because of me!"
fr: Je voulais vous dire que, quand deux etres s'aiment veritablement, je comprends qu'il puisse y avoir des situations qui donnent le droit d'agir contre l'opinion publique... Et si vous vous sentez le moins du monde engage, -- engage envers la personne dont nous avons parle... et s'il y a un moyen, -- un moyen de remplir vos engagements -- meme au prix de son divorce... Newland, n'essayez pas de vous soustraire a votre parole a cause de moi.

eng: His surprise at discovering that her fears had fastened upon an episode so remote and so completely of the past as his love-affair with Mrs. Thorley Rushworth gave way to wonder at the generosity of her view.
fr: Archer fut etonne de decouvrir que les craintes de la jeune fille visaient a un episode aussi completement entre dans le passe que sa liaison avec Mrs Thorley Rushworth ; mais son etonnement fit bientot place a une vive admiration pour la generosite de sa fiancee.

eng: There was something superhuman in an attitude so recklessly unorthodox, and if other problems had not pressed on him he would have been lost in wonder at the prodigy of the Wellands' daughter urging him to marry his former mistress.
fr: Il etait trop preoccupe pour s'emerveiller du prodige de cette heresie chez la fille des Welland : lui conseiller d'epouser son ancienne maitresse !

eng: But he was still dizzy with the glimpse of the precipice they had skirted, and full of a new awe at the mystery of young-girlhood.
fr: Il etait encore tout emu du coup d'oeil jete sur le precipice que tous deux venaient de cotoyer, et plein d'epouvante devant le mystere d'une ame de jeune fille.

eng: For a moment he could not speak; then he said: "There is no pledge--no obligation whatever--of the kind you think.
fr: Il put enfin articuler : -- Je n'ai pas d'engagement, pas d'obligation du genre que vous imaginez...

eng: Such cases don't always--present themselves quite as simply as ...
fr: Tout n'est pas aussi simple que... mais ca ne fait rien...

eng: But that's no matter ... ~~~ I love your generosity, because I feel as you do about those things ... ~~~ I feel that each case must be judged individually, on its own merits ... irrespective of stupid conventionalities ...
fr: J'adore votre generosite, car je juge ces choses comme vous-meme... Chaque cas doit etre considere individuellement, selon sa valeur reelle, -- sans tenir compte de l'opinion...

eng: I mean, each woman's right to her liberty--" He pulled himself up, startled by the turn his thoughts had taken, and went on, looking at her with a smile: "Since you understand so many things, dearest, can't you go a little farther, and understand the uselessness of our submitting to another form of the same foolish conventionalities?
fr: Toute femme a droit a sa liberte. ~~~ -- Il se redressa, gene par la tournure que ses paroles avaient prise et continua en souriant : -- Puisque vous comprenez tant de choses, ma cherie, ne pouvez-vous pas admettre que nous puissions nous soustraire a une autre forme de ces memes banales conventions ?...

eng: If there's no one and nothing between us, isn't that an argument for marrying quickly, rather than for more delay?"
fr: Si personne et si rien ne nous separe, n'est-ce pas une raison pour nous marier bientot ?

eng: She flushed with joy and lifted her face to his; as he bent to it he saw that her eyes were full of happy tears.
fr: Elle leva son visage vers lui, et Newland, se penchant sur elle, vit dans ses yeux des larmes de bonheur.

eng: But in another moment she seemed to have descended from her womanly eminence to helpless and timorous girlhood; and he understood that her courage and initiative were all for others, and that she had none for herself.
fr: Mais un moment apres, elle sembla descendre des hauteurs ou elle s'etait tenue et retrouver ses timidites de jeune fille. ~~~ Il comprit qu'elle n'avait de courage et d'initiative que pour les autres, mais non pour elle-meme.

eng: It was evident that the effort of speaking had been much greater than her studied composure betrayed, and that at his first word of reassurance she had dropped back into the usual, as a too-adventurous child takes refuge in its mother's arms.
fr: Evidemment, l'effort qu'elle avait fait pour parler etait beaucoup plus grand que ne le revelait son attitude ; au premier mot rassurant de son fiance, elle reculait comme un enfant trop aventureux qui se jette dans les bras de sa mere.

eng: XVII. "Your cousin the Countess called on mother while you were away," Janey Archer announced to her brother on the evening of his return.
fr: XVII -- Ta cousine, la comtesse Olenska, est venue voir maman pendant ton absence. Ce fut Janey qui annonca la nouvelle a Newland, le soir de son retour, pendant le diner.

eng: May seemed to be aware of his disappointment, but without knowing how to alleviate it; and they stood up and walked silently home.
fr: May semblait se rendre compte de sa deception, sans trouver un moyen de la dissiper. Ils se leverent et rentrerent silencieusement.

eng: Mrs. Archer did not regard her seclusion from the world as a reason for being forgotten by it; and Newland guessed that she was slightly annoyed that he should be surprised by Madame Olenska's visit.
fr: Mrs Archer ne considerait pas son eloignement du monde comme une raison d'en etre oubliee, et Newland comprit qu'il l'avait legerement froissee en s'etonnant de la visite de Mme Olenska.

eng: "She had on a black velvet polonaise with jet buttons, and a tiny green monkey muff; I never saw her so stylishly dressed," Janey continued.
fr: -- Elle portait une polonaise en velours noir, avec des boutons de jais et un petit manchon en singe ; je ne l'ai jamais vue plus elegante, continua Janey...

eng: "She came alone, early on Sunday afternoon; luckily the fire was lit in the drawing-room. She had one of those new card-cases."
fr: Elle est venue seule, dimanche, de bonne heure ; heureusement, le feu etait allume dans le salon. Elle avait un de ces nouveaux porte-cartes.

eng: Archer had no heart to go on pleading with her; he was too much disappointed at the vanishing of the new being who had cast that one deep look at him from her transparent eyes.
fr: Archer n'insista pas : il etait trop decourage d'avoir vu s'evanouir la femme nouvelle qui l'avait regarde du fond de ses yeux clairs.

eng: The young man, who was dining alone with his mother and sister, glanced up in surprise and saw Mrs. Archer's gaze demurely bent on her plate.
fr: Surpris, le jeune homme regarda sa mere, qui avait les yeux baisses sur son assiette.

eng: She said she wanted to know us because you'd been so good to her."
fr: Elle a dit vouloir nous connaitre, parce que tu avais ete si bon pour elle !...

eng: Newland laughed.
fr: Archer se mit a rire.

eng: "Madame Olenska always takes that tone about her friends.
fr: -- Mme Olenska parle toujours ainsi de ses amis...

eng: "I hope you liked her, mother."
fr: 'J'espere qu'elle vous a plu, maman...'

eng: "She's very happy at being among her own people again."
fr: 'Elle est tres heureuse d'etre revenue parmi les siens...'

eng: Archer had left St. Augustine charged with many messages for old Mrs. Mingott; and a day or two after his return to town he called on her.
fr: 'Archer avait quitte Saint-Augustin, charge de nombreux messages pour la vieille Mrs Mingott : un ou deux jours apres son retour, il alla la voir.'

eng: "Ah," said her son, "they're not alike."
fr: 'Assurement, elles ne se ressemblent pas, repondit son fils.'

eng: "It's just my old-fashioned feeling; dear May is my ideal," said Mrs. Archer.
fr: 'C'est que je suis une personne d'autrefois... La chere May est mon ideal, dit Mrs Archer.'

eng: "I must say she seems thankful to be here."
fr: 'Je dois avouer qu'elle parait reconnaissante de notre accueil...'

eng: "She certainly lays herself out to please, even when she is calling on an old lady."
fr: 'Elle fait certainement tout ce qu'elle peut pour etre aimable et se rendre agreable, meme quand elle vient voir une vieille dame...'

eng: "Mother doesn't think her simple," Janey interjected, her eyes screwed upon her brother's face.
fr: 'Maman trouve qu'elle manque de simplicite, ajouta Janey, cherchant a lire sur le visage de son frere.'

eng: "Yes, so she told us," said Mrs. Archer.
fr: 'Oui, elle nous l'a dit, observa Mrs Archer.'

eng: Mrs. Archer drew her lips together.
fr: 'Mrs Archer serra les levres.'

eng: The old lady received him with unusual warmth; she was grateful to him for persuading the Countess Olenska to give up the idea of a divorce; and when he told her that he had deserted the office without leave, and rushed down to St. Augustine simply because he wanted to see May, she gave an adipose chuckle and patted his knee with her puff-ball hand.
fr: La vieille dame le recut avec empressement, et lui temoigna sa reconnaissance qu'il eut obtenu de la comtesse Olenska de renoncer au divorce. ~~~ Quand le jeune homme lui apprit qu'il s'etait evade de New-York dans le seul dessein de voir May, Mrs Mingott fit entendre un petit rire gras et lui frappa doucement le genou de sa main potelee. ~~~ -- Ah !

eng: "Ah, ah--so you kicked over the traces, did you?
fr: ah ! ~~~ c'est ainsi que vous lachez le travail !

eng: And I suppose Augusta and Welland pulled long faces, and behaved as if the end of the world had come?
fr: Augusta et Welland ont du faire grise mine ; ils ont du croire que le monde tournait a l'envers...

eng: But little May--she knew better, I'll be bound?"
fr: Mais la petite May ?... ~~~ Ca n'a pas ete son avis, bien sur ?...

eng: "I hoped she did; but after all she wouldn't agree to what I'd gone down to ask for."
fr: '-- Je l'espere ; cependant, elle ne m'a pas accorde ce que j'etais alle lui demander...'

eng: "Wouldn't she indeed? And what was that?"
fr: '-- Vraiment... Et qu'etait-ce donc ?...'

eng: "I wanted to get her to promise that we should be married in April. What's the use of our wasting another year?"
fr: '-- La promesse que nous serions maries en avril. Pourquoi perdre encore un an ?...'

eng: Mrs. Manson Mingott screwed up her little mouth into a grimace of mimic prudery and twinkled at him through malicious lids.
fr: Mrs Manson Mingott prit un petit air de pruderie ironique.

eng: "Ah, these Mingotts--all alike!"
fr: 'Oh ! ces Mingott ! ~~~ Tous les memes !'

eng: "'Ask Mamma,' I suppose--the usual story."
fr: '-- << Demandez a maman ! >> La formule habituelle !'

eng: Born in a rut, and you can't root 'em out of it.
fr: Nes dans une orniere d'ou rien ne peut les tirer.

eng: Nobody ever HAD built above Fortieth Street--no, says I, nor above the Battery either, before Christopher Columbus discovered America.
fr: Personne ne s'etait aventure plus loin que la Quarantieme Rue, et moi, je dis : Personne, non plus, n'habitait New-York, avant que Christophe Colomb eut decouvert l'Amerique.

eng: No, no; not one of them wants to be different; they're as scared of it as the small-pox.
fr: Non, non, ils sont tous pareils : ils veulent tous faire ce que tous les autres auraient fait.

eng: When I built this house you'd have thought I was moving to California!
fr: Quand j'ai bati cette maison, on aurait cru que je partais pour la Californie.

eng: Ah, my dear Mr. Archer, I thank my stars I'm nothing but a vulgar Spicer; but there's not one of my own children that takes after me but my little Ellen."
fr: Je rends grace au ciel de n'etre qu'une humble Spicer ; il n'y a, parmi tous les miens, que ma petite Ellen qui tienne de moi.

eng: She broke off, still twinkling at him, and asked, with the casual irrelevance of old age: "Now, why in the world didn't you marry my little Ellen?"
fr: Elle s'interrompit, le regardant toujours de ses yeux clignotants, puis demanda : -- Pourquoi n'avez-vous pas epouse ma petite Ellen ?

eng: Archer laughed.
fr: Archer rit.

eng: "For one thing, she wasn't there to be married."
fr: -- D'abord parce qu'elle n'etait pas la...

eng: "No--to be sure; more's the pity."
fr: Ca, c'est vrai. C'est bien dommage.

eng: And now it's too late; her life is finished."
fr: Maintenant il est trop tard : sa vie est finie.

eng: She spoke with the cold-blooded complacency of the aged throwing earth into the grave of young hopes.
fr: Elle parlait avec la froide indifference des vieillards jetant de la terre sur la tombe de jeunes esperances.

eng: The young man's heart grew chill, and he said hurriedly: "Can't I persuade you to use your influence with the Wellands, Mrs. Mingott?
fr: Archer eut froid au coeur et s'empressa de dire : -- Oserais-je vous demander d'employer votre influence aupres des Welland ?

eng: "When you were a little boy I've no doubt you liked to be helped first."
fr: "Quand vous etiez petit, je suis sure que vous aimiez a etre servi le premier."

eng: "She threw back her head with a laugh that made her chins ripple like little waves."
fr: "Elle renversa la tete d'un mouvement qui fit onduler les petites vagues de son double menton."

eng: "Ah!"
fr: "-- Ah ! ~~~ tiens !..." (Partial match)

eng: "Old Catherine beamed on him approvingly."
fr: "La vieille Catherine le regarda, epanouie :"

eng: "I wasn't made for long engagements."
fr: "Je ne suis pas fait pour les longues fiancailles."

eng: "No; I can see that."
fr: "Je vois cela."

eng: "You've got a quick eye."
fr: "Vous avez la mine eveillee."

eng: "Ah, here's my Ellen now!"
fr: Voici ma petite Ellen !

eng: she exclaimed, as the portieres parted behind her.
fr: s'ecria-t-elle, en voyant s'ouvrir les portieres.

eng: Madame Olenska came forward with a smile.
fr: Mme Olenska s'avanca souriante.

eng: Her face looked vivid and happy, and she held out her hand gaily to Archer while she stooped to her grandmother's kiss.
fr: Elle tendit gaiment sa main a Archer, tout en se penchant pour recevoir le baiser de sa grand'mere.

eng: "And what did he answer?"
fr: '-- Et qu'a-t-il repondu ?... '

eng: "Oh, my darling, I leave you to find that out!"
fr: '-- Oh ! mon amour, je te le laisse a deviner.'

eng: "I was just saying to him, my dear: 'Now, why didn't you marry my little Ellen?'"
fr: '-- Ma cherie, j'etais justement en train de lui dire : Pourquoi n'avez-vous pas epouse ma petite Ellen ?... '

eng: Madame Olenska looked at Archer, still smiling.
fr: Mme Olenska regarda Archer en souriant toujours :

eng: He's been down to Florida to see his sweetheart."
fr: Il est alle en Floride, voir sa fiancee.

eng: "Yes, I know."
fr: -- Oui, je sais.

eng: She still looked at him.
fr: -- La comtesse Olenska continuait a regarder Archer.

eng: "I went to see your mother, to ask where you'd gone.
fr: -- Je suis allee chez votre mere, pour lui demander ou vous etiez.

eng: I sent a note that you never answered, and I was afraid you were ill." He muttered something about leaving unexpectedly, in a great hurry, and having intended to write to her from St. Augustine.
fr: Je vous avais envoye un mot auquel vous n'avez pas repondu, et je craignais que vous ne fussiez malade... ~~~ Il murmura quelque chose sur un depart imprevu, precipite, et sur l'intention qu'il avait eue de lui ecrire de Saint-Augustin.

eng: "And of course once you were there you never thought of me again!"
fr: -- Et naturellement, une fois la, vous n'avez plus pense a moi ?

eng: She continued to beam on him with a gaiety that might have been a studied assumption of indifference.
fr: Elle gardait encore cet air heureux, qui pouvait n'etre que le masque etudie de l'indifference.

eng: "If she still needs me, she's determined not to let me see it," he thought, stung by her manner.
fr: << Si elle a encore besoin de moi, elle est decidee a ne pas me le laisser voir, >> pensa-t-il, pique de l'attitude de la jeune femme.

eng: He wanted to thank her for having been to see his mother, but under the ancestress's malicious eye he felt himself tongue-tied and constrained.
fr: Il voulait la remercier d'etre allee voir sa mere ; mais sous les yeux malicieux de l'aieule, il se sentait gene. ~~~ -- Regarde-le.

eng: "Look at him--in such hot haste to get married that he took French leave and rushed down to implore the silly girl on his knees!
fr: Il est si presse de se marier, qu'il a file a la francaise, pour aller implorer a genoux cette petite sotte. ~~~ Voila un amoureux !

eng: The overcoats were in fact the very strangest he had ever seen under a polite roof; and it took but a glance to assure himself that neither of them belonged to Julius Beaufort.
fr: Les pardessus etaient des plus etranges ; d'un coup d'oeil, il vit qu'il n'y en avait aucun qui put appartenir a Julius Beaufort.

eng: Few as they had been, they were thick with memories.
fr: Si breves qu'elles eussent ete, elles etaient pourtant lourdes d'emotions.

eng: This lady, who was long, lean and loosely put together, was clad in raiment intricately looped and fringed, with plaids and stripes and bands of plain colour disposed in a design to which the clue seemed missing.
fr: Cette dame longue, maigre, degingandee, etait enveloppee de draperies compliquees : ses cheveux, decolores, etaient surmontes d'un peigne espagnol et d'une mantille de dentelle noire. Des mitaines de soie, reprisees, couvraient ses mains deformees par les rhumatismes.

eng: Her hair, which had tried to turn white and only succeeded in fading, was surmounted by a Spanish comb and black lace scarf, and silk mittens, visibly darned, covered her rheumatic hands.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text - details already covered)

eng: Beside her, in a cloud of cigar-smoke, stood the owners of the two overcoats, both in morning clothes that they had evidently not taken off since morning.
fr: A cote d'elle, derriere un nuage de fumee, se tenaient les proprietaires des deux pardessus. Ils etaient encore en vestons du matin.

eng: In one of the two, Archer, to his surprise, recognised Ned Winsett; the other and older, who was unknown to him, and whose gigantic frame declared him to be the wearer of the "Macfarlane," had a feebly leonine head with crumpled grey hair, and moved his arms with large pawing gestures, as though he were distributing lay blessings to a kneeling multitude.
fr: L'un d'eux etait Ned Winsett ; l'autre, plus age, tres grand, etait evidemment le possesseur du << macfarlane. >> Il avait une tete de lion bonasse a criniere grise ; et il remuait ses bras avec de grands gestes benins, comme s'il distribuait des benedictions sur une foule agenouillee.

eng: These three persons stood together on the hearth-rug, their eyes fixed on an extraordinarily large bouquet of crimson roses, with a knot of purple pansies at their base, that lay on the sofa where Madame Olenska usually sat.
fr: Ces trois personnes consideraient un magnifique bouquet de roses rouges dont les longues tiges disparaissaient sous une immense touffe de pensees. Le bouquet etait place sur le sofa ou se tenait habituellement Mme Olenska.

eng: "What they must have cost at this season--though of course it's the sentiment one cares about!"
fr: -- Ce qu'elles ont du couter dans cette saison !... Mais il n'y a que l'intention qui compte ! disait la dame sur un ton de staccato quand Archer entra.

eng: The three turned with surprise at his appearance, and the lady, advancing, held out her hand.
fr: Tous trois se retournerent, et la dame, s'avancant, tendit la main a Archer.

eng: "Dear Mr. Archer--almost my cousin Newland!"
fr: -- Cher Mr Archer ! Presque mon cousin Newland ! ~~~ dit-elle.

eng: "I am the Marchioness Manson."
fr: Je suis la marquise Manson.

eng: Archer bowed, and she continued: "My Ellen has taken me in for a few days. I came from Cuba, where I have been spending the winter with Spanish friends--such delightful distinguished people: the highest nobility of old Castile--how I wish you could know them! But I was called away by our dear great friend here, Dr. Carver. You don't know Dr. Agathon Carver, founder of the Valley of Love Community?"
fr: Elle continua : -- Mon Ellen me garde pour quelques jours. J'arrive de Cuba, ou j'ai passe l'hiver avec des amis Espagnols : des gens tres distingues, de la plus vieille noblesse de Castille. J'ai ete appelee ici par notre cher grand ami, le docteur Carver. Vous ne connaissez pas le docteur Agathon Carver, fondateur de la communaute de << La vallee de l'amour ? >>

eng: Dr. Carver inclined his leonine head, and the Marchioness continued: "Ah, New York--New York--how little the life of the spirit has reached it! But I see you do know Mr. Winsett."
fr: Le docteur Carver inclina sa tete leonine, et la marquise continua : -- Ah ! New-York, New-York, combien peu tu marches dans la voie de l'Esprit ! Mr Archer, je vois que vous connaissez Mr Winsett ?

eng: "Oh, yes--I reached him some time ago; but not by that route," Winsett said with his dry smile.
fr: -- Oui, je suis arrive jusqu'a lui, il y a quelque temps, mais pas par la voie de l'Esprit, repliqua Winsett avec un sourire caustique.

eng: The Marchioness shook her head reprovingly. "How do you know, Mr. Winsett? The spirit bloweth where it listeth."
fr: La marquise secoua la tete avec reprobation... -- Qu'en savez-vous, Mr Winsett ?... L'esprit souffle ou il veut...

eng: "List--oh, list!" interjected Dr. Carver in a stentorian murmur. "But do sit down, Mr. Archer. We four have been having a delightful little dinner together, and my child has gone up to dress. She expects you; she will be down in a moment. We were just admiring these marvellous flowers, which will surprise her when she reappears."
fr: -- Ou il veut, repeta le docteur Carver d'une voix vibrante. -- Mais asseyez-vous donc, Mr Archer. Nous avons eu un delicieux petit diner, tous les quatre, et ma chere enfant est montee s'habiller. Elle vous attend. Elle sera ici dans un moment. Nous admirions ces fleurs merveilleuses, qui la surprendront quand elle entrera.

eng: Winsett remained on his feet. "I'm afraid I must be off. Please tell Madame Olenska that we shall all feel lost when she abandons our street. This house has been an oasis."
fr: Winsett resta debout. -- Il faut que je me sauve. Veuillez dire a Mme Olenska que nous sommes bien attristes de son depart. ~~~ Cette maison a ete une oasis...

eng: "Ah, but she won't abandon YOU. Poetry and art are the breath of life to her. It IS poetry you write, Mr. Winsett?"
fr: -- Elle ne vous abandonnera pas. La poesie et l'art font partie de sa vie. Vous etes poete, Mr Winsett ?...

eng: "Well, no; but I sometimes read it," said Winsett, including the group in a general nod and slipping out of the room.
fr: -- Pas precisement. Mais je lis quelquefois des vers, dit Winsett, saluant le groupe du seuil de la porte.

eng: "A caustic spirit--un peu sauvage. But so witty; Dr. Carver, you DO think him witty?"
fr: -- Il est si spirituel !... Ne trouvez-vous pas qu'il est spirituel, docteur Carver ?...

eng: "I never think of wit," said Dr. Carver severely.
fr: -- Je ne m'occupe jamais de ce qui est spirituel, repondit severement le docteur Carver.

eng: The young man saw at once that his hostess was not in the room; then, with surprise, he discovered another lady standing by the fire.
fr: Le jeune homme vit tout de suite que Mme Olenska n'y etait pas ; puis il eut la surprise de decouvrir une autre dame installee aupres du feu.

eng: Archer raised his eyebrows enquiringly at Nastasia, who raised hers in return with a fatalistic "Gia!" as she threw open the drawing-room door.
fr: Archer questionna des yeux Nastasia, qui lui repondit par sa mimique ordinaire, en prononcant son fataliste Gia, tandis qu'elle ouvrait la porte du salon.

eng: On it lay a ragged grey scarf and an odd felt hat of semiclerical shape.
fr: Au-dessus etaient poses un foulard defraichi et un vieux chapeau, de forme vaguement clericale.

eng: This garment, which appeared to be made for a person of prodigious size, had evidently seen long and hard wear, and its greenish-black folds gave out a moist sawdusty smell suggestive of prolonged sessions against bar-room walls.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text - details already covered)

eng: That's something like a lover--that's the way handsome Bob Spicer carried off my poor mother; and then got tired of her before I was weaned--though they only had to wait eight months for me!
fr: 'C'est ainsi que le beau Bob Spicer a persuade ma pauvre mere, et ensuite s'est fatigue d'elle avant que je fusse sevree !... Cependant je ne me suis fait attendre que huit mois.

eng: But there--you're not a Spicer, young man; luckily for you and for May.
fr: Mais voila ! ~~~ vous n'etes pas un Spicer, jeune homme ; heureusement pour vous et pour May.

eng: It's only my poor Ellen that has kept any of their wicked blood; the rest of them are all model Mingotts," cried the old lady scornfully.
fr: Il n'y a que ma pauvre Ellen qui tienne d'eux : tous les autres sont des modeles de Mingott, s'ecria la vieille dame dedaigneusement.

eng: Archer was aware that Madame Olenska, who had seated herself at her grandmother's side, was still thoughtfully scrutinising him.
fr: Archer s'apercut que Mme Olenska, qui s'etait assise aupres de sa grand'mere, continuait, songeuse, a l'observer.

eng: The gaiety had faded from her eyes, and she said with great gentleness: "Surely, Granny, we can persuade them between us to do as he wishes."
fr: La gaite avait disparu de ses yeux et elle disait tres doucement : -- Surement, grand'mere, a nous deux, nous pourrons obtenir ce que Mr Archer desire.

eng: Archer rose to go, and as his hand met Madame Olenska's he felt that she was waiting for him to make some allusion to her unanswered letter.
fr: Archer se leva pour s'en aller. Quand sa main toucha celle de Mme Olenska, il comprit qu'elle attendait qu'il fit une allusion quelconque a la lettre restee sans reponse.

eng: "When can I see you?"
fr: -- Quand pourrai-je vous rencontrer ? demanda-t-il.

eng: "Whenever you like; but it must be soon if you want to see the little house again. I am moving next week."
fr: -- Quand vous voudrez ; mais il faudra que ce soit bientot, si vous desirez revoir la petite maison. Je demenage la semaine prochaine...

eng: A pang shot through him at the memory of his lamplit hours in the low-studded drawing-room.
fr: Une angoisse etreignit Archer au souvenir des heures passees dans le petit salon au plafond bas.

eng: "Ah--ah--you never think of wit! How merciless he is to us weak mortals, Mr. Archer! But he lives only in the life of the spirit; and tonight he is mentally preparing the lecture he is to deliver presently at Mrs. Blenker's.
fr: -- C'est qu'il est sans pitie pour nos faiblesses, Mr Archer : il ne vit que de la vie de l'ame ; ce soir il prepare mentalement une conference qu'il doit faire tout a l'heure chez les Blenker.'

eng: "Tomorrow evening?"
fr: -- Demain soir ? fit-il...

eng: The next day was a Sunday, and if she were "going out" on a Sunday evening it could, of course, be only to Mrs. Lemuel Struthers's.
fr: Le lendemain etait un dimanche : si Ellen sortait, ce ne pouvait etre que pour se rendre chez Mrs Lemuel Struthers.

eng: He felt a slight movement of annoyance, not so much at her going there (for he rather liked her going where she pleased in spite of the van der Luydens), but because it was the kind of house at which she was sure to meet Beaufort, where she must have known beforehand that she would meet him--and where she was probably going for that purpose.
fr: Il en eprouva une legere contrariete, parce que c'etait une maison ou elle etait sure de rencontrer Beaufort. Elle ne pouvait l'ignorer : peut-etre, meme, est-ce pour cela qu'elle y allait.

eng: "Very well; tomorrow evening," he repeated, inwardly resolved that he would not go early, and that by reaching her door late he would either prevent her from going to Mrs. Struthers's, or else arrive after she had started--which, all things considered, would no doubt be the simplest solution.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was only half-past eight, after all, when he rang the bell under the wisteria; not as late as he had intended by half an hour--but a singular restlessness had driven him to her door.
fr: Le lendemain, des huit heures et demie, il sonnait a la porte encadree de glycine. Il fut surpris de trouver des chapeaux et des pardessus dans le vestibule de Mme Olenska.

eng: He reflected, however, that Mrs. Struthers's Sunday evenings were not like a ball, and that her guests, as if to minimise their delinquency, usually went early.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The one thing he had not counted on, in entering Madame Olenska's hall, was to find hats and overcoats there.
fr: Pourquoi l'avoir invite a venir de bonne heure, si elle avait du monde a diner ?

eng: Why had she bidden him to come early if she was having people to dine?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text - already covered)

eng: On a closer inspection of the garments besides which Nastasia was laying his own, his resentment gave way to curiosity.
fr: Un examen plus attentif des vetements eveilla sa curiosite.

eng: One was a shaggy yellow ulster of "reach-me-down" cut, the other a very old and rusty cloak with a cape--something like what the French called a "Macfarlane."
fr: A cote d'un ulster jaune, se trouvait un vieux manteau a pelerine, tout rape. Ce dernier paraissait appartenir a une personne de taille exceptionnelle, et avait evidemment vu des temps tres durs, car de ses plis verdatres, s'exhalait une odeur de poussiere humide.

eng: "Tomorrow; yes; but early. I'm going out."
fr: -- Oui, demain. ~~~ Mais de bonne heure, car je dois sortir...

eng: Carver, would there be time, before you start for the Blenkers' to explain to Mr. Archer your illuminating discovery of the Direct Contact?
fr: Docteur Carver, auriez-vous le temps, avant de partir chez les Blenker, d'expliquer a Mr Archer votre lumineuse decouverte sur le << Contact Direct ?

eng: But no; I see it is nearly nine o'clock, and we have no right to detain you while so many are waiting for your message." ~~~ Dr.
fr: >> Mais non, je vois qu'il est pres de neuf heures, et nous n'avons pas le droit de vous retenir quand tant de gens aspirent a vous entendre...

eng: Carver looked slightly disappointed at this conclusion, but, having compared his ponderous gold time-piece with Madame Olenska's little travelling-clock, he reluctantly gathered up his mighty limbs for departure.
fr: Le docteur Carver parut legerement desappointe de cette conclusion, mais ayant compare l'heure de sa massive montre avec celle de la petite pendule de Mme Olenska, il se prepara a partir.

eng: "Little did you know that at that very moment I was being appealed to: being approached, in fact--from the other side of the Atlantic!"
fr: Vous ignoriez qu'a ce meme moment on s'adressait a moi, on me demandait mon concours de l'autre cote de l'Atlantique...'

eng: "Ah, but in doing it--in doing it you were the unconscious instrument of--of--what word have we moderns for Providence, Mr. Archer?" cried the lady, tilting her head on one side and drooping her lids mysteriously.
fr: -- Mais en la conseillant ainsi, vous avez ete l'inconscient instrument de... Nous modernes, quel nom avons-nous pour << la Providence, >> Mr Archer ?...

eng: "I shall see you later, dear friend?" he suggested to the Marchioness, who replied with a smile: "As soon as Ellen's carriage comes I will join you; I do hope the lecture won't have begun."
fr: '-- Je vous verrai plus tard, chere amie ? dit-il a la marquise, qui repondit avec un sourire : -- Des que la voiture d'Ellen arrivera, j'irai vous rejoindre. J'espere que la conference ne sera pas commencee.'

eng: The young man listened with considerable embarrassment. Was there any one, he wondered, to whom Madame Olenska had not proclaimed his intervention in her private affairs?
fr: Newland Archer ecoutait ces declarations avec un extreme embarras, se demandant s'il etait une personne au monde a laquelle Mme Olenska se fut abstenue de raconter la part qu'il avait prise dans ses affaires privees.

eng: Archer murmured his pleasure at their meeting, and the Marchioness continued, in her low sighing accents: "I know everything, dear Mr. Archer--my child has told me all you have done for her. Your wise advice: your courageous firmness--thank heaven it was not too late!"
fr: Cher Mr Archer, mon enfant m'a dit tout ce que vous aviez fait pour elle, vos avis eclaires, votre courageuse fermete. Remercions le ciel qu'il n'ait pas ete trop tard !...

eng: "Madame Olenska exaggerates; I simply gave her a legal opinion, as she asked me to."
fr: -- Mme Olenska exagere. Je lui ai simplement donne l'avis juridique qu'elle m'a demande...

eng: Dr. Carver bowed himself out, and Mrs. Manson, with a sigh that might have been either of regret or relief, again waved Archer to a seat.
fr: Le docteur Carver disparut dans un salut. Mrs Manson, avec un soupir qui pouvait etre de regret ou de soulagement, invita de nouveau Archer a s'asseoir.

eng: "That," said Dr. Carver, "is unfortunate--but here is my card." He handed it to Archer, who read on it, in Gothic characters: +---------------------------+ | Agathon Carver | | The Valley of Love | | Kittasquattamy, N. Y. | +---------------------------+
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh, dear friend, if it were possible--I am sure she would be too happy. But I fear my Ellen counts on Mr. Archer herself."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Dr. Carver looked thoughtfully at Archer. "Perhaps, if this young gentleman is interested in my experiences, Mrs. Blenker might allow you to bring him with you?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ellen will be down in a moment; and before she comes, I am so glad of this quiet moment with you."
fr: '-- Ellen va descendre dans un instant ; mais auparavant, je serai tres heureuse de causer un peu avec vous...'

eng: She glanced over her shoulder, as though fearful of being overheard, and then, drawing her chair nearer, and raising a tiny ivory fan to her lips, breathed behind it: "By the Count himself--my poor, mad, foolish Olenski; who asks only to take her back on her own terms."
fr: Elle regarda par-dessus son epaule comme si elle craignait d'etre entendue et, rapprochant sa chaise, portant a ses levres un petit eventail d'ivoire, elle dit dans un souffle : -- C'est le comte lui-meme, mon pauvre fou d'Olenski, qui ne demande qu'a la reprendre sans conditions !...

eng: "Good God!"
fr: -- Grand Dieu !

eng: "I have his letter here."
fr: J'ai sa lettre la...

eng: "A letter?--Has Madame Olenska seen it?" Archer stammered, his brain whirling with the shock of the announcement.
fr: Une lettre ? Mme Olenska le sait-elle ? balbutia Archer, sentant la tete lui tourner.

eng: I don't defend poor Stanislas, though he has always called me his best friend.
fr: Je ne defends pas le pauvre Stanislas, quoiqu'il m'appelle sa meilleure amie.

eng: He does not defend himself--he casts himself at her feet: in my person.
fr: Il se jette aux pieds d'Ellen en ma personne.

eng: Archer exclaimed, springing up.
fr: 's'ecria Archer, en se levant d'un bond.

eng: She tapped her emaciated bosom.
fr: Elle frappa sur sa maigre poitrine.

eng: "You are horrified? Yes, of course; I understand."
fr: Vous etes epouvante ! Oui, je comprends.

eng: The Marchioness Manson shook her head softly.
fr: La marquise fit un geste negatif.

eng: "Time--time; I must have time.
fr: -- Du temps, du temps... il me faut du temps...

eng: 'I know my Ellen--haughty, intractable; shall I say, just a shade unforgiving?'
fr: 'Je connais mon Ellen, hautaine, intraitable, dirais-je presque implacable, pardonnant difficilement...'

eng: '"Ah, yes," the Marchioness acquiesced.'
fr: '~~~ dit la marquise.'

eng: '"So she describes it--my sensitive child!"
fr: 'C'est ainsi qu'elle decrit la maison de son mari !'

eng: 'But on the material side, Mr. Archer, if one may stoop to consider such things; do you know what she is giving up?'
fr: 'Mais du cote materiel, savez-vous ce qu'elle sacrifie ?'

eng: '"But, good heavens, to forgive is one thing; to go back into that hell--"
fr: 'Mais pardonner est une chose... retourner dans cet enfer, en est une autre.'

eng: Those roses there on the sofa--acres like them, under glass and in the open, in his matchless terraced gardens at Nice!
fr: Ces roses-la sur le canape ; mais il en a des kilometres, sous verre et a l'air libre, dans ses merveilleux jardins de Nice !

eng: Jewels--historic pearls: the Sobieski emeralds--sables,--but she cares nothing for all these!
fr: Et les bijoux, les perles historiques, les emeraudes de Sobieski, les zibelines ! ~~~ Bah ! ~~~ elle ne se soucie pas de tout cela.

eng: Art and beauty, those she does care for, she lives for, as I always have; and those also surrounded her.
fr: L'art et la beaute, voila ce qui l'attire... des tableaux, un mobilier sans prix, de la musique, une conversation brillante... et ca, ce sont des choses, cher monsieur, dont on n'a aucune idee ici.

eng: 'Pictures, priceless furniture, music, brilliant conversation--ah, that, my dear young man, if you'll excuse me, is what you've no conception of here!'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'And she had it all; and the homage of the greatest.'
fr: 'Elle possedait tout cela, et recevait les hommages des plus grands personnages...'

eng: 'She tells me she is not thought handsome in New York--good heavens!'
fr: 'Elle me dit qu'on ne la trouve pas jolie a New-York. Est-ce possible ?'

eng: 'Her portrait has been painted nine times; the greatest artists in Europe have begged for the privilege.'
fr: 'Mais son portrait a ete peint neuf fois ! Les plus grands artistes d'Europe ont sollicite le privilege de la faire poser.'

eng: Are these things nothing?
fr: Tout cela, n'est-ce rien ?

eng: He would have laughed if any one had foretold to him that his first sight of poor Medora Manson would have been in the guise of a messenger of Satan; but he was in no mood for laughing now, and she seemed to him to come straight out of the hell from which Ellen Olenska had just escaped.
fr: La marquise lui semblait venir en droite ligne de l'enfer qu'avait fui la comtesse Olenska.

eng: "And the remorse of an adoring husband?"
fr: 'Et le remords d'un mari qui l'adore ?...'

eng: As the Marchioness Manson rose to her climax her face assumed an expression of ecstatic retrospection which would have moved Archer's mirth had he not been numb with amazement.
fr: Le visage de la marquise Manson prit une telle expression d'extase retrospective qu'il aurait excite la gaite d'Archer, si Archer eut ete en humeur de rire.

eng: "She knows nothing yet--of all this?"
fr: -- Elle ne sait rien de tout cela ?

eng: "The truth is, Mr. Archer, I have been waiting to see you."
fr: "Mr Archer, je desirais beaucoup vous voir, car, des l'instant ou j'ai su la ferme attitude que vous aviez prise et votre influence sur ma niece, j'ai espere obtenir votre appui, vous convaincre..."

eng: "That she ought to go back?"
fr: "-- Qu'elle doit retourner chez son mari ?"

eng: "From the moment I heard of the firm stand you had taken, and of your influence over her, I hoped it might be possible to count on your support--to convince you ..."
fr: "Mr Archer, je desirais beaucoup vous voir, car, des l'instant ou j'ai su la ferme attitude que vous aviez prise et votre influence sur ma niece, j'ai espere obtenir votre appui, vous convaincre..."

eng: "he asked abruptly."
fr: "demanda-t-il vivement."

eng: "Who can tell?"
fr: "Mais qui peut dire ce qu'elle soupconne ?"

eng: "Nothing directly--but does she suspect?"
fr: "-- Elle ne sait rien positivement. Mais qui peut dire ce qu'elle soupconne ?"

eng: "Mrs. Manson laid a purple finger on her lips."
fr: "Mrs Manson porta son doigt sur ses levres."

eng: I would rather see her dead!"
fr: J'aimerais mieux la voir morte !

eng: cried the young man violently.
fr: s'ecria le jeune homme avec violence.

eng: Why a bouquet?
fr: Pourquoi un bouquet ?

eng: XVIII.
fr: XVIII --

eng: After all, marriage is marriage ... and my niece is still a wife..."
fr: Apres tout, le mariage est le mariage ; et ma niece est une femme mariee...

eng: I am not going to a ball;
fr: Je ne vais pas au bal !

eng: I am not a girl engaged to be married.'
fr: ~~~ Je ne suis pas une fiancee !'

eng: "Ah," she exclaimed, in a shrill voice that the young man had never heard, "who is ridiculous enough to send me a bouquet?
fr: -- Ah ! ~~~ s'ecria-t-elle, d'une voix que le jeune homme ne lui connaissait pas, qui ose m'envoyer un bouquet ?

eng: Her colour did not change, but a sort of white radiance of anger ran over her like summer lightning.
fr: Elle ne changea pas de couleur, mais un pale eclair de colere sembla jaillir d'elle ; ses yeux brillaient comme un ciel d'orage.

eng: And why tonight of all nights?
fr: Et surtout ce soir !

eng: "We were saying, my dear, that here was something beautiful to surprise you with," Mrs. Manson rejoined, rising to her feet and pointing archly to the flowers.
fr: -- Nous disions, ma cherie, qu'une magnifique surprise vous attendait, reprit Mrs Manson en designant les fleurs.

eng: "What are you two plotting together, aunt Medora?" Madame Olenska cried as she came into the room.
fr: -- Que complotez-vous tous les deux, tante Medora ? s'ecria Mme Olenska en entrant dans le salon.

eng: "Here she comes," she said in a rapid whisper;
fr: -- La voila ! chuchota-t-elle.

eng: but suddenly she lifted her head and listened.
fr: puis, tout a coup, elle leva la tete

eng: Madame Olenska stopped short and looked at the bouquet.
fr: Mme Olenska s'arreta court.

eng: and then, pointing to the bouquet on the sofa: "Am I to understand that you prefer THAT, Mr. Archer?
fr: ~~~ Et brusquement, indiquant le bouquet : -- Dois-je conclure que vous preferez ce que signifient ces fleurs, Mr Archer ?

eng: Everything about her shimmered and glimmered softly, as if her dress had been woven out of candle-beams; and she carried her head high, like a pretty woman challenging a roomful of rivals.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She was dressed as if for a ball.
fr: Elle etait paree comme pour un bal,

eng: "Ah," the Marchioness murmured, without visible resentment.
fr: '-- Ah ! ~~~ murmura la marquise, sans paraitre offensee.

eng: For a while she sat in her arm-chair, opening and shutting the absurd ivory fan between her mittened fingers;
fr: Elle resta assise, ouvrant et refermant son ridicule petit eventail d'ivoire de ses doigts gantes de mitaines ;

eng: But some people are always ridiculous."
fr: Il y a des gens qui ne manquent jamais une occasion d'etre ridicules !...

eng: His wife is ill--they may give her pleasure ...
fr: Sa femme est malade. Elles lui feront peut-etre plaisir...

eng: Tell the boy to carry them to the house three doors away, the house of Mr. Winsett, the dark gentleman who dined here.
fr: Dites au groom de les porter dans la maison de ce monsieur qui a dine ici ce soir.

eng: and then, as Nastasia stared protestingly: "But no--it's not the fault of the poor flowers.
fr: Et comme Nastasia, saisie, paraissait protester, elle ajouta : -- Apres tout, ce n'est pas la faute de ces pauvres fleurs.

eng: She turned back to the door, opened it, and called out: "Nastasia!"
fr: Elle se retourna vers la porte, l'ouvrit et appela : -- Nastasia !...

eng: The boy is out, you say? Then, my dear one, run yourself; here, put my cloak over you and fly.
fr: Le petit est sorti ? Alors, ma chere, courez-y vous-meme. Tenez, mettez mon manteau et filez !

eng: I want the thing out of the house immediately!
fr: Je veux que ces fleurs sortent de la maison immediatement !

eng: And, as you live, don't say they come from me!"
fr: Et sur votre ame, ne dites pas que c'est moi qui les envoie.

eng: The ubiquitous handmaiden promptly appeared, and Archer heard Madame Olenska say, in an Italian that she seemed to pronounce with intentional deliberateness in order that he might follow it: "Here--throw this into the dustbin!"
fr: La servante apparut, et Archer entendit Mme Olenska lui dire en italien : -- Tenez ! jetez cela a la boite aux ordures !

eng: She flung her velvet opera cloak over the maid's shoulders and turned back into the drawing-room, shutting the door sharply.
fr: Elle jeta son manteau de velours sur les epaules de la servante et rentra dans le salon, fermant la porte avec brusquerie.

eng: Her bosom was rising high under its lace, and for a moment Archer thought she was about to cry; but she burst into a laugh instead, and looking from the Marchioness to Archer, asked abruptly: "And you two--have you made friends!"
fr: Sa poitrine se soulevait sous les dentelles... Archer crut un moment qu'elle allait pleurer ; mais elle eclata de rire, regarda tour a tour la marquise et Archer, et demanda : -- Et vous deux ?

eng: "It's for Mr. Archer to say, darling; he has waited patiently while you were dressing."
fr: J'espere que vous faites une paire d'amis ?... -- C'est a Mr Archer de repondre, mon tresor ; il a attendu patiemment pendant que tu t'habillais...

eng: "Yes--I gave you time enough: my hair wouldn't go," Madame Olenska said, raising her hand to the heaped-up curls of her chignon.
fr: -- Oui, je vous en ai donne tout le temps. Je ne pouvais pas arriver a me coiffer, dit Mme Olenska, en portant la main aux boucles de son chignon.

eng: "But that reminds me: I see Dr. Carver is gone, and you'll be late at the Blenkers'. Mr. Archer, will you put my aunt in the carriage?"
fr: Mais je vois que le docteur Carver est parti, et vous serez en retard chez les Blenker. Mr Archer, voulez-vous mettre ma tante en voiture ?...

eng: Then she returned to the drawing-room, where Archer, on re-entering it, found her standing by the mantelpiece, examining herself in the mirror.
fr: Apres avoir accompagne la marquise jusqu'a la voiture, Archer retrouva Mme Olenska dans le salon.

eng: It was not usual, in New York society, for a lady to address her parlour-maid as "my dear one," and send her out on an errand wrapped in her own opera-cloak; and Archer, through all his deeper feelings, tasted the pleasurable excitement of being in a world where action followed on emotion with such Olympian speed.
fr: Une femme du monde, a New-York, n'aurait pas appele sa servante << ma chere, >> et ne l'aurait pas envoyee faire une course en lui pretant sa sortie de bal : Archer goutait un plaisir d'une qualite rare a se trouver dans un monde ou l'action jaillissait de l'emotion.

eng: Madame Olenska did not move when he came up behind her, and for a second their eyes met in the mirror; then she turned, threw herself into her sofa-corner, and sighed out: "There's time for a cigarette."
fr: Mme Olenska, qui se tenait debout devant la glace, ne bougea pas quand il s'approcha d'elle ; leurs yeux se rencontrerent dans le miroir. Se detournant vivement, elle se rassit sur le canape et dit : -- Nous avons encore le temps de fumer une cigarette.

eng: He handed her the box and lit a spill for her; and as the flame flashed up into her face she glanced at him with laughing eyes and said: "What do you think of me in a temper?"
fr: Il lui tendit la boite, alluma pour elle une allumette de papier. La flamme illumina son visage. Les yeux rieurs, elle demanda : -- Que pensez-vous de moi, quand je suis en colere ?...

eng: Archer paused a moment; then he answered with sudden resolution: "It makes me understand what your aunt has been saying about you."
fr: Archer hesita, puis il risqua : -- Cela me fait comprendre ce que votre tante m'a dit de vous...

eng: "I knew she'd been talking about me. Well?"
fr: -- J'etais sure qu'elle vous avait parle de moi. ~~~ Alors ?...

eng: "She said you were used to all kinds of things--splendours and amusements and excitements--that we could never hope to give you here."
fr: -- Elle a dit que vous etiez habituee a une existence brillante, a des choses que nous ne pouvons pas vous offrir ici...

eng: Madame Olenska smiled faintly into the circle of smoke about her lips. "Medora is incorrigibly romantic. It has made up to her for so many things!"
fr: Mme Olenska sourit. -- Medora est incorrigiblement romanesque. Cela l'a consolee de tant de choses !

eng: Archer hesitated again, and again took his risk. "Is your aunt's romanticism always consistent with accuracy?"
fr: Archer hesita, puis il risqua : -- Est-ce que le romanesque de votre tante comporte toujours l'exactitude ?

eng: "You mean: does she speak the truth?" Her niece considered. "Well, I'll tell you: in almost everything she says, there's something true and something untrue.'
fr: -- Vous voudriez savoir si elle dit toujours la verite ? Eh bien ! ~~~ voila. Dans presque tout ce qu'elle dit, il y a quelque chose qui est vrai et quelque chose qui n'est pas vrai...'

eng: She followed the Marchioness into the hall, saw her fitted into a miscellaneous heap of overshoes, shawls and tippets, and called from the doorstep: "Mind, the carriage is to be back for me at ten!"
fr: Elle suivit Mrs Manson dans le vestibule, l'enveloppa dans divers chales et palatines, la chaussa de galoches, et cria de la porte : -- Rappelez-vous que la voiture doit revenir me prendre.

eng: But why do you ask?
fr: Mais pourquoi cette question ?

eng: "His heart tightened with the thought that this was their last evening by that fireside, and that in a moment the carriage would come to carry her away."
fr: "Son coeur se serra. C'etait leur derniere soiree au coin de cette cheminee, et, dans un moment, la voiture arriverait pour l'emporter !"

eng: "He looked away into the fire, and then back at her shining presence."
fr: "Le regard d'Archer quitta le feu pour se porter vers la jeune femme."

eng: "What has she been telling you?"
fr: "Qu'est-ce qu'elle a bien pu vous raconter ?"

eng: "She says--she pretends that Count Olenski has asked her to persuade you to go back to him." ~~~ Madame Olenska made no answer.
fr: -- Elle pretend que le comte Olenski l'a chargee d'effectuer une reconciliation... Mme Olenska ne repondit pas.

eng: The expression of her face had not changed; and Archer remembered that he had before noticed her apparent incapacity for surprise.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh, Ellen--forgive me; I'm a fool and a brute!"
fr: -- Ellen, pardonnez-moi ! Je suis un imbecile et une brute !

eng: "Many cruel things have been believed of me," she said.
fr: On a cru sur moi de bien vilaines choses, dit-elle.

eng: She blushed seldom and painfully, as if it hurt her like a burn.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A deep blush rose to her face and spread over her neck and shoulders.
fr: Une soudaine rougeur colora son visage, gagnant son cou et ses epaules.

eng: Madame Olenska raised her head quickly.
fr: Mme Olenska releva vivement la tete.

eng: "You know that your aunt believes you will go back?"
fr: Vous savez que votre tante est persuadee que vous retournerez aupres de votre mari ? finit-il par dire.

eng: A sudden restlessness possessed him, and he was tongue-tied by the sense that their minutes were numbered, and that at any moment he might hear the wheels of the returning carriage.
fr: Une agitation violente s'empara de lui. Il sentait que les minutes etaient comptees, et que d'un moment a l'autre il entendrait les roues de la voiture qui venait chercher Ellen.

eng: The young man rose and went to lean against the fireplace.
fr: Le jeune homme se leva et alla s'appuyer contre la cheminee.

eng: Again Madame Olenska brooded silently; then she said: "After all, it was to be expected."
fr: Apres tout, je n'en serais pas surprise.

eng: "But you do believe she has a letter from your husband?"
fr: Croyez-vous vraiment qu'elle ait recu une lettre de votre mari ?

eng: Really, I don't know why she came."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I think she was with them as a sort of paid companion.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But perhaps the people in Cuba just got tired of her!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She told me she had had a 'spiritual summons,' whatever that is, from Dr. Carver.
fr: Elle m'a dit avoir eu un appel du docteur Carver.

eng: "There again: one can't tell.
fr: Je n'en sais rien.

eng: "Is it at your husband's request that she has arrived here suddenly?"
fr: Est-ce a la priere de votre mari qu'elle est venue ici ?...

eng: Medora's hints--"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "She has hinted about a letter: poor darling!
fr: Ma tante a fait allusion a une lettre...

eng: She brushed it to the floor.
fr: elle la secoua de sa robe.

eng: She was silent for so long that the ash dropped from her cigarette.
fr: Elle garda si longtemps le silence que la cendre de la cigarette tomba ;

eng: "You knew, then?" he broke out.
fr: Vous le saviez deja ? demanda-t-il.

eng: She sat motionless, holding her cigarette in her half-lifted hand.
fr: Immobile, sa cigarette dans sa main a demi levee, elle le regardait sans surprise.

eng: Madame Olenska seemed to consider this question also.
fr: Mme Olenska reflechit un instant.

eng: I'm afraid she's going to marry Dr. Carver ... poor Medora, there's always some one she wants to marry.
fr: J'ai peur qu'elle n'epouse le docteur Carver. Pauvre Medora, elle a toujours envie d'epouser quelqu'un !

eng: She smiled a little.
fr: Elle sourit doucement.

eng: "You are horribly nervous; you have your own troubles."
fr: "-- Vous etes horriblement nerveux : vous aussi, vous avez vos ennuis."

eng: "I know you think the Wellands are unreasonable about your marriage, and of course I agree with you."
fr: "Je sais que vous voudriez hater votre mariage, et que les Welland s'y opposent."

eng: "In Europe people don't understand our long American engagements; I suppose they are not as calm as we are."
fr: "En Europe, on ne connait pas nos longues fiancailles americaines. ~~~ Sans doute les Europeens sont moins calmes que nous."

eng: She pronounced the "we" with a faint emphasis that gave it an ironic sound.
fr: Elle avait prononce le << nous >> avec une legere emphase qui donnait au mot un sens ironique.

eng: Archer felt the irony but did not dare to take it up.
fr: Archer comprit l'ironie, mais n'osa pas la relever.

eng: After all, she had perhaps purposely deflected the conversation from her own affairs, and after the pain his last words had evidently caused her he felt that all he could do was to follow her lead.
fr: Apres tout, c'etait peut-etre expres qu'elle avait detourne la conversation. ~~~ Apres l'avoir si evidemment blessee, il sentait qu'il n'avait plus qu'a la suivre sur le terrain qu'elle avait choisi.

eng: "Well, then--I don't understand."
fr: -- Je comprends de moins en moins.

eng: Madame Olenska looked at him.
fr: Mme Olenska le regarda, etonnee.

eng: "She IS too intelligent--she's not their slave."
fr: La cause du refus de May n'est pas celle que vous croyez.

eng: "Because she's not like that: she's so much nobler. She insists all the more on the long engagement, to give me time--"
fr: -- Elle a une delicatesse de sentiments que je n'ai pas. Elle exige de longues fiancailles, pour me donner le temps de...

eng: There's no reason why we shouldn't be married then.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Yes," he said abruptly; "I went south to ask May to marry me after Easter.
fr: -- Oui, dit-il enfin, je suis alle dans le Midi pour demander a May de fixer notre mariage apres Paques...

eng: But the sense of the waning hour made him desperate: he could not bear the thought that a barrier of words should drop between them again.
fr: Il s'affolait de sentir couler les minutes, et ne pouvait supporter l'idee qu'une barriere de mots allait retomber entre eux.

eng: "We had a frank talk--almost the first. She thinks my impatience a bad sign."
fr: -- Nous avons eu une explication franche,... presque la premiere. May croit voir dans mon impatience un mauvais signe...

eng: "Merciful heavens--a bad sign?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "She thinks it means that I can't trust myself to go on caring for her. She thinks, in short, I want to marry her at once to get away from some one that I--care for more."
fr: -- May craint que mon impatience ne signifie que je ne suis pas sur de lui rester fidele. Elle s'imagine que je veux l'epouser pour m'eloigner d'une personne que j'aime davantage...

eng: "If I want to."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Madame Olenska examined this curiously.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "But if she thinks that--why isn't she in a hurry too?"
fr: -- Alors, comment se fait-il qu'elle ne soit pas aussi pressee que vous ?

eng: Archer reddened, and hurried on with a rush.
fr: Archer rougit et brusquement se decida.

eng: "And May adores you--and yet you couldn't convince her? I thought her too intelligent to be the slave of such absurd superstitions."
fr: Et vous n'avez pu l'obtenir... Pourtant May vous adore. Et je la croyais trop intelligente pour etre a ce point l'esclave des conventions.

eng: "Time to give her up for the other woman?"
fr: -- Le temps de la sacrifier a une autre femme ?

eng: Madame Olenska leaned toward the fire and gazed into it with fixed eyes.
fr: -- Si j'en ai le desir... Mme Olenska se pencha vers le feu, le regard fixe.

eng: Down the quiet street Archer heard the approaching trot of her horses.
fr: De la rue silencieuse, Archer entendit le trot des chevaux qui approchaient.

eng: "That IS noble," she said, with a slight break in her voice.
fr: -- C'est tres noble, en effet, dit-elle d'une voix emue.

eng: "Yes. ~~~ But it's ridiculous." ~~~ "Ridiculous?
fr: -- Tres noble, oui, mais absurde... -- Pourquoi ?

eng: Because you don't care for any one else?"
fr: Parce que vous n'en aimez pas une autre ?

eng: "Because I don't mean to marry any one else." ~~~ "Ah."
fr: -- Parce que je n'ai pas l'intention d'en epouser une autre... -- Ah !

eng: There was another long interval.
fr: Il y eut encore un long intervalle de silence.

eng: At length she looked up at him and asked: "This other woman--does she love you?"
fr: Enfin, elle leva les yeux sur lui et demanda : -- Cette autre femme vous aime-t-elle ?

eng: "Ah, don't make love to me! Too many people have done that," she said, frowning.
fr: "-- Ah ! ~~~ non, pas cela ! Ne me faites pas la cour ! On me l'a faite trop souvent, dit-elle en froncant les sourcils."

eng: "I have never made love to you," he said, "and I never shall. But you are the woman I would have married if it had been possible for either of us."
fr: "-- Il ne s'agit pas de vous faire la cour... La femme que j'aurais voulu epouser, si cela avait ete possible, c'est vous !... Voila."

eng: "Possible for either of us?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He stared at her, groping in a blackness through which a single arrow of light tore its blinding way.
fr: "A son tour, il la regardait avec stupeur."

eng: "And you say that--when it's you who've made it impossible?"
fr: "-- Et c'est vous qui dites cela, vous qui avez rendu la chose impossible ! s'ecria-t-elle."

eng: She started up, and freeing herself from him moved away to the other side of the hearth.
fr: "Elle se leva vivement et, se degageant, alla de l'autre cote de la cheminee."

eng: "I'VE made it impossible--?"
fr: "-- Moi ? ~~~ balbutia-t-il."

eng: "You, you, YOU!"
fr: "-- Vous ! ~~~ Vous !"

eng: She looked at him with unfeigned astonishment.
fr: "Elle le regarda avec un etonnement profond."

eng: After a moment he sat down beside her, and, taking her hand, softly unclasped it, so that the gloves and fan fell on the sofa between them.
fr: "Un moment apres, Newland s'approcha, d'elle et, prenant sa main, la desserra doucement ; les gants et l'eventail tomberent."

eng: Archer felt that at any cost he must keep her beside him, must make her give him the rest of her evening.
fr: "Archer ne repondit pas. Il sentit qu'a tout prix il devait la retenir, la forcer a lui consacrer la fin de sa soiree."

eng: "May guessed the truth," he said. "There is another woman--but not the one she thinks."
fr: "-- May a devine la verite, dit-il. Il y a une autre femme, mais ce n'est pas celle qu'elle soupconne..."

eng: Ignoring her question, he continued to lean against the chimney-piece, his eyes fixed on the hand in which she held her gloves and fan, as if watching to see if he had the power to make her drop them.
fr: "Il s'appuya contre la cheminee, les yeux fixes sur les mains de la jeune femme, comme si son regard avait le pouvoir de leur faire lacher les gants et l'eventail."

eng: "Yes."
She smiled and added: "I must go where I am invited, or I should be too lonely. Why not come with me?"
fr: "Elle sourit et ajouta : -- Il faut bien que j'aille ou l'on m'invite ; autrement, je serais trop seule. Ne voulez-vous pas m'accompagner ?"

eng: "Oh, there's no other woman; I mean, the person that May was thinking of is--was never--"
fr: "-- Il n'y a pas d'autre femme. ~~~ Je veux dire que la personne a laquelle May pensait n'a jamais..."

eng: "Then, why, after all, are you in such haste?"
fr: "-- D'ou vient alors cette hate de conclure votre union ?"

eng: She half-rose and looked about her with absent eyes.
fr: "Ellen Olenska se redressa a moitie, et jeta autour d'elle un regard distrait."

eng: Her fan and gloves lay on the sofa beside her and she picked them up mechanically.
fr: "Ses gants et son eventail etaient pres d'elle sur le canape : elle les prit machinalement."

eng: "Yes; I suppose I must be going."
fr: "-- Il faut que je m'en aille..."

eng: "You're going to Mrs. Struthers's?"
fr: "-- Vous allez chez Mrs Struthers ?"

eng: Ellen Olenska made no answer, and did not move.
fr: "Mme Olenska ne repondit pas, ne bougea pas."

eng: Archer, changing colour, stood up also: it was the bitterest rebuke she could have given him.
fr: "Archer palit et se leva aussi : c'etait la plus cruelle rebuffade qu'elle eut pu lui infliger."

eng: "There's your carriage," said Archer.
fr: "-- Votre voiture est arrivee, dit Archer."

eng: she cried, her lip trembling like a child's on the verge of tears.
fr: Vous ! ~~~ cria-t-elle, ses levres tremblantes comme celles d'un enfant pret a fondre en larmes.

eng: "Isn't it you who made me give up divorcing--give it up because you showed me how selfish and wicked it was, how one must sacrifice one's self to preserve the dignity of marriage ... and to spare one's family the publicity, the scandal?
fr: N'est-ce pas vous qui m'avez fait renoncer a ce divorce ? ~~~ C'est vous qui m'avez fait comprendre qu'on doit se sacrifier pour preserver la dignite du mariage, pour epargner a sa famille un scandale.

eng: And because my family was going to be your family--for May's sake and for yours--I did what you told me, what you proved to me that I ought to do.
fr: Et parce que ma famille allait devenir la votre, pour May et pour vous j'ai fait ce que vous m'avez demande, ce que vous m'avez affirme que je devais faire !

eng: She sat upright, facing him with a rigid dignity.
fr: Elle se tenait droite, lui faisant face avec une dignite grave.

eng: "You thought?"
fr: -- Vous avez cru ?...

eng: "Good God," he groaned. "When I thought--"
fr: -- Grand Dieu, murmura-t-il, quand j'ai cru...

eng: She sank down on the sofa again, crouching among the festive ripples of her dress like a stricken masquerader; and the young man stood by the fireplace and continued to gaze at her without moving.
fr: Elle retomba sur le canape, abimee dans les ondes etincelantes de sa robe. Le jeune homme continuait a la regarder.

eng: "Ah," she broke out with a sudden laugh, "I've made no secret of having done it for you!"
fr: -- Ce n'est un secret pour personne que j'ai fait cela pour vous !

eng: "I do ask you."
fr: Je vous le demande...

eng: "Well, then: there were things in that letter you asked me to read--"
fr: -- Eh bien, donc, il y avait des choses dans la lettre que vous m'avez demande de lire...

eng: "My husband's letter?"
fr: -- La lettre de mon mari ?...

eng: "Ah, don't ask me what I thought!"
fr: -- Ah ! ne me demandez pas ce que j'ai cru !...

eng: "Yes."
Still looking at her, he saw the same burning flush creep up her neck to her face.
fr: La contemplant toujours, il vit la meme rougeur brulante de nouveau envahir son cou et son visage.

eng: "I had nothing to fear from that letter: absolutely nothing! All I feared was to bring notoriety, scandal, on the family--on you and May."
fr: Je n'ai rien a craindre de cette lettre, absolument rien. Mon unique idee, en me sacrifiant, a ete d'empecher la repercussion de ce scandale sur la famille, sur May, sur vous !

eng: "Good God," he groaned again, bowing his face in his hands.
fr: -- Mon Dieu ! murmura-t-il, cachant sa figure dans ses mains.

eng: 'Ah,' she broke out with a sudden laugh.
fr: Elle eut un eclat de rire convulsif.

eng: The silence that followed lay on them with the weight of things final and irrevocable.
fr: Dans le silence qui suivit, Archer sentit sur lui le poids de l'irrevocable.

eng: It seemed to Archer to be crushing him down like his own grave-stone; in all the wide future he saw nothing that would ever lift that load from his heart.
fr: Dans toute sa vie a venir, il n'imaginait rien qui dut jamais le delivrer de ce poids.

eng: He did not move from his place, or raise his head from his hands; his hidden eyeballs went on staring into utter darkness.
fr: Il demeurait immobile, la tete dans ses mains.

eng: "At least I loved you--" he brought out.
fr: -- Je vous aime, murmura-t-il.

eng: On the other side of the hearth, from the sofa-corner where he supposed that she still crouched, he heard a faint stifled crying like a child's.
fr: Du canape ou elle etait toujours blottie, il entendit s'elever un leger gemissement, comme celui d'un enfant qui se plaint.

eng: He started up and came to her side.
fr: Il tressaillit et s'approcha d'elle.

eng: "Ellen!
fr: -- Ellen !

eng: What madness!
fr: Quelle folie !

eng: Why are you crying?
fr: Pourquoi pleurez-vous ?

eng: Nothing's done that can't be undone.
fr: Rien n'est fait qui ne puisse se defaire.

eng: I'm still free, and you're going to be."
fr: Je suis encore libre et vous allez l'etre.

eng: He had her in his arms, her face like a wet flower at his lips, and all their vain terrors shrivelling up like ghosts at sunrise.
fr: Il l'avait prise dans ses bras, le visage de la jeune femme etait sous ses levres, pareil a une fleur mouillee ; toutes leurs vaines terreurs s'evanouissaient comme des fantomes a l'aurore.
