eng: "No, no--it mustn't, it can't. You're engaged to May Welland; and I'm married."
fr: -- Non, non, il ne faut pas, ce n'est pas possible ! Vous etes fiance a May, et moi, je suis mariee...

eng: It's too late for that sort of thing.
fr: Il est trop tard pour reculer !

eng: "Nonsense!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "It alters the whole of life for me."
fr: -- Cela change toute la vie pour moi.

eng: We've no right to lie to other people or to ourselves.
fr: Nous n'avons pas le droit de mentir aux autres ni a nous-memes.

eng: We won't talk of your marriage; but do you see me marrying May after this?"
fr: Me voyez-vous maintenant epousant May ?

eng: She stood silent, resting her thin elbows on the mantelpiece, her profile reflected in the glass behind her.
fr: Elle resta silencieuse, accoudee a la cheminee, son profil reflete par la glace.

eng: One of the locks of her chignon had become loosened and hung on her neck; she looked haggard and almost old.
fr: Une des boucles de son chignon s'etait detachee et tombait sur son cou ; subitement elle apparaissait presque vieille.

eng: "I don't see you," she said at length, "putting that question to May.
fr: -- Je ne vous vois pas, dit-elle enfin douloureusement, lui posant la question que vous venez de me poser.

eng: Do you?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He gave a reckless shrug.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "It's too late to do anything else."
fr: -- Il est trop tard pour agir autrement...

eng: "You say that because it's the easiest thing to say at this moment--not because it's true. In reality it's too late to do anything but what we'd both decided on."
fr: -- Il est trop tard pour changer ce que nous avions decide tous les deux...

eng: He stood up too, flushed and resolute.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ah, my poor Newland--I suppose this had to be. But it doesn't in the least alter things," she said, looking down at him in her turn from the hearth.
fr: -- Ah ! mon pauvre Newland ; cela devait arriver ; mais cela ne change absolument rien.

eng: "Yes. I was perfectly unconscious at first that people here were shy of me--that they thought I was a dreadful sort of person. It seems they had even refused to meet me at dinner. I found that out afterward; and how you'd made your mother go with you to the van der Luydens'; and how you'd insisted on announcing your engagement at the Beaufort ball, so that I might have two families to stand by me instead of one--"
fr: -- Oui. Je ne m'apercevais pas tout d'abord qu'on ne m'accueillait qu'avec reserve, qu'on me trouvait compromettante. Il parait qu'on a refuse de diner avec moi chez les Lovell Mingott ! Je l'ai su plus tard, et j'ai appris aussi que vous aviez tout raconte aux van der Luyden et que vous aviez voulu que vos fiancailles fussent annoncees au bal des Beaufort, afin que j'aie deux familles pour me soutenir, au lieu d'une...

eng: The one thing that astonished him now was that he should have stood for five minutes arguing with her across the width of the room, when just touching her made everything so simple.
fr: Ce qui etonnait Archer maintenant, c'etait d'avoir pu discuter, separe d'elle par la largeur de la chambre, quand tout devenait si simple, des qu'il la tenait dans ses bras !

eng: "All I'd done?"
fr: -- Ellen !

eng: "You don't understand because you haven't yet guessed how you've changed things for me: oh, from the first--long before I knew all you'd done."
fr: -- Vous ne comprenez pas, parce que vous ne savez pas encore combien j'ai change depuis que je vous ai connu.

eng: "Just imagine," she said, "how stupid and unobservant I was! I knew nothing of all this till Granny blurted it out one day. New York simply meant peace and freedom to me: it was coming home. And I was so happy at being among my own people that every one I met seemed kind and good, and glad to see me.'
fr: Vous voyez combien j'etais sotte et etourdie : jusqu'a ce que grand'mere m'ait tout raconte, je ne me rendais compte de rien. New-York me representait simplement la paix et la liberte : je rentrais chez moi. J'etais si contente de m'y retrouver ! J'avais l'impression, en arrivant ici, que tout le monde etait pour moi plein de bienveillance, heureux de me voir.

eng: "Ah, I don't understand you!"
fr: -- Je ne vous comprends pas ! s'ecria-t-il.

eng: At that he broke into a laugh.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She gave him back all his kiss, but after a moment he felt her stiffening in his arms, and she put him aside and stood up.
fr: Elle lui rendit son baiser ; mais, un moment apres, il sentit qu'elle se raidissait dans son etreinte. Puis elle le repoussa et se redressa.

eng: She forced a pitiful smile that pinched her face instead of smoothing it.
fr: Elle s'efforca de sourire, mais son sourire etait plus triste que ses larmes.

eng: But from the very beginning," she continued, "I felt there was no one as kind as you; no one who gave me reasons that I understood for doing what at first seemed so hard and--unnecessary.
fr: Cependant, personne ne semblait me comprendre comme vous ; personne ne me donnait d'aussi bonnes raisons pour faire ce qui, au premier abord, me revoltait comme inutile et difficile.

eng: The very good people didn't convince me; I felt they'd never been tempted.
fr: Les gens trop sages ne me persuadent pas : ils n'ont jamais ete tentes...

eng: Suddenly he knelt down and kissed the shoe.
fr: Tout a coup il s'agenouilla et baisa le soulier.

eng: He sat bowed over, his head between his hands, staring at the hearthrug, and at the tip of the satin shoe that showed under her dress.
fr: Il se tenait courbe en avant, la tete dans les mains, les yeux fixes sur la pointe du soulier de satin qui depassait la robe scintillante.

eng: She spoke in a low even voice, without tears or visible agitation; and each word, as it dropped from her, fell into his breast like burning lead.
fr: Elle parlait d'une voix basse et egale, sans larmes ni agitation, et chaque mot tombait comme du plomb brulant dans le coeur du jeune homme.

eng: That was what I'd never known before--and it's better than anything I've known."
fr: Jamais je n'avais connu personne qui vous ressemblat, qui fut aussi loyal, aussi genereux.

eng: But you knew; you understood; you had felt the world outside tugging at one with all its golden hands--and yet you hated the things it asks of one; you hated happiness bought by disloyalty and cruelty and indifference.
fr: Mais vous, vous compreniez ! Vous saviez comment la vie vous tire a elle avec ses mains tentatrices ; et pourtant vous haissiez les concessions qu'elle suggere, vous haissiez la jouissance achetee au prix du mensonge, de la cruaute, de l'indifference !

eng: She bent over him, laying her hands on his shoulders, and looking at him with eyes so deep that he remained motionless under her gaze.
fr: Elle se pencha et plongea dans ses yeux un regard si profond qu'il en fut comme fascine.

eng: "Ah, don't let us undo what you've done!"
fr: -- Ne detruisons pas ce qui est votre oeuvre !

eng: she cried.
fr: s'ecria-t-elle.

eng: His arms were yearning up to her; but she drew away, and they remained facing each other, divided by the distance that her words had created.
fr: Les bras de Newland se levaient, suppliants, mais elle s'eloigna doucement et ils se trouverent face a face, separes par la distance que les paroles de la jeune femme avaient mise entre eux.

eng: I can't love you unless I give you up."
fr: Je ne peux vous aimer, que si je renonce a vous...

eng: "I can't go back now to that other way of thinking.
fr: Je ne peux pas revenir aux manieres de penser que j'avais avant vous.

eng: Then, abruptly, his anger overflowed.
fr: Puis subitement la colere envahit Archer.

eng: "And Beaufort? Is he to replace me?"
fr: '-- Et Beaufort ? C'est sans doute lui qui va me remplacer aupres de vous ?'

eng: But Madame Olenska only grew a shade paler, and stood with her arms hanging down before her, and her head slightly bent, as her way was when she pondered a question.
fr: Mme Olenska devint seulement un peu plus pale et resta immobile, les bras pendants, la tete legerement inclinee.

eng: As the words sprang out he was prepared for an answering flare of anger; and he would have welcomed it as fuel for his own.
fr: A peine avait-il prononce ces paroles qu'il en eut honte. ~~~ Mais son coeur etait gonfle d'amertume, et il souhaita presque une reponse violente.

eng: "He's waiting for you now at Mrs. Struthers's; why don't you go to him?"
fr: -- Il vous attend maintenant chez Mrs Struthers. ~~~ Pourquoi n'allez-vous pas le retrouver ?

eng: "What! Three days after you've entreated her on your knees to hasten your marriage?"
fr: -- Quoi ! trois jours apres que vous etes alle la supplier a genoux de hater votre mariage ?

eng: At length he began to plead again.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Her tone and her look still enveloped her in a soft inaccessibility, and Archer groaned out again: "I don't understand you!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I shan't be lonely now. I WAS lonely; I WAS afraid. But the emptiness and the darkness are gone; when I turn back into myself now I'm like a child going at night into a room where there's always a light."
fr: -- Je ne serai pas seule maintenant. J'etais seule ; j'avais peur ; mais le vide et l'obscurite se sont dissipes. Desormais, quand je rentrerai en moi-meme, je serai comme un enfant qui revient la nuit dans une chambre ou il y a toujours une lumiere.

eng: She smiled a little under her wet lashes.
fr: Elle sourit sous ses paupieres humides.

eng: "Why this sacrifice? Since you tell me that you're lonely I've no right to keep you from your friends."
fr: -- Pourquoi ce sacrifice, puisque l'isolement vous pese ? Je n'ai aucun droit de vous retenir loin de vos amis...

eng: After the door had closed again Archer continued to look at her with bitter eyes.
fr: Quand la porte fut refermee, Archer continua a regarder Mme Olenska avec des yeux mauvais.

eng: "Yet you understand May!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I shall not go out this evening; tell the carriage to go and fetch the Signora Marchesa," she said when the maid came.
fr: -- Je ne sortirai pas ce soir. Dites a la voiture d'aller chercher la signora marchesa, dit-elle, quand la servante se presenta.

eng: Archer sneered.
fr: 'ricana Archer.

eng: If he could have got her in his arms again he might have swept away her arguments; but she still held him at a distance by something inscrutably aloof in her look and attitude, and by his own awed sense of her sincerity.
fr: S'il avait pu reprendre la jeune femme dans ses bras, il aurait refute ses arguments. Mais toute la personne d'Ellen Olenska semblait enveloppee d'une douceur qui la rendait inaccessible : elle le tenait a distance, lui inspirant, par sa sincerite, un sentiment mele de crainte et de respect.

eng: He felt as though he had been struggling for hours up the face of a steep precipice, and now, just as he had fought his way to the top, his hold had given way and he was pitching down headlong into darkness.
fr: C'etait comme s'il eut, pendant des heures, fait des efforts surhumains pour remonter la paroi d'un precipice, et qu'au moment d'en atteindre le bord, son etreinte se relachant, il retombat dans les tenebres.

eng: He turned away with a sense of utter weariness.
fr: Archer eprouvait une fatigue indicible.

eng: "Ah, you've taught me what an ugly word that is," she said.
fr: -- Le droit ? Vous m'avez appris combien ce mot-la est un vilain mot, dit-elle.

eng: "She's refused; that gives me the right--"
fr: -- Elle a refuse, ce qui me donne le droit...

eng: She turned to ring the bell.
fr: Elle alla tirer le cordon de la sonnette.

eng: "May is ready to give me up."
fr: -- May est prete a me rendre ma liberte...

eng: "If we do this now it will be worse afterward--worse for every one--" "No--no--no!"
fr: Il insista de nouveau : -- Si nous nous sacrifions, ce sera pire pour tout le monde. ~~~ -- Non, non, non !

eng: Her mistress smiled and took the yellow envelope.
fr: Sa maitresse sourit et prit l'enveloppe jaune.

eng: In it he read: "Granny's telegram successful. Papa and Mamma agree marriage after Easter. Am telegraphing Newland.
fr: il annoncait : << Telegramme de grand'mere plein succes. Parents acceptent mariage apres Paques. Je telegraphie a Newland.'

eng: It was dated from St. Augustine, and addressed to the Countess Olenska.
fr: Date de Saint-Augustin, a l'adresse de la comtesse Olenska,

eng: She tore it open and carried it to the lamp; then, when the door had closed again, she handed the telegram to Archer.
fr: Puis, quand Nastasia fut partie, et la porte refermee, elle tendit le telegramme a Archer.

eng: "The lady was very happy at the flowers," Nastasia said, smoothing her apron. "She thought it was her signor marito who had sent them, and she cried a little and said it was a folly."
fr: -- La dame a ete tres heureuse des fleurs, dit Nastasia. Elle a cru que c'etait son mari qui les envoyait ; elle a pleure un peu, disant que c'etait une folie.

eng: They had heard no carriage stopping at the door, and they stood motionless, looking at each other with startled eyes.
fr: Ils n'entendirent pas de voiture s'arreter, et resterent sans mouvement, les yeux egares.

eng: At that moment the bell sent a long tinkle through the house.
fr: Au meme moment, la sonnette de la porte tinta.

eng: Outside, Nastasia's step crossed the hall, the outer door opened, and a moment later she came in carrying a telegram which she handed to the Countess Olenska.
fr: Au dehors, le pas rapide de Nastasia traversait le vestibule : la porte d'entree s'ouvrit, se referma, et, un instant apres, la servante parut, portant un telegramme qu'elle remit a la comtesse Olenska.

eng: 'she almost screamed, as if he frightened her.
fr: 'cria-t-elle, comme s'il lui faisait peur.

eng: Am too happy for words and love you dearly.
fr: Suis bien heureuse. ~~~ Vous aime tendrement.

eng: Your grateful May."
fr: Votre reconnaissante May.

eng: Half an hour later, when Archer unlocked his own front-door, he found a similar envelope on the hall-table on top of his pile of notes and letters.
fr: >> Une demi-heure plus tard, Archer, rentrant chez lui, trouva sur la table du vestibule une autre enveloppe jaune. ~~~ C'etait aussi une depeche de May Welland.

eng: The message inside the envelope was also from May Welland, and ran as follows: "Parents consent wedding Tuesday after Easter at twelve Grace Church eight bridesmaids please see Rector so happy love May."
fr: << Parents consentent mariage mardi de Paques a midi. ~~~ Grace church, huit demoiselles d'honneur. ~~~ Veuillez voir pasteur. ~~~ Si heureuse ! ~~~ Tendrement May.

eng: Archer crumpled up the yellow sheet as if the gesture could annihilate the news it contained.
fr: >> Archer chiffonna dans le creux de sa main la feuille de papier jaune, comme si, par ce geste, il eut pu annihiler les nouvelles qu'elle annoncait.

eng: and her brother rapped impatiently on the panel.
fr: Newland frappa impatiemment a la porte, et Janey parut dans sa robe de chambre de flanelle violette, ses cheveux roules sur des epingles a friser.

eng: Then he pulled out a small pocket-diary and turned over the pages with trembling fingers;
fr: Puis il tira un petit agenda de sa poche, en tourna les pages avec des doigts tremblants.

eng: but he did not find what he wanted, and cramming the telegram into his pocket he mounted the stairs.
fr: Il ne trouva pas ce qu'il cherchait, et serrant le telegramme dans sa poche, il monta l'escalier.

eng: A light was shining through the door of the little hall-room which served Janey as a dressing-room and boudoir,
fr: Une lumiere brillait sous la porte de la petite chambre qui servait a Janey de cabinet de toilette et de boudoir.

eng: The door opened, and his sister stood before him in her immemorial purple flannel dressing-gown, with her hair "on pins."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Her face looked pale and apprehensive.
fr: Son visage etait pale et inquiet.

eng: "Newland!
fr: -- Newland !

eng: 'I hope there's no bad news in that telegram?
fr: 'J'espere que ce telegramme ne contient pas de mauvaises nouvelles ?

eng: I waited on purpose, in case--" (No item of his correspondence was safe from Janey.)
fr: J'ai attendu expres.

eng: He took no notice of her question.
fr: Sans repondre, il interrogea : -- Dis-moi ! Paques tombe a quelle date cette annee ?

eng: He turned again to the pages of his diary, calculating rapidly under his breath.
fr: Il tourna encore quelques pages de son agenda, faisant un calcul rapide a voix basse.

eng: She looked shocked at such unchristian ignorance.
fr: Elle parut choquee d'une si paienne ignorance.

eng: "My God," he thought, "HAVE I got the ring?"
fr: -- Mon Dieu ! pensa-t-il, ai-je bien la bague ?

eng: The music, the scent of the lilies on the altar, the vision of the cloud of tulle and orange-blossoms floating nearer and nearer, the sight of Mrs. Archer's face suddenly convulsed with happy sobs, the low benedictory murmur of the Rector's voice, the ordered evolutions of the eight pink bridesmaids and the eight black ushers: all these sights, sounds and sensations, so familiar in themselves, so unutterably strange and meaningless in his new relation to them, were confusedly mingled in his brain.
fr: et son coeur se desserra. La musique, la senteur printaniere des lys, la vision de May, qui flottait vers lui dans un nuage de tulle, le visage de sa mere, baigne d'heureuses larmes, le murmure des paroles du pasteur, les evolutions symetriques du cortege d'honneur, tous ces mouvements, tous ces bruits bien connus, lui semblaient maintenant etranges et depourvus de sens.

eng: Archer opened his eyes (but could they really have been shut, as he imagined? ), and felt his heart beginning to resume its usual task.
fr: Archer ouvrit les yeux (les avait-il vraiment fermes, comme il le croyait ?)

eng: A long time had apparently passed since his heart had stopped beating, for the white and rosy procession was in fact half way up the nave, the Bishop, the Rector and two white-winged assistants were hovering about the flower-banked altar, and the first chords of the Spohr symphony were strewing their flower-like notes before the bride.
fr: Il avait du perdre conscience de ce qui se passait autour de lui. La procession blanche et rose etait deja parvenue a la moitie de la nef : l'eveque et le pasteur, accompagnes de deux assistants en surplis blancs, se tenaient devant l'autel fleuri, et les premiers accords de la Symphonie de Spohr tombaient sous les pas de la mariee comme des bouquets de roses.

eng: Archer roused himself with a start.
fr: chuchota son jeune cousin. Archer sursauta.

eng: the best man whispered.
fr: La voila !

eng: "Newland--I say: SHE'S HERE!"
fr: -- Newland !

eng: but the little procession was at an end, for all the lesser members of the family had taken their seats, and the eight tall ushers, gathering themselves together like birds or insects preparing for some migratory manoeuvre, were already slipping through the side doors into the lobby.
fr: Mais le cortege finissait la : les parents plus eloignes avaient deja pris leurs places. Les huit garcons d'honneur se reunissaient pour aller rejoindre au bas de la nef les huit demoiselles d'honneur.

eng: For a moment Archer stood with his eyes fixed on Medora's fantastic figure, straining to see who came behind her;
fr: Archer se demandait qui allait paraitre derriere cette fantastique Medora.

eng: and in the circumstances no one had expected either of the ladies to return for the wedding.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was generally understood that their abrupt departure was due to Madame Olenska's desire to remove her aunt from the baleful eloquence of Dr. Agathon Carver, who had nearly succeeded in enlisting her as a recruit for the Valley of Love;
fr: On attribuait leur brusque depart au desir qu'avait eu la niece de soustraire sa tante a la funeste eloquence du docteur Agathon Carver. N'etait-il pas sur le point de faire d'elle une recrue pour la << Vallee de l'Amour ? >>

eng: He had taken it for granted that the Marchioness Manson was still in Washington, where she had gone some four weeks previously with her niece, Madame Olenska.
fr: Il avait cru que la marquise Manson etait depuis six semaines a Washington avec Ellen Olenska.

eng: and as this last apparition glided into view Archer's heart contracted and stopped beating.
fr: A cette derniere apparition, le coeur d'Archer se contracta.

eng: Far different was the impression produced by the gaunt and mincing lady who followed on Mr. Mingott's arm, in a wild dishevelment of stripes and fringes and floating scarves;
fr: Toute differente etait l'impression produite par la grande femme maigre et minaudante qui, dans une etrange confusion de rayures, de franges, d'echarpes flottantes, defilait au bras de Mr Mingott.

eng: but once the disappointment occasioned by her mother-in-law's non-appearance had subsided, it was agreed that her black Chantilly over lilac satin, with a bonnet of Parma violets, formed the happiest contrast to Mrs. Welland's blue and plum-colour.
fr: mais quand on fut revenu du desappointement cause par l'absence de Mrs Manson Mingott, on convint que la robe de satin lilas voilee de Chantilly et le chapeau en violettes de Parme de sa belle-fille s'harmonisaient heureusement a la toilette prune et bleue de Mrs Welland.

eng: Mrs. Lovell Mingott had the high colour and glassy stare induced in ladies of her age and habit by the effort of getting into a new dress;
fr: Mrs Lovell Mingott avait ce teint echauffe et ce regard vide des femmes d'age et d'embonpoint engoncees dans des robes neuves ;

eng: Though all these transactions had been widely reported by the Jacksons a sporting minority still clung to the belief that old Catherine would appear in church, and there was a distinct lowering of the temperature when she was found to have been replaced by her daughter-in-law.
fr: Tout le monde connaissait ces negociations par les Jackson ; mais une minorite d'esprits hardis croyait encore que Mrs Mingott assisterait a la ceremonie, et un leger refroidissement se manifesta dans l'allegresse generale quand on vit que Mrs Lovell Mingott remplacait sa belle-mere.

eng: The ancestress had had to give in; but her concession was bought only by the promise that the wedding-breakfast should take place under her roof, though (as the Washington Square connection said) with the Wellands' house in easy reach it was hard to have to make a special price with Brown to drive one to the other end of nowhere.
fr: L'ancetre avait du ceder, mais contre la promesse que le repas de noces aurait lieu sous son toit. Les amis de la famille qui habitaient autour de Washington Square, trouvaient que la maison des Welland aurait ete d'acces plus facile, et qu'il etait dur d'avoir a debattre avec Brown le prix de la voiture qui les menerait a l'autre bout de la ville.

eng: Mrs. Welland exclaimed when her mother's last plan was hinted to her; and from this unthinkable indecency the clan recoiled with a collective shudder.
fr: s'etait ecriee Mrs Welland. Le clan tout entier avait recule devant une pareille inconvenance.

eng: "Why, they might take a photograph of my child AND PUT IT IN THE PAPERS!"
fr: << Comment ! on pourrait photographier ma fille et la mettre dans les journaux ! >>

eng: The idea of doing away with this awning, and revealing the bride to the mob of dressmakers and newspaper reporters who stood outside fighting to get near the joints of the canvas, exceeded even old Catherine's courage, though for a moment she had weighed the possibility.
fr: L'idee de renoncer a cette tente, d'exposer la mariee a la curiosite des couturieres et des journalistes, eut raison du courage de la vieille Catherine.

eng: The idea of this monstrous exposure of her person was so painful to her relations that they could have covered with gold the ingenious person who suddenly discovered that the chair was too wide to pass between the iron uprights of the awning which extended from the church door to the curbstone.
fr: L'exhibition de sa monstrueuse personne etait apparue si facheuse a ses parents, qu'ils auraient volontiers couvert d'or le genie qui avait decouvert que la chaise de Mrs Mingott etait trop large pour passer entre les supports de la tente dressee a la porte de l'eglise.

eng: It was known that she had insisted on sending her own carpenter to look into the possibility of taking down the end panel of the front pew, and to measure the space between the seat and the front; but the result had been discouraging, and for one anxious day her family had watched her dallying with the plan of being wheeled up the nave in her enormous Bath chair and sitting enthroned in it at the foot of the chancel.
fr: On savait qu'elle avait envoye son menuisier examiner la possibilite d'elargir le premier banc ; mais le resultat avait ete negatif. Sa famille avait passe une journee d'angoisse, pendant qu'elle deliberait sur le projet de se faire rouler dans son enorme chaise et de troner devant le choeur.

eng: --and once more he went through the bridegroom's convulsive gesture.
fr: et il refit le geste nerveux de tous les maries.

eng: and the idea was so much in keeping with her sporting character that bets ran high at the clubs as to her being able to walk up the nave and squeeze into a seat.
fr: Comment pourrait-elle traverser la nef ? Quel siege serait assez vaste pour la contenir ?

eng: Then, in a moment, May was beside him, such radiance streaming from her that it sent a faint warmth through his numbness, and he straightened himself and smiled into her eyes.
fr: Un instant apres, May se trouvait a cote de lui, et le coeur fige du jeune homme se ranima au contact de cette purete rayonnante.

eng: The ring was on her hand, the Bishop's benediction had been given, the bridesmaids were a-poise to resume their place in the procession, and the organ was showing preliminary symptoms of breaking out into the Mendelssohn March, without which no newly-wedded couple had ever emerged upon New York.
fr: La bague avait ete passee au doigt de May ; les maries avaient recu la benediction de l'eveque ; les demoiselles d'honneur se preparaient a reprendre leurs places dans la procession, et la marche nuptiale de Mendelssohn roulait sous la voute de la nef.

eng: "Look here--what day is Easter this year?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She was alone for the first time with her husband; but her husband was only the charming comrade of yesterday.
fr: Elle etait seule, pour la premiere fois, avec son mari ; mais, de toute evidence, elle ne voyait encore en

eng: At first Archer had fancied that this detachment was the disguise of an inward tremor; but her clear eyes revealed only the most tranquil unawareness.
fr: Archer avait pense d'abord que ce detachement provenait d'un trouble secret ; mais les yeux clairs de la jeune mariee ne revelaient qu'une tranquille ignorance.

eng: May was still, in look and tone, the simple girl of yesterday, eager to compare notes with him as to the incidents of the wedding, and discussing them as impartially as a bridesmaid talking it all over with an usher.
fr: May etait encore la naive jeune fille de la veille : elle discutait avec une impartialite de simple temoin tous les incidents de la journee.

eng: Once they were settled in their compartment, and the train, shaking off the endless wooden suburbs, had pushed out into the pale landscape of spring, talk became easier than Archer had expected.
fr: Quand les maries furent installes dans leur compartiment, que le train eut depasse les faubourgs et fut entre dans la campagne printaniere, la conversation devint plus aisee qu'Archer ne l'avait espere.

eng: It was thought "very English" to have a country-house lent to one, and the fact gave a last touch of distinction to what was generally conceded to be the most brilliant wedding of the year; but where the house was no one was permitted to know, except the parents of bride and groom, who, when taxed with the knowledge, pursed their lips and said mysteriously: "Ah, they didn't tell us--" which was manifestly true, since there was no need to.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: May was enchanted at the idea of going to the country, and childishly amused at the vain efforts of the eight bridesmaids to discover where their mysterious retreat was situated.
fr: May, enchantee d'aller a la campagne, s'etait amusee comme une enfant des vains efforts des huit demoiselles d'honneur pour arriver a savoir le lieu de la mysterieuse retraite.

eng: and Archer, glad to escape the usual "bridal suite" in a Philadelphia or Baltimore hotel, had accepted with an equal alacrity.
fr: Newland, heureux d'echapper aux hotels de Baltimore ou de Philadelphie, ou il etait d'usage de passer les premiers jours de la lune de miel, avait accepte la proposition de grand coeur.

eng: The old du Lac aunts at Rhinebeck had put their house at the disposal of the bridal couple, with a readiness inspired by the prospect of spending a week in New York with Mrs. Archer;
fr: Les vieilles tantes de Rhinebeck avaient mis leur maison a la disposition des jeunes maries, avec un empressement peut-etre du a la perspective seduisante d'un sejour chez Mrs Archer.

eng: and there was still half an hour left in which to drive to the station, buy the last weeklies at the bookstall with the air of seasoned travellers, and settle themselves in the reserved compartment in which May's maid had already placed her dove-coloured travelling cloak and glaringly new dressing-bag from London.
fr: Ils purent choisir, sans se presser, a la bibliotheque de la gare, les magazines de la semaine, avec l'air detache de voyageurs ordinaires, et enfin s'installer dans le compartiment reserve, ou la femme de chambre de May avait deja place le manteau gris-palombe et le sac de voyage, tout battant neuf, et qui venait de Londres.

eng: Every detail of the day had been so carefully thought out that the young couple, after the wedding-breakfast, had ample time to put on their travelling-clothes, descend the wide Mingott stairs between laughing bridesmaids and weeping parents, and get into the brougham under the traditional shower of rice and satin slippers;
fr: Tous les details de la journee avaient ete si soigneusement regles, qu'apres le dejeuner, les jeunes maries eurent tout le temps necessaire pour se preparer au depart. En tenue de voyage, ils descendirent le large escalier de Mrs Mingott, escortes de la bande rieuse des demoiselles d'honneur ; ils embrasserent leurs parents et monterent dans la voiture qui les attendait, tandis qu'on jetait derriere eux la traditionnelle averse de riz et la pantoufle de satin.

eng: "But none ever CAN happen now, can it, Newland, as long as we two are together?"
fr: -- Mais rien ne peut nous arriver maintenant, dit-elle, puisque nous sommes ensemble !

eng: She surprised him by turning, in full Fifth Avenue, and flinging her arms about his neck.
fr: En pleine Cinquieme Avenue, May l'etonna en lui jetant les bras autour du cou :

eng: But you DID keep me waiting, you know! I had time to think of every horror that might possibly happen."
fr: J'ai eu le temps d'imaginer mille catastrophes.

eng: Archer said--and suddenly the same black abyss yawned before him and he felt himself sinking into it, deeper and deeper, while his voice rambled on smoothly and cheerfully: "Yes, of course I thought I'd lost the ring; no wedding would be complete if the poor devil of a bridegroom didn't go through that.
fr: dit Archer, -- et de nouveau l'abime s'ouvrait devant lui, pendant que sa voix articulait tendrement et gaiement : -- J'ai cru avoir perdu la bague. Ce frisson-la fait partie de la ceremonie ! C'est un peu votre faute, vous m'avez bien fait attendre !

eng: "Darling!"
fr: -- Cherie !

eng: She turned to him with a triumphant smile and their hands clasped under her veil.
fr: Elle se retourna vers lui avec un sourire triomphant et leurs mains s'unirent sous les voiles de tulle.

eng: The footman, who had a still bigger white favour on his lapel, wrapped May's white cloak about her, and Archer jumped into the brougham at her side.
fr: Le valet de pied, decore aussi d'une cocarde blanche, enveloppa May d'un manteau neigeux, et Archer sauta dans le coupe a cote d'elle.

eng: And now he and his wife were pacing slowly down the nave, carried forward on the light Mendelssohn ripples, the spring day beckoning to them through widely opened doors, and Mrs. Welland's chestnuts, with big white favours on their frontlets, curvetting and showing off at the far end of the canvas tunnel.
fr: Lentement il descendit la nef avec May : les ondes rythmees de la marche les accompagnerent jusqu'aux portes grandes ouvertes, au travers desquelles la belle journee de printemps semblait les accueillir. Les alezans de Mrs Welland, de gros noeuds de ruban blanc au frontail, piaffaient devant la tente.

eng: Perhaps the glimpse, among the anonymous spectators in the transept, of a dark coil of hair under a hat which, a moment later, revealed itself as belonging to an unknown lady with a long nose, so laughably unlike the person whose image she had evoked that he asked himself if he were becoming subject to hallucinations.
fr: Etait-ce pour avoir apercu dans la foule anonyme cette masse de cheveux sombres, sous le bord d'un chapeau ? Mais, un instant apres, ce n'etait qu'une dame inconnue au long nez. Il aurait pu rire de s'y etre presque trompe, et se demander s'il devenait le jouet d'hallucinations.

eng: What was it that had sent him there, he wondered?
fr: Comment son imagination s'egarait-elle ainsi ?

eng: young Newland nervously hissed; and once more Archer became aware of having been adrift far off in the unknown.
fr: dit, entre ses dents, van der Luyden Newland. Archer eut de nouveau la sensation de revenir de tres loin...

eng: "Your arm--I SAY, GIVE HER YOUR ARM!"
fr: -- Votre bras, donnez-lui votre bras !

eng: "Dearly beloved, we are gathered together here," the Rector began ...
fr: << Reunis ici sous le regard de Dieu... >> L'office commencait.

eng: Wild rumours had been abroad the day before to the effect that Mrs. Manson Mingott, in spite of her physical disabilities, had resolved on being present at the ceremony;
fr: De vagues rumeurs avaient circule la veille ; on disait que Mrs Manson Mingott, dans son obesite impotente, pretendait assister a la ceremonie.

eng: Overhead, Handel's March swelled pompously through the imitation stone vaulting, carrying on its waves the faded drift of the many weddings at which, with cheerful indifference, he had stood on the same chancel step watching other brides float up the nave toward other bridegrooms.
fr: La marche nuptiale de Haendel roulait pompeusement sous les voutes de stuc, evoquant la vision de tous les mariages auxquels Archer avait assiste avec une sereine indifference, tandis que d'autres maries s'avancaient vers l'autel.

eng: Her large pink face was appropriately solemn, and her plum-coloured satin with pale blue side-panels, and blue ostrich plumes in a small satin bonnet, met with general approval;
fr: L'expression de sa large figure rose avait la solennite voulue ; sa robe prune aux panneaux bleu pale, sa petite capote de satin ornee de plumes turquoises, eveillerent l'approbation generale.

eng: Archer made the gesture which he had seen so many bridegrooms make: with his ungloved right hand he felt in the pocket of his dark grey waistcoat, and assured himself that the little gold circlet (engraved inside: Newland to May, April ---, 187-) was in its place;
fr: Archer fit le meme geste que tous les maries avaient fait avant lui : de sa main droite degantee, il s'assura qu'il avait bien dans la poche de son gilet le petit anneau d'or grave de leurs deux noms : << Newland a May, avril 187... >>

eng: whispered young van der Luyden Newland, who was inexperienced in the duties of a best man, and awed by the weight of his responsibility.
fr: chuchota van der Luyden Newland tout neuf dans son role, et qui semblait ecrase sous le poids de sa responsabilite.

eng: "Got the ring all right?"
fr: -- Vous avez la bague ?

eng: and a private compartment had been engaged in the train that was to carry the young couple to their unknown destination--concealment of the spot in which the bridal night was to be spent being one of the most sacred taboos of the prehistoric ritual.
fr: Le mystere sur le lieu ou devait s'ecouler la nuit nuptiale etait l'element le plus sacre du rite immemorial.

eng: his own luggage was already at Mrs. Manson Mingott's, where the wedding-breakfast was to take place, and so were the travelling clothes into which he was to change;
fr: Le dejeuner devait avoir lieu chez Mrs Manson Mingott. Les bagages d'Archer y avaient ete envoyes, ainsi que ses vetements de voyage, et un compartiment avait ete reserve dans le train qui devait emmener les jeunes maries vers une destination inconnue.

eng: the fees for the Bishop and the Rector were safely in the pocket of his best man;
fr: Les offrandes destinees a l'eveque et au pasteur etaient en securite dans la poche du premier garcon d'honneur.

eng: Archer had sat up half the night trying to vary the wording of his thanks for the last batch of presents from men friends and ex-lady-loves;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The bridesmaids' eight bouquets of white lilac and lilies-of-the-valley had been sent in due time, as well as the gold and sapphire sleeve-links of the eight ushers and the best man's cat's-eye scarf-pin;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: So far he was reasonably sure of having fulfilled all his obligations.
fr: Rien n'etait oublie, ni les huit bouquets de lilas blanc et de muguet des demoiselles d'honneur, ni les boutons de manchettes (saphirs a montures d'or) des garcons d'honneur, ni l'epingle de cravate (un oeil de chat) choisie pour le jeune van der Luyden Newland.

eng: Everything was equally easy--or equally painful, as one chose to put it--in the path he was committed to tread, and he had obeyed the flurried injunctions of his best man as piously as other bridegrooms had obeyed his own, in the days when he had guided them through the same labyrinth.
fr: Il obeissait scrupuleusement aux injonctions agitees de son garcon d'honneur, comme autrefois les maries qu'il avait diriges a travers le meme labyrinthe, lui avaient obei a lui-meme.

eng: During this unavoidable lapse of time the bridegroom, in proof of his eagerness, was expected to expose himself alone to the gaze of the assembled company; and Archer had gone through this formality as resignedly as through all the others which made of a nineteenth century New York wedding a rite that seemed to belong to the dawn of history.
fr: C'etait la regle : le fiance devait temoigner de son empressement, en s'exposant ainsi seul aux regards de l'assemblee. Archer se resignait a cette formalite, comme a toutes les autres exigences d'un rite qui semblait venir de la nuit des temps.

eng: The signal meant that the brougham bearing the bride and her father was in sight; but there was sure to be a considerable interval of adjustment and consultation in the lobby, where the bridesmaids were already hovering like a cluster of Easter blossoms.
fr: Mais il fallait s'attendre encore a d'assez longs preliminaires sous le portail, ou les huit demoiselles d'honneur se groupaient deja en un bouquet d'avril.

eng: Newland Archer, at a signal from the sexton, had come out of the vestry and placed himself with his best man on the chancel step of Grace Church.
fr: Newland Archer, sur un signal du suisse, etait sorti de la sacristie, et avait pris place, avec son premier garcon d'honneur, le jeune van der Luyden Newland, sur les marches du choeur : le coupe de la mariee etait en vue.

eng: All the old ladies in both families had got out their faded sables and yellowing ermines, and the smell of camphor from the front pews almost smothered the faint spring scent of the lilies banking the altar.
fr: Les vieilles dames des deux familles avaient exhume leurs zibelines decolorees et leurs hermines jaunies ; une odeur de camphre s'elevait des premiers bancs de l'assistance, etouffant le doux parfum de printemps qui montait des lys autour de l'autel.

eng: The day was fresh, with a lively spring wind full of dust.
fr: La journee de printemps etait fraiche et le vent soufflait, charge d'une poussiere penetrante.

eng: Book II XIX.
fr: XIX

eng: "Oh Newland, how wonderful! I'm so glad! But, dearest, why do you keep on laughing? Do hush, or you'll wake Mamma."
fr: -- Je suis si heureuse ! Mais, mon cheri, pourquoi ris-tu comme ca ? Tais-toi. Tu vas reveiller maman.

eng: Janey fell upon his neck and pressed him to her purple flannel breast.
fr: Janey se jeta sur lui et le pressant contre elle : -- Oh ! Newland ! Quelle bonne nouvelle !

eng: "Nothing's the matter, except that I'm going to be married in a month."
fr: -- Je n'ai rien... sinon que je me marie dans six semaines.

eng: "For mercy's sake what's the matter?"
fr: Newland ! Qu'est-ce que tu as ?

eng: He threw back his head with a long laugh.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "The first week?"
fr: -- Tu dis : la premiere semaine ?

eng: "Easter? Newland! Why, of course, the first week in April. Why?"
fr: -- Paques ? Mais, la premiere semaine d'avril ! Pourquoi me demandes-tu cela, Newland ?

eng: then, resuming his former attitude, his tall hat and pearl-grey gloves with black stitchings grasped in his left hand, he stood looking at the door of the church.
fr: Puis il se remit en position, son chapeau haut de forme et ses gants gris-perle, soutaches de noir, serres dans sa main gauche ; et il recommenca de surveiller la porte de l'eglise.

eng: "How like a first night at the Opera!"
fr: -- On dirait une premiere a l'Opera, pensa-t-il.

eng: "The first week, did you say?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: After that there was still time to review, one by one, the familiar countenances in the first rows; the women's sharp with curiosity and excitement, the men's sulky with the obligation of having to put on their frock-coats before luncheon, and fight for food at the wedding-breakfast.
fr: Ensuite, il eut le temps de passer la revue des visages familiers : les femmes curieuses, interessees ; les hommes, maussades d'avoir eu a endosser leur redingote des le matin, et ennuyes de la perspective d'avoir a jouer des coudes pour s'approcher du buffet apres la ceremonie.

eng: Mrs. Welland came first, on the arm of her eldest son.
fr: Mrs Welland marchait en tete, au bras de son fils aine.

eng: he thought, recognising all the same faces in the same boxes (no, pews), and wondering if, when the Last Trump sounded, Mrs. Selfridge Merry would be there with the same towering ostrich feathers in her bonnet, and Mrs. Beaufort with the same diamond earrings and the same smile--and whether suitable proscenium seats were already prepared for them in another world.
fr: ~~~ Reconnaissant les memes figures dans les memes loges... (non ! c'etaient des bancs)... il se demandait si, lorsque retentirait la trompette du jugement dernier, Mrs Selfridge Merry aurait son meme panache de marabout, Mrs Beaufort ses memes diamants aux oreilles, son meme sourire aux levres ; et si des avant-scenes etaient deja reservees pour ces dames dans l'autre monde.

eng: The door was softly shut again; then after another interval it swung majestically open, and a murmur ran through the church: "The family!"
fr: La porte fut doucement refermee, puis rouverte a deux battants ; un murmure courut dans l'assemblee : c'etait la famille de la mariee.

eng: The cautious opening of the door of the church meant only that Mr. Brown the livery-stable keeper (gowned in black in his intermittent character of sexton) was taking a preliminary survey of the scene before marshalling his forces.
fr: Il savait que la porte de l'eglise ne s'ouvrait encore que pour le suisse, qui jetait un coup d'oeil sur la scene avant de mobiliser ses forces.

eng: but the bridegroom knew better.
fr: ... mais le marie ne s'emut pas.

eng: breathed the best man excitedly;
fr: souffla le premier garcon d'honneur ;

eng: "THERE THEY COME!"
fr: Les voila !

eng: "And all the while, I suppose," he thought, "real people were living somewhere, and real things happening to them ..."
fr: << Et pendant ce temps, pensait-il, il y a dans le monde des etres reels, qui se debattent dans la verite de la vie !...

eng: Yet there was a time when Archer had had definite and rather aggressive opinions on all such problems, and when everything concerning the manners and customs of his little tribe had seemed to him fraught with world-wide significance.
fr: Pourtant il y eut un temps ou Archer avait eu des opinions definies et plutot aggressives sur tous ces problemes, et ou tout ce qui concernait les moeurs et les coutumes de sa petite tribu lui avait semble plein d'importance mondiale.

eng: and it seemed inconceivable to Archer that grown-up people should work themselves into a state of agitation over such trifles, and that the matter should have been decided (in the negative) by Mrs. Welland's saying, with indignant tears: "I should as soon turn the reporters loose in my house."
fr: et il trouvait inconcevable que l'on s'agitat ainsi pour ces enfantillages, et que la question ait ete resolue (par la negative) par Mrs Welland disant, les larmes de colere aux yeux : << J'aimerais autant lacher les reporters dans ma maison ! >>

eng: A stormy discussion as to whether the wedding presents should be "shown" had darkened the last hours before the wedding;
fr: Une discussion houleuse sur la question de savoir si les cadeaux de noces seraient exposes : les dernieres heures avant le mariage en avaient ete assombries.

eng: The things that had filled his days seemed now like a nursery parody of life, or like the wrangles of mediaeval schoolmen over metaphysical terms that nobody had ever understood.
fr: Les choses qui avaient rempli ses jours lui semblaient maintenant comme une parodie enfantine de la vie, ou comme les querelles des scolastiques du moyen age sur des termes metaphysiques que personne n'avait jamais compris.

eng: but before she had settled herself with a stately rustle in the pew opposite Mrs. Archer's the spectators were craning their necks to see who was coming after her.
fr: Mais avant que l'imposant frou-frou des jupes de soie se fut apaise, les spectateurs se retournaient pour apercevoir la suite du cortege.

eng: Archer wondered how many flaws Lefferts's keen eyes would discover in the ritual of his divinity;
fr: Archer se demandait combien de defauts les yeux perspicaces de Lefferts decouvriraient dans le rituel de sa divinite ;

eng: and on the far side of the ribbon, Lawrence Lefferts's sleekly brushed head seemed to mount guard over the invisible deity of "Good Form" who presided at the ceremony.
fr: De l'autre cote du ruban, la tete bien lissee de Lawrence Lefferts semblait monter la garde pour preserver de toute offense l'implacable divinite du << Bon-Ton. >>

eng: Beside him sat his wife, all silvery chinchilla and violets;
fr: A cote de lui se trouvait Mrs Beaufort, couronnee de violettes et tout argentee de chinchilla.

eng: On the hither side of the white ribbon dividing off the seats reserved for the families he saw Beaufort, tall and redfaced, scrutinising the women with his arrogant stare.
fr: En avant du ruban blanc tendu entre les bancs des deux familles et ceux des invites, il vit Beaufort, grand, haut en couleur, qui devisageait les femmes de son air arrogant.

eng: he thought, looking at his sister, "even by screwing her head around she can see only the people in the few front pews; and they're mostly dowdy Newlands and Dagonets."
fr: elle a beau se disloquer le cou, elle ne peut voir que les premiers rangs des Newland et des Dagonet, cossus, mais poncifs.

eng: "Poor Janey!"
fr: -- Pauvre Janey, songea-t-il en regardant sa soeur,

eng: Archer's eyes lingered a moment on the left-hand pew, where his mother, who had entered the church on Mr. Henry van der Luyden's arm, sat weeping softly under her Chantilly veil, her hands in her grandmother's ermine muff.
fr: Les yeux d'Archer s'arreterent un moment sur le banc de gauche, ou sa mere, entree au bras de Mr Henry van der Luyden, etait assise. Elle pleurait doucement sous son voile de Chantilly, les mains dans le manchon d'hermine de sa grand'mere.

eng: It's to be served at small tables, in the new English fashion."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: then he suddenly recalled that he too had once thought such questions important.
fr: puis il se rappela soudain qu'il avait lui aussi juge ces questions importantes autrefois.

eng: And he could imagine Sillerton Jackson adding with authority: "My dear fellow, haven't you heard?
fr: Et sans doute Sillerton Jackson repondait avec autorite : << Ne vous a-t-on pas dit, mon cher ami, que le lunch sera servi par petites tables, a la nouvelle mode anglaise ? >>

eng: "Too bad the breakfast is at old Catherine's," the bridegroom could fancy Reggie Chivers saying.
fr: Il croyait entendre dire a Reggie Chivers : << C'est malheureux que le lunch soit chez la vieille Catherine ;

eng: "But I'm told that Lovell Mingott insisted on its being cooked by his own chef, so it ought to be good if one can only get at it."
fr: mais on dit que Lovell Mingott l'a fait preparer par son chef : cela sera donc mangeable, si l'on peut s'en approcher. >>

eng: Even in the tumult of new discoveries Archer remembered his indignant exclamation, and the fact that since then his wife had never named Madame Olenska to him.
fr: >> Il se souvint de sa riposte indignee. ~~~ Il se rendit compte aussi que, depuis lors, sa femme n'avait plus prononce devant lui le nom de Mme Olenska.

eng: Her careless allusion had no doubt been the straw held up to see which way the wind blew; the result had been reported to the family, and thereafter Archer had been tacitly omitted from their counsels.
fr: L'allusion de May n'avait ete sans doute que le brin de paille leve pour voir d'ou vient le vent. ~~~ Le resultat avait ete communique a la famille, et Archer tacitement exclu de leurs conseils.

eng: He admired the tribal discipline which made May bow to this decision.
fr: Il admirait la discipline de tribu qui soumettait May a cette decision.

eng: She would not have done so, he knew, had her conscience protested; but she probably shared the family view that Madame Olenska would be better off as an unhappy wife than as a separated one, and that there was no use in discussing the case with Newland, who had an awkward way of suddenly not seeming to take the most fundamental things for granted.
fr: Elle trouvait probablement, avec sa famille, que Mme Olenska aurait une meilleure situation comme femme malheureuse que comme femme separee, et qu'il etait inutile de discuter le cas avec Newland, qui mettait parfois en doute les verites les plus evidentes.

eng: Archer looked up and met his visitor's anxious gaze. ~~~ "Don't you know, Monsieur--is it possible you don't know--that the family begin to doubt if they have the right to advise the Countess to refuse her husband's last proposals?"
fr: -- Est-il possible, reprit M. Riviere, que vous ne sachiez pas que la famille se demande si elle a le droit de conseiller a la comtesse Olenska le refus des dernieres propositions de son mari ?

eng: "The proposals you brought?"
fr: -- Celles que vous avez apportees ?

eng: "The proposals I brought."
fr: -- Celles que j'ai apportees.

eng: It was on Archer's lips to exclaim that whatever he knew or did not know was no concern of M. Riviere's; but something in the humble and yet courageous tenacity of M. Riviere's gaze made him reject this conclusion, and he met the young man's question with another.
fr: Archer fut sur le point de repondre que ce qu'il pouvait savoir ou ne pas savoir ne regardait en rien M. Riviere ; mais l'attitude du jeune homme lui en imposait, et il repondit a la question par une autre.

eng: Archer looked at him with increasing astonishment.
fr: Archer le regarda avec un etonnement croissant.

eng: "What is your object in speaking to me of this?"
fr: '-- Quel est votre but en venant me parler de tout ceci ?'

eng: "May I ask," he said at length, "if this is the line you took with the Countess Olenska?"
fr: '-- Puis-je vous demander, dit-il enfin, si c'est dans ce sens que vous avez parle a Mme Olenska ?'

eng: He had not to wait a moment for the answer.
fr: La reponse ne se fit pas attendre.

eng: "I should not have accepted it."
fr: '-- Je ne l'aurais pas acceptee.'

eng: "So I supposed: you could hardly have accepted such a mission otherwise."
fr: '-- Evidemment ; sinon, vous auriez difficilement accepte une pareille mission.'

eng: "No, Monsieur: I accepted my mission in good faith. I really believed--for reasons I need not trouble you with--that it would be better for Madame Olenska to recover her situation, her fortune, the social consideration that her husband's standing gives her."
fr: '-- J'ai accepte ma mission de bonne foi. Je croyais vraiment, pour des raisons dont il est inutile que je vous importune, qu'il valait mieux pour Mme Olenska retrouver la situation, la fortune et les conditions sociales que la position de son mari lui assure.'

eng: M. Riviere reddened, but his eyes did not falter.
fr: M. Riviere rougit, mais ses yeux ne se baisserent point.

eng: Archer considered.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was no mistaking the sincerity of his distress or the strength of his determination: he had evidently resolved to let everything go by the board but the supreme need of thus putting himself on record.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "To beg you, Monsieur--to beg you with all the force I'm capable of--not to let her go back.--Oh, don't let her!"
fr: '-- Je viens vous prier, monsieur, vous prier avec toute la force dont je suis capable, de ne pas laisser la comtesse Olenska retourner aupres de son mari.'

eng: "Well, then--?"
fr: -- Alors ?

eng: Archer paused again, and their eyes met in another protracted scrutiny.
fr: Durant un silence, leurs regards se croiserent, cherchant a se penetrer.

eng: "Ah, Monsieur, after I had seen her, after I had listened to her, I knew she was better off here."
fr: '-- Ah ! ~~~ monsieur, apres l'avoir vue, apres l'avoir ecoutee, j'ai compris qu'elle etait mieux ici.

eng: "You knew--?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Monsieur, I discharged my mission faithfully: I put the Count's arguments,"
fr: "J'ai rempli ma mission loyalement. J'ai developpe les arguments du comte."

eng: "I stated his offers, without adding any comment of my own."
fr: "J'ai communique ses offres, sans y ajouter aucun commentaire personnel."

eng: The Countess was good enough to listen patiently; she carried her goodness so far as to see me twice; she considered impartially all I had come to say.
fr: La comtesse a bien voulu m'ecouter patiemment ; elle a pousse la bonte jusqu'a me recevoir deux fois ; elle a etudie impartialement tout ce que j'etais venu lui dire.

eng: And it was in the course of these two talks that I changed my mind, that I came to see things differently."
fr: Et c'est au cours de ces deux conversations que j'ai change d'avis, et que les choses me sont apparues sous un autre jour.

eng: "Then you knew her before?"
fr: "-- Vous connaissiez donc deja la comtesse ?"

eng: "May I ask what led to this change?"
fr: "-- Puis-je vous demander a quoi est du ce revirement ?"

eng: "Simply seeing the change in HER," M. Riviere replied.
fr: "-- Au changement que j'ai constate en elle."

eng: "The young man's colour again rose."
fr: "Le visage du jeune homme se colora a nouveau."

eng: "I used to see her in her husband's house.
fr: -- Je la voyais chez son mari.

eng: I have known Count Olenski for many years.
fr: Je connais le comte Olenski depuis plusieurs annees.

eng: "The change--what sort of a change?"
fr: '-- Et de quel genre est ce changement que vous avez constate ?'

eng: "You can imagine that he would not have sent a stranger on such a mission."
fr: 'Vous comprenez qu'il n'aurait pu charger un etranger d'une pareille mission.'

eng: "And that if you're an American of HER kind--of your kind--things that are accepted in certain other societies, or at least put up with as part of a general convenient give-and-take--become unthinkable, simply unthinkable."
fr: 'Si les parents de Mme Olenska connaissaient mieux le milieu ou il s'agit pour elle de rentrer, ils la soutiendraient dans son refus ; mais ils ont l'air de prendre la demarche du comte pour un elan de tendresse conjugale...'

eng: "Tenez--the discovery, I suppose, of what I'd never thought of before: that she's an American."
fr: 'Apres tout, ce n'est peut-etre pas elle qui a change, c'est moi qui me suis rendu compte pour la premiere fois, en la voyant dans son pays, qu'elle est une Americaine, et que certaines choses acceptees dans d'autres, societes, ou au moins tolerees, pour une Americaine de son espece sont impossibles.'
(No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Thank you," Archer said simply.
fr: '-- Merci, dit-il, simplement.'

eng: During this interval he heard M. Riviere's chair pushed back, and was aware that the young man had risen.
fr: 'Il entendit M. Riviere reculer sa chaise, comprit que celui-ci s'etait leve, et, ayant tourne les yeux vers lui, il le vit aussi emu qu'il l'etait lui-meme.'

eng: For a second or two he could not trust himself to speak.
fr: 'Pendant quelques secondes, Archer ne se sentit pas assez maitre de lui pour prononcer une parole.'

eng: "Archer's gaze, wandering away to the blank walls of the office, rested on a hanging calendar surmounted by the rugged features of the President of the United States. That such a conversation should be going on anywhere within the millions of square miles subject to his rule seemed as strange as anything that the imagination could invent."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Whereas it's far from being as simple as that."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ah, Monsieur, if I could tell you!"
fr: 'Cela est difficile a expliquer...'

eng: "If Madame Olenska's relations understood what these things were, their opposition to her returning would no doubt be as unconditional as her own; but they seem to regard her husband's wish to have her back as proof of an irresistible longing for domestic life."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "There's nothing to thank me for, Monsieur: it is I, rather--" M. Riviere broke off, as if speech for him too were difficult.
fr: -- Vous n'avez pas a me remercier, monsieur, c'est moi qui... plutot... M. Riviere s'arreta comme s'il eprouvait, lui aussi, une difficulte a parler.

eng: That's all, Monsieur."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But from the moment that I have taken the step of coming here to say these things to you I consider myself discharged, and I shall tell him so on my return, and give him the reasons.
fr: mais, depuis que j'ai fait la demarche de venir vous voir pour vous faire certaines confidences, je considere que je ne puis continuer mes fonctions aupres du comte. Je le lui dirai en arrivant.

eng: I am at this moment: I returned to him, a few months ago, for reasons of private necessity such as may happen to any one who has persons, ill and older persons, dependent on him.
fr: Je suis revenu chez lui, il y a quelques mois, en raison de difficultes personnelles comme il s'en presente quand on a la charge de parents malades ou ages ;

eng: You asked me if I was in Count Olenski's employ.
fr: vous m'avez demande si j'etais au service du comte Olenski.

eng: XXVI. Every year on the fifteenth of October Fifth Avenue opened its shutters, unrolled its carpets and hung up its triple layer of window-curtains.
fr: XXVI Tous les ans, le quinze octobre, la Cinquieme Avenue rouvrait ses persiennes, deroulait ses tapis et raccrochait ses triples rideaux.

eng: "I should like, though," he continued in a firmer voice, "to add one thing.
fr: Puis il continua d'une voix plus ferme : -- Je voudrais cependant ajouter une chose,

eng: By the first of November this household ritual was over, and society had begun to look about and take stock of itself.
fr: Vers le premier novembre, ces preparatifs etaient termines, et la vie mondaine recommencait.

eng: By the fifteenth the season was in full blast, Opera and theatres were putting forth their new attractions, dinner-engagements were accumulating, and dates for dances being fixed.
fr: Vers le quinze, la saison battait son plein : l'opera et les theatres affichaient leurs nouveaux programmes, les invitations pleuvaient ; on fixait les dates des bals.

eng: "Thank you," Archer said again, as their hands met.
fr: Archer lui tendit les mains et les deux hommes s'etreignirent.

eng: M. Riviere bowed and drew back a step.
fr: M. Riviere salua, pret a se retirer.

eng: And punctually at about this time Mrs. Archer always said that New York was very much changed.
fr: Et, invariablement, a cette epoque, Mrs Archer disait que New-York etait bien change.

eng: Observing it from the lofty stand-point of a non-participant, she was able, with the help of Mr. Sillerton Jackson and Miss Sophy, to trace each new crack in its surface, and all the strange weeds pushing up between the ordered rows of social vegetables.
fr: Mrs Archer vivait retiree du monde et l'observait du haut de sa solitude. ~~~ Secondee par Mr Jackson et Miss Sophy, elle notait chaque craquement nouveau a la surface de la societe, chaque plante intruse qui cherchait a pousser entre les carres reguliers des gros legumes mondains.

eng: It had been one of the amusements of Archer's youth to wait for this annual pronouncement of his mother's, and to hear her enumerate the minute signs of disintegration that his careless gaze had overlooked.
fr: Toute sa jeunesse durant, Archer s'etait amuse de cet oracle annuel, et d'entendre enumerer de menus signes de desagregation qui avaient echappe a son insouciance de jeune homme.

eng: For New York, to Mrs. Archer's mind, never changed without changing for the worse; and in this view Miss Sophy Jackson heartily concurred.
fr: Selon Mrs Archer, New-York ne changeait que pour empirer, et Miss Sophy Jackson, la-dessus, rencherissait.

eng: These points had been raised, as usual, at Mrs. Archer's Thanksgiving dinner.
fr: Ce sujet fut aborde comme d'habitude au diner du Thanksgiving Day[1] que donnait Mrs Archer.

eng: At the date when she was officially enjoined to give thanks for the blessings of the year it was her habit to take a mournful though not embittered stock of her world, and wonder what there was to be thankful for.
fr: A la date ou elle etait officiellement invitee a rendre graces pour les benedictions de l'annee, elle avait coutume de faire, avec tristesse, quoique sans amertume, le bilan de son petit univers, et de se demander quel objet donner a sa gratitude.

eng: At any rate, not the state of society; society, if it could be said to exist, was rather a spectacle on which to call down Biblical imprecations--and in fact, every one knew what the Reverend Dr. Ashmore meant when he chose a text from Jeremiah (chap. ii., verse 25) for his Thanksgiving sermon.
fr: Ce n'etait certes pas l'etat de la societe. La societe, -- si toutefois elle existait encore ! -- offrait plutot un spectacle digne des maledictions bibliques et, du reste, chacun savait quelles etaient les intentions du reverend Dr Ashmore quand il avait choisi comme texte un passage de Jeremie pour son sermon d'action de graces.

eng: But even he never denied that New York had changed; and Newland Archer, in the winter of the second year of his marriage, was himself obliged to admit that if it had not actually changed it was certainly changing.
fr: Cependant, il ne pouvait nier que la societe changeat. ~~~ Meme Newland Archer, le second hiver apres son mariage, fut oblige d'avouer que, si le changement n'etait pas encore accompli, certainement il etait en cours.

eng: Mr. Sillerton Jackson, as became a man of the world, suspended his judgment and listened with an amused impartiality to the lamentations of the ladies.
fr: Mr Sillerton Jackson, en homme du monde, pretait l'oreille aux lamentations des dames, et suspendait son jugement.

eng: "There's no doubt that Dr. Ashmore is right: there IS a marked trend," she said, as if it were something visible and measurable, like a crack in a house.
fr: -- Il n'y a pas de doute, le docteur Ashmore a raison, disait-elle en secouant la tete.

eng: Dr. Ashmore, the new Rector of St. Matthew's, had been chosen because he was very "advanced": his sermons were considered bold in thought and novel in language.  (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: Ce n'etait certes pas l'etat de la societe. La societe, -- si toutefois elle existait encore ! -- offrait plutot un spectacle digne des maledictions bibliques et, du reste, chacun savait quelles etaient les intentions du reverend Dr Ashmore quand il avait choisi comme texte un passage de Jeremie pour son sermon d'action de graces.

eng: "Oh,--" the ladies murmured; and Mrs. Archer added, partly to distract her daughter's attention from forbidden topics: "Poor Regina! Her Thanksgiving hasn't been a very cheerful one, I'm afraid.'
fr: -- Oh ! firent les dames, et Mrs Archer ajouta : -- La pauvre Regina, son jour de Thanksgiving n'a pas ete bien gai.'

eng: "Like her rivals," said Mr. Sillerton Jackson, with the air of producing an epigram.
fr: -- A ses rivales, dit Mr Sillerton Jackson, comme pour lancer une epigramme.

eng: "It was Beaufort who started the new fashion by making his wife clap her new clothes on her back as soon as they arrived: I must say at times it takes all Regina's distinction not to look like ... like ..." Miss Jackson glanced around the table, caught Janey's bulging gaze, and took refuge in an unintelligible murmur.
fr: -- C'est Beaufort qui a lance le nouveau genre, en faisant arborer a sa femme ses toilettes parisiennes des leur arrivee. Quelquefois il faut toute la distinction de Regina pour ne pas ressembler a... a... Miss Jackson jeta un regard autour de la table, surprit les yeux ronds de Janey, et finit sa phrase dans un murmure inintelligible.

eng: "Ah, well, Boston is more conservative than New York; but I always think it's a safe rule for a lady to lay aside her French dresses for one season," Mrs. Archer conceded.
fr: -- Boston est plus conservateur que New-York ; mais je trouve plus comme il faut de ne porter ses robes francaises qu'apres une saison, dit Mrs Archer.

eng: Old Mrs. Baxter Pennilow, who did everything handsomely, used to import twelve a year, two velvet, two satin, two silk, and the other six of poplin and the finest cashmere. It was a standing order, and as she was ill for two years before she died they found forty-eight Worth dresses that had never been taken out of tissue paper; and when the girls left off their mourning they were able to wear the first lot at the Symphony concerts without looking in advance of the fashion."
fr: La vieille Mrs Baxter Pennilow, qui faisait tres bien les choses, faisait venir douze robes par an : deux de satin, deux de soie et six autres de popeline ou de cachemire fin. C'etait une commande a date fixe, et comme elle a ete alitee pendant deux ans avant sa mort, ses filles ont trouve quarante-huit robes de Worth qui etaient toujours restees dans leur papier de soie.

eng: "Yes; she's one of the few. In my youth," Miss Jackson rejoined, "it was considered vulgar to dress in the newest fashions; and Amy Sillerton has always told me that in Boston the rule was to put away one's Paris dresses for two years.
fr: -- Oui, reprit Miss Jackson, elle est du petit nombre de celles qui gardent les traditions. Dans ma jeunesse, il etait de mauvais gout de porter les dernieres modes ; Amy Sillerton m'a toujours dit qu'a Boston il fallait mettre en reserve pendant deux ans les robes de Paris.

eng: "Ah, Jane Merry is one of US," said Mrs. Archer sighing, as if it were not such an enviable thing to be in an age when ladies were beginning to flaunt abroad their Paris dresses as soon as they were out of the Custom House, instead of letting them mellow under lock and key, in the manner of Mrs. Archer's contemporaries.
fr: -- Ah ! Jane Merry est des notres, dit Mrs Archer en soupirant. ~~~

eng: "Sillerton took me to the first night of the Opera, and I can only tell you that Jane Merry's dress was the only one I recognised from last year; and even that had had the front panel changed. Yet I know she got it out from Worth only two years ago, because my seamstress always goes in to make over her Paris dresses before she wears them."
fr: Sillerton m'a menee a la premiere de l'Opera, et je vous affirme que Jane Merry etait la seule qui portat une robe de l'annee derniere, une robe venue de chez Worth il y a deux ans ; je le sais parce que c'est ma couturiere qui rectifie a l'arrivee ses robes de Paris.

eng: "The extravagance in dress--" Miss Jackson began.
fr: -- La folie de la toilette d'abord, commenca Miss Jackson.

eng: Archer had been wont to smile at these annual vaticinations of his mother's; but this year even he was obliged to acknowledge, as he listened to an enumeration of the changes, that the "trend" was visible. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: -- C'est egal, c'est un singulier texte pour un jour d'actions de graces, observa Miss Jackson, et son hotesse reprit sechement : -- Il nous engage a remercier le ciel pour le peu qui nous reste.

eng: "It was odd, though, to preach about it on Thanksgiving," Miss Jackson opined; and her hostess drily rejoined: "Oh, he means us to give thanks for what's left."
fr: -- C'est egal, c'est un singulier texte pour un jour d'actions de graces, observa Miss Jackson, et son hotesse reprit sechement : -- Il nous engage a remercier le ciel pour le peu qui nous reste.

eng: When he fulminated against fashionable society he always spoke of its "trend"; and to Mrs. Archer it was terrifying and yet fascinating to feel herself part of a community that was trending. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: Ce n'etait certes pas l'etat de la societe. La societe, -- si toutefois elle existait encore ! -- offrait plutot un spectacle digne des maledictions bibliques et, du reste, chacun savait quelles etaient les intentions du reverend Dr Ashmore quand il avait choisi comme texte un passage de Jeremie pour son sermon d'action de graces.

eng: Have you heard the rumours about Beaufort's speculations, Sillerton?"
fr: Avez-vous entendu parler, Sillerton, des bruits qui courent sur les speculations de Beaufort ? ~~~ Mr.

eng: Mr. Jackson nodded carelessly.
fr: Jackson fit un oui nonchalant.

eng: A gloomy silence fell upon the party.
fr: Il se fit un lourd silence.

eng: It was a long time since any well-known banker had failed discreditably; but every one remembered the social extinction visited on the heads of the firm when the last event of the kind had happened.
fr: Il n'etait personne qui ne se rappelat comment, apres la derniere faillite de Wall Street, les chefs de la maison qui croulait avaient ete frappes d'aneantissement social.

eng: Every one had heard the rumours in question, and he scorned to confirm a tale that was already common property.
fr: Tout le monde etait au courant : il dedaignait de confirmer une histoire passee deja dans le domaine public.

eng: It would be the same with the Beauforts, in spite of his power and her popularity; not all the leagued strength of the Dallas connection would save poor Regina if there were any truth in the reports of her husband's unlawful speculations.
fr: Il en serait de meme pour les Beaufort, en depit du pouvoir du banquier et de la vogue mondaine de sa femme. Toute la force liguee de ses parents ne pourrait sauver la pauvre Regina, si les bruits qu'on faisait courir sur les speculations illicites de son mari se confirmaient.

eng: The talk took refuge in less ominous topics; but everything they touched on seemed to confirm Mrs. Archer's sense of an accelerated trend.
fr: La conversation aborda des sujets moins sombres, mais qui semblaient tous renforcer chez Mrs Archer le sentiment que la societe etait en train de s'effondrer.

eng: "Of course, Newland, I know you let dear May go to Mrs. Struthers's Sunday evenings--" she began; and May interposed gaily: "Oh, you know, everybody goes to Mrs. Struthers's now; and she was invited to Granny's last reception."
fr: -- Je sais, Newland, que tu autorises la chere May a aller aux dimanches de Mrs Struthers, commenca-t-elle. May l'interrompit en riant : -- Oh ! ~~~ vous savez, tout le monde va maintenant chez Mrs Struthers. Elle a ete invitee a la derniere reception de grand'mere.

eng: It was thus, Archer reflected, that New York managed its transitions: conspiring to ignore them till they were well over, and then, in all good faith, imagining that they had taken place in a preceding age. There was always a traitor in the citadel; and after he (or generally she) had surrendered the keys, what was the use of pretending that it was impregnable? Once people had tasted of Mrs. Struthers's easy Sunday hospitality they were not likely to sit at home remembering that her champagne was transmuted Shoe-Polish.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I know, dear, I know," Mrs. Archer sighed. "Such things have to be, I suppose, as long as AMUSEMENT is what people go out for; but I've never quite forgiven your cousin Madame Olenska for being the first person to countenance Mrs. ~~~ Struthers."
fr: -- Je sais, je sais, ma cherie, soupira Mrs Archer, mais que voulez-vous, quand on ne va dans le monde que pour s'amuser ! J'en veux encore un peu a votre cousine Mme Olenska d'avoir ete la premiere a patronner Mrs Struthers.

eng: A sudden blush rose to young Mrs. Archer's face; it surprised her husband as much as the other guests about the table.
fr: Une rougeur subite colora le visage de la jeune Mrs Archer.

eng: "Oh, ELLEN--" she murmured, much in the same accusing and yet deprecating tone in which her parents might have said: "Oh, THE BLENKERS--."
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ Ellen, murmura-t-elle, du meme ton de desapprobation dont ses parents auraient dit : << Oh ! les Blenker ! >>

eng: No one really liked Beaufort, and it was not wholly unpleasant to think the worst of his private life; but the idea of his having brought financial dishonour on his wife's family was too shocking to be enjoyed even by his enemies.
fr: Personne n'aimait veritablement Beaufort, et on n'eut pas ete fache d'apprendre les pires choses sur sa vie privee. Cependant, qu'il put entacher d'un deshonneur financier la famille de sa femme, c'etait la un scandale dont ses ennemis eux-memes ne pouvaient se rejouir.

eng: It was the note which the family had taken to sounding on the mention of the Countess Olenska's name, since she had surprised and inconvenienced them by remaining obdurate to her husband's advances; but on May's lips it gave food for thought, and Archer looked at her with the sense of strangeness that sometimes came over him when she was most in the tone of her environment.
fr: C'etait la note adoptee par la famille quand il s'agissait de Mme Olenska, depuis que celle-ci, contre l'avis de ses parents, s'etait derobee aux avances de son mari. Pourtant, chez May, cette attitude surprenait ; Archer la regardait, gene, et la sentant etrangere a lui, comme cela lui arrivait chaque fois qu'elle subissait l'ambiance familiale.

eng: May's blush remained permanently vivid: it seemed to have a significance beyond that implied by the recognition of Madame Olenska's social bad faith.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I've no doubt we all seem alike to foreigners," said Miss Jackson tartly.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I don't think Ellen cares for society; but nobody knows exactly what she does care for," May continued, as if she had been groping for something noncommittal.
fr: Elle ajouta : -- Je ne crois pas qu'Ellen se soucie beaucoup de l'opinion du monde.

eng: "Ah, well--" Mrs. Archer sighed again.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Everybody knew that the Countess Olenska was no longer in the good graces of her family.
fr: Chacun savait que la comtesse Olenska n'etait plus dans les bonnes graces de sa famille.

eng: His mother, with less than her usual sensitiveness to atmosphere, still insisted: "I've always thought that people like the Countess Olenska, who have lived in aristocratic societies, ought to help us to keep up our social distinctions, instead of ignoring them."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer's New York tolerated hypocrisy in private relations; but in business matters it exacted a limpid and impeccable honesty.
fr: Le vieux New-York d'Archer tolerait l'hypocrisie dans les relations privees, mais en affaires il exigeait une honnetete complete et inattaquable.

eng: Even her devoted champion, old Mrs. Manson Mingott, had been unable to defend her refusal to return to her husband.
fr: La vieille Mrs Manson Mingott elle-meme, son champion, avait du renoncer a la defendre quand elle avait refuse de rejoindre son mari.

eng: The Mingotts had not proclaimed their disapproval aloud: their sense of solidarity was too strong.
fr: Les Mingott n'avaient pas formule tout haut leur opinion : la solidarite chez eux etait trop forte.

eng: The fact enforced the contention that she had made a fatal mistake in not returning to Count Olenski.
fr: La conclusion n'en etait que plus evidente ; elle avait commis une lourde faute en ne retournant pas chez Olenski.

eng: They had simply, as Mrs. Welland said, "let poor Ellen find her own level"--and that, mortifyingly and incomprehensibly, was in the dim depths where the Blenkers prevailed, and "people who wrote" celebrated their untidy rites.
fr: Comme le disait Mrs Welland, ils s'etaient contentes de laisser la pauvre Ellen chercher un milieu a son niveau, et elle l'avait trouve dans les obscures regions ou regnaient les Blenker, et ou les << gens de lettres >> celebraient leurs rites sans prestiges.

eng: It was incredible, but it was a fact, that Ellen, in spite of all her opportunities and her privileges, had become simply "Bohemian."
fr: C'etait incroyable, mais c'etait un fait : Ellen tournant le dos a son destin de privilegiee se declassait.

eng: "Madame Olenska is a great favourite with the gentlemen," said Miss Sophy, with her air of wishing to put forth something conciliatory when she knew that she was planting a dart.
fr: -- Mme Olenska est tres appreciee par les messieurs, observa miss Sophy avec un faux air de conciliation.

eng: "A pity? ~~~ In God's name, why?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ah, that's the danger that a young woman like Madame Olenska is always exposed to," Mrs. Archer mournfully agreed; and the ladies, on this conclusion, gathered up their trains to seek the carcel globes of the drawing-room, while Archer and Mr. Sillerton Jackson withdrew to the Gothic library.
fr: -- Ah ! ~~~ c'est la le danger pour une jeune femme comme Mme Olenska, opina tristement Mrs Archer ; et la-dessus les dames ramasserent leurs traines pour se rendre dans le salon pendant que les hommes gagnaient la bibliotheque gothique.

eng: Once established before the grate, and consoling himself for the inadequacy of the dinner by the perfection of his cigar, Mr. Jackson became portentous and communicable.
