eng: "What can't?"
fr: Qu'est-ce qui ne peut pas durer ?

eng: "If you're not blind, then, you must see that this can't last."
fr: Ellen, fit-il brusquement, comprenez-moi : ceci ne peut pas durer.

eng: The young man, trembling, felt the pressure of her shoulder, and passed his arm about her.
fr: Le jeune homme, fremissant, sentit sur lui la pression de l'epaule d'Ellen. Il lui passa le bras autour de la taille.

eng: As they gained the street Archer began to speak hurriedly.
fr: Quand ils eurent gagne la rue, Archer se mit a parler avec volubilite.

eng: "I couldn't have spoken like this yesterday, because when we've been apart, and I'm looking forward to seeing you, every thought is burnt up in a great flame."
fr: Je n'aurais pas pu vous parler ainsi hier, parce que, quand nous sommes separes et que j'aspire a vous revoir, tout mon etre s'enflamme et chacune de mes pensees me brule.

eng: I don't suppose you mind a little snow?"
fr: Un peu de neige ne vous fait pas peur.

eng: She laughed again, more gently.
fr: Elle rit encore, mais plus doucement.

eng: "No; I shan't get out and walk, because my business is to get to Granny's as quickly as I can.
fr: -- Non, je ne descendrai pas. ~~~ J'ai hate d'arriver chez grand-mere.

eng: And you'll sit beside me, and we'll look, not at visions, but at realities."
fr: Vous allez rester assis a cote de moi, et nous envisagerons ensemble non des reves, mais des realites.

eng: "I don't know what you mean by realities.
fr: -- Je ne sais pas ce que vous entendez par des realites.

eng: The only reality to me is this."
fr: Pour moi, il n'y en a qu'une.

eng: She met the words with a long silence, during which the carriage rolled down an obscure side-street and then turned into the searching illumination of Fifth Avenue.
fr: Elle ne repondit que par un long silence, pendant lequel la voiture descendait une obscure rue transversale pour deboucher dans la lumiere eclatante de la Cinquieme Avenue.

eng: "Is it your idea, then, that I should live with you as your mistress--since I can't be your wife?"
fr: -- Vous voudriez donc faire de moi votre maitresse, puisque je ne peux pas etre votre femme ?

eng: The crudeness of the question startled him: the word was one that women of his class fought shy of, even when their talk flitted closest about the topic.
fr: Cette question directe le deconcerta. Maitresse, c'etait la un mot que les femmes de son monde evitaient de prononcer.

eng: "Oh, my dear--where is that country? Have you ever been there?" she asked;
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ mon ami ! ~~~ Ou est-il, ce pays ? Y etes-vous jamais alle ?

eng: and as he remained sullenly dumb she went on:
fr: Archer restait silencieux. ~~~ Elle continua :

eng: "I know so many who've tried to find it; and, believe me, they all got out by mistake at wayside stations: at places like Boulogne, or Pisa, or Monte Carlo--and it wasn't at all different from the old world they'd left, but only rather smaller and dingier and more promiscuous."
fr: -- J'en connais tant qui ont essaye de le trouver ; et, croyez-moi, ils sont tous descendus par erreur aux stations d'a cote, a Boulogne, a Pise, a Monte-Carlo, et ils y retrouvaient toujours le meme vieux monde qu'ils voulaient abandonner, seulement plus petit, plus mesquin, plus laid.

eng: He had never heard her speak in such a tone, and he remembered the phrase she had used a little while before.
fr: Archer ne lui connaissait pas cette aprete de langage.

eng: "Well, she opened my eyes too; it's a delusion to say that she blinds people.
fr: -- Et elle m'a ouvert les yeux. Ce n'est pas vrai de dire qu'elle rend les gens aveugles.

eng: What she does is just the contrary--she fastens their eyelids open, so that they're never again in the blessed darkness.
fr: Au contraire, elle leur ouvre les yeux tout grands, elle leur coupe les paupieres. Et l'on ne connait plus jamais l'obscurite bienfaisante.

eng: Isn't there a Chinese torture like that? There ought to be. ~~~ Ah, believe me, it's a miserable little country!"
fr: Parmi les supplices qu'ont inventes les Chinois, n'en est-il pas un de ce genre ?

eng: The carriage had crossed Forty-second Street: May's sturdy brougham-horse was carrying them northward as if he had been a Kentucky trotter.
fr: La voiture avait traverse la Quarante-deuxieme Rue au trot rapide d'un cheval vigoureux.

eng: Archer choked with the sense of wasted minutes and vain words.
fr: Archer etait oppresse par le sentiment des minutes perdues, des paroles vaines.

eng: "Then what, exactly, is your plan for us?"
fr: -- Maintenant, dit-il, qu'allons-nous faire ?

eng: he asked.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "For US? But there's no US in that sense! We're near each other only if we stay far from each other.'
fr: -- Nous ? Il n'y a pas de nous dans ce sens-la ! Nous ne sommes l'un pres de l'autre qu'a condition de rester separes.'

eng: she asked.
fr: demanda-t-elle.

eng: She drew a deep sigh that ended in another laugh.
fr: Elle poussa un long soupir, qui s'acheva en un rire amer.

eng: Where we shall be simply two human beings who love each other, who are the whole of life to each other; and nothing else on earth will matter."
fr: ou nous serons simplement deux etres qui s'aiment, qui sont tout l'un pour l'autre, pour lesquels le monde ne compte pas...

eng: "Yes, the Gorgon HAS dried your tears," he said.
fr: -- Je vois, dit-il enfin : la Gorgone a brule vos larmes.

eng: Her question pulled him up with a jerk, and he floundered.
fr: Decontenance, il balbutia :

eng: He noticed that Madame Olenska pronounced it as if it had a recognised place in her vocabulary, and he wondered if it had been used familiarly in her presence in the horrible life she had fled from.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I want--I want somehow to get away with you into a world where words like that--categories like that--won't exist.
fr: -- Ce que je veux, c'est partir avec vous pour un monde ou des mots comme celui-la, -- des categories comme celles-la, -- n'existent pas :

eng: Then we can be ourselves.
fr: Alors seulement nous pouvons etre nous-memes.

eng: Otherwise we're only Newland Archer, the husband of Ellen Olenska's cousin, and Ellen Olenska, the cousin of Newland Archer's wife, trying to be happy behind the backs of the people who trust them."
fr: Autrement, nous serons Newland Archer, le mari de la cousine d'Ellen Olenska, et Ellen Olenska, la cousine de la femme de Newland Archer, volant un bonheur qui ne leur appartient pas.

eng: For a moment she was silent; then she said very low, her head bowed over her work: "I shall never worry if you're happy."
fr: -- Mon cher, suis-je tout a fait affreuse a voir ? demanda-t-elle gaiment, en ramenant sur le promontoire de sa poitrine les plis de batiste.

eng: "Ah, my dear; and I shall never be happy unless I can open the windows!"
fr: Mes filles disent que ca n'a pas d'importance a mon age, comme si la laideur n'etait pas pire a mesure qu'elle devient plus difficile a cacher !

eng: The mere fact of not looking at May, seated beside his table, under his lamp, the fact of seeing other houses, roofs, chimneys, of getting the sense of other lives outside his own, other cities beyond New York, and a whole world beyond his world, cleared his brain and made it easier to breathe.
fr: Il ne faisait rien pour essayer de la voir.

eng: ~~~ she remonstrated; and with a sigh he buried his head in his book.
fr: La vieille dame renversa la tete en riant.

eng: Six or seven days passed. Archer heard nothing from Madame Olenska, and became aware that her name would not be mentioned in his presence by any member of the family.
fr: -- Excepte Ellen ! s'amusa-t-elle a dire, en clignant des yeux malicieusement ; et avant qu'il put repondre, elle ajouta :

eng: He did not try to see her; to do so while she was at old Catherine's guarded bedside would have been almost impossible.
fr: -- Elle etait donc bien belle, le jour ou tu as ete la chercher a la gare ? Est-ce parce que tu le lui as dit qu'elle a du te deposer en route ?

eng: The strength of that resolve made it easy to wait and make no sign.
fr: Quel malheur qu'elle ne se soit pas mariee avec toi ! Je le lui ai repete cent fois...

eng: Then one day May told him that Mrs. Manson Mingott had asked to see him.
fr: Archer se demanda si la maladie avait affaibli les facultes de la vieille dame ; mais deja elle continuait :

eng: There was nothing surprising in the request, for the old lady was steadily recovering, and she had always openly declared that she preferred Archer to any of her other grandsons-in-law.
fr: -- Eh ! bien, j'ai tout arrange : Ellen va rester avec moi : la famille dira ce qu'elle voudra.

eng: May gave the message with evident pleasure: she was proud of old Catherine's appreciation of her husband.
fr: Tu as su comme ils etaient tous apres moi, Lovell et Letterblair et Augusta Welland : ils voulaient que je lui coupe les vivres : histoire de lui dicter sa conduite.

eng: There was a moment's pause, and then Archer felt it incumbent on him to say: "All right. Shall we go together this afternoon?"
fr: Ils ont cru m'avoir decidee quand je ne sais quel secretaire est arrive avec les dernieres propositions du mari.

eng: His wife's face brightened, but she instantly answered: "Oh, you'd much better go alone. It bores Granny to see the same people too often."
fr: Le gaillard se montrait genereux.

eng: In the uncertainty of the situation he let himself drift, conscious, somewhere below the surface of his thoughts, of a resolve which had come to him when he had leaned out from his library window into the icy night.
fr: De mon temps, les jeunes gens ne quittaient ainsi les jolies femmes que si elles les y obligeaient...

eng: "Because I shall never be able to open a window without worrying you," he rejoined, laughing also.
fr: La mulatresse disparut et la vieille dame se retourna vers son petit-fils.

eng: ~~~ he said.
fr: -- Sapho, dit-elle a la femme de chambre, ne laissez entrer personne.

eng: "Poor May!"
fr: Elle tendit a Archer une des petites mains qui etaient nichees sur ses larges genoux comme des souris blanches.

eng: She bent over her work-frame, and as he passed he laid his hand on her hair.
fr: Dans son bonnet tuyaute, attache par un noeud empese entre ses deux premiers mentons, le fichu de mousseline croise sur les vagues de sa robe de chambre violette, on aurait pu la prendre pour le portrait de quelque aieule bienveillante et avisee, gonflee outre mesure par les plaisirs gastronomiques.

eng: He shook his head and turned toward his arm-chair.
fr: Elle etait seulement plus pale, avec des ombres plus noires dans les plis de son visage trop gras.

eng: After he had leaned out into the darkness for a few minutes he heard her say: "Newland! Do shut the window. You'll catch your death."
fr: Une resolution germait en lui depuis qu'il s'etait penche a la fenetre de sa bibliotheque dans la nuit glacee.

eng: He pulled the sash down and turned back.
fr: La force grandissante de cette resolution lui donnait du calme pour supporter l'attente.

eng: ~~~ And suddenly the play of the word flashed up a wild suggestion. What if it were SHE who was dead!
fr: Son coeur battait violemment quand il sonna chez la vieille Mrs Mingott.

eng: ~~~ If she were going to die--to die soon--and leave him free!
fr: Il etait la, sur les marches du seuil : derriere la porte, derriere les rideaux du boudoir de damas jaune, la comtesse Olenska l'attendait surement.

eng: ~~~ The sensation of standing there, in that warm familiar room, and looking at her, and wishing her dead, was so strange, so fascinating and overmastering, that its enormity did not immediately strike him.
fr: Dans un moment, il la verrait ; il pourrait lui parler, avant d'etre introduit dans la chambre de la malade.

eng: He simply felt that chance had given him a new possibility to which his sick soul might cling.
fr: Il voulait seulement lui poser une question ; apres, il savait ce qu'il aurait a faire...

eng: Yes, May might die--people did: young people, healthy people like herself: she might die, and set him suddenly free.
fr: Quelle ne fut pas sa deception, quand il ne trouva que la mulatresse qui l'introduisit aupres de la vieille Catherine !

eng: She glanced up, and he saw by her widening eyes that there must be something strange in his own.
fr: L'aieule etait assise dans un vaste fauteuil pres de son lit ; a cote d'elle, un gueridon d'acajou portait une lampe de bronze au globe grave, voile sous un papier vert.

eng: Archer's heart was beating violently when he rang old Mrs. Mingott's bell.
fr: ~~~ Et apres tout, le mariage est le mariage, l'argent est l'argent : je ne savais que repondre.

eng: "Newland! Are you ill?"
fr: Archer ne remarqua sur son visage aucune trace de la recente attaque.

eng: "Poor? ~~~ Why poor?" she echoed with a strained laugh.
fr: Si mes filles me demandent, dites que je dors.

eng: He had wanted above all things to go alone, for he felt sure the visit would give him the chance of saying a word in private to the Countess Olenska.
fr: Elle s'arreta court, respirant longuement, comme si de parler lui etait devenu un effort.

eng: "My dear, am I perfectly hideous?" she asked gaily, launching out one hand in search of the folds of muslin on her inaccessible bosom.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Behind the door, behind the curtains of the yellow damask room next to the hall, she was surely awaiting him; in another moment he should see her, and be able to speak to her before she led him to the sick-room.
fr: Et maintenant, c'est arrange ; elle va rester ici pour soigner sa grand'mere tant qu'il y aura une grand'mere a soigner.

eng: If Ellen had consented to come and live with her grandmother it must surely be because she had recognised the impossibility of giving him up.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But gradually there stole over him the delicious sense of difficulties deferred and opportunities miraculously provided.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He had so definitely decided on the course he meant to pursue that for the moment he could not readjust his thoughts.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The young man heard her with veins aglow; but in his confusion of mind he hardly knew whether her news brought joy or pain.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It's not a gay prospect, but she doesn't mind; and of course I've told Letterblair that she's to be given her proper allowance."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: ~~~ Shut you up in that cage again? Never!' And now it's settled that she's to stay here and nurse her Granny as long as there's a Granny to nurse.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "But the minute I laid eyes on her, I said: 'You sweet bird, you!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She broke off and drew a long breath, as if speaking had become an effort.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: After all, marriage is marriage, and money's money--both useful things in their way ... and I didn't know what to answer--"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They thought they'd convinced me when the secretary, or whatever he was, came out with the last proposals: handsome proposals I confess they were.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer listened in silence, and she went on: "They'd talked me over, as no doubt you know: persuaded me, Lovell, and Letterblair, and Augusta Welland, and all the rest of them, that I must hold out and cut off her allowance, till she was made to see that it was her duty to go back to Olenski.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She hadn't been here five minutes before I'd have gone down on my knees to keep her--if only, for the last twenty years, I'd been able to see where the floor was!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer wondered if her illness had blurred her faculties; but suddenly she broke out: "Well, it's settled, anyhow: she's going to stay with me, whatever the rest of the family say!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: ~~~ But who ever thought of sparing their grandmother worry?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She gave another chuckle, and interrupted it to say almost querulously: "It's a pity she didn't marry you; I always told her so. It would have spared me all this worry.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He laughed, and she continued: "Was it because you told her so that she had to put you out on the way? In my youth young men didn't desert pretty women unless they were made to!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ah, but not as handsome as Ellen!" she jerked out, twinkling at him maliciously; and before he could answer she added: "Was she so awfully handsome the day you drove her up from the ferry?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He wanted only to put one question: after that his course would be clear.
fr: Le jeune homme ecoutait, les veines brulantes.

eng: What he wished to ask was simply the date of her return to Washington; and that question she could hardly refuse to answer.
fr: Dans la confusion de son esprit, il savait a peine si la nouvelle lui causait de la joie ou du chagrin.

eng: But in the yellow sitting-room it was the mulatto maid who waited.
fr: Il s'etait si bien resolu a un autre parti, qu'il ne pouvait ajuster ses pensees a celui-ci.

eng: Her white teeth shining like a keyboard, she pushed back the sliding doors and ushered him into old Catherine's presence.
fr: Mais peu a peu, un repos delicieux l'envahit.

eng: The old woman sat in a vast throne-like arm-chair near her bed.
fr: ~~~ Les difficultes s'eloignaient, miraculeusement.

eng: Beside her was a mahogany stand bearing a cast bronze lamp with an engraved globe, over which a green paper shade had been balanced.
fr: Ellen avait consenti a venir vivre avec sa grand'mere ; c'etait donc qu'elle s'avouait ne pouvoir renoncer a lui.'

eng: He had determined to wait till the chance presented itself naturally; and here it was, and here he was on the doorstep.
fr: -- Mais aussitot que j'ai revu Ellen, j'ai dit : << Toi, mon joli oiseau, t'enfermer encore dans cette cage conjugale ? Jamais ! >>

eng: There was not a book or a newspaper in reach, nor any evidence of feminine employment: conversation had always been Mrs. Mingott's sole pursuit, and she would have scorned to feign an interest in fancywork.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She merely looked paler, with darker shadows in the folds and recesses of her obesity; and, in the fluted mob-cap tied by a starched bow between her first two chins, and the muslin kerchief crossed over her billowing purple dressing-gown, she seemed like some shrewd and kindly ancestress of her own who might have yielded too freely to the pleasures of the table.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She held out one of the little hands that nestled in a hollow of her huge lap like pet animals, and called to the maid: "Don't let in any one else. If my daughters call, say I'm asleep."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The maid disappeared, and the old lady turned to her grandson.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He had insisted that the library curtains should draw backward and forward on a rod, so that they might be closed in the evening, instead of remaining nailed to a gilt cornice, and immovably looped up over layers of lace, as in the drawing-room; and he pulled them back and pushed up the sash, leaning out into the icy night.
fr: Une semaine se passa. Archer n'entendait plus parler de Mme Olenska, et il se rendait compte que le nom de la jeune femme ne serait prononce devant lui par aucun membre de la famille.

eng: "My daughters tell me it doesn't matter at my age--as if hideousness didn't matter all the more the harder it gets to conceal!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "My dear, you're handsomer than ever!" Archer rejoined in the same tone; and she threw back her head and laughed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer saw no trace of the slight distortion left by her stroke.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "The room is stifling: I want a little air."
fr: << Mourir de froid ? pensa-t-il ; mais ne suis-je pas deja mort ? n'y a-t-il pas des mois et des mois que ma vie est pareille a la mort ? >>

eng: "In THIS weather?"
fr: -- Ma chere grand'mere, vous etes mieux que jamais, repondit Archer sur le meme ton d'empressement, mieux que personne...

eng: He laid down his book and stood up impatiently; and at once she raised her head.
fr: -- Newland ! Fermez la fenetre ; vous allez mourir de froid.

eng: But she shone on him with her usual tenderness, and her eyes had kept the blue dazzle of the day before.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had put on the low-necked and tightly-laced dinner-dress which the Mingott ceremonial exacted on the most informal occasions, and had built her fair hair into its usual accumulated coils; and her face, in contrast, was wan and almost faded.
fr: Pas une coque ne manquait aux rouleaux compliques de ses cheveux blonds. Mais Archer lui trouva le teint pale et les traits tires.

eng: When May appeared he thought she looked tired.
fr: Elle apparut enfin, en robe decolletee etroitement lacee : le protocole de leur monde exigeait la grande toilette, meme en famille.

eng: Sometimes he felt as if he had found the clue to his father-in-law's absorption in trifles; perhaps even Mr. Welland, long ago, had had escapes and visions, and had conjured up all the hosts of domesticity to defend himself against them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He had fallen into the way of dwelling on such conjectures as a means of tying his thoughts fast to reality.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He knew that she was at home, for while he dressed he had heard her moving about in her room; and he wondered what had delayed her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He and May were dining alone, all the family engagements having been postponed since Mrs. Manson Mingott's illness; and as May was the more punctual of the two he was surprised that she had not preceded him.
fr: Il devait diner seul avec sa femme ; toutes les sorties du soir avaient ete suspendues depuis la maladie de Mrs Manson Mingott, et il fut surpris que May, si exacte, ne l'eut pas devance.

eng: ~~~ XXX. That evening when Archer came down before dinner he found the drawing-room empty.
fr: Ce soir-la, quand Archer descendit, il ne trouva personne au salon.

eng: He thrust his hands in his pockets, and walked at a sharp pace down Fifth Avenue to his own house.
fr: Il mit ses mains dans ses poches et descendit la Cinquieme Avenue, pour rentrer chez lui.

eng: Suddenly he felt something stiff and cold on his lashes, and perceived that he had been crying, and that the wind had frozen his tears.
fr: Tout a coup il sentit quelque chose de raide et de froid sur ses cils : il pleurait, et le vent avait gele ses larmes.

eng: The snow was over, and a tingling wind had sprung up, that lashed his face as he stood gazing.
fr: La neige avait cesse, et un vent cinglant le frappait au visage.

eng: She bent forward, and seemed about to speak; but he had already called out the order to drive on, and the carriage rolled away while he stood on the corner.
fr: La voiture s'eloignait. ~~~ Archer resta cloue sur place.

eng: "You're right: I ought not to have come today," he said, lowering his voice so that the coachman should not hear.
fr: Elle se pencha en avant et sembla prete a parler, mais deja il avait donne l'ordre de repartir.

eng: He closed the door, and leaned for a moment in the window.
fr: -- Vous avez raison, je n'aurais pas du venir aujourd'hui, dit-il, en baissant la voix pour ne pas etre entendu du cocher.

eng: By the light of a street-lamp he saw her startled face, and the instinctive motion she made to detain him.
fr: Il ferma la portiere et s'y appuya un moment.

eng: "No: I shall get out here," he stammered, opening the door and jumping to the pavement.
fr: A la lueur d'un reverbere, il vit le visage bouleverse de la jeune femme, le mouvement instinctif qu'elle fit pour le retenir.

eng: "Why are we stopping? This is not Granny's," Madame Olenska exclaimed.
fr: -- Je descends ici, begaya-t-il, et il sauta sur le pave.

eng: He pressed the bell, and the carriage drew up beside the curbstone.
fr: -- Pourquoi nous arretons-nous ? Nous ne sommes pas arrives, s'ecria Mme Olenska.

eng: He remembered that May rang twice when she wished to stop.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Then he groped in the darkness of the carriage for the little bell that signalled orders to the coachman.
fr: Puis, dans l'obscurite de la voiture, il chercha le porte-voix et donna l'ordre au cocher d'arreter.

eng: He sat silent, dazed with inarticulate pain.
fr: Il resta silencieux, abime dans sa douleur.

eng: ~~~ And I have," she said, in a strange voice, "and I know what it looks like there."
fr: et moi je le sais, ajouta-t-elle d'une voix singuliere.

eng: "No, you're not! You've never been beyond.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: '"Ah, I'm beyond that," he groaned.
fr: '-- Ah ! ~~~ je n'en suis plus la ! gemit Archer.

eng: "What's the matter?"
fr: Il baissa le carreau et se retourna.

eng: "What became of you, dear?" she asked.
fr: -- Qu'etes-vous devenu ? demanda-t-elle.

eng: "I was waiting at Granny's, and Ellen came alone, and said she had dropped you on the way because you had to rush off on business.
fr: Je vous ai attendu chez grand'mere. Ellen est arrivee seule, disant qu'elle vous avait laisse en route, que vous aviez du courir a vos affaires.

eng: "Catch my death!" he echoed; and he felt like adding: "But I've caught it already. I AM dead--I've been dead for months and months."
fr: Enfin, Mrs Manson Mingott lui fit dire qu'elle souhaitait le voir.

eng: "Only some letters I'd forgotten, and wanted to get off before dinner."
fr: -- Non ; quelques lettres a expedier.

eng: Now she was simply ripening into a copy of her mother, and mysteriously, by the very process, trying to turn him into a Mr. Welland.
fr: Puis il entendit May qui appelait.

eng: There's nothing wrong?"
fr: Rien de facheux ?

eng: She had spent her poetry and romance on their short courting: the function was exhausted because the need was past.
fr: Il resta quelques minutes ainsi, accoude dans l'obscurite.

eng: As she sat thus, the lamplight full on her clear brow, he said to himself with a secret dismay that he would always know the thoughts behind it, that never, in all the years to come, would she surprise him by an unexpected mood, by a new idea, a weakness, a cruelty or an emotion.
fr: Ne plus voir May, assise pres de la table, sous la lampe ; apercevoir d'autres existences en dehors de la sienne, d'autres villes au dela de New-York, et tout un monde au dela de son monde, cela le soulageait ; l'air en devenait plus respirable.

eng: She was so placed that Archer, by merely raising his eyes, could see her bent above her work-frame, her ruffled elbow-sleeves slipping back from her firm round arms, the betrothal sapphire shining on her left hand above her broad gold wedding-ring, and the right hand slowly and laboriously stabbing the canvas.
fr: Il ouvrit les rideaux, releva le chassis a guillotine, et se pencha sur la nuit glacee.

eng: She was not a clever needle-woman; her large capable hands were made for riding, rowing and open-air activities; but since other wives embroidered cushions for their husbands she did not wish to omit this last link in her devotion.
fr: -- On etouffe ici. J'ai besoin d'air.

eng: Seeing that he had chosen history she fetched her workbasket, drew up an arm-chair to the green-shaded student lamp, and uncovered a cushion she was embroidering for his sofa.
fr: -- Qu'y a-t-il ?

eng: He had taken to history in the evenings since May had shown a tendency to ask him to read aloud whenever she saw him with a volume of poetry: not that he disliked the sound of his own voice, but because he could always foresee her comments on what he read.
fr: Il posa son livre et se leva.

eng: They went up to the library for coffee, and Archer lit a cigar and took down a volume of Michelet.
fr: Maintenant, May murissait tranquillement, en une exacte reproduction de sa mere ; et mysterieusement, et par suite du meme developpement, elle tendait a faire de lui un second Mr Welland.

eng: He was thankful for the fact, yet felt it to be vaguely ominous.
fr: Pendant leurs courtes fiancailles, elle avait epuise tout ce qu'il y avait en elle de poetique et de romanesque.

eng: ~~~ During dinner their talk moved in its usual limited circle; but Archer noticed that his wife made no allusion to Madame Olenska, nor to old Catherine's reception of her.
fr: En la voyant assise ainsi, sous la lampe, Archer se disait avec une sorte de decouragement qu'il saurait toujours toutes les pensees que recelait ce front pur ; que jamais, au cours des annees a venir, elle ne le surprendrait par une fantaisie, une idee nouvelle, une faiblesse, une violence ou une emotion.

eng: The preposterousness of the case was beyond discussion, and they went in to dinner.
fr: Ses manches courtes, bordees de ruches, decouvraient ses bras ronds et fermes ; le saphir de ses fiancailles brillait a sa main gauche, au-dessus de sa large alliance d'or, et l'autre main percait lentement et laborieusement le canevas.

eng: ~~~ I believe he's going into an insurance business, or something. They're looking about for a small house."
fr: ~~~ Archer, quand il levait les yeux, la voyait penchee sur son metier.

eng: In the days of their engagement she had simply (as he now perceived) echoed what he told her; but since he had ceased to provide her with opinions she had begun to hazard her own, with results destructive to his enjoyment of the works commented on.
fr: Elle redressa la tete.

eng: "What news?"
fr: Elle n'etait pas trop habile ouvriere : ses grandes mains fortes etaient faites pour tenir les guides ou la rame.

eng: To disguise his own annoyance he asked how her grandmother was, and she answered that Mrs. Mingott was still improving, but had been rather disturbed by the last news about the Beauforts.
fr: Dans la bibliotheque, Archer alluma une cigarette et ouvrit un livre, tandis que May prenait son panier a ouvrage, et, approchant un fauteuil de la lampe voilee de vert, decouvrait un coussin qu'elle brodait pour Newland.

eng: If May had spoken out her grievances (he suspected her of many) he might have laughed them away; but she was trained to conceal imaginary wounds under a Spartan smile.
fr: Ce silence ne laissait pas d'avoir quelque chose d'inquietant.

eng: He was weary of living in a perpetual tepid honeymoon, without the temperature of passion yet with all its exactions.
fr: Puis la conversation tourna dans l'etroit cercle habituel ; mais Archer remarqua que sa femme ne fit aucune allusion a Mme Olenska, ni a l'accueil qu'avait fait a celle-ci la vieille Catherine.

eng: Now he was smitten with compunction, yet irritated that so trifling an omission should be stored up against him after nearly two years of marriage.
fr: Un tel aplomb passait toute imagination.

eng: "Ah--" she said; and a moment afterward: "I'm sorry you didn't come to Granny's--unless the letters were urgent."
fr: -- Je regrette bien que vous ne soyez pas venu chez grand'mere ; sans doute ces lettres etaient urgentes ?

eng: He had called back a cheery "Yes!" and then, absorbed in other visions, had forgotten his promise.
fr: On disait que les Beaufort ne quittaient pas la ville, que Beaufort allait entrer dans une affaire d'assurances.

eng: Then he remembered that, as he had left the house that morning, she had called over the stairs that she would meet him at her grandmother's so that they might drive home together.
fr: Pendant le diner, May lui apprit la nouvelle qui courait New-York.

eng: As she stood there, lifting her long arm to fasten a puff that had slipped from its place in her intricate hair, Archer was struck by something languid and inelastic in her attitude, and wondered if the deadly monotony of their lives had laid its weight on her also.
fr: Il etait las de vivre dans la fiction d'une lune de miel qui avait les exigences de la passion sans en avoir la chaleur.

eng: She turned and moved to the looking-glass above the mantel-piece.
fr: Cela l'irritait qu'un si leger manquement fut releve contre lui apres deux ans de mariage.

eng: "Besides, I don't see why I should have gone to your grandmother's. I didn't know you were there."
fr: C'est vrai qu'il avait promis, le matin, d'aller retrouver May chez sa grand'mere.

eng: "It seems they're going to stay in New York.
fr: Mais toutes les femmes brodant des coussins pour leurs maris, elle n'aurait pas manque a cet acte de devotion conjugale.

eng: "They were," he rejoined, surprised at her insistence.
fr: -- Oui, fit-il, gene par cette insistance.

eng: This was her answer to his final appeal of the other day: if she would not take the extreme step he had urged, she had at last yielded to half-measures.
fr: C'etait sa reponse a l'appel supreme de l'autre jour. ~~~ Si elle ne voulait pas faire le dernier pas, elle cedait pourtant a demi.

eng: He sank back into the thought with the involuntary relief of a man who has been ready to risk everything, and suddenly tastes the dangerous sweetness of security. ~~~ "She couldn't have gone back--it was impossible!"
fr: Il s'abandonnait a cette pensee avec le soulagement d'un homme qui a ete pret a tout risquer, et goute soudain la dangereuse douceur de la securite... -- Elle n'aurait pas pu retourner aupres de son mari, c'etait impossible !

eng: He winced a little at her terrifying perspicacity, and longed to ask: "And May--do they quote her?" But he judged it safer to turn the question.
fr: Il eut un sursaut : cette perspicacite l'effrayait.

eng: "Then we're safe!" she sighed; and smiling on him with all her ancient cunning she added, as she settled her head among the cushions: "I always knew you'd back us up, because they never quote you when they talk about its being her duty to go home."
fr: Alors nous voila sauves ! soupira-t-elle ; et, lui souriant avec toute son ancienne finesse, elle ajouta, calant sa tete sur ses oreillers : J'ai toujours pense que tu serais avec nous ; sais-tu pourquoi ? C'est qu'ils ne prononcent jamais ton nom quand ils ressassent leur antienne au sujet du retour d'Ellen chez Olenski.

eng: "Oh, my dear, I back you to hold your own against them all without my help; but you shall have it if you need it," he reassured her.
fr: Chere grand'mere, vous pouvez tres bien tenir contre eux tous, a vous toute seule ; mais, si vous avez besoin de moi, je serai derriere vous.

eng: "Well, you're Letterblair's partner, ain't you? You've got to get at them through Letterblair. Unless you've got a reason," she insisted.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh, I don't count--I'm too insignificant."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer, under the exposure of her gaze, had recovered his self-possession.
fr: Archer, sous ce regard, reprit possession de lui-meme.

eng: "Why not?" she searchingly repeated.
fr: Pourquoi pas ? repeta-t-elle.

eng: Her hand fluttered from its chair-arm and lit on his with a clutch of little pale nails like bird-claws.
fr: Sa main quitta le bras de son fauteuil pour aller se poser sur celle du jeune homme, qu'elle agrippa de ses petits ongles pareils a des griffes d'oiseau.

eng: "You. ~~~ Why not?" she jerked back at him, her round eyes suddenly as sharp as pen-knives.
fr: Pourquoi pas ? -- Elle fixa sur lui des regards devenus soudain coupants comme des lames de couteau.

eng: "And Madame Olenska? ~~~ When am I to see her?" ~~~ he said.
fr: Il demanda : -- Quand pourrai-je voir Mme Olenska ?

eng: "I?" he stammered.
fr: Moi ? balbutia-t-il.

eng: The old lady chuckled, crumpled her lids, and went through the pantomime of archness.
fr: La vieille dame joua toute la pantomime de l'espieglerie.

eng: "Ah, my dear, I always knew you were on her side; and that's why I sent for you today, and why I said to your pretty wife, when she proposed to come with you: 'No, my dear, I'm pining to see Newland, and I don't want anybody to share our transports.'"
fr: Ah ! mon cher, j'ai toujours su que tu etais pour elle, et c'est pourquoi je t'ai fait venir.

eng: "For you see, my dear--" she drew her head back as far as its tethering chins permitted, and looked him full in the eyes--"you see, we shall have a fight yet. The family don't want her here, and they'll say it's because I've been ill, because I'm a weak old woman, that she's persuaded me."
fr: Car tu vois, -- elle redressa la tete autant que le lui permettaient ses doubles mentons, et le regarda en plein dans les yeux, -- tu vois, nous aurons encore a combattre.

eng: "he exclaimed.
fr: 's'ecria-t-il.

eng: "I'm not well enough yet to fight them one by one, and you've got to do it for me."
fr: A moi toute seule, je ne suis pas de force, il faut que tu viennes a mon aide.

eng: "Not today.
fr: -- Pas aujourd'hui.

eng: After all, Regina's a brave woman, and so is she; and I've always liked courage above everything.
fr: Apres tout, Regina est une femme courageuse, et Ellen aussi : et j'aime le courage par-dessus tout.

eng: Now, my dear, I looked out of the window, and saw it wasn't raining a drop; but I understood her, and I let her have the carriage....
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'What for?' I asked her; and she said: 'To go and see cousin Regina'--COUSIN!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Well, that floored me, and I let her go; and finally one day she said it was raining too hard to go out on foot, and she wanted me to lend her my carriage.
fr: Eh ! bien, a cela je n'ai rien trouve a repondre et je lui ai permis d'y aller. Aujourd'hui je lui ai meme permis d'y aller dans ma voiture !...

eng: 'Well,' she says, 'and so am I, and yet all my family want me to go back to him.'
fr: ~~~ -- Et moi donc ? Cependant toute ma famille veut que je retourne chez mon mari. >>

eng: 'She's the wife of a scoundrel,' I answered.
fr: -- La femme d'un miserable !

eng: 'She's your grand-niece, and a most unhappy woman,' she says.
fr: -- C'est votre petite niece, une femme malheureuse !

eng: The day after she got here she put on her best bonnet, and told me, as cool as a cucumber, that she was going to call on Regina Beaufort.
fr: Le lendemain de son arrivee, elle a mis son plus beau chapeau, et m'a dit avec un parfait sang-froid qu'elle allait voir Regina Beaufort.

eng: "That's what she's reduced me to already.
fr: -- Voila ou nous en sommes deja !

eng: She paused for this announcement to produce its effect.
fr: Elle s'arreta, laissant cette declaration produire tout son effet.

eng: 'I don't know her; who is she?'
fr: J'ai repondu : << Je ne la connais plus !

eng: Madame Olenska's gone out.
fr: Mme Olenska est sortie.

eng: One at a time, please.
fr: Une de nous a la fois, s'il te plait !

eng: He flushed with disappointment, and she went on: "She's gone out, my child: gone in my carriage to see Regina Beaufort."
fr: Il rougit. La deconvenue etait cruelle. Mrs Mingott continua : -- Elle est sortie, mon enfant, sortie dans ma voiture, pour aller voir Regina Beaufort !

eng: Archer bent down and pressed his lips on the little hand that still lay on his.
fr: Archer se pencha et appuya ses levres sur la petite main qui tenait encore la sienne.

eng: But during the ten days which had elapsed since her return to New York she had perhaps guessed from his silence, and from the fact of his making no attempt to see her, that he was meditating a decisive step, a step from which there was no turning back.
fr: Mais dix jours s'etaient ecoules depuis son retour a New-York, et il n'avait fait aucune tentative pour la revoir. Avait-elle peut-etre devine qu'il meditait quelque projet desespere ?

eng: At the thought, a sudden fear of her own weakness might have seized her, and she might have felt that, after all, it was better to accept the compromise usual in such cases, and follow the line of least resistance.
fr: Redoutant sa propre faiblesse, n'avait-elle pas trouve preferable d'accepter un compromis, et de rester a New-York ?

eng: An hour earlier, when he had rung Mrs. Mingott's bell, Archer had fancied that his path was clear before him. He had meant to have a word alone with Madame Olenska, and failing that, to learn from her grandmother on what day, and by which train, she was returning to Washington. In that train he intended to join her, and travel with her to Washington, or as much farther as she was willing to go. His own fancy inclined to Japan. At any rate she would understand at once that, wherever she went, he was going. He meant to leave a note for May that should cut off any other alternative.
fr: Quant a Archer, a l'instant ou il etait arrive chez Mrs Mingott, il etait non seulement pret a l'irrevocable, mais impatient de s'y jeter.

eng: Yes, but in ten minutes more he would be mounting his own doorstep; and there were May, and habit, and honour, and all the old decencies that he and his people had always believed in ...
fr: Au coin de sa rue, il hesita, puis continua a descendre la Cinquieme Avenue.'

eng: He had fancied himself not only nerved for this plunge but eager to take it; yet his first feeling on hearing that the course of events was changed had been one of relief.
fr: Le cours nouveau des choses lui avait procure un premier instant de detente ;

eng: Now, however, as he walked home from Mrs. Mingott's, he was conscious of a growing distaste for what lay before him.
fr: mais peu a peu il retrouvait toute sa repugnance pour la voie qui s'ouvrait devant lui.

eng: There was nothing unknown or unfamiliar in the path he was presumably to tread; but when he had trodden it before it was as a free man, who was accountable to no one for his actions, and could lend himself with an amused detachment to the game of precautions and prevarications, concealments and compliances, that the part required.
fr: Cette voie, il la connaissait, pour l'avoir deja parcourue ; mais alors il etait libre, il ne devait compte de ses actions a personne ; il pouvait se preter avec un detachement amuse au jeu clandestin de l'adultere.

eng: This procedure was called "protecting a woman's honour"; and the best fiction, combined with the after-dinner talk of his elders, had long since initiated him into every detail of its code.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was, in fact, that which, with a secret fatuity, he had watched Mrs. Thorley Rushworth play toward a fond and unperceiving husband: a smiling, bantering, humouring, watchful and incessant lie.
fr: C'etait le role de l'eternel mensonge : mensonge des sourires, des badinages, des gentillesses, mensonge de jour, mensonge de nuit, mensonge du regard, mensonge dans les caresses et mensonge meme dans les querelles, mensonge de chaque parole et de chaque silence.

eng: Ellen Olenska was like no other woman, he was like no other man: their situation, therefore, resembled no one else's, and they were answerable to no tribunal but that of their own judgment.
fr: Oui, mais dans dix minutes il rentrerait chez lui, et la il retrouverait May, l'habitude de la vie conjugale, l'honneur du foyer, toutes les convenances que lui et les siens avaient toujours respectees.

eng: But to love Ellen Olenska was not to become a man like Lefferts: for the first time Archer found himself face to face with the dread argument of the individual case.
fr: ils ne relevaient que de leur propre jugement.

eng: ~~~ In the rotation of crops there was a recognised season for wild oats; but they were not to be sown more than once. Archer had always shared this view: in his heart he thought Lefferts despicable.
fr: Il y avait un temps pour la vie de garcon ; la saison passee, il n'y fallait pas revenir. Bien sur, Ellen Olenska n'etait pas comme les autres femmes, ni lui comme les autres hommes :

eng: But in Archer's little world no one laughed at a wife deceived, and a certain measure of contempt was attached to men who continued their philandering after marriage.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was easier, and less dastardly on the whole, for a wife to play such a part toward her husband. A woman's standard of truthfulness was tacitly held to be lower: she was the subject creature, and versed in the arts of the enslaved. Then she could always plead moods and nerves, and the right not to be held too strictly to account; and even in the most strait-laced societies the laugh was always against the husband.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A lie by day, a lie by night, a lie in every touch and every look; a lie in every caress and every quarrel; a lie in every word and in every silence.
fr: (Already covered in previous sentence)

eng: He knew that there was no calculated coquetry in her words; she was fighting her fate as he had fought his, and clinging desperately to her resolve that they should not break faith with the people who trusted them.
fr: Il la savait incapable d'un calcul de coquetterie. Elle luttait contre son sort, comme il avait lutte contre le sien : elle s'attachait de toutes ses forces a la resolution de ne pas trahir la confiance de May, de toute la famille.

eng: Now he saw the matter in a new light, and his part in it seemed singularly diminished.
fr: Maintenant, il apercevait sous un nouveau jour le role qui l'attendait.

eng: On the way from the ferry she had told him that he and she must remain apart; but she had said it with her head on his breast.
fr: mais elle le lui avait dit la tete sur sa poitrine.

eng: He knew the exact figure of the small income which her husband had allowed her at their separation. Without the addition of her grandmother's allowance it was hardly enough to live on, in any sense known to the Mingott vocabulary; and now that Medora Manson, who shared her life, had been ruined, such a pittance would barely keep the two women clothed and fed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Therefore if she had changed her course it must be for a different reason.
fr: Ces raisons, il n'avait pas a les chercher bien loin.

eng: Moreover, as Archer knew, several months had passed since her allowance had been cut off; yet in the interval she had made no effort to regain her grandmother's favour.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had the heedless generosity and the spasmodic extravagance of persons used to large fortunes, and indifferent to money; but she could go without many things which her relations considered indispensable, and Mrs. Lovell Mingott and Mrs. Welland had often been heard to deplore that any one who had enjoyed the cosmopolitan luxuries of Count Olenski's establishments should care so little about "how things were done."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Yet Archer was convinced that Madame Olenska had not accepted her grandmother's offer from interested motives.
fr: Elle avait eu d'autres raisons.

eng: Archer was sure that Madame Olenska's decision had not been influenced by the change in her financial situation.
fr: Archer etait sur que les considerations materielles n'etaient pour rien dans cette nouvelle resolution.

eng: but that she should have decided to remain under her roof--especially now that Mrs. Mingott had almost regained her health--was less easy to explain.
fr: -- mais qu'elle se decidat ainsi a rester chez Mrs Mingott, maintenant que celle-ci etait presque remise, cela s'expliquait moins facilement.

eng: It was only natural that Madame Olenska should have hastened from Washington in response to her grandmother's summons;
fr: Que Mme Olenska fut accourue a l'appel de sa grand'mere, c'etait tout naturel,

eng: XXXI. Archer had been stunned by old Catherine's news.
fr: XXXI Archer etait abasourdi de ce que lui avait appris la vieille Catherine.

eng: and as he rose to go she called out after him: "Give her her Granny's love; but you'd better not say anything about our talk."
fr: et comme il se levait pour partir, elle lui cria : -- Dis-lui les tendresses de sa grand'mere. Mais il vaut mieux ne pas lui parler de notre conversation.

eng: '"Eh--eh--eh! Whose hand did you think you were kissing, young man--your wife's, I hope?" the old lady snapped out with her mocking cackle;
fr: '-- Eh ! ~~~ Eh ! Eh ! Quelle main imagines-tu embrasser, jeune amoureux ? Celle de ta femme, j'espere..., fit la vieille dame avec un gloussement moqueur ;

eng: He did not have far to seek for that reason.
fr: En revenant de la gare, Mme Olenska lui avait dit qu'ils devaient vivre separes l'un de l'autre ;

eng: Ahead of him, in the winter night, loomed a big unlit house.
fr: Devant lui, dans la nuit d'hiver, se dressait une grande maison sombre.

eng: As he drew near he thought how often he had seen it blazing with lights, its steps awninged and carpeted, and carriages waiting in double line to draw up at the curbstone.
fr: Que de fois l'avait-il vue flamboyante de lumieres, la tente des galas s'avancant sur le perron, une double file de voitures alignee dans la rue !

eng: It was in the conservatory that stretched its dead-black bulk down the side street that he had taken his first kiss from May; it was under the myriad candles of the ball-room that he had seen her appear, tall and silver-shining as a young Diana.
fr: La, dans le jardin d'hiver qui etendait sa masse noire sur la rue transversale, il avait pris a May son premier baiser : c'etait la, sous les lustres de la salle de bal, qu'il l'avait vue apparaitre, svelte et gracieuse comme une jeune Diane.

eng: Now the house was as dark as the grave, except for a faint flare of gas in the basement, and a light in one upstairs room where the blind had not been lowered.
fr: Maintenant, la maison etait noire comme la tombe, sauf la petite lueur de gaz qui montait des cuisines, et la lumiere qui brillait a une des fenetres de l'etage superieur, dont les volets n'avaient pas ete fermes.

eng: As Archer reached the corner he saw that the carriage standing at the door was Mrs. Manson Mingott's.
fr: En arrivant au coin de la rue, Archer vit que la voiture arretee devant la porte etait bien celle de Mrs Manson Mingott.

eng: What an opportunity for Sillerton Jackson, if he should chance to pass!
fr: Quelle aubaine pour Mr Sillerton Jackson, s'il etait venu a passer !

eng: Archer had been greatly moved by old Catherine's account of Madame Olenska's attitude toward Mrs. Beaufort; it made the righteous reprobation of New York seem like a passing by on the other side. ~~~ But he knew well enough what construction the clubs and drawing-rooms would put on Ellen Olenska's visits to her cousin.
fr: Archer avait ete touche d'apprendre, par le recit de la vieille Catherine, l'attitude de Mme Olenska envers Mrs Beaufort ; mais il savait assez quelle interpretation les salons et les cercles preteraient aux visites de Mme Olenska chez sa cousine.

eng: "Ellen," he said in a low voice, as she reached the pavement.
fr: -- Ellen ! ~~~ appela Archer a voix basse.

eng: He paused and looked up at the lighted window.
fr: Il s'arreta et regarda la fenetre eclairee.

eng: No doubt the two women were sitting together in that room: Beaufort had probably sought consolation elsewhere. There were even rumours that he had left New York with Fanny Ring; but Mrs. Beaufort's attitude made the report seem improbable.
fr: Sans doute les deux femmes etaient assises ensemble dans cette chambre...

eng: Archer had the nocturnal perspective of Fifth Avenue almost to himself.
fr: Archer se trouvait presque seul dans la perspective nocturne de la Cinquieme Avenue.

eng: At that hour most people were indoors, dressing for dinner; and he was secretly glad that Ellen's exit was likely to be unobserved.
fr: A l'heure ou tout le monde etait rentre s'habiller pour le diner, la sortie d'Ellen passerait probablement inapercue : tant mieux, se disait-il.

eng: As the thought passed through his mind the door opened, and she came out.
fr: Comme cette pensee lui traversait l'esprit, la porte s'ouvrit pour laisser passer la jeune femme.

eng: Behind her was a faint light, such as might have been carried down the stairs to show her the way.
fr: Derriere elle, une faible lueur vacillait, portee par quelqu'un qui avait du l'eclairer.

eng: She turned to say a word to some one; then the door closed, and she came down the steps.
fr: Mme Olenska se retourna pour faire un geste d'adieu, puis descendit le perron.

eng: She stopped with a slight start, and just then he saw two young men of fashionable cut approaching.
fr: Elle tressaillit : et, juste au meme moment, il vit deux jeunes gens d'allure elegante qui s'approchaient.

eng: There was a familiar air about their overcoats and the way their smart silk mufflers were folded over their white ties; and he wondered how youths of their quality happened to be dining out so early.
fr: Il y avait pour Archer, dans leurs pardessus, dans la maniere dont leurs foulards de soie se croisaient sur leurs cravates blanches, quelque chose de familier.

eng: Then he remembered that the Reggie Chiverses, whose house was a few doors above, were taking a large party that evening to see Adelaide Neilson in Romeo and Juliet, and guessed that the two were of the number.
fr: Ce n'etait pas encore l'heure d'aller diner en ville, -- mais Archer se rappela que les Reggie Chivers, a quelques pas de la, allaient en bande ce soir meme au theatre et donnaient a diner de bonne heure.

eng: While he watched her he was aware that Lefferts and Chivers, on reaching the farther side of the street corner, had discreetly struck away across Fifth Avenue.
fr: Sans la quitter des yeux, Archer vit que Lefferts et Chivers avaient discretement traverse.

eng: Avoiding the popular "Wolfe collection," whose anecdotic canvases filled one of the main galleries of the queer wilderness of cast-iron and encaustic tiles known as the Metropolitan Museum, they had wandered down a passage to the room where the "Cesnola antiquities" mouldered in unvisited loneliness.
fr: Comme toujours, il s'absorbait dans la contemplation des ravissants details qui faisaient que la jeune femme etait elle et non pas une autre.

eng: They had this melancholy retreat to themselves, and seated on the divan enclosing the central steam-radiator, they were staring silently at the glass cabinets mounted in ebonised wood which contained the recovered fragments of Ilium.
fr: Ce fut elle qui demanda : -- Qu'aviez-vous a me dire qui fut si grave et si presse ?

eng: "It's odd," Madame Olenska said, "I never came here before."
fr: -- Ce que j'avais a vous dire ? C'est qu'a mon avis, si vous etes venue a New-York, c'est que vous aviez peur.

eng: "Ah, well--. Some day, I suppose, it will be a great Museum."
fr: -- Peur de quoi ?

eng: "Yes," she assented absently.
fr: -- Vous craigniez que je ne vinsse vous rejoindre a Washington.

eng: She stood up and wandered across the room.
fr: Elle regarda son manchon, le retournant dans ses mains nerveuses.

eng: Archer, remaining seated, watched the light movements of her figure, so girlish even under its heavy furs, the cleverly planted heron wing in her fur cap, and the way a dark curl lay like a flattened vine spiral on each cheek above the ear.
fr: -- C'est vrai, dit-elle a demi-voix.

eng: Presently he rose and approached the case before which she stood.
fr: -- Nous rencontrer ainsi, en nous cachant ?... Mais c'est juste le contraire de ce que je veux ! Cela me fait horreur.

eng: "She'll come!" he said to himself, almost contemptuously.
fr: Leurs pas retentirent dans le vide des longues galeries sonores : ils s'arreterent dans la salle ou la collection Cesnola moisit dans une solitude inviolee et firent mine de regarder les mouvements souples du corps si jeune sous les epaisses fourrures ; l'aile de heron bien plantee dans la toque de loutre ; la petite boucle de cheveux sombres aplatie sur chaque joue comme une vrille de vigne.

eng: Its glass shelves were crowded with small broken objects--hardly recognisable domestic utensils, ornaments and personal trifles--made of glass, of clay, of discoloured bronze and other time-blurred substances.
fr: -- A moi aussi ! s'ecria-t-elle, avec un profond soupir de soulagement.

eng: "It seems cruel," she said, "that after a while nothing matters ... any more than these little things, that used to be necessary and important to forgotten people, and now have to be guessed at under a magnifying glass and labelled: 'Use unknown.'"
fr: -- Eh bien ! alors, c'est a mon tour de demander : N'imaginez-vous pas pour nous un meilleur avenir ?

eng: "Yes; but meanwhile--"
fr: Elle pencha la tete. Ses mains, dans le manchon, s'agitaient toujours. On s'approchait ; un gardien a casquette galonnee traversa la salle avec le pas errant d'un fantome dans une necropole. Simultanement, Archer et Mme Olenska se mirent a examiner la vitrine qui leur faisait face.

eng: "Ah, meanwhile--"
fr: Quand le personnage eut disparu dans une perspective de momies et de sarcophages, Archer renouvela sa question.

eng: As she stood there, in her long sealskin coat, her hands thrust in a small round muff, her veil drawn down like a transparent mask to the tip of her nose, and the bunch of violets he had brought her stirring with her quickly-taken breath, it seemed incredible that this pure harmony of line and colour should ever suffer the stupid law of change.
fr: Au lieu de repondre, Ellen murmura : -- J'ai promis a grand'mere de rester avec elle parce qu'il m'a semble que j'etais ici moins en danger.

eng: "Meanwhile everything matters--that concerns you," he said.
fr: -- Moins en danger de m'aimer ? demanda-t-il.

eng: His mind, as always when they first met, was wholly absorbed in the delicious details that made her herself and no other.
fr: -- Alors ? -- Alors... ceci vaut mieux, n'est-ce pas ? reprit-elle avec un long soupir. Nous ferons moins de mal aux autres. Apres tout, n'est-ce pas ce que vous avez toujours voulu ?

eng: It seemed to him that he had been speaking not to the woman he loved but to another, a woman he was indebted to for pleasures already wearied of: it was hateful to find himself the prisoner of this hackneyed vocabulary.
fr: Le lendemain, Archer et Ellen se retrouverent sur le seuil du Musee.

eng: He stared after her in a turmoil of contradictory feelings.
fr: Ecoeure de ce vocabulaire de rendez-vous, qui avait trop servi, << elle viendra, >> se dit-il avec une sorte d'amertume.

eng: As it drove off she leaned forward, and he thought she waved her hand in the obscurity.
fr: Il lui semblait, non pas avoir parle a la femme qu'il aimait, mais a une autre, a une femme envers laquelle il avait contracte la dette du plaisir, mais dont il etait deja fatigue.

eng: They passed under a lamp, and he recognised Lawrence Lefferts and a young Chivers.
fr: A la lumiere du reverbere, Archer reconnut Lawrence Lefferts et un des jeunes Chivers.

eng: A mean desire not to have Madame Olenska seen at the Beauforts' door vanished as he felt the penetrating warmth of her hand.
fr: Le desir un peu pueril qu'on ne reconnut pas Mme Olenska devant la porte des Beaufort, s'evanouit des qu'il sentit la chaleur penetrante de la main d'Ellen dans la sienne.

eng: "I shall see you now--we shall be together," he broke out, hardly knowing what he said.
fr: -- Je vous verrai donc : nous serons ensemble ! s'ecria-t-il, sachant a peine ce qu'il disait.

eng: "Ah," she answered, "Granny has told you?"
fr: -- Ah ! repondit-elle, grand'mere vous a dit ?

eng: It was the kind of masculine solidarity that he himself often practised; now he sickened at their connivance.
fr: Lui-meme avait souvent pratique ce genre de solidarite masculine. Non, il ne pourrait se resigner a cette vie de mensonge et de complicites.

eng: Did she really imagine that he and she could live like this? And if not, what else did she imagine?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Tomorrow I must see you--somewhere where we can be alone," he said, in a voice that sounded almost angry to his own ears.
fr: -- Des demain, dit-il, j'ai besoin de vous voir quelque part ou nous soyons seuls.

eng: She wavered, and moved toward the carriage.
fr: Sans repondre, elle monta rapidement dans la voiture.

eng: "But I shall be at Granny's--for the present that is," she added, as if conscious that her change of plans required some explanation.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Somewhere where we can be alone," he insisted.
fr: -- Seuls, a New-York ? Mais il n'y a ni eglises ni monuments.

eng: She gave a faint laugh that grated on him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "In New York? But there are no churches ... no monuments."
fr: -- Il y a le Musee, repliqua-t-il.

eng: "There's the Art Museum--in the Park," he explained, as she looked puzzled.
fr: A deux heures et demie, je vous attendrai a l'entree principale.

eng: "At half-past two. I shall be at the door ..."
fr: En s'eloignant, elle se pencha a la portiere : Archer devina un signe d'adieu dans l'obscurite.

eng: She turned away without answering and got quickly into the carriage.
fr: Il resta les yeux fixes dans la direction ou elle disparaissait, en proie a un tumulte de sentiments contradictoires.

eng: She looked at him thoughtfully, and turned back to the divan.
fr: Le profil de la jeune femme resta immobile, mais Archer vit une larme glisser de sa paupiere et se prendre aux mailles de son voile.

eng: "What is it you wanted to tell me?" she asked, as if she had received the same warning.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He sat down beside her and waited; but suddenly he heard a step echoing far off down the empty rooms, and felt the pressure of the minutes.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Afraid?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Her profile did not stir, but he saw a tear overflow on her lashes and hang in a mesh of her veil.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Safer from loving me?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "What I wanted to tell you?" he rejoined. "Why, that I believe you came to New York because you were afraid."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Instead of answering she murmured: "I promised Granny to stay with her because it seemed to me that here I should be safer."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "What do you think better?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They fixed their eyes simultaneously on the case opposite them, and when the official figure had vanished down a vista of mummies and sarcophagi Archer spoke again.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The step drew nearer, and a guardian in a braided cap walked listlessly through the room like a ghost stalking through a necropolis.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She hung her head and continued to clasp and unclasp her hands in her muff.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He sprang up impatiently. "Well, then--it's my turn to ask: what is it, in God's name, that you think better?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh, so do I!" she cried with a deep breath of relief.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "A thousand times!" He paused. "It would be easy to lie to you; but the truth is I think it detestable."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "From me?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "To have you here, you mean--in reach and yet out of reach? To meet you in this way, on the sly? It's the very reverse of what I want. I told you the other day what I wanted."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She hesitated. "And you still think this--worse?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She looked down at her muff, and he saw her hands stir in it uneasily.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well--?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well--yes," she said. "You WERE afraid? You knew--?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Of my coming to Washington."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well, then?" he insisted.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well, then: this is better, isn't it?" she returned with a long questioning sigh.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Better--?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "We shall hurt others less. Isn't it, after all, what you always wanted?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Yes: I knew ..."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Safer from doing irreparable harm.
fr: -- Moins en danger de faire un mal irreparable.

eng: Don't let us be like all the others!"
fr: Ne soyons pas comme tous les autres !

eng: she protested.
fr: protesta-t-elle.

eng: His heart beat with awe: he felt that he had never before beheld love visible.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh, I shall be late--good-bye. No, don't come any farther than this," she cried, walking hurriedly away down the long room, as if the reflected radiance in his eyes had frightened her. When she reached the door she turned for a moment to wave a quick farewell.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Archer walked home alone. Darkness was falling when he let himself into his house, and he looked about at the familiar objects in the hall as if he viewed them from the other side of the grave.
fr: Archer rentra seul a pied. La nuit tombait quand il arriva chez lui. Il regarda les objets familiers du hall comme de l'autre cote de la tombe.

eng: The parlour-maid, hearing his step, ran up the stairs to light the gas on the upper landing. "Is Mrs. Archer in?" "No, sir; Mrs. Archer went out in the carriage after luncheon, and hasn't come back."
fr: May etait sortie en voiture apres le dejeuner et n'etait pas encore rentree.

eng: "If I were to let her come," he said to himself, "I should have to let her go again." And that was not to be imagined.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: With a sense of relief he entered the library and flung himself down in his armchair.
fr: Content d'etre seul, il entra dans la bibliotheque et se laissa tomber dans son fauteuil.

eng: "I'm dreadfully late--you weren't worried, were you?" she asked, laying her hand on his shoulder with one of her rare caresses.
fr: -- Je suis horriblement en retard. Vous n'etiez pas inquiet ? demanda-t-elle.

eng: "I went to see Granny, and just as I was going away Ellen came in from a walk; so I stayed and had a long talk with her. It was ages since we'd had a real talk...." She had dropped into her usual armchair, facing his, and was running her fingers through her rumpled hair. He fancied she expected him to speak.
fr: -- Je suis allee voir grand'mere, et comme je partais, Ellen est rentree. Alors je suis restee, et nous avons cause longuement. Il y avait des siecles que nous n'avions vraiment cause !...

eng: "After seven. I believe you've been asleep!" She laughed, and drawing out her hat pins tossed her velvet hat on the sofa. She looked paler than usual, but sparkling with an unwonted animation.
fr: -- Sept heures passees. Je vous soupconne d'avoir dormi. Elle rit. ~~~ Ayant retire les epingles de son chapeau de velours, elle le jeta sur le canape. Elle avait le visage a la fois plus pale et plus anime que de coutume.

eng: He looked up astonished. "Is it late?"
fr: Il la regarda surpris : -- Est-ce qu'il est tard ?

eng: The door opened and May came in.
fr: La porte s'ouvrit et May entra.

eng: What he had dreamed of had been so different that there was a mortal chill in his rapture.
fr: Ce qu'il avait reve etait si different !

eng: "This was what had to be, then ... this was what had to be," he kept repeating to himself, as if he hung in the clutch of doom.
fr: << Cela devait etre... ~~~ Cela devait etre..., >> se repetait-il.

eng: The parlour-maid followed, bringing the student lamp and shaking some coals onto the dying fire. When she left he continued to sit motionless, his elbows on his knees, his chin on his clasped hands, his eyes fixed on the red grate. He sat there without conscious thoughts, without sense of the lapse of time, in a deep and grave amazement that seemed to suspend life rather than quicken it.
fr: Il n'avait plus conscience du temps qui passait. ~~~ Une sorte de stupeur l'envahissait.

eng: "Dearest--!" he said again. She had disengaged her wrist; but for a moment they continued to hold each other's eyes, and he saw that her face, which had grown very pale, was flooded with a deep inner radiance.
fr: Ils resterent les yeux dans les yeux, Archer sur le pale visage d'Ellen lisait l'intense rayonnement interieur. Alors, il comprit que jamais auparavant il n'avait de ses yeux vu l'amour.

eng: "A really good talk," she went on, smiling with what seemed to Archer an unnatural vividness. "She was so dear--just like the old Ellen.'
fr: Elle a ete delicieuse, tout a fait comme l'ancienne Ellen.'

eng: "The day after."
fr: -- Je vous attendrai.

eng: It would have been easy to say: "Yes, come; come once." He knew the power she would put in his hands if she consented; there would be no difficulty then in persuading her not to go back to her husband. But something silenced the word on his lips. A sort of passionate honesty in her made it inconceivable that he should try to draw her into that familiar trap.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well, then: come to me once," he said, his head turning suddenly at the thought of losing her; and for a second or two they looked at each other almost like enemies.
fr: -- Quand viendrez-vous ? dit-il enfin.

eng: "What else is there? I can't stay here and lie to the people who've been good to me."
fr: -- Qu'y a-t-il d'autre a faire ? Je ne veux pas rester ici et mentir aux gens qui ont eu pitie de moi.

eng: "When?" he insisted. "Tomorrow?"
fr: Elle hesita : -- Apres-demain.

eng: She raised her troubled eyes to his.
fr: Elle leva sur lui des yeux troubles.

eng: "And you expect me to say yes to that?"
fr: -- Et vous croyez que jamais j'y consentirai ?

eng: "Home to my husband."
fr: -- Je retournerai chez mon mari.

eng: "Go home? What do you mean by going home?"
fr: -- Vous partirez ? Que voulez-vous dire ?

eng: Then her last phrase struck his ear and his face clouded.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It seemed as if he held his heart in his hands, like a full cup that the least motion might overbrim.
fr: Il lui semblait tenir dans ses mains son propre coeur, comme une coupe trop pleine que le moindre geste ferait deborder.

eng: "But that's the very reason why I ask you to come away!"
fr: -- Mais c'est justement pourquoi je demande que nous partions ensemble !

eng: "Dearest!" he said, without moving.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Shall I--once come to you; and then go home?" she suddenly hazarded in a low clear voice.
fr: -- Eh bien ! j'irai chez vous une fois, et puis nous nous dirons adieu : je partirai, hasarda-t-elle tout a coup, d'une voix basse, mais nette.

eng: She glanced at him with a kind of terror, and he saw a faint colour steal into her cheeks.
fr: Elle le regarda avec une sorte de terreur, et Archer vit une faible rougeur colorer son visage.

eng: "What others? I don't profess to be different from my kind. I'm consumed by the same wants and the same longings."
fr: '-- Les autres ? Pourquoi serais-je different des autres ? N'ai-je pas les memes desirs ? Ne suis-je pas brule des memes ardeurs ?'

eng: Archer sprang to his feet and stood looking down on her in inarticulate despair.
fr: Archer se leva brusquement et la regarda avec un desespoir muet.

eng: But he saw the shadow of the lashes on her wet cheek, and wavered.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "After all," he began again, "we have lives of our own.... There's no use attempting the impossible. You're so unprejudiced about some things, so used, as you say, to looking at the Gorgon, that I don't know why you're afraid to face our case, and see it as it really is--unless you think the sacrifice is not worth making."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She stood up also, her lips tightening under a rapid frown.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Call it that, then--I must go," she said, drawing her little watch from her bosom.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She turned away, and he followed and caught her by the wrist.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The blood rushed to the young man's forehead.
fr: Le sang monta au front du jeune homme.

eng: "And destroy their lives, when they've helped me to remake mine?"
fr: -- Et que nous brisions leurs existences, quand ils m'ont aidee a refaire la mienne ?

eng: I'm afraid I haven't been fair to her lately.
fr: Je crains de ne pas avoir ete juste pour elle dernierement.

eng: "Yes, you've thought--?" he echoed as she paused.
fr: -- Qu'est-ce que vous avez cru ?...

eng: She takes up such odd people--she seems to like to make herself conspicuous.
fr: Elle frequente des gens si bizarres. On dirait qu'elle prend plaisir a se singulariser.

eng: She's so different--at least on the surface.
fr: Elle est trop differente.

eng: "Well, perhaps I haven't judged her fairly.
fr: Peut-etre ne l'ai-je pas toujours comprise.

eng: Archer stood up and leaned against the mantelpiece, out of the radius of the lamp.
fr: Archer se leva et alla s'appuyer contre la cheminee hors du cercle lumineux de la lampe.

eng: I've sometimes thought--
fr: J'ai cru quelquefois...

eng: I suppose it's the life she's led in that fast European society; no doubt we seem dreadfully dull to her.
fr: Cela tient sans doute a la vie agitee qu'elle a menee dans cette societe d'Europe ; nous devons lui paraitre bien ennuyeux !

eng: But I don't want to judge her unfairly."
fr: Mais je ne veux plus etre injuste pour elle.

eng: He became aware of the same obscure effort in her, the same reaching out toward something beyond the usual range of her vision.
fr: Il devina en elle le meme effort secret pour atteindre quelque chose au dela de la portee habituelle de sa vision.

eng: "She hates Ellen," he thought, "and she's trying to overcome the feeling, and to get me to help her to overcome it."
fr: << Elle deteste Ellen, pensa-t-il elle essaie de dominer ce sentiment. ~~~ >>

eng: The thought moved him, and for a moment he was on the point of breaking the silence between them, and throwing himself on her mercy.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You understand, don't you," she went on, "why the family have sometimes been annoyed? We all did what we could for her at first; but she never seemed to understand.
fr: May continua : -- Nous avons fait tout ce que nous avons pu pour Ellen ; mais elle n'a jamais paru comprendre.

eng: She paused again, a little breathless with the unwonted length of her speech, and sat with her lips slightly parted and a deep blush on her cheeks.
fr: Elle s'arreta un peu haletante d'avoir, contre son habitude, parle si longtemps. Elle avait les levres entr'ouvertes, une sombre rougeur aux joues.

eng: Archer, as he looked at her, was reminded of the glow which had suffused her face in the Mission Garden at St. Augustine.
fr: Archer, en la regardant, se rappela le mysterieux eclat qui avait inonde son visage dans le jardin de la mission a Saint-Augustin.

eng: And now this idea of going to see Mrs. Beaufort, of going there in Granny's carriage!
fr: Et maintenant, cette idee d'aller voir Mrs Beaufort, et surtout dans la voiture de grand'mere !

eng: "It's time to dress; we're dining out, aren't we?" he asked, moving from the fire.
fr: 'Il est temps de nous habiller : nous dinons en ville, n'est-ce pas ? demanda-t-il.'

eng: As he walked past her she moved forward impulsively, as though to detain him: their eyes met, and he saw that hers were of the same swimming blue as when he had left her to drive to Jersey City.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You haven't kissed me today," she said in a whisper; and he felt her tremble in his arms.
fr: 'Vous ne m'avez pas embrassee aujourd'hui, dit-elle tendrement. Et il la sentit trembler dans ses bras.'

eng: She flung her arms about his neck and pressed her cheek to his.
fr: Elle se leva, mais ce fut pour jeter les bras autour du cou de son mari et presser sa joue contre la sienne.

eng: She rose also, but lingered near the hearth.
fr: Elle se leva, mais ce fut pour jeter les bras autour du cou de son mari et presser sa joue contre la sienne.

eng: The open door had closed between them again.
fr: La barriere qui les separait s'etait de nouveau dressee entre eux.

eng: "Ah," said Archer with an impatient laugh.
fr: 'Ah ! ~~~ dit Archer avec un rire enerve.'

eng: "I'm afraid she's quite alienated the van der Luydens ..."
fr: 'J'ai peur qu'elle se soit aliene les van der Luyden.'

eng: XXXII. ~~~ "At the court of the Tuileries," said Mr. Sillerton Jackson with his reminiscent smile, "such things were pretty openly tolerated."
fr: XXXII -- A la cour des Tuileries, disait Mr Sillerton Jackson, avec le sourire de ses reminiscences parisiennes, ces choses-la etaient assez ouvertement tolerees.

eng: The scene was the van der Luydens' black walnut dining-room in Madison Avenue, and the time the evening after Newland Archer's visit to the Museum of Art.
fr: C'etait le lendemain de la visite d'Archer au musee ; on dinait dans la salle a manger lambrissee de noyer des van der Luyden.

eng: Mr. and Mrs. van der Luyden had come to town for a few days from Skuytercliff, whither they had precipitately fled at the announcement of Beaufort's failure.
fr: Ceux-ci, incapables de supporter les emotions d'un scandale, s'etaient refugies a Skuytercliff apres la faillite de Beaufort.

eng: It had been represented to them that the disarray into which society had been thrown by this deplorable affair made their presence in town more necessary than ever.
fr: Mais on leur avait fait observer que leur presence a New-York etait indispensable : n'etaient-ils pas les piliers de cette societe ebranlee par la faillite ?

eng: It was one of the occasions when, as Mrs. Archer put it, they "owed it to society" to show themselves at the Opera, and even to open their own doors.
fr: -- Vous devez a vos amis, leur disait Mrs Archer, de vous montrer a l'Opera et meme d'ouvrir vos salons.

eng: "It will never do, my dear Louisa, to let people like Mrs. Lemuel Struthers think they can step into Regina's shoes. ~~~ It is just at such times that new people push in and get a footing.
fr: Il ne faut surtout pas, ma chere Louisa, laisser des gens comme Mrs Lemuel Struthers chausser les souliers de Regina ; ce sont les occasions que saisissent les parvenus pour se pousser et prendre pied dans le monde.

eng: You and dear Henry, Louisa, must stand in the breach as you always have.
fr: Vous, Louisa, et ce cher Henri, devez garder la place, comme vous l'avez toujours fait.

eng: It was owing to the epidemic of chicken-pox in New York the winter Mrs. Struthers first appeared that the married men slipped away to her house while their wives were in the nursery.
fr: C'est grace a l'epidemie de varicelle de l'hiver dernier que les hommes maries ont pu s'echapper pour aller chez Mrs Struthers pendant que les femmes soignaient leurs enfants.

eng: Mr. and Mrs. van der Luyden could not remain deaf to such a call, and reluctantly but heroically they had come to town, unmuffled the house, and sent out invitations for two dinners and an evening reception.
fr: A contre-coeur, mais toujours heroiquement soumis au devoir, ils etaient rentres en ville, avaient ote leurs housses, envoye leurs invitations pour deux diners et une soiree.

eng: On this particular evening they had invited Sillerton Jackson, Mrs. Archer and Newland and his wife to go with them to the Opera, where Faust was being sung for the first time that winter.
