eng: ~~~ The very mysteriousness of such a cure made her the more confident of its efficacy.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: His children had urged him to travel: Mary Chivers had felt sure it would do him good to go abroad and "see the galleries."
fr: mais il s'etait trouve retenu par l'habitude, les souvenirs, et par une certaine apprehension de ce qui etait nouveau.

eng: Since her death, nearly two years before, there had been no reason for his continuing in the same routine.
fr: Depuis deux ans que May etait morte, Archer n'avait aucune raison de continuer sa vie sedentaire ;

eng: It would be their last time together in this kind of way: the boy was right.
fr: La derniere fois qu'ils seraient ensemble tous les deux comme autrefois !... L'enfant avait raison.

eng: But Mary and Bill wanted mountain-climbing, and had already yawned their way in Dallas's wake through the English cathedrals; and May, always fair to her children, had insisted on holding the balance evenly between their athletic and artistic proclivities.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: After Dallas had taken his degree she had thought it her duty to travel for six months; and the whole family had made the old-fashioned tour through England, Switzerland and Italy. Their time being limited (no one knew why) they had omitted France. Archer remembered Dallas's wrath at being asked to contemplate Mont Blanc instead of Rheims and Chartres.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: May had disliked to move except for valid reasons, such as taking the children to the sea or in the mountains: she could imagine no other motive for leaving the house in Thirty-ninth Street or their comfortable quarters at the Wellands' in Newport.
fr: May ne s'etait jamais deplacee que pour des raisons serieuses : mener les enfants dans la montagne ou au bord de la mer.

eng: Still, change was change, and differences were differences, and much as he felt himself drawn toward his future daughter-in-law, it was tempting to seize this last chance of being alone with his boy.
fr: Cependant, -- il fallait se l'avouer, -- et, malgre sa sympathie pour sa future belle-fille, c'etait tentant pour Archer de saisir cette derniere occasion de se trouver seul avec son fils.

eng: On the contrary, from what he had seen of her, he thought she would be naturally included in it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They would have lots of other "times" after Dallas's marriage, his father was sure; for the two were born comrades, and Fanny Beaufort, whatever one might think of her, did not seem likely to interfere with their intimacy.
fr: Sans doute, ils seraient ensemble bien souvent apres le mariage de Dallas. Ils avaient toujours ete camarades, et Fanny Beaufort, quoi qu'on put dire d'elle, ne paraissait pas disposee a gener leur intimite.

eng: ~~~ The trenchant divisions between right and wrong, honest and dishonest, respectable and the reverse, had left so little scope for the unforeseen. There are moments when a man's imagination, so easily subdued to what it lives in, suddenly rises above its daily level, and surveys the long windings of destiny. Archer hung there and wondered....
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had indeed proposed that her husband should go to Paris for a fortnight, and join them on the Italian lakes after they had "done" Switzerland; but Archer had declined. "We'll stick together," he said; and May's face had brightened at his setting such a good example to Dallas.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Chicago rang off, and Archer rose and began to pace up and down the room.
fr: Chicago coupa. Archer se leva et arpenta la chambre.

eng: But the laugh did startle him; it still seemed wonderful that across all those miles and miles of country--forest, river, mountain, prairie, roaring cities and busy indifferent millions--Dallas's laugh should be able to say: "Of course, whatever happens, I must get back on the first, because Fanny Beaufort and I are to be married on the fifth."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: What was left of the little world he had grown up in, and whose standards had bent and bound him?
fr: Il se rappelait une railleuse prophetie du pauvre Lawrence Lafferts, emise dans cette meme piece tant d'annees auparavant : << Si les choses vont de ce train, nos enfants epouseront les batards de Beaufort : >>

eng: Mary Chivers's mighty feats of athleticism could not have been performed with the twenty-inch waist that May Archer's azure sash so easily spanned.
fr: Mary Chivers n'aurait pas pu accomplir ses hauts faits d'athletisme avec les cinquante centimetres de tour de taille que mesurait la ceinture bleu de ciel de May Archer.

eng: And the difference seemed symbolic; the mother's life had been as closely girt as her figure.
fr: La difference etait symbolique : l'ame de la mere avait ete pareillement enfermee dans une armature aussi rigide que sa fine taille.

eng: ~~~ Mary, who was no less conventional, and no more intelligent, yet led a larger life and held more tolerant views.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was good in the new order too.
fr: Il y avait du bon aussi dans le nouvel ordre des choses.

eng: The telephone clicked, and Archer, turning from the photographs, unhooked the transmitter at his elbow.
fr: L'appel du telephone se fit entendre.

eng: The voice began again: "Think it over? No, sir: not a minute. You've got to say yes now. Why not, I'd like to know? If you can allege a single reason--No; I knew it. Then it's a go, eh? Because I count on you to ring up the Cunard office first thing tomorrow; and you'd better book a return on a boat from Marseilles. I say, Dad; it'll be our last time together, in this kind of way--. Oh, good! I knew you would."
fr: La voix reprit : -- Reflechir ? Pas une minute ! Dites tout de suite !... Avez-vous une raison de refuser ? Non. ~~~ J'en etais sur. Alors, ca va ? Dites, pere, ce sera la derniere fois que nous voyagerons tous les deux, comme autrefois. Allons ! bien ! J'etais sur que vous viendriez.

eng: How far they were from the days when the legs of the brass-buttoned messenger boy had been New York's only means of quick communication!
fr: Comme on etait loin du temps ou toute communication rapide a New-York se faisait par les jambes des petits messenger boys a livree bleue !

eng: Ah--it must be a long-distance from Dallas, who had been sent to Chicago by his firm to talk over the plan of the Lakeside palace they were to build for a young millionaire with ideas.
fr: Ah ! ~~~ ce devait etre un message de Dallas. ~~~ Il avait ete envoye a Chicago pour etudier le plan d'un palais que sa maison construisait pour un jeune millionnaire a idees.

eng: The firm always sent Dallas on such errands.
fr: Les missions de ce genre etaient toujours confiees a Dallas.

eng: ~~~ "Hallo, Dad--Yes: Dallas. I say--how do you feel about sailing on Wednesday? Mauretania: Yes, next Wednesday as ever is. Our client wants me to look at some Italian gardens before we settle anything, and has asked me to nip over on the next boat. I've got to be back on the first of June--"
fr: -- Allo ! ~~~ pere. Voulez-vous vous embarquer avec moi mercredi sur le Mauretania ? Notre client veut que je visite quelques jardins italiens avant de rien decider ; et vous savez, je dois etre rentre le 1er juin.

eng: the voice broke into a joyful conscious laugh--"so we must look alive. I say, Dad, I want your help: do come."
fr: Il eclata d'un rire joyeux. << Quoi qu'il arrive, semblait dire ce rire, je dois etre de retour le premier, puisque Fanny Beaufort et moi devons nous marier le cinq. >>

eng: Dallas seemed to be speaking in the room: the voice was as near by and natural as if he had been lounging in his favourite arm-chair by the fire.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The fact would not ordinarily have surprised Archer, for long-distance telephoning had become as much a matter of course as electric lighting and five-day Atlantic voyages.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Chicago wants you."
fr: << Chicago vous demande. >>

eng: He remembered a sneering prophecy of poor Lawrence Lefferts's, uttered years ago in that very room: "If things go on at this rate, our children will be marrying Beaufort's bastards."
fr: C'etait justement ce que le fils aine d'Archer, l'orgueil de sa vie, allait faire, sans que personne l'en blamat ou s'etonnat seulement.

eng: There was no reason why he should not seize it, except the profound one that he had lost the habit of travel.
fr: Rien ne le retenait. ~~~ Seulement il avait perdu l'habitude de voyager.

eng: Even the boy's Aunt Janey, who still looked so exactly as she used to in her elderly youth, had taken her mother's emeralds and seed-pearls out of their pink cotton-wool, and carried them with her own twitching hands to the future bride; and Fanny Beaufort, instead of looking disappointed at not receiving a "set" from a Paris jeweller, had exclaimed at their old-fashioned beauty, and declared that when she wore them she should feel like an Isabey miniature.
fr: Et Fanny Beaufort, loin de paraitre decue de ne pas recevoir une parure d'un joaillier de Paris, avait admire le style ancien de ces bijoux, et declare qu'en les portant elle se sentirait digne d'etre peinte par Isabey.

eng: Fanny Beaufort, who had appeared in New York at eighteen, after the death of her parents, had won its heart much as Madame Olenska had won it thirty years earlier; only instead of being distrustful and afraid of her, society took her joyfully for granted.
fr: Fanny Beaufort, qui avait fait son apparition a New-York a l'age de dix-huit ans, apres la mort de ses parents, avait conquis les coeurs un peu comme Mme Olenska trente ans auparavant. Seulement, au lieu de la regarder avec une sorte de mefiance, la societe l'avait joyeusement acceptee.

eng: She was pretty, amusing and accomplished: what more did any one want?
fr: Elle etait jolie, amusante et douee : que pouvait-on demander de plus ?

eng: Nobody was narrow-minded enough to rake up against her the half-forgotten facts of her father's past and her own origin.
fr: Personne n'avait l'esprit assez etroit pour lui faire un grief du passe de son pere, ni de son origine a elle.

eng: Only the older people remembered so obscure an incident in the business life of New York as Beaufort's failure, or the fact that after his wife's death he had been quietly married to the notorious Fanny Ring, and had left the country with his new wife, and a little girl who inherited her beauty.
fr: Les personnes agees, seules, se souvenaient d'un incident perdu dans le mouvement des affaires a New-York : le krach Beaufort. Du reste, apres la mort de sa femme, Beaufort, ayant epouse sans bruit la trop celebre Fanny Ring, avait quitte le pays avec sa nouvelle femme et une petite fille qui heritait de la beaute de sa mere.

eng: It was just what Archer's eldest son, the pride of his life, was doing; and nobody wondered or reproved.
fr: Tante Janey, restee si exactement la meme qu'aux jours de sa jeunesse fanee, avait retire de leur coton rose les emeraudes serties de perles de sa mere, et les avait portees elle-meme, de ses mains tremblantes, a la fiancee.

eng: He was subsequently heard of in Constantinople, then in Russia; and a dozen years later American travellers were handsomely entertained by him in Buenos Ayres, where he represented a large insurance agency.
fr: On avait ensuite appris qu'il etait a Constantinople, puis en Russie, et, une douzaine d'annees plus tard, des voyageurs americains furent brillamment recus chez lui a Buenos-Ayres, ou il representait une grande Compagnie d'assurances.

eng: He and his wife died there in the odour of prosperity; and one day their orphaned daughter had appeared in New York in charge of May Archer's sister-in-law, Mrs. Jack Welland, whose husband had been appointed the girl's guardian.
fr: Il etait mort la, ainsi que sa femme ; et, un jour, leur fille, riche et orpheline, etait arrivee a New-York, sous la conduite de la belle-soeur de May, Mrs Jack Welland, dont le mari etait le tuteur de l'enfant.

eng: The fact threw her into almost cousinly relationship with Newland Archer's children, and nobody was surprised when Dallas's engagement was announced.
fr: Elle se trouvait ainsi dans des relations presque de cousinage avec les enfants de Newland Archer, et personne ne s'etait etonne quand Dallas avait annonce ses fiancailles.

eng: Nothing could more dearly give the measure of the distance that the world had travelled.
fr: Rien ne pouvait donner plus exactement la mesure du chemin que le monde avait parcouru.

eng: People nowadays were too busy--busy with reforms and "movements," with fads and fetishes and frivolities--to bother much about their neighbours.
fr: On etait trop absorbe par les reformes et les mouvements sociaux, par les engouements et les modes du jour, pour s'inquieter beaucoup du passe de ses voisins.

eng: Newland Archer, looking out of his hotel window at the stately gaiety of the Paris streets, felt his heart beating with the confusion and eagerness of youth.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And of what account was anybody's past, in the huge kaleidoscope where all the social atoms spun around on the same plane?
fr: Qu'importait le passe dans le grand kaleidoscope ou tous les atomes sociaux roulaient sur le meme plan ?

eng: It was the day after their arrival in Paris, and the spring sunshine held Archer in his open window, above the wide silvery prospect of the Place Vendome.
fr: Le lendemain de leur arrivee a Paris, Archer, de la fenetre de son hotel, contemplait le beau decor de la place Vendome.

eng: Only, I wonder--the thing one's so certain of in advance: can it ever make one's heart beat as wildly?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "The difference is that these young people take it for granted that they're going to get whatever they want, and that we almost always took it for granted that we shouldn't.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "It functions as actively, no doubt, but the rhythm is different," he reflected, recalling the cool composure with which the young man had announced his engagement, and taken for granted that his family would approve.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He wondered if it was thus that his son's conducted itself in the presence of Miss Fanny Beaufort--and decided that it was not.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was long since it had thus plunged and reared under his widening waistcoat, leaving him, the next minute, with an empty breast and hot temples.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: One of the things he had stipulated--almost the only one--when he had agreed to come abroad with Dallas, was that, in Paris, he shouldn't be made to go to one of the newfangled "palaces."
fr: Une des choses qu'il avait stipulees, presque la seule, quand il avait accepte d'accompagner Dallas, etait qu'il ne serait pas oblige de descendre a Paris dans un des nouveaux palaces a la mode.

eng: "I'll take you to some jolly old-fashioned place--the Bristol say--"
fr: Je vous menerai dans un bon vieil hotel : le Bristol.

eng: leaving his father speechless at hearing that the century-long home of kings and emperors was now spoken of as an old-fashioned inn, where one went for its quaint inconveniences and lingering local colour.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: then the personal vision had faded, and he had simply tried to see the city as the setting of Madame Olenska's life.
fr: Combien de fois Archer n'avait-il pas pense a Paris comme au cadre ou vivait Mme Olenska !

eng: "Oh, all right--of course," Dallas good-naturedly agreed.
fr: '-- Entendu, avait acquiesce Dallas bon prince.

eng: Archer had pictured often enough, in the first impatient years, the scene of his return to Paris;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Sitting alone at night in his library, after the household had gone to bed, he had evoked the radiant outbreak of spring down the avenues of horse-chestnuts, the flowers and statues in the public gardens, the whiff of lilacs from the flower-carts, the majestic roll of the river under the great bridges, and the life of art and study and pleasure that filled each mighty artery to bursting.
fr: Seul, tard le soir, dans sa bibliotheque, quand toute la maison reposait, il avait evoque le retour radieux du printemps le long des avenues de marronniers, les fleurs et les statues des jardins publics, les bouffees des lilas entasses dans les charrettes, le cours majestueux du fleuve sous les arches des ponts, et la vie d'art, d'etude et de plaisir qui roulait impetueusement dans les arteres de la grande ville.

eng: They stood for a while looking out in silence, and then the young man continued:
fr: Ils resterent un moment, regardant devant eux ; puis le jeune homme continua :

eng: He said it lightly, carelessly, as he might have imparted any casual item of information, such as the hour at which their train was to leave for Florence the next evening.
fr: Il disait cela avec insouciance comme s'il s'agissait de l'heure du depart pour Florence le lendemain soir.

eng: "By the way, I've got a message for you: the Countess Olenska expects us both at half-past five."
fr: -- Au fait, j'ai une commission pour vous : la comtesse Olenska nous attend a cinq heures et demie.

eng: "Hullo, father: this is something like, isn't it?"
fr: -- Eh bien ! pere ! ca vaut la peine, hein ?

eng: Dallas's hand came down cheerily on his shoulder.
fr: La main de Dallas se posa gaiement sur son epaule.

eng: Now the spectacle was before him in its glory, and as he looked out on it he felt shy, old-fashioned, inadequate: a mere grey speck of a man compared with the ruthless magnificent fellow he had dreamed of being....
fr: Maintenant, le spectacle etait devant lui et, en le considerant, Archer se sentait timide et suranne : un pauvre etre insignifiant compare a l'homme d'energie qu'il avait reve d'etre...

eng: Archer looked at him, and thought he saw in his gay young eyes a gleam of his great-grandmother Mingott's malice.
fr: Archer le regarda, et crut voir dans les yeux gais de son fils un eclair de la malice de son arriere-grand'mere Mingott.

eng: Archer felt his colour rise under his son's unabashed gaze.
fr: Archer se sentit rougir sous le clair regard de son fils.

eng: "Come, own up: you and she were great pals, weren't you? Wasn't she most awfully lovely?"
fr: -- Allons, avouez, vous avez ete tres emballe pour elle, est-ce vrai ? N'etait-elle pas ravissante ?

eng: "I say, father: what was she like?"
fr: -- Dites, pere, comment etait-elle ?

eng: "And she's our cousin, of course."
fr: -- et puis elle est notre cousine.

eng: "Of course--why not?" Dallas's eye brows went up whimsically.
fr: -- Bien sur : pourquoi pas ? Dallas eut un sourire innocent.

eng: "You told her I was here?"
fr: -- Tu lui as dit que j'etais ici ?

eng: Archer continued to stare at him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "So I rang her up this morning, before I went out, and told her you and I were here for two days and wanted to see her."
fr: Aussi, je l'ai appelee au telephone ce matin avant de sortir, et lui ai dit que nous etions ici pour deux jours, et desirions la voir.

eng: "I believe she was a great friend of the first Mrs. Beaufort's."
fr: Je crois que Mme Olenska a ete tres liee avec la premiere Mrs Beaufort,

eng: "Fanny hadn't any friends in Paris, and Madame Olenska used to be kind to her and trot her about on holidays."
fr: Fanny ne connaissait personne a Paris : Mme Olenska s'est occupee d'elle, l'a promenee les jours de conge.

eng: "You know she was awfully good to Fanny when Mr. Beaufort sent her over from Buenos Ayres to the Assomption."
fr: Vous savez que celle-ci a ete la bonte meme pour Fanny, quand Mr Beaufort l'a envoyee de Buenos-Ayres au couvent de l'Assomption.

eng: "Fanny made me swear to do three things while I was in Paris: get her the score of the last Debussy songs, go to the Grand-Guignol and see Madame Olenska."
fr: J'ai jure a Fanny de faire trois choses pendant mon sejour a Paris : lui acheter le recueil des dernieres melodies de Debussy ; aller au Grand Guignol ; et voir Mme Olenska.

eng: "Oh, didn't I tell you?" Dallas pursued.
fr: '-- Est-ce que je ne vous l'avais pas dit ? poursuivit Dallas.

eng: Then, getting no answer, he slipped his arm through his father's with a confidential pressure.
fr: Puis, ne recevant pas de reponse, il glissa son bras sous celui de son pere.

eng: "Lovely?
fr: -- Ravissante ?

eng: I don't know.
fr: Je ne sais pas.

eng: She was different."
fr: Elle etait differente des autres.

eng: "Ah--there you have it!
fr: -- Ah ! ~~~ nous y voila !

eng: That's what it always comes to, doesn't it?
fr: Toute la question est la, n'est-ce pas ?

eng: "His father drew back a step, releasing his arm."
fr: "Son pere recula d'un pas, degageant son bras :"

eng: "When she comes, SHE'S DIFFERENT--and one doesn't know why."
fr: "Quand on la trouve, la femme qu'on attend, elle est toujours differente, -- et on ne sait pas pourquoi."

eng: "It's exactly what I feel about Fanny."
fr: "C'est exactement ce que j'eprouve avec Fanny."

eng: "About Fanny?"
fr: "Avec Fanny ?"

eng: "But, my dear fellow--I should hope so! Only I don't see--"
fr: "Mais, mon ami, je l'espere bien ; seulement, je ne vois pas..."

eng: "Dash it, Dad, don't be prehistoric! Wasn't she--once--your Fanny?"
fr: "Voyons, pere, ne soyez pas cachottier ! N'a-t-elle pas ete, autrefois, votre Fanny ?"

eng: Dallas belonged body and soul to the new generation.
fr: Dallas appartenait de tout son etre a la nouvelle generation.

eng: He was the first-born of Newland and May Archer, yet it had never been possible to inculcate in him even the rudiments of reserve.
fr: A ce premier ne de Newland et de May Archer, il avait ete impossible d'inculquer les plus elementaires notions de reserve.

eng: "What's the use of making mysteries?
fr: << Pourquoi faire des mysteres ?

eng: It only makes people want to nose 'em out," he always objected when enjoined to discretion.
fr: Les gens flairent toujours ce qu'on veut leur cacher, >> objectait-il quand on lui recommandait la discretion.

eng: "My Fanny?"
fr: -- Ma << Fanny >>... ?

eng: "Well, the woman you'd have chucked everything for: only you didn't," continued his surprising son.
fr: -- Eh bien ! la femme pour laquelle vous auriez tout envoye promener. ~~~ Seulement, vous ne l'avez pas fait.

eng: "I didn't," echoed Archer with a kind of solemnity.
fr: -- Non, je ne l'ai pas fait, repeta Archer avec une sorte de solennite.

eng: "No: you date, you see, dear old boy. But mother said--"
fr: -- Vous datez, voyez-vous, mon pauvre papa ! Ma mere m'a dit...

eng: "Your mother?"
fr: -- Ta mere ?

eng: But Archer, meeting his eyes, saw the filial light under their banter.
fr: Mais Archer, rencontrant les yeux de son fils, sentit la lueur filiale sous la malice.

eng: "Yes: the day before she died.
fr: -- Oui, la veille de sa mort.

eng: It was when she sent for me alone--you remember?
fr: Quand elle a voulu me voir seul. ~~~ Vous vous rappelez ?

eng: She said she knew we were safe with you, and always would be, because once, when she asked you to, you'd given up the thing you most wanted."
fr: Elle m'a dit qu'elle etait tranquille en nous quittant parce qu'une fois, quand elle vous en avait fait la demande, vous lui aviez sacrifie la chose a laquelle vous teniez le plus.

eng: Archer received this strange communication in silence.
fr: Archer recut en silence cette singuliere communication.

eng: His eyes remained unseeingly fixed on the thronged sunlit square below the window.
fr: Son regard perdu embrassa la place ensoleillee ou s'ecoulaient les passants.

eng: "No.  I forgot. You never did ask each other anything, did you? And you never told each other anything."
fr: Non, naturellement. Vous ne vous etes jamais rien demande l'un a l'autre, n'est-ce pas ? Et vous ne vous etes jamais rien dit.

eng: At length he said in a low voice: "She never asked me."
fr: Enfin, il dit a voix basse : -- Elle ne me l'a jamais demande. --

eng: He had to deal all at once with the packed regrets and stifled memories of an inarticulate lifetime.
fr: Les regrets accumules, les souvenirs etouffes d'une vie muette, pesaient lourdement sur son ame...

eng: He preferred to spend the afternoon in solitary roamings through Paris.
fr: Il prefera vaguer seul a travers la lumineuse solitude de Paris.

eng: Archer did not accompany his son to Versailles.
fr: Archer n'accompagna pas son fils a Versailles.

eng: "I say, Dad," Dallas broke off, "you're not angry with me? If you are, let's make it up and go and lunch at Henri's. I've got to rush out to Versailles afterward."
fr: Nous n'avons pas le temps... Dites... pere, fit Dallas, vous n'etes pas fache, j'espere ? Si vous l'etes, nous allons faire la paix et dejeuner chez Henri... Apres, il faut que je coure a Versailles.

eng: "Well, I back your generation for knowing more about each other's private thoughts than we ever have time to find out about our own."
fr: Avec cela, je parie que chacun de vous en savait plus long sur ce que pensait l'autre que nous ne savons, nous, sur ce que nous pensons nous-memes.

eng: "A deaf-and-dumb asylum, in fact!"
fr: -- un duo de sourds-muets, pas vrai ?

eng: "You just sat and watched each other, and guessed at what was going on underneath."
fr: Vous etes restes l'un devant l'autre, a observer, a deviner ce qui se passait en dedans,

eng: After a little while he did not regret Dallas's indiscretion.
fr: A la reflexion, il ne regretta pas l'indiscretion de Dallas.

eng: It seemed to take an iron band from his heart to know that, after all, some one had guessed and pitied.... And that it should have been his wife moved him indescribably.
fr: Il sentit son coeur allege d'un lourd fardeau. ~~~ Quelqu'un avait donc devine, avait eu pitie ; et que ce quelqu'un eut ete May, il en ressentait une emotion indicible.

eng: "That's it: they feel equal to things--they know their way about," he mused, thinking of his son as the spokesman of the new generation which had swept away all the old landmarks, and with them the sign-posts and the danger-signal.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: For a long time Archer sat on a bench in the Champs Elysees and wondered, while the stream of life rolled by....
fr: Longtemps, Archer, assis sur un banc aux Champs-Elysees, resta perdu dans ses pensees. Autour de lui, la vie... la vie des autres... passait comme un fleuve.

eng: Dallas, for all his affectionate insight, would not have understood that.
fr: Dallas, avec toute sa perspicacite affectueuse, n'aurait pas compris cela.

eng: To the boy, no doubt, the episode was only a pathetic instance of vain frustration, of wasted forces.
fr: Pour l'enfant, sans doute, l'episode n'etait que l'exemple pathetique d'une vie gachee.

eng: But was it really no more?
fr: N'etait-ce vraiment que cela ?

eng: The dome of Mansart floated ethereally above the budding trees and the long grey front of the building: drawing up into itself all the rays of afternoon light, it hung there like the visible symbol of the race's glory.
fr: Le dome de Mansart rayonnant, sur la masse grise du monument, absorbait et renvoyait les ors du soleil couchant. ~~~ Dans l'ether lumineux il semblait le symbole visible de la gloire d'une race.

eng: They had come out into the great tree-planted space before the Invalides.
fr: (Partially corresponds to: Tous deux traverserent la place de la Concorde et la Seine, s'engagerent sur l'Esplanade des Invalides.)

eng: Suddenly Dallas stopped short, grasping his father's arm. "Oh, by Jove," he exclaimed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: As Archer listened, his sense of inadequacy and inexpressiveness increased.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He had had but one previous glimpse of it, during a holiday trip in which he had tried to pack all the sights he had been deprived of when he had had to go with the family to Switzerland; and tumultuous enthusiasm and cock-sure criticism tripped each other up on his lips.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Dallas, unconscious of what was going on in his father's mind, was talking excitedly and abundantly of Versailles.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The boy was not insensitive, he knew; but he had the facility and self-confidence that came of looking at fate not as a master but as an equal.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: For such summer dreams it was too late; but surely not for a quiet harvest of friendship, of comradeship, in the blessed hush of her nearness.
fr: Pour les reves du chaud ete, c'etait trop tard ; mais non pour un tranquille automne aupres d'Ellen, dans la paix benie de sa presence.

eng: Suddenly, before an effulgent Titian, he found himself saying: "But I'm only fifty-seven--" and then he turned away.
fr: Soudain, devant un triomphal Titien, il se prit a dire : << Mais je n'ai que cinquante-sept ans ! >> Puis, il se detourna.

eng: After all, his life had been too starved....
fr: La beaute, il en avait eu faim toute sa vie...

eng: For an hour or more he wandered from gallery to gallery through the dazzle of afternoon light, and one by one the pictures burst on him in their half-forgotten splendour, filling his soul with the long echoes of beauty.
fr: Pendant plus d'une heure, il erra de salle en salle dans l'eblouissement d'une journee de printemps. L'un apres l'autre, des tableaux se revelaient a lui dans leur splendeur a moitie oubliee, et il se laissait peu a peu envahir par les emotions qu'inspire la beaute.

eng: She had once told him that she often went there, and he had a fancy to spend the intervening time in a place where he could think of her as perhaps having lately been.
fr: Mme Olenska lui avait dit une fois qu'elle allait souvent au Louvre, et il eut la fantaisie de passer les heures de l'attente dans un endroit ou peut-etre elle avait ete recemment.

eng: He got up and walked across the Place de la Concorde and the Tuileries gardens to the Louvre.
fr: Il se leva et traversa le jardin des Tuileries.

eng: There was nothing now to keep her and Archer apart--and that afternoon he was to see her.
fr: Il n'y avait plus rien pour la separer d'Archer : tout a l'heure, il allait la voir.

eng: She had never gone back to her husband, and when he had died, some years before, she had made no change in her way of living.
fr: Elle n'etait jamais retournee chez son mari, et depuis la mort d'Olenski, elle n'avait rien change a sa maniere de vivre.

eng: He went back to the hotel, where he and Dallas were to meet; and together they walked again across the Place de la Concorde and over the bridge that leads to the Chamber of Deputies.
fr: Il revint a l'hotel ou il devait retrouver Dallas. Tous deux traverserent la place de la Concorde et la Seine, s'engagerent sur l'Esplanade des Invalides.

eng: A few streets away, a few hours away, Ellen Olenska waited.
fr: La, tout pres, cette meme fin d'apres-midi, Ellen Olenska l'attendait.

eng: Archer knew that Madame Olenska lived in a square near one of the avenues radiating from the Invalides; and he had pictured the quarter as quiet and almost obscure, forgetting the central splendour that lit it up.
fr: Archer savait que Mme Olenska demeurait pres d'une des avenues qui aboutissent aux Invalides : pourquoi s'etait-il figure un quartier paisible et modeste, oubliant la brillante coupole qui regne sur lui.

eng: Now, by some queer process of association, that golden light became for him the pervading illumination in which she lived.
fr: Par un singulier enchainement d'idees, cette lumiere doree devint pour lui la lumiere meme ou Ellen vivait.

eng: For nearly thirty years, her life--of which he knew so strangely little--had been spent in this rich atmosphere that he already felt to be too dense and yet too stimulating for his lungs.
fr: Pendant pres de trente ans, la vie de Mme Olenska, -- cette vie dont il etait si etrangement ignorant, -- s'etait deroulee dans cette riche atmosphere.

eng: He thought of the theatres she must have been to, the pictures she must have looked at, the sober and splendid old houses she must have frequented.
fr: Il pensa a tous les beaux spectacles auxquels elle avait du assister, aux tableaux qu'elle avait du regarder, aux sobres et magnifiques demeures ou elle avait du entrer.

eng: the people she must have talked with, the incessant stir of ideas, curiosities, images and associations thrown out by an intensely social race in a setting of immemorial manners;
fr: Il pensa aux gens avec qui elle avait du causer, aux idees, aux curiosites, aux images et aux comparaisons que remue sans treve une race d'une intense sociabilite, dans le charme d'une politesse traditionnelle.

eng: and suddenly he remembered the young Frenchman who had once said to him: "Ah, good conversation--there is nothing like it, is there?"
fr: Tout a coup, Archer se rappela le jeune Francais qui lui avait dit une fois : << Une conversation interessante, il n'y a rien de tel, n'est-ce pas ? >>

eng: Archer had not seen M. Riviere, or heard of him, for nearly thirty years;
fr: Il n'avait jamais revu M. Riviere, ni entendu parler de lui depuis trente ans.

eng: and that fact gave the measure of his ignorance of Madame Olenska's existence.
fr: Tout ce qui avait rapport a Mme Olenska etait pour lui si lointain !

eng: More than half a lifetime divided them, and she had spent the long interval among people he did not know, in a society he but faintly guessed at, in conditions he would never wholly understand.
fr: Il etait reste separe d'elle pendant la moitie de sa vie. Elle avait passe ce long intervalle de temps parmi des gens qu'il ne connaissait pas, entouree d'une societe dont il pouvait a peine se faire une idee.

eng: During that time he had been living with his youthful memory of her;
fr: Lui, il avait vecu avec son souvenir ;

eng: but she had doubtless had other and more tangible companionship.
fr: mais autour d'elle il y avait eu toute une societe, toute une vie...

eng: Perhaps she too had kept her memory of him as something apart; but if she had, it must have been like a relic in a small dim chapel, where there was not time to pray every day....
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They had crossed the Place des Invalides, and were walking down one of the thoroughfares flanking the building.
fr: Ils traverserent la Place des Invalides et suivirent une des avenues qui longent le monument.

eng: It was a quiet quarter, after all, in spite of its splendour and its history;
fr: Archer s'etonnait de ces grandes voies un peu desertes dans ce paysage de splendeur et d'histoire.

eng: and the fact gave one an idea of the riches Paris had to draw on, since such scenes as this were left to the few and the indifferent.
fr: Paris, en verite, avait donc beaucoup de ces glorieux tresors, pour qu'autour de celui-ci il y eut le calme et le vide.

eng: The day was fading into a soft sun-shot haze, pricked here and there by a yellow electric light, and passers were rare in the little square into which they had turned.
fr: Le jour s'evanouissait dans un leger brouillard, illumine par de rares rayons de soleil, et pique ca et la par les points jaunes des lampes electriques. Les passants etaient rares dans la petite place vers laquelle Archer et son fils s'etaient diriges.

eng: Dallas stopped again, and looked up.
fr: Brusquement, Dallas s'arreta et leva la tete.

eng: "It must be here," he said, slipping his arm through his father's with a movement from which Archer's shyness did not shrink; and they stood together looking up at the house.
fr: -- Ce doit etre ici, dit-il, en glissant son bras sous celui de son pere. ~~~ Ils resterent l'un pres de l'autre a regarder la maison.

eng: It was a modern building, without distinctive character, but many-windowed, and pleasantly balconied up its wide cream-coloured front.
fr: C'etait une construction moderne sans caractere, avec de nombreuses fenetres, et des balcons qui se detachaient avec elegance sur une haute facade blanche.

eng: On one of the upper balconies, which hung well above the rounded tops of the horse-chestnuts in the square, the awnings were still lowered, as though the sun had just left it.
fr: Sur un des balcons superieurs, qui s'avancaient au-dessus des domes arrondis des marronniers, les stores etaient encore baisses ; le soleil venait de les quitter.

eng: "I wonder which floor--?" Dallas conjectured;
fr: '-- Je me demande... a quel etage ? dit Dallas.'

eng: and moving toward the porte-cochere he put his head into the porter's lodge, and came back to say: "The fifth. It must be the one with the awnings."
fr: '-- Il passa la tete dans la loge du concierge, et revint en disant : -- Au cinquieme ! ce doit etre l'etage aux stores.'

eng: Archer remained motionless, gazing at the upper windows as if the end of their pilgrimage had been attained.
fr: Archer restait immobile, les yeux fixes sur les hautes fenetres, comme si le but de son pelerinage eut ete atteint.

eng: "I believe I'll sit there a moment," he said.
fr: -- Je vais m'asseoir un moment, dit-il.

eng: "Why--aren't you well?" his son exclaimed.
fr: -- Qu'est-ce qu'il y a ? Est-ce que vous n'etes pas bien ?

eng: "Oh, perfectly."
fr: -- Si, tres bien.

eng: "I say, you know, it's nearly six," his son at length reminded him.
fr: '-- Vous savez, pere, il est pres de six heures, lui rappela enfin son fils.

eng: The father glanced away at an empty bench under the trees.
fr: Le pere jeta un coup d'oeil sur un banc vide sous les arbres.

eng: But I should like you, please, to go up without me."
fr: Mais j'aime mieux que tu montes sans moi.

eng: Dallas paused before him, visibly bewildered.
fr: Dallas le regarda, deconcerte.

eng: "But, I say, Dad: do you mean you won't come up at all?"
fr: '-- Voyons, pere, est-ce que vous vous ne viendrez pas ?'

eng: "I don't know," said Archer slowly.
fr: '-- J'hesite, repondit lentement Archer.'

eng: "If you don't she won't understand."
fr: '-- Si vous ne venez pas, elle ne comprendra pas.'

eng: "Go, my boy; perhaps I shall follow you."
fr: '-- Va, mon garcon. Je te suivrai peut-etre.'

eng: "But what on earth shall I say?"
fr: '-- Mais que voulez-vous que je lui dise ?'

eng: "Dallas gave him a long look through the twilight."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "My dear fellow, don't you always know what to say?"
fr: -- Mon cher enfant, ne sais-tu pas toujours ce qu'il faut dire ?

eng: his father rejoined with a smile.
fr: repliqua son pere en souriant.

eng: At that, as if it had been the signal he waited for, Newland Archer got up slowly and walked back alone to his hotel.
fr: Comme si c'etait le signal qu'il attendait, Newland Archer se leva lentement et revint seul a son hotel.

eng: At length a light shone through the windows, and a moment later a man-servant came out on the balcony, drew up the awnings, and closed the shutters.
fr: A la fin, une lumiere perca les fenetres. ~~~ Un moment apres, un domestique vint relever les stores et fermer les persiennes.

eng: He sat for a long time on the bench in the thickening dusk, his eyes never turning from the balcony.
fr: Longtemps, il demeura ainsi dans l'envahissement du crepuscule, sans quitter des yeux le balcon.

eng: "It's more real to me here than if I went up," he suddenly heard himself say; and the fear lest that last shadow of reality should lose its edge kept him rooted to his seat as the minutes succeeded each other.
fr: -- Je la retrouve mieux que si j'etais la-haut a cote d'elle, se dit-il a haute voix. Et la crainte de sentir s'evanouir cette derniere illusion le tenait immobile sur le banc pendant que les minutes s'ecoulaient.

eng: He thought she would be sitting in a sofa-corner near the fire, with azaleas banked behind her on a table.
fr: Archer imagina qu'elle serait assise sur un canape au coin du feu, et qu'il y aurait des azalees en fleurs derriere elle sur une table.

eng: Then he tried to see the persons already in the room--for probably at that sociable hour there would be more than one--and among them a dark lady, pale and dark, who would look up quickly, half rise, and hold out a long thin hand with three rings on it....
fr: Ensuite, il essaya de se figurer les personnes qui etaient deja dans le salon ; car, a la fin de l'apres-midi, il devait y avoir quelques personnes. Mais il ne voyait qu'une dame au pale visage, avec une masse de cheveux sombres, qui redresserait la tete vivement, se levant a demi pour tendre a Dallas sa longue main fine, ornee de trois bagues.

eng: He pictured Dallas entering that room with his quick assured step and his delightful smile, and wondered if the people were right who said that his boy "took after him."
fr: Il imagina Dallas entrant dans la piece de son pas vif, assure, avec son charmant sourire. Avait-on raison de dire que son fils tenait de lui ?

eng: He calculated the time it would take his son to be carried up in the lift to the fifth floor, to ring the bell, and be admitted to the hall, and then ushered into the drawing-room.
fr: Il calcula le temps que mettrait son fils a monter dans l'ascenseur jusqu'au cinquieme, a sonner a la porte, a etre admis dans l'antichambre, puis introduit dans le salon.

eng: Archer sat down on the bench and continued to gaze at the awninged balcony.
fr: Archer s'assit sur le banc, et continua a regarder le balcon aux stores.

eng: Dallas looked at him again, and then, with an incredulous gesture, passed out of sight under the vaulted doorway.
fr: Dallas le regarda encore : puis, avec un geste d'incredulite, il disparut sous la voute.

eng: "Say I'm old-fashioned: that's enough."
fr: '-- Dis que je suis vieux jeu, ca suffira...'

eng: "Very well. I shall say you're old-fashioned, and prefer walking up the five flights because you don't like lifts."
fr: '-- Je dirai que vous etes vieux jeu, et que vous preferez monter les cinq etages a pied, parce que vous n'aimez pas les ascenseurs.'

eng: His father smiled again.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)
